                <p class="runhead1"><strong>Physics 200</strong> Introductory Physics I - Study Guide</p>

                <span class="unit"> Unit 0</span>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit00" >

                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Course Orientation</h1>
					<hr>

                  <p>Welcome to <a href="http://www.athabascau.ca/syllabi/phys/phys200.php" title="syllabus" target="_blank">Physics 200: Introductory Physics I</a>. This online environment gives you access to all the course study materials. Here, you can also submit your assignments and lab reports for marking and feedback using the online Assignment and Lab Drop Boxes.</p>

                  <p>Before starting, please read the <a href="http://www.athabascau.ca/courses/student_manual/" target="_blank">Student Manual</a>. It outlines important information you need to complete this course successfully, such as the course contract, <a href="https://my.athabascau.ca/" target="_blank">MyAU portal</a>, requesting examinations, and services for students.</p>

                  <p>The Study Guide is the main body of your course. Its ten course units provide learning objectives, the concepts covered in the unit, and identify the learning activities you are expected to complete.</p>

                  </div>


<!--    fdsaf   -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit00-course-material">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Course Orientation</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Course Materials</h2>

                  <h3>eTextbook</h3>
                  <p><ul>
                      <li>OpenStax College, <a href="https://openstax.org/details/books/college-physics/" target="_blank">College Physics</a>. OpenStax College. 21 June 2012.</li>
                    </ul>

                  <p>The PHYS 200 course is designed based on the <a href="https://openstax.org/" target="_blank">OpenStax</a> College Physics etextbook, which is an open source material licensed under <a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/" target="_blank">Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License</a>. </p>

                  <h3>Athabasca University Materials</h3>
                  <p>
                  <ul>
                      <li>PHYS 200 Study Guide. <a href="http://www.athabascau.ca/" target="_blank">Athabasca University</a>, 2017.</li>
                  </ul>


                  <p>In this revision of PHYS 200, the Study Guide merges relevant sections of the eTextbook with the AU-produced lab experiments, assignment questions, and detailed solutions  for problems selected from the end of each chapter in the eTextbook.</p>

                  <p>The Study Guide has been prepared in html code and uses the open-source <a href="https://www.mathjax.org/" target="_blank">MathJax</a> JavaScript platform. This combines the accessibility of html with the beauty and convenience of the <a href="https://www.latex-project.org/" target="_blank">LaTeX</a> mathematical equations and symbols. Special effort has also been made to make the learning materials accessible on mobile devices.</p>

                  <p>An important feature is the inclusion of interactive activities using the free simulations of the <a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/" target="_blank">PhET project</a>. This is in addition to a number of interactive diagrams developed using the dynamic capabilities of <a href="https://www.wolfram.com/mathematica/" target="_blank">Mathematica</a>, which can be displayed using the free <a href="https://www.wolfram.com/cdf-player/" target="_blank">Wolfram CDF Player</a>. This allows you to watch (and interact with) objects moving in real time. The Study Guide is also supplemented with 3D animation videos created using text-to-speech technology software (State) developed by Xtranormal Technology Inc.</p>

                  <h3>Other Course Materials</h3>
                  <p>
                  <ul>
                      <li><a href="http://physlets.org/tracker/" target="_blank">Tracker</a> software.</li>
                  </ul>


                  <p>This is an open-source video analysis and modeling tool you will use in the lab to make accurate video analysis of moving objects.</p>

                </div>

<!--**********************************************************************************************************************-->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit00-course-outline">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Course Orientation</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Course Outline</h2>

                  <p>There are ten units in PHYS 200:</p>

                  <p>
                  <ul>
                      <li><a href="../unit01/index01.html" target="_self"><b>Unit 1</b></a> Introduction: The Nature of Science and Physics</li>
                      <li><a href="../unit02/index02.html" target="_self"><b>Unit 2</b></a> Kinematics</li>
                      <li><a href="../unit03/index03.html" target="_self"><b>Unit 3</b></a> Two-Dimensional Kinematics</li>
                      <li><a href="../unit04/index04.html" target="_self"><b>Unit 4</b></a> Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</li>
                      <li><a href="../unit05/index05.html" target="_self"><b>Unit 5</b></a> Further Applications of Newton&rsquo;s Laws: Friction, Drag, and Elasticity</li>
                      <li><a href="../unit06/index06.html" target="_self"><b>Unit 6</b></a> Uniform Circular Motion and Gravitation</li>
                      <li><a href="../unit07/index07.html" target="_self"><b>Unit 7</b></a> Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</li>
                      <li><a href="../unit08/index08.html" target="_self"><b>Unit 8</b></a> Linear Momentum and Collisions</li>
                      <li><a href="../unit09/index09.html" target="_self"><b>Unit 9</b></a> Statics and Torque</li>
                      <li><a href="../unit10/index10.html" target="_self"><b>Unit 10</b></a> Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</li>
                  </ul>

                  <p>The course also includes six home-lab experiments:</p>

                  <p>
                  <ul>
                      <li><a href="../lab01/lab01.html" target="_self"><b>Lab 1</b></a> Graphical Analysis</li>
                      <li><a href="../lab02/lab02.html" target="_self"><b>Lab 2</b></a> Kinematics in One Dimension</li>
                      <li><a href="../lab03/lab03.html" target="_self"><b>Lab 3</b></a> Projectile Motion</li>
                      <li><a href="../lab04/lab04.html" target="_self"><b>Lab 4</b></a> Hooke&rsquo;s Law</li>
                      <li><a href="../lab05/lab05.html" target="_self"><b>Lab 5</b></a> Collision in Two Dimensions</li>
                      <li><a href="../lab06/lab06.html" target="_self"><b>Lab 6</b></a> Rolling Motion</li>
                  </ul>


                </div>

<!--**********************************************************************************************************************-->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit00-study-strategy">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Course Orientation</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Study Strategy</h2>

                  <h3>Schedule</h3>

                  <p>Students who approach their studies in a systematic and organized manner are more likely to complete their courses successfully than those who do not plan their activities. You are advised, therefore, to develop and follow a study schedule to assist you in budgeting your time and scheduling your progress. <b>When designing your study schedule, keep in mind that to complete the course within the contracted period, you should do at least one unit, lab, or assignment per week.</b> However, it is best to aim for a shorter period, in case an unforeseen circumstance arises within your contract period. Remember that physics is like a heavy meal. You should &ldquo;eat it&rdquo; one plate at a time, and allow your brain enough time for &ldquo;digestion.&rdquo;</p>

                  <h3>Approach</h3>

                  <p>Each unit in PHYS 200 opens with a brief introduction and a set of learning objectives. Pay close attention to the objectives: they indicate what you must be able to do to demonstrate your mastery of the unit material. Each unit specifies several learning activities, which indicate which sections of the textbook you should read, and which problems you are expected to attempt. The units also include solutions to selected problems, instructions about laboratory assignments, and credit assignments.</p>

                  <p>It is important that you work through the units carefully. Begin by reading the objectives, and keep them in mind as you proceed through the unit. Next, read the assigned material. You will probably find it helpful to read the material at least twice (once to familiarize yourself with it, and a second time to make notes and to work through the examples and solved problems). Then, answer the assigned exercises and review your work with the answers provided. Discuss any discrepancies between your answers and those provided with your tutor.</p>

                  <p>Problem solving is a very important part of the learning process. Therefore, you are encouraged to spend time solving problems at various degrees of difficulty. This strategy provides a good test of your understanding of the main concepts and increases your efficiency in solving exam questions. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve the problems presented in the Study Guide independently before you read through the solutions provided. If you reach an impasse, and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>

                  </div>

<!--**********************************************************************************************************************-->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit00-assignments">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Course Orientation</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Assignments</h2>
                <p>You are expected to do two assignments, which are worth 20% of your final grade in the course.</p>

                <p>
                  <ul>
                      <li><a href="../assignment1/assign1.html" target="_self"><b>Assignment 1</b></a> (covers Units 1–5)</li>
                      <li><a href="../assignment2/assign2.html" target="_self"><b>Assignment 2</b></a> (covers Units 6–10)</li>
                  </ul>


                <p>Although you may find it convenient to answer the assigned problems in the briefest possible way, you should get into the habit of showing all your work. This strategy enables the marker to identify where you are having trouble with concepts or mathematical skills.</p>

                <p>Once you have answered all the questions in a particular assignment, submit it for marking by uploading it to the appropriate drop box. Scanned copies of your handwritten solutions are acceptable.</p>

                </div>

<!--**********************************************************************************************************************-->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit00-labs">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Course Orientation</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Lab Component</h2>
                <p>The lab is a mandatory component of the PHYS 200 course and it is worth 20% of your final grade. The six experiments in the home lab are meant to go with the course material and may be conducted in the place of your choice.</p>

                <h3>Equipment  and Materials</h3>
                <p>The lab component is designed to provide quality hands-on physics experiments that utilize the widely available smartphones in addition to some common household items. A computer running <a href="http://physlets.org/tracker/" target="_blank">Tracker</a> software is required for data analysis, and also for the production of lab reports.</p>

                <h3>Lab Report</h3>
                <p>Lab reports are an effective way of communicating important information, and their use is stressed in this course. There is little point in doing a wonderful experiment with great results if you cannot effectively communicate your method and findings to others. Although you have some freedom in preparing your lab report, make sure to include the following sections:

                <ul>
                        <li><b>Cover Page</b></li>
                        <li><b>Introduction</b> - Provide a concise theoretical background.</li>
                        <li><b>Procedure</b> - Describe your procedure in your own words.</li>
                        <li><b>Pictures</b> - Include clear pictures of your setup.</li>
                        <li><b>Data</b> - Organize and present the data you collect in the experiment. Also provide a description of the behaviour and apparent trend of the collected data.</li>
                        <li><b>Analysis and Discussion</b> - Give clear and detailed analysis of your data as described in the manual. Make sure to include sample calculations, especially for newly calculated columns in data tables. You may also need to produce graphs and perform appropriate fits. Error analysis and a discussion of measurement uncertainties should be provided.</li>
                        <li><b>Conclusion</b> - Present a brief summary of your findings and results.</li>
                        <li><b>Questions</b> - Provide detailed answers to the questions at the end of the lab.</li>
                </ul>


                <h3>Lab Safety</h3>
                <p>Appropriate care should be taken due to moving objects and other potentially hazardous situations and materials. The level of risk involved in doing these labs is comparable to that of day-to-day activities and care has been taken to avoid suggesting activities that produce hazards.</p>

                <p>It is your decision to proceed with any experiment and in making that decision, you control your own situation and assume any risks involved. It is your responsibility to act in a responsible manner to avoid hazard to yourself or members of the public.</p>

                <p>The authors, Athabasca University, or any equipment supplier cannot be held liable for the consequences of any action undertaken in association with these lab exercises. If you cannot safely do these labs, please withdraw from the course.</p>

                </div>

<!--**********************************************************************************************************************-->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit00-exams">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Course Orientation</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Examinations</h2>
                    <p>You are required to write two exams (midterm and final) to be supervised by a person authorized by <a href="http://www.athabascau.ca/" target="_blank">Athabasca University</a>. Please <a href="http://www.athabascau.ca/courses/student_manual/#Procedures_for_Exams" target="_blank">request your exam</a> well in advance of the write date. You are advised to contact the <a href="http://calendar.athabascau.ca/undergrad/current/page07_03.php" target="_blank">examination centre</a> or <a href="http://calendar.athabascau.ca/undergrad/current/page07_04.php" target="_blank">supervisor</a> to ensure the examination materials have arrived before you go in to write. Also, make sure to bring your student ID number and a picture identification with you to your exam.</p>

                    <p>The <a href="../exam1/exam1.html" target="_self">midterm exam</a> covers Units 1–5 and it is worth 20% of the total course mark. The <a href="../exam2/exam2.html" target="_self">final exam</a> covers all units (1&ndash;10) and it is worth 40% of the total course mark. These are closed-book exams to be written without any printed material or electronic devices, other than the examination booklet and a calculator.</p>

                    </div>

<!--**********************************************************************************************************************-->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit00-evaluation">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Course Orientation</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Evaluation</h2>
                    <p>Your final grade in PHYS 200 is based on the marks you achieve in two tutor-marked assignments, six lab reports, and two invigilated exams. You must achieve at least fifty per cent (50%) on the final examination and on the lab component, and an overall course grade of at least fifty per cent (50%) to pass the course. Students who do not achieve a minimum passing grade on the final exam are allowed to write a <a href="http://www.athabascau.ca/courses/student_manual/#Supplemental_Examinations" target="_blank">supplemental examination</a>. There is a fee for this service</p>

                    <p>The following chart summarizes the evaluation activities and their credit weight:</p>

                    <p>
                    <table class="datatable" id="table-lab1.1">
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td><b>Activity</b></td> <td><b>Credit Weight</b></td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td>Assignment 1</td> <td> 10% </td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td>Assignment 2</td> <td> 10% </td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td>Lab 1</td> <td> 3.0% </td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td>Lab 2</td> <td> 3.4% </td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td>Lab 3</td> <td> 3.4% </td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td>Lab 4</td> <td> 3.4% </td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td>Lab 5</td> <td> 3.4% </td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td>Lab 6</td> <td> 3.4% </td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td>Midterm Exam</td> <td> 20% </td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td>Final Exam</td> <td> 40% </td> </tr>
                    <tr class="centerText"> <td><b>Total</b></td> <td><b>100%</b></td> </tr>
                    </table>


                </div>

                <p class="runhead1"><strong>Physics 200</strong> Introductory Physics I - Study Guide</p>

                <p class="unit"> Unit 1 <span>(Chapter 1)</span></p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit01" >

                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Introduction: The Nature of Science and Physics</h1>
                  <hr>

                  <p>It&rsquo;s sometime back in the mid-1980s. You&rsquo;re driving home listening to the hockey game on the car radio. You hear the excited voice of the commentator&mdash;he&rsquo;s almost screaming&mdash;&ldquo;Gretzky is waiting at the blue line, Kurri is at the corner digging out the puck! Kurri passes the puck, Gretzky is moving away from the blue line, now he has the puck. Gretzky is moving, faster and faster! He makes a beautiful move, splits the defense, he shoots, he s-c-o-r-e-s!!&rdquo;</p>
					<p><a href=""></a></p>

                  <p> If you were a hockey fan, you were happy, but not surprised. You expected such wonderful plays from Gretzky, possibly the greatest hockey player of all time, one whose moves were described by ecstatic sports writers as poetry in motion. What may surprise you is that those few lines of the commentator, describing Gretzky&rsquo;s goal, can be used as starting points for more than half the topics to be discussed in this course. Consider the statement &ldquo;Gretzky is waiting at the blue line.&rdquo; For the split second that Gretzky was waiting, he was not different from a book on the tabletop or an electron in equilibrium between two charged plates&mdash;a &ldquo;body at rest&rdquo; in the language of a physicist. As Gretzky moves faster and faster, a physicist observes an accelerating body&mdash;like a proton in a linear accelerator. And when Gretzky shoots the puck, the physicist thinks of elastic and inelastic collisions, conservation of energy and momentum, coefficient of friction, and so on. </p>

                  <p> Physics, contrary to popular belief, does not only deal with things that are out of this world; the physical world we live in is also the subject matter of physics. This world is governed by laws that apply to everything happening within its boundaries&mdash;be it Gretzky&rsquo;s breakaway goal or one proton colliding with another. Some of these laws we already know, others are yet to be found. Our purpose in studying physics is to learn the known laws, how they were discovered, and how they explain our observations of what is happening around us. With that knowledge behind us, we can attempt to discover those laws that are as yet unknown. </p>

                  <p style="margin-top:2.0em;">
                  <div class="learningobjectives">
                    <h3>Learning Objectives</h3>
                    <p>After completing this unit, you should be able to</p>
                    <ul>
                      <li>discuss the relationship between theory and observation in physics.</li>
                      <li>define and describe the SI system of units.</li>
                      <li>identify the units of measurement used in describing physical quantities.</li>
                      <li>convert from one system of units to another.</li>
                      <li>explain the meaning of significant figures.</li>
                      <li>specify the uncertainty of a measurement.</li>
                      <li>estimate the combined uncertainty of a quantity calculated from a set of uncertain measurements.</li>
                    </ul>
                  </div> <!-- end of content -->
                </div> <!-- end of this section -->

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit01-units-of-measurement">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Introduction: The Nature of Science and Physics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Units of Measurement</h2>
                  <p>Christine: &ldquo;How much coffee do you drink, Mary?&rdquo;<br>
                        Mary: &ldquo;About four.&rdquo;<br>
                        Christine: &ldquo;Four what?&rdquo;</p>

                  <p>In this conversation, Mary&rsquo;s answer is not complete because she gives a quantitative value without specifying the units. There is a big difference between &ldquo;four extra-large cups per day&rdquo; and &ldquo;four small cups per week&rdquo;!</p>

                  <p>So, you will not make much sense if you tell a person the distance between two points, A and B, is 100. The person will demand to know if you mean 100 kilometres, 100 feet, or maybe 100 angstroms! Physical measurements are expressed in numbers, but numbers are meaningless until you make it clear what unit of measurement is being used. Furthermore, the quantity changes depending on the choice of unit. For example, if you mean the distance between A and B is 100 miles, a person using kilometres as the unit of measurement will say the distance is 161 kilometres. The number 100 changes to 161 because a different unit of measurement is chosen.</p>

                  <p>Physicists consider themselves fortunate because all measurable physical quantities can be expressed in terms of four fundamental units: unit of length, unit of mass, unit of time, and unit of electric current (or alternatively, the unit of electric charge). These four fundamental units can be combined in various ways to express other units of measurement. The unit of velocity, for example, is expressed in terms of the units of length and time as follows:
                  \begin{equation}
                  \text{unit of velocity} = \frac{\text{unit of length}}{\text{unit of time}}
                  \end{equation}
                  </p>

                  <p>To study the physical world, the units of measurements of only these four quantities must be settled. At one time, there were many different sets of units, just as there are still different currencies in different countries. The English favoured the &ldquo;fps system&rdquo; (or the &ldquo;British engineering system&rdquo;) in which length was measured in feet, mass was measured in a convoluted way in terms of weight expressed in pounds, and time was measured in seconds. The rest of Europe at that time worked in the &ldquo;cgs system&rdquo; in which centimetre, gram, and second were used as units of length, mass, and time. Now, the scientific world has agreed to use one set of units, called the SI (<em>Syst&egrave;me International</em>) units, in which length is measured in metres, mass is measured in kilograms, time is measured in seconds, and electric current is measured in amperes.</p>

                  <p>SI units are used in PHYS 200. However, keep in mind that there is nothing absolute about this system of measurement. It has been chosen for standardization and convenience, not because it is superior to the other systems in some mystical way. One system of units can always be changed to another the same way you can change dollars to euros and yen to pounds.</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit01-vid01.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 1.1</b>: Difference between units and dimensions.
                  </p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit01-significant-figures">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Introduction: The Nature of Science and Physics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Significant Figures and Measurement Uncertainty</h2>

                  <p>Assume you want to calculate the surface area and volume of a textbook.  Of course, you need to measure the book&rsquo;s dimensions (length, width, and thickness). Using a ruler, you first measure the length of the textbook.  Since the smallest division on the ruler is the millimetre, you can only give an upper limit ($26.3\, \text{cm}$) and a lower limit ($26.1\, \text{cm}$) for the length.  Due to the limitations of the instrument (the ruler in this case), you can then say the correct length ($L$) of the textbook is most probably between these two values.  This is written as ($L = 26.2 \pm 0.1\, \text{cm}$), where the first number is called the measured value and the second number is called the uncertainty (or error) in the measurement.  Similarly, you measure the width ($W$) and the thickness ($T$) of the textbook to be ($W = 20.6 \pm 0.1\, \text{cm}$) and ($T = 3.9 \pm 0.1\, \text{cm}$) respectively. In these measurements, the first digit after the decimal is uncertain, which makes it meaningless (or insignificant) to include more digits. The digits in a measured value, up to and including the first uncertain digit, are called significant figures.  So, there are three significant figures in $L$ and $W$ and two significant figures in $T$.  Note that the length cannot be written as $L = 26.20\, \text{cm}$ since it will then include two uncertain digits.</p>

                  <p>In counting the number of significant figures in a measurement, start from the first non-zero digit and end at the first uncertain digit. If the uncertainty of a measurement is known, then it becomes easy to specify the uncertain digit and count the number of significant figures. However, if the uncertainty of a measured value is not known, then you need to be careful. If there is no decimal point in the number, the last non-zero digit is considered to be the first uncertain digit. If the number contains a decimal point, the last digit after the decimal (whether it is a zero or not) is considered uncertain. Ambiguity in the number of significant figures is avoided by using the scientific notation in which only one digit is kept to the left of the decimal point while the remaining digits, up to and including the uncertain one, are moved to the right. Of course, you must multiply by the appropriate exponent (see <a href="#unit01_tab01"><b>Table 1.1</b></a> for examples).</p>

                  <table class="datatable" id="unit01_tab01">
                  <caption style="margin-bottom:1.0em;"><b>Table 1.1:</b> Examples of scientific notation expressions of different significant figures.</caption>
                        <tr class="centerText"> <td><b>Measured Value</b></td> <td><b>Scientific Notation</b></td> <td><b>Number of <br> Significant Figures</b></td></tr>
                        <tr class="centerText"> <td>$9.80$</td> <td>$9.80$</td> <td>3</td> </tr>
                        <tr class="centerText"> <td>$120$</td> <td>$1.2 \times 10^2$</td> <td>2</td> </tr>
                        <tr class="centerText"> <td>$120 \pm 2$ </td> <td> $(1.20 \pm 0.02 ) \times 10^2$ </td> <td> 3</td> </tr>
                        <tr class="centerText"> <td>$120.0$ </td> <td> $1.200 \times 10^2$ </td> <td> 4 </td> </tr>
                        <tr class="centerText"> <td>$1.00560$ </td> <td> $1.00560$ </td> <td> 6 </td> </tr>
                        <tr class="centerText"> <td>$0.00560$ </td> <td> $5.60 \times 10^{-3}$ </td> <td> 3 </td> </tr>
                        <tr class="centerText"> <td>$375 \times 10^{-9}$ </td> <td> $3.75 \times 10^{-7}$ </td> <td> 3 </td> </tr>
                </table>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit01-limit-error">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Introduction: The Nature of Science and Physics</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Limit Error</h2>
                <p>Knowledge of measurement uncertainty and error propagation in a series of calculations is crucial in evaluating the accuracy of a certain set of data. There are two major types of measurement uncertainties: random and systematic. In measuring the textbook&rsquo;s dimensions, for example, the uncertainty due to your limited ability to read the ruler to better than $1\,\text{mm}$ is a random error. If, on the other hand, you confuse the inch and the centimetre units, your measurements will include a systematic error of scale.</p>

                <p>Returning to your measuring exercise, the surface area ($A$) of the textbook is calculated using the equation ($A = L \times W$). If you multiply the measured values of length and width using a calculator, you will get $A = 539.72\, \text{cm}^2$. But how accurate is this value?  How many significant figures are there in $A$, and what is its uncertainty?  As a general rule for combining numbers by multiplication or division, the final result should not have more significant figures than the original value with the least number of significant figures. For addition and subtraction, however, the final result should not have more decimal places than the original value with the least number of decimal places. Therefore, since $L$ and $W$ have three significant figures each, $A$ should be rounded to three significant figures and written as $A = 540\, \text{cm}^2$  (or $5.40 \times 10^2\, \text{cm}^2$). Similarly, the volume of the textbook is written as $V = 2100\, \text{cm}^3$ (or $2.1 \times 10^3\, \text{cm}^3$), which should not include more than two significant figures.</p>

                <p>What about the uncertainties of $A$ and $V$? Since the area and the volume of the textbook are calculated from the measured dimensions, the errors in $A$ and $V$ are a propagation of the errors of $L$, $W$, and $T$. <a href="#unit01_tab02"><b>Table 1.2</b></a> lists the rules used to calculate the propagated errors in various arithmetic operations. Notice that whether we are adding or subtracting numbers, the combined error simply adds up. The same rule is used for combining error whether the operation is a multiplication or a division. Notice that in the last rule, $k$ is an exact constant factor that has no uncertainty (i.e., $\delta k = 0$).</p>

                <table class="datatable" id="unit01_tab02">
                <caption style="margin-bottom:1.0em;"><b>Table 1.2:</b> Rules of error propagation.</caption>
                <tr> <td><b>Relation</b></td> <td><b>Equation</b></td> <td><b>Limit Error</b></td> </tr>
                <tr> <td>Addition </td> <td> $z = x + y$ </td> <td> $\delta z = \delta x + \delta y$</td> </tr>
                <tr> <td>Subtraction </td> <td> $z = x - y$ </td> <td> $\delta z = \delta x + \delta y$</td> </tr>
                <tr> <td>Multiplication </td> <td> $z = x y$ </td> <td> $\delta z = |z| \left( \frac{\delta x}{x} + \frac{\delta y}{y} \right)$ </td> </tr>
                <tr> <td>Division </td> <td> $z = x/y$ </td> <td> $\delta z = |z| \left( \frac{\delta x}{x} + \frac{\delta y}{y} \right)$ </td> </tr>
                <tr> <td>Power </td> <td> $z = x^n$ </td> <td> $\delta z = n \, x^{n-1} \, \delta x$ </td> </tr>
                <tr> <td>Exact constant </td> <td> $z = k \, x$ </td> <td> $\delta z = k \, \delta x$ </td> </tr>
                </table>

                <p>So, the uncertainty in area is given by
                \begin{align}
                \delta A &= |A| \left( \frac{\delta L}{L} + \frac{\delta W}{W} \right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                &= 540 \times \left( \frac{0.1}{26.2} + \frac{0.1}{20.6} \right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                &= 4.7\, \text{cm}^2
                \end{align}
                which is reduced to $\delta A = 5\, \text{cm}^2$ because it is not an actual measurement. The third digit in $A$ is uncertain, indicating that the number of significant figures in $A$ is indeed three. The final answer is then written as
                \begin{equation}
                A = (5.40 \pm 0.05)\times 10^2\, \text{cm}^2
                \end{equation}
                Similarly, the volume of the textbook is equal to
                \begin{equation}
                V = (2.1 \pm 0.1)\times 10^2\, \text{cm}^3
                \end{equation}</p>

                <p>It is often useful to speak of the relative error $\delta x/x$ to compare the size of error to the size of the value measured. Another advantage is that the relative error of a product or dividend is the sum of the relative errors of what makes them up.</p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit01-examples">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Introduction: The Nature of Science and Physics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Examples</h2>
                    <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of examples relevant to the content of <span style="white-space: nowrap;">Unit 1</span>. Make an attempt to answer each question on your own, before you read through the solution provided.</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Example ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit01-e01">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 1, Example 1</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Earth has an equatorial diameter of $d_\text{E} = 12{,}756\,\text{km}$. (a) What is the diameter in feet? (b) Approximately how many Earths can fit side by side along the line from the Earth to the Moon?</div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e01_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $4.185 \times 10^7\,\text{ft}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $30$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Referring to <a href="../textbook/appendices.pdf#page=13" title="Appendices" target="_blank">Table C7</a> in the textbook, you have
                        \begin{equation}
                         1\,\text{ft} = 0.3048\,\text{m}
                        \end{equation}
                    So, the unit conversion of Earth&rsquo;s diameter proceeds as follows:
                        \begin{align}
                        d_\text{E} &= 12{,}756\,\text{km} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 12{,}756\,\color{blue}{\text{km}} \times \left( \frac{1000\,\text{m}}{1\,\color{blue}{\text{km}}} \right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 12{,}756\,\color{blue}{\text{km}} \times \frac{1000\,\color{red}{\text{m}}}{1\,\color{blue}{\text{km}}} \times \frac{1\,\text{ft}}{0.3048\,\color{red}{\text{m}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.185 \times 10^7\,\text{ft}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The average Earth-Moon distance (see <a href="../textbook/appendices.pdf#page=12" title="Appendices" target="_blank">Table C3</a> in the textbook) is equal to
                      \begin{equation}
                      D_\text{EM} = 3.84 \times 10^5\,\text{km}
                      \end{equation}
                    So, the number of Earths that can fit along this distance is approximately
                      \begin{align}
                      \frac{D_\text{EM}}{d_\text{E}} &= \frac{3.84 \times 10^5\,\text{km}}{1.2756 \times 10^4 \,\text{km}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                      & \approx 30
                      \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Example ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit01-e02">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 1, Example 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">What is the uncertainty of the volume ($V$) of a cylinder in terms of its radius ($r$) and height ($h$)?</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e02_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02_btn">Solution</button>
                  <p></p>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>\begin{equation*} V \left( \frac{2 \delta r}{r} + \frac{\delta h}{h} \right) \end{equation*}</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The volume of the cylinder is given by the formula
                        \begin{equation}
                        V = \pi\, r^2 h
                        \end{equation}
                    Using the rules in <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit01-limit-error">Table 1.2</a>, the uncertainty in $V$ is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \delta V &= \pi \times \delta (r^2 h) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \pi \times \left|r^2 h\right| \left( \frac{\delta r^2}{r^2} + \frac{\delta h}{h} \right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \pi r^2 h \left( \frac{2 r \delta r}{r^2} + \frac{\delta h}{h} \right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= V \left( \frac{2 \delta r}{r} + \frac{\delta h}{h} \right)
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                  </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter01-problems">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Introduction: The Nature of Science and Physics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Solutions of Selected Problems</h2>
                    <p>Next are detailed solutions to a number of problems selected from the end of <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-1.pdf#page=25" title="Chapter 1" target="_blank">Chapter 1</a></span> in the textbook. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve each problem independently, before you read through the solution provided. You are also advised to make a second attempt to solve the problem if your answer is different from the one posted. If you reach an impasse and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter01-ch01-p02">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 1, Problem 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A car is traveling at a speed of $33\,\text{m/s}$. (a) What is its speed in kilometers per hour? (b) Is it exceeding the $90\,\text{km/h}$ speed limit? </div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer2_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution2a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution2b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer2" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $120 \,\text{km/h}$</p>
                      <p>(b) Yes</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution2a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    First, find the conversion factors. You know that
                        \begin{equation}
                        1\,\text{h} = 60\,\text{min}
                        \end{equation}
                    as well as
                        \begin{equation}
                        1\,\text{min} = 60\,\text{s}
                        \end{equation}
                    Therefore,
                        \begin{align}
                        1\,\text{h} &= 60\,\color{red}{\text{min}} \times \frac{60\,\text{s}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{min}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 60 \times 60\,\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3600\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    You also know that
                        \begin{equation}
                        1\,\text{km} = 1000\,\text{m}
                        \end{equation}
                    Putting all this together, you get
                        \begin{align}
                        33\,\text{m/s} &= \frac{33\,\color{red}{\text m}}{\color{blue}{\text s}} \times \frac{1\,\text{km}}{1000\,\color{red}{\text m}} \times \frac{3600\,\color{blue}{\text s}}{1\,\text{h}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 120 \,\text{km/h}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that the answer is rounded to two <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit01-significant-figures">significant figures</a>.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution2b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The car exceeds the maximum speed allowed.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter01-ch01-p08">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 1, Problem 8</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The speed of sound is measured to be $342\,\text{m/s}$ on a certain day. What is it in $\text{km/h}$?</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer08_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution08_btn">Solution</button>
                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer08">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$1230\,\text{km/h}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution08">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Since we know that there are $1000\,\text{km}$ in $1\,\text{m}$ and $3600\,\text{s}$ in $1\,\text{h}$, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        342\,\text{m/s} &= \frac{342\,\color{red}{\text m}}{\color{blue}{\text s}} \times \frac{1\,\text{km}}{1000\,\color{red}{\text m}} \times \frac{3600\,\color{blue}{\text s}}{1\,\text{h}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1230\,\text{km/h}
                        \end{align}
                    In this case, the answer is rounded to three <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit01-significant-figures">significant figures</a>.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter01-ch01-p12">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 1, Problem 12</div>
                    <div class="panel-body"> A good-quality measuring tape can be off by $0.50\,\text{cm}$ over a distance of $20\,\text{m}$. What is its percent uncertainty?</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer12_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution12_btn">Solution</button>
                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer12">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.025\%$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution12">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                      First convert the units of the uncertainty to match that of the measurement.
                        \begin{align}
                        \delta L &= 0.5\,\text{cm} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        & = 0.5\,\color{red}{\text{cm}} \times \frac{1\,\text{m}}{100\,\color{red}{\text{cm}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.005\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      So, the measured distance can be expressed as
                        \begin{equation}
                        L = 20.000 \pm 0.005\,\text{m}
                        \end{equation}
                      Now calculate the percent uncertainty ($\%\,\text{unc}$) as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \%\,\text{unc} &= \frac{\delta L}{L} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{0.005\,\color{red}{\text m}}{20.000\,\color{red}{\text m}} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.025\%
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter01-ch01-p18">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 1, Problem 18</div>
                    <div class="panel-body"> (a) How many significant figures are in the numbers $99$ and $100$? (b) If the uncertainty in each number is $1$, what is the percent uncertainty in each? (c) Which is a more meaningful way to express the accuracy of these two numbers, significant figures or percent uncertainties?</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer18_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution18a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution18b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution18c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer18">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $2,\; 3$</p>
                      <p>(b) $1.0\%,\; 1.00\%$ </p>
                      <p>(c) Percent uncertainty</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    If the uncertainty in each number is $1$, you can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        x = 99 \pm 1
                         \end{equation}
                    and
                        \begin{equation}
                        y = 100 \pm 1
                        \end{equation}
                    Since the uncertain digit in each number is the last one on the right, you can conclude that $99$ has two significant figures, while $100$ has three <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit01-significant-figures">significant figures</a>.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The percent uncertainties in the two numbers are calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \%\,\text{unc}_x &= \frac{\delta x}{x} \times 100\%  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1}{99} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.0101010...\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.0\%
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        \%\,\text{unc}_y &= \frac{\delta y}{y} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1}{100} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.00\%
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The percent uncertainty is more meaningful because it gives the relative size of possible error in each number. Specifying only the significant figures does not give much information about the accuracy of a certain number.
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter01-ch01-p20">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 1, Problem 20</div>
                    <div class="panel-body"> (a) A person&rsquo;s blood pressure is measured to be $120 \pm 2 \,\text{mm Hg}$. What is its percent uncertainty? (b) Assuming the same percent uncertainty, what is the uncertainty in a blood pressure measurement of $80 \,\text{mm Hg}$?</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer20_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer20" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $\approx 2\%$</p>
                      <p>(b) $\approx 1\,\text{mm Hg}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    If the person&rsquo;s blood pressure is expressed as
                        \begin{equation}
                        P_1 = 120 \pm 2\,\text{mm Hg}
                        \end{equation}
                    the percent uncertainty in the measurement is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \%\,\text{unc} &= \frac{\delta P_1}{P_1} \times 100\% \label{ch1_20_pUnc}\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{2}{120} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.67\% \quad (\approx 2\%)
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    From Equation \ref{ch1_20_pUnc}, you can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \%\,\text{unc} &= \frac{\delta P_2}{P_2} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow \quad 1.67\% &= \frac{\delta P_2}{80} \times 100\%
                        \end{align}
                    By solving for $\delta P_2$, the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit01-limit-error">uncertainty</a> is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \delta P_2 &= \frac{1.67}{100} \times 80 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.3\,\text{mm Hg} \quad (\approx 1\,\text{mm Hg})
                        \end{align}
                    So, you can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        P_2 = 80 \pm 1\,\text{mm Hg}
                        \end{equation}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter01-ch01-p24">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 1, Problem 24</div>
                    <div class="panel-body"> A marathon runner completes a $42.188\,\text{km}$ course in $2\,\text{h}$, $30\,\text{min}$, and $12\,\text{s}$. There is an uncertainty of $25\,\text{m}$ in the distance traveled and an uncertainty of $1\,\text{s}$ in the elapsed time. (a) Calculate the percent uncertainty in the distance. (b) Calculate the uncertainty in the elapsed time. (c) What is the average speed in meters per second? (d) What is the uncertainty in the average speed?</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer24_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24d_btn">Solution (d)</button>
                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer24">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $0.06\%$</p>
                      <p>(b) $0.01\%$</p>
                      <p>(c) $4.681\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                      <p>(d) $0.003\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    First, express the distance ($d$) in metres, where
                        \begin{align}
                        d &= 42.188\,\text{km} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 42.188\,\color{red}{\text{km}} \times \frac{1000\,\text{m}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{km}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 42{,}188\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    The percent uncertainty in the distance is then calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \%\,\text{unc}_d &= \frac{\delta d}{d} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{25}{42{,}188} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.059\% \quad (\approx 0.06\%)
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    By converting the elapsed time to seconds, you have
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= 2\,\text{h} + 30\,\text{min} + 12\,\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= \left(2\,\color{red}{\text{h}} \times \frac{3{,}600\,\text{s}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{h}}}\right) + \left(30\,\color{blue}{\text{min}} \times \frac{60\,\text{s}}{1\,\color{blue}{\text{min}}}\right) + 12\,\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9{,}012\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    Now find the percent uncertainty in time as
                        \begin{align}
                        \%\,\text{unc}_t &= \frac{\delta t}{t} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1}{9012} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.01111\% \quad (\approx 0.01\%)
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-velocity-speed">average speed</a> $v$ of the runner is
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= \frac{d}{t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{42{,}188\,\text{m}}{9{,}012\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.681\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24d">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (d)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Since the percent uncertainties are small and you are dividing the distance by the time, you can use the method of adding percents to find the percent uncertainty of the average speed.
                        \begin{align}
                        \%\,\text{unc}_v &= \%\,\text{unc}_d + \%\,\text{unc}_t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.06\% + 0.01\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.07\%
                        \end{align}
                    The uncertainty in the average speed satisfies the equation
                        \begin{align}
                        \%\,\text{unc}_v &= \frac{\delta v}{v} \times 100\% \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0.07\% &= \frac{\delta v}{4.681\,\text{m/s}} \times 100\%
                        \end{align}
                    and is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \delta v &= \frac{0.07 \times 4.681\,\text{m/s}}{100} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.003\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter01-ch01-p30">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 1, Problem 30</div>
                    <div class="panel-body"> A generation is about one-third of a lifetime. Approximately how many generations have passed since the year $0\,\text{AD}$?</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer30_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution30_btn">Solution</button>
                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$100\,\text{generations}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <P>
                    While the current <a href="http://www.who.int/gho/mortality_burden_disease/life_tables/" target="_blank">global life expectancy</a> is about $70\,\text{years}$, we&rsquo;ll use $60\,\text{years}$ as a lifetime, as life expectancy was not always this high. So, a generation is approximately
                        \begin{align}
                        1\,\text{generation} &= \tfrac{1}{3}\, \text{lifetime} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{3} (60\,\text{years}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 20\,\text{years}
                        \end{align}
                    and the number of generations since $0\,\text{AD}$ is estimated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{number of generations} &= \frac{2019\,\text{years}}{20\,\text{years}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &\approx 100\,\text{generations}
                        \end{align}
                    </P>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

                <p class="runhead1"><strong>Physics 200</strong> Introductory Physics I</p>

		<p class="unit"> Unit 2 <span> (Chapter 2)</span></p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit02" >
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Kinematics</h1>
                  <hr>

                  <p> The study of motion, technically known as <em>mechanics</em>, forms the basis of physics. You will spend a significant part of your time in this course studying various types of motions. The study of motion is divided into two parts: <em>kinematics</em> and <em>dynamics.</em>  Kinematics is concerned with describing motion, and dynamics with analyzing why a body moves in the way it does. The simplest form of motion is the motion of a body along a straight line, called <em>motion in one dimension.</em> We will start with the kinematics of this type of motion, or the description of linear motion. The three important concepts in kinematics are displacement, velocity, and acceleration. In this unit, we restrict ourselves to the study of motion of a body along a straight line with a constant acceleration.</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:2.0em;">
                  <div class="learningobjectives">
                    <h3>Learning Objectives</h3>
                    <p>After completing this unit, you should be able to</p>
                    <ul>
                      <li>explain the importance of the frame of reference in the description of the motion of a body.</li>
                      <li>provide the mathematical definitions of <em>distance</em> and <em>displacement</em> and describe the difference between these quantities.</li>
                      <li>provide the mathematical definitions of <em>speed</em> and <em>velocity</em> and describe the difference between these quantities.</li>
                      <li>explain the difference between <em>average velocity</em> and <em>instantaneous velocity</em> and solve problems dealing with both concepts.</li>
                      <li>give the mathematical definition of acceleration.</li>
                      <li>write out the kinematic equations, which describe the motion of a body experiencing constant acceleration.</li>
                      <li>use the kinematic equations to describe and predict the linear motion of a body under constant acceleration.</li>
                      <li>define of the phrase &ldquo;acceleration due to gravity.&rdquo;</li>
                      <li>use the kinematic equations to describe and predict the vertical motion of a free-falling body.</li>
                    </ul>
                  </div>

                  <!-- end of content -->

                </div> <!-- end of this section -->

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit02-displacement">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Kinematics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Displacement and Reference Frames</h2>

                  <p> Although we do not usually make a distinction between distance and displacement in our everyday lives, there is a significant difference between the two in physics. By distance, we mean the total length traveled by a body in motion. Displacement is defined as the change between a body&rsquo;s initial position and its final position, and contains two pieces of information: the length of the straight line joining the final and initial positions, and the direction in which the body has been displaced. </p>

                  <p> You are walking down the street and a stranger asks you &ldquo;Where is <a href="http://www.reddeer.ca/" target="_blank">Red Deer</a>?&rdquo; Your answer, if you live in <a href="https://www.edmonton.ca/" target="_blank">Edmonton</a>, most probably will be, &ldquo;Red Deer is about one hundred and fifty kilometers south.&rdquo; If you happen to be in <a href="http://www.calgary.ca/" target="_blank">Calgary</a>, there is a good chance that you will say, &ldquo;Approximately one hundred and forty five kilometers north.&rdquo;</p>

                  <p> It may appear to be a silly question, but let us jump into it anyway. Are the two responses the same or different? The two answers have provided the same information, the location of the City of Red Deer, although the quoted numbers and the directions are different in each response. And we do understand that the differences, in numbers and directions, are caused by the fact that the two responses came from two different observers, located at two different reference points. </p>

                  <p> The crucial point here is that we cannot tell the position of a body in an absolute way. We need a point of reference to define the position of a body precisely. In our example, we can use either Edmonton or Calgary as our reference point, and locate the precise position of Red Deer with respect to either of these points. And if we know the positional relationship between Edmonton and Calgary&mdash;that Edmonton is $295\,\text{km}$ north of Calgary (or Calgary is $295\,\text{km}$ south of Edmonton)&mdash;we can explain why the two observers gave two seemingly different answers. </p>

                  <p> In certain circumstances, such as when a body is moving along a straight line, the direction of the displacement is always the same, and the magnitude of the displacement equals the distance traveled by the body. In such situations, we usually do not make an issue of distinguishing between displacement and distance, since the direction of motion of the body does not change. However, such situations form only a small portion of this course. </p>

<!-- *******  Reading *************  -->
                  <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <div class="readassign">

<!--*******************************-->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit02-velocity-speed">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Kinematics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Velocity and Speed</h2>

                  <h3>Average Velocity and Average Speed</h3>
                  <p> In studying motion, we observe how the position of a body changes with time. Suppose at a particular time, say at 3:15 PM, we observe the position of an object, for example, a car, a person, or a star far away. After five minutes, at 3:20 PM, we look again, trying to locate the same object. If we find it at the same position as before, we conclude that the object has not moved, and call it a &ldquo;body at rest relative to the observer.&rdquo; On the other hand, if we find that the object is at a different position, we conclude that the object has been in motion during this period of time. Studying motion is, therefore, the process of observing and identifying the position of an object or a body as time goes by.</p>

                  <p> We will begin our study of linear motion with the simplest kinematic concepts of <em>average speed</em> and <em>average velocity</em>. You are already familiar with the concept of average speed. If you drive $550\,\text{km}$ from <a href="http://www.regina.ca/" target="_blank">Regina</a> to <a href="http://www.winnipeg.ca" target="_blank">Winnipeg</a> in $5.5\,\text{h}$ in your new sports car, you boast that you had maintained an average speed of $100\,\text{km/h}$. To compute average speed, you divide the distance travelled by the time taken to cover the distance. The average velocity, on the other hand, is computed by dividing the displacement of the object by the time taken to perform the displacement. </p>

                  <h3>Instantaneous Velocity and Speed</h3>
                  <p> In your trip from Regina to Winnipeg, you said that your average speed was $100\,\text{km/h}$. However, it is unlikely that the speedometer of your car was pointing at this speed during the whole trip. Probably, there were instances when you had to reduce your speed to $80\,\text{km/h}$ because of a slower vehicle in front of you, and there were instances when the speedometer was pointing at $110\,\text{km/h}$. Your speed at a particular instant in time, as indicated by the speedometer, is called your <em>instantaneous speed</em>. If the direction of motion is also specified at the same instant then you have indicated the <em>instantaneous velocity</em>.</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit02-vid01.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 2.1</b>: Difference between average velocity and average speed.
                  </p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                  <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <div class="readassign">

                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-2.pdf#page=6" title="Chapter 2" target="_blank">2.3.&nbsp; Time, Velocity, and Speed</a></li>
