<!--********************************-->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit02-constant-acceleration">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Kinematics</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Motion at Constant Acceleration</h2>

                <p> Two cars, in adjacent lanes, stopped at the red light at an intersection. When the traffic light turned green, the car drivers stepped on the gas, simultaneously, and started moving. Six seconds later, one car reached a speed of $60\,\text{km/h}$, while the speedometer in the other car was still pointing at $45\,\text{km/h}$. We conclude that the speed of the first car was changing at a higher rate than the speed of the second car. To be more quantitative, the speed of the first car was changing at a rate of $10\,\text{km/h}$ every second, while the corresponding rate of change for the second car was $7.5\,\text{km/h}$ per second. This simple example introduces an important concept in kinematics called <em>acceleration</em> ($a$). </p>

                <p> More formally, acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity with time. So, it is computed by dividing the change in velocity vector by the time interval over which the velocity change takes place, or
                \begin{align}
                a &= \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                &= \frac{v - v_0}{t - t_0}
                \end{align}
                Thus, acceleration is a vector quantity. Apart from its importance in describing motion, acceleration is also a key concept for understanding the causes of motion. </p>

                <p>Suppose that at the initial time $t_0 = 0$ the position of a body is $x_0$ and its velocity is $v_0$. If the body is restricted to move along a straight line with constant acceleration $a$ we should be able to predict the position $x$ and the velocity $v$ of the body at a later time $t$. Starting with the definitions of acceleration and velocity, we can establish the following important kinematic equations
                  \begin{align}
                   v &= v_0 + a t \label{u02_ke_v}\\[6pt]
                   x &= x_0 + v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2}\, a t^2 \label{u02_ke_x}\\[6pt]
                   v^2 &= v_0^2 + 2 a (x - x_0) \label{u02_ke_v2}\\[6pt]
                   x &= x_0 + \bar{v} t
                   \label{u02_ke_xvavg}
                   \end{align}
                where the average velocity ($\bar{v}$) in Equation \ref{u02_ke_xvavg} is defined as
                        \begin{equation}
                        \bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>It is important to note that these equations are valid only when the acceleration is constant. They are very useful for predicting the position and velocity of a body at different times from knowledge of its position, velocity, and acceleration at known times.</p>

                <h3>PhET  Simulation: The Moving Man</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-2.pdf#page=19" title="Chapter 2" target="_blank">textbook</a>, &ldquo;learn about position, velocity, and acceleration graphs. Move the little man back and forth with the mouse and plot his motion. Set the position, velocity, or acceleration and let the simulation move the man for you.&rdquo;</p>

                <p>Note: You may need to download the simulation file and open it using <a href="https://java.com/en/download/" target="_blank">Java</a>.</p>

                <p><div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 197px;"><a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/moving-man/moving-man_en.jnlp" target="_blank" style="text-decoration: none;"><img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/moving-man/moving-man-600.png" alt="The Moving Man" style="border: none;" width="300" height="197"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);"></div><table style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px;"><tr><td style="text-align: center; color: #000; font-size: 24px; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Click to Run</td></tr></table></a></div>

<!--***********************************************************************************************************************-->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit02-free-fall">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Kinematics</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Free Falling Objects</h2>

                <p>All objects near the surface of the Earth experience much the same effect from gravity. They are attracted down, which causes them to accelerate downward at a constant rate. This constant acceleration is called the <em>acceleration due to gravity</em> or <em>gravitational acceleration</em>, and it is represented by $g$. To be precise, the value of $g$  is not a true constant, but changes from place to place, depending on the latitude, longitude and altitude of the place. However, these changes are small enough and can be ignored for most practical purposes.</p>

                <p>So, the acceleration due to gravity of a free-falling object near the surface of the Earth always points straight down and has a magnitude equal to
                  \begin{equation}
                  g = 9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                  \end{equation}
                This is true for any object experiencing free fall, regardless of its shape, size, mass, speed, or direction of motion. However, in substituting the acceleration due to gravity into the kinematic equations we must be careful about the sign, which depends on the coordinate system used in a particular situation. If the upward direction is taken to be positive in the coordinate system used, then the acceleration of the object due to gravity will have a negative value.</p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit02-vid02.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 2.2</b>: Concept of free fall.
                </p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit02-examples">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Kinematics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Examples</h2>
                  <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of examples relevant to the content of <span style="white-space: nowrap;">Unit 2</span>. Make an attempt to answer each question on your own, before you read through the solution provided.</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit02-e01">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 2, Example 1</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The position of a ball was recorded at the beginning and the end of a four-second time interval, as shown in <b>Figure E2.1</b>. During this time, the ball moved toward the wall and bounced back. Calculate (a) the average speed and (b) the average velocity of the ball during this interval.
                    <hr>
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit02-e01.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E2.1</b></p>

                  </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e01_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <p></p>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $2.1\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $0.60\,\text{m/s}\; \text{directed to the right}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The total distance $d$ travelled by the ball is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        d &= 3.0\,\text{m} + 5.4\,\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.4\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      So, the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-velocity-speed">average speed</a> of the ball during the time interval $\Delta t = t_2 - t_1$ is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \bar{v} &= \frac{d}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        & = \frac{8.4\,\text{m}}{4.0\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.1\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>During the same time interval, the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-displacement">displacement</a> of the ball in the $x$ direction is
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta x &= x_2 - x_1 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        & = 5.4\,\text{m} - 3.0\,\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.4\,\text{m},\; \text{directed to the right}
                        \end{align}
                      So, the average velocity is found to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \bar{v}_{x} &= \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        & = \frac{2.4\,\text{m}}{4.0\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.60\,\text{m/s},\; \text{directed to the right}
                        \end{align}</p>
                    </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit02-e02">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 2, Example 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">An automobile commercial claims a sports car can accelerate from rest to $90\,\text{km/h}$ in $3.0\,\text{s}$. Determine the acceleration of the sports car in $\text{m}/\text{s}^2$.</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e02_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02_btn">Solution</button>
                  <p></p>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$8.3\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                      Since the sports car starts from rest, its initial speed is equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        v_0 = 0
                        \end{equation}
                      The final speed after $t = 3.0\,\text{s}$ is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= 90\,\text{km/h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{90\,\color{red}{\text{km}}}{1\,\color{blue}{\text{h}}} \times \frac{1000\,\text{m}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{km}}} \times \frac{1\,\color{blue}{\text{h}}}{3600\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 25\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>

                      <p>
                      The acceleration $a$ can be calculated by substituting into the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-constant-acceleration">kinematic equation</a>
                        \begin{equation}
                        v = v_0 + a t
                        \end{equation}
                      where we have
                        \begin{align}
                        25\,\text{m/s} &=  0 + a\, (3.0\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad a & = \frac{25\,\text{m/s}}{3.0\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.3\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  </div>

<!-- ****** Example 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit02-e03">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 2, Example 3</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A piece of chalk is released $173\,\text{cm}$ above the floor. Calculate (a) the falling time and (b) the chalk&rsquo;s speed (in $\text{km/h}$) just before it hits the floor.</div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e03_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e03_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <p></p>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $0.594\,\text{s}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $21.0\,\text{km/h}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p><img src="./unit02-e03s.svg" alt="image"></p>
                      <p class="centerText"><b>Figure E2.3s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">

                      <p>
                      Before we begin the solution of this example, we will do two things: select an appropriate coordinate system and extract the relevant information about the motion of the chalk. This is an example of a one-dimensional motion along a vertical straight line. So, we can set the coordinate system (see <b>Figure E2.3s</b>) so that the $y$ axis is vertical with the origin at the floor. In this convention, the upward direction is positive, and the downward direction is negative.
                      </p>

                      <p>
                      According to the chosen coordinate system the initial position of the chalk is $y_0 = +173\,\text{cm}$, and the final position is $y = 0$. Also the word <em>released</em> indicates that the chalk was not given any initial velocity and, therefore, $v_0 = 0$. While falling to the ground, its speed increases at a steady rate equal to the gravitational acceleration. Since it is directed downward, the acceleration of the chalk is negative, and written as $a = -g$. So, to summarize
                        \begin{align}
                        y_0 &= +1.73\,\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        y &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        v_0 &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        a &= -9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \label{u02_e03_data}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>

                      <p>
                      We should now be ready to answer the question. The kinematic equation (see <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-constant-acceleration">Equation \ref{u02_ke_x}</a>) containing all the variables above is
                      \begin{equation}
                      y = y_0 + v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2}\; a t^2
                      \label{u02_e03_yf}
                      \end{equation}
                      By substituting from Equation \ref{u02_e03_data} into Equation \ref{u02_e03_yf}, we have
                      \begin{align}
                      0 &= 1.73\,\text{m} + (0)\, t + \tfrac{1}{2} (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, t^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                      \Rightarrow\quad 1.73\,\text{m} &= (4.90\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, t^2
                      \end{align}
                      So, the time it takes the chalk to fall to the floor is calculated to be
                      \begin{align}
                      t &= \sqrt{\frac{1.73\,\text{m}}{4.90\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                      &= 0.594\,\text{s}
                      \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                      The final velocity of the chalk, just before it hits the floor, is calculated by substituting into the equation
                        \begin{equation}
                         v = v_0 + a t
                        \end{equation}
                      So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= 0 + (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (0.594\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -5.82\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                      The negative sign indicates that the final velocity is directed downward based on the adopted convention for the coordinate system.<p>

                      <p>
                      The chalk&rsquo;s speed can be expressed in $\text{km/h}$ as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= \frac{5.82\,\color{red}{\text{m}}}{\color{blue}{\text{s}}} \times \frac{1\,\text{km}}{1000\,\color{red}{\text{m}}} \times \frac{3600\,\color{blue}{\text{s}}}{1\,\text{h}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 21.0\,\text{km/h}
                        \end{align}
                      Note that the sign is omitted here because the question asks for the speed, which corresponds to the magnitude of the velocity.
                      </p>
                    </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit02-e04">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 2, Example 4</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A sportsboat moves with an initial speed of $99.0\,\text{km/h}$. At $t = 0$ the pilot slows the boat down at a uniform rate of $3.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$. Determine (a) the time and (b) the speed of the boat as it passes a buoy located $110\,\text{m}$ away.</div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e04_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e04_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e04a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e04b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="interactive-e04_btn">Interactive Activity</button>
                  <p></p>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $5.90\,\text{s}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $9.81\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit02-e04s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E2.4s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">

                    <p>It is convenient to set our reference at the location and the instant in time at which the boat starts to slow down (see <b>Figure E2.4s</b>). This allows us to write
                        \begin{align}
                        x_0 &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        x &= 110\,\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        v_0 &= 99.0\,\text{km/h} = 27.5\,\text{m/s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        a &= -3.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>The time $t$ it takes the boat to reach the buoy, can be calculated by substituting into the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-constant-acceleration">kinematic equation</a>
                        \begin{equation}
                        x = x_0 + v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2} a t^2
                        \end{equation}
                    such that
                        \begin{equation}
                        110\,\text{m} = 0 + (27.5\,\text{m/s})\, t + \tfrac{1}{2}\, (-3.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, t^2
                        \label{unit02_e04_x}
                        \end{equation}
                    After rearranging the terms, and omitting units for convenience, Equation \ref{unit02_e04_x} reduces to the quadratic equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        1.50\, t^2 - 27.5\, t + 110 = 0
                        \end{equation}
                    By solving for $t$, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= \frac{27.5 \pm \sqrt{(27.5)^2 - 4\, (1.50) (110)}}{2\, (1.50)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.90 \quad (\text{or}\; 12.4)
                        \end{align}
                    So, the time it takes the boat to reach the buoy is
                        \begin{equation}
                        t = 5.90\,\text{s}
                        \end{equation}
                    Note that the other solution ($12.4\,\text{s}$) corresponds to the time it would take the boat to return to the buoy if it continues its negative acceleration after passing the buoy.
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>The velocity ($v$) of the boat near the location of the buoy is calculated by substituting into the kinematic equation
                                \begin{equation}
                                v^2 = v_0^2 + 2 a\, (x - x_0)
                                \end{equation}
                        such that
                                \begin{align}
                                v^2 &= (27.5\,\text{m/s})^2 + 2\, (-3.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (110\,\text{m} - 0) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                \Rightarrow\quad v_f &= 9.81\,\text{m/s}
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="interactive-e04">
                <div class="panel-heading">Interactive Activity</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>This is the first of a number of interactive activities, which you will encounter in the Study Guide. To manipulate and play the relevant diagrams, you will need first to install the <a href="https://www.wolfram.com/cdf-player/" target="_blank">Wolfram CDF Player</a> which you can download for free. Please note that this may not work on a mobile device.</p>

                        <div class="panel-body">
                                <p class="centerText"><a href="./unit02-e04i.cdf"><img  src="unit02-e04i.png" alt="unit02-e04i.png"></a><br>
                                <br><b>Figure E2.4i</b></p>
                        </div>

                        <p>Download the interactive diagram (<a href="./unit02-e04i.cdf"><b>Figure E2.4i</b></a>) onto your computer and open it using the <a href="https://www.wolfram.com/cdf-player/" target="_blank">Wolfram CDF Player</a>.</p>

                        <p>Answer the additional questions below and use the interactive diagram to check your calculations. <em>Use the &ldquo;Reset&rdquo; button (at the top-right corner) to refresh the interactive diagram after each run</em>.</p>

                        <p>
                        <ol>
                        <li>With the acceleration of the speedboat equal to $-5.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$, calculate the stopping distance and the total travel time.</li>
                        <li>Repeat the question above with the acceleration equal to $-2.50\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$.</li>
                        <li>What should the acceleration of the speedboat be if it is to stop at the buoy?</li>
                        <li>Would the speedboat pass the buoy if its acceleration is changed to $-4.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$?</li>
                      </ol>

                    </div>
                </div>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-problems">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Kinematics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Solutions of Selected Problems</h2>
                    <p>Next are detailed solutions to a number of problems selected from the end of <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-2.pdf" title="Chapter 2" target="_blank">Chapter 2</a></span> in the textbook. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve each problem independently, before you read through the solution provided. You are also advised to make a second attempt to solve the problem if your answer is different from the one posted. If you reach an impasse and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>
