<!-- ****** Problem 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p04">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 4</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Find the following for path $\text{D}$ in <b>Figure P2.4</b>: (a) The distance traveled. (b) The magnitude of the displacement from start to finish. (c) The displacement from start to finish.
                    <hr>
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch02-p04.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P2.4</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer04_btn">Answer</button> <!-- to change: 1) id="***"; 2) the text, e.g. Answer, Solution, ...-->
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution04a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution04b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution04c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer04" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $8\,\text{m}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $4\,\text{m}$</p>
                      <p>(c) $-4\,\text{m}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution04a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The path begins at $x_\text{i} = 9\,\text{m}$, then moves to $x = 3\,\text{m}$, and ends at $x_\text{f} = 5\,\text{m}$. So the path moves $9\,\text{m} - 3\,\text{m} = 6\,\text{m}$ backwards, and then $5\,\text{m} - 3\,\text{m} = 2\,\text{m}$ forward. So, the total distance traveled is
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{distance} &= 6\,\text{m} + 2\,\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution04b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The initial position is $9\,\text{m}$ and the the final position is $5\,\text{m}$, so the magnitude of the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-displacement">displacement</a> is
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{displacement magnitude} &= 9\,\text{m} - 5\,\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution04c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Since $x_\text{i} = 9\,\text{m}$, and $x_\text{f} = 5\,\text{m}$, the displacement is calculated to be
                       \begin{align}
                       \Delta x &= x_\text{f} - x_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                       &= 5\,\text{m} - 9\,\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                       &= -4\,\text{m}
                       \end{align}
                    Note that the net displacement is directed backward, in the negative $x$ direction.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 6 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p06">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 6</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A helicopter blade spins exactly $100$ revolutions per minute. Its tip is $5.00\,\text{m}$ from the center of rotation. (a) Calculate the average speed of the blade tip in the helicopter&rsquo;s frame of reference. (b) What is its average velocity over one revolution?</div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer06_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution06a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution06b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $52.3\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $0$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution06a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Recall that the circumference of a circle, of radius $r$, is equal to $2 \pi r$. So the distance traveled by a blade&rsquo;s tip in one rotation is
                        \begin{align}
                        d &= 2 \pi r \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2 \pi\, (5.00\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 31.4\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    The time required to complete one rotation is
                        \begin{align}
                        T &= \frac{1}{100\,\text{rev/min}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.0100\,\text{min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.600\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    So the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-velocity-speed">average speed</a> of the blade tip in the helicopter&rsquo;s frame of reference is
                        \begin{align}
                        \bar{v} &= \frac{d}{T}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{31.4\,\text{m}}{0.600\,\text{s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 52.3\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution06b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Since it returns to the initial position, the displacement of the blade tip after a complete revolution is equal to zero, which corresponds to zero average velocity.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 12 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p12">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 12</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The speed of propagation of the action potential (an electrical signal) in a nerve cell depends (inversely) on the diameter of the axon (nerve fiber). If the nerve cell connecting the spinal cord to your feet is $1.1\,\text{m}$ long, and the nerve impulse speed is $18\,\text{m/s}$, how long does it take for the nerve signal to travel this distance? </div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer12_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution12_btn">Solution</button>
                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer12">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.061 \,\text{s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution12">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                      We know the distance that the signal must travel, $d = 1.1\,\text{m}$, and also its constant speed of $v = 18\,\text{m/s}$. From this, we can solve for the time it takes the signal to travel this distance, as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= \frac{d}{v} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1.1\,\text{m}}{18\,\text{m/s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.061 \,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 14 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p14">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 14</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A football quarterback runs $15.0\,\text{m}$ straight down the playing field in $2.50\,\text{s}$. He is then hit and pushed $3.00\,\text{m}$ straight backward in $1.75\,\text{s}$. He breaks the tackle and runs straight forward another $21.0\,\text{m}$ in $5.20\,\text{s}$. Calculate his average velocity (a) for each of the three intervals and (b) for the entire motion. </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer14_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram14_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution14a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution14b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer14">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $6.00\,\text{m/s},\; -1.71\,\text{m/s},\; 4.04\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $3.49\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram14">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch02-p14s.svg" alt="./ch02-p14s.png"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E2.14s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    In the first interval, the quarterback runs forward and has a displacement of $\Delta x_1 = 15.0\,\text{m}$ over a time of $\Delta t_1 = 2.50\,\text{s}$. So the average velocity for the first interval is
                        \begin{align}
                        \bar{v}_1 &= \frac{\Delta x_1}{\Delta t_1}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{15.0\,\text{m}}{2.50\,\text{s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 6.00\,\text{m/s},\; \text{forward}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    <p>
                    In the second interval, the quarterback is pushed back and has a displacement of $\Delta x_2 = -3.00\,\text{m}$ during a time interval of $\Delta t_2 = 1.75\,\text{s}$. From this, we can find the average velocity of the second interval to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \bar{v}_2 &= \frac{\Delta x_2}{\Delta t_2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{-3.00\,\text{m}}{1.75\,\text{s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -1.71\,\text{m/s} \quad (\text{or}\;\; 1.71\,\text{m/s},\; \text{backward})
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    <p>
                    In the third interval, the quarterback runs forward by another $\Delta x_3 = 21.0\,\text{m}$ during a time of $\Delta t_3 = 5.20\,\text{s}$. During this interval, the quarterback has an average velocity of
                        \begin{align}
                        \bar{v}_3 &= \frac{\Delta x_3}{\Delta t_3}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{21.0\,\text{m}}{5.20\,\text{s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.04\,\text{m/s},\; \text{forward}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The average velocity for the entire motion, is calculated by dividing the net displacement ($\Delta x$) by the total time ($\Delta t$) of the three intervals. Since,
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta x &= \Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2 + \Delta x_3\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 15.0\,\text{m} - 3.00\,\text{m} + 21.0\,\text{m}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 33.0\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta t &= \Delta t_1 + \Delta t_2 + \Delta t_3 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.50\,\text{s} + 1.75\,\text{s} + 5.20\,\text{s}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9.45\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    we can calculate the average velocity for the entire motion to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \bar{v} &= \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{33.0\,\text{m}}{9.45\,\text{s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.49\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 16 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p16">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2 Problem 16</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A cheetah can accelerate from rest to a speed of $30.0\,\text{m/s}$ in $7.00\,\text{s}$. What is its acceleration? </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer16_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution16_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer16">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$4.29\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution16">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                      Since the cheetah begins from rest, it&rsquo;s initial speed is $v_0 = 0$. The final speed of $v = 30.0\,\text{m/s}$ is reached over a time period of $\Delta t = 7.00\,\text{s}$. The cheetah&rsquo;s <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-constant-acceleration">acceleration</a> is therefore equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        a &= \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{v-v_0}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{30.0\,\text{m/s} - 0}{7.00\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.29\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 18 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p18">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 18</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A commuter backs her car out of her garage with an acceleration of $1.40\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$. (a) How long does it take her to reach a speed of $2.00\,\text{m/s}$? (b) If she then brakes to a stop in $0.800\,\text{s}$, what is her deceleration?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer18_btn">Answer</button> <!-- to change: 1) id="***"; 2) the text, e.g. Answer, Solution, ...-->
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution18a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution18b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer18" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1.43\,\text{s}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $2.50\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The driver starts from rest ($v_0 = 0$) and accelerates at $a = 1.40\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ to a final speed of $v = 2.00\,\text{m/s}$. Using the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-constant-acceleration">kinematic equation</a>
                       \begin{equation}
                       v = v_0 + a t
                       \end{equation}
                    we can solve for the time and find
                       \begin{align}
                       t &= \frac{v - v_0}{a} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                       &= \frac{2.00\,\text{m/s} - 0}{1.40\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                       &= 1.43\,\text{s}
                       \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Now the driver brakes to a stop in $t = 0.800\,\text{s}$, which means that the initial speed is $v_0 = 2.00\,\text{m/s}$ and the final speed is $v = 0$. So, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + at\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad a &= \frac{v - v_0}{t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{0 - 2.00\,\text{m/s}}{0.800\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -2.50\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    So, the deceleration of the car while braking is $2.50\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 20 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p20">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 20</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">An Olympic-class sprinter starts a race with an acceleration of $4.50\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$. (a) What is her speed $2.40\,\text{s}$ later? (b) Sketch a graph of her position vs. time for this period.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer20_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram20_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $10.8\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch02-p20s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P2.20s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The sprinter begins from rest with an initial speed of $v_0 = 0$. Her final speed after $t = 2.40\,\text{s}$ is
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + a t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 + (4.50\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.40\,\text{s})\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 10.8\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>The Solution Diagram (<b>Figure P2.20s</b>) shows a graph of the sprinter&rsquo;s position vs. time.</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 24 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p24">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 24</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">While entering a freeway, a car accelerates from rest at a rate of $2.40\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ for $12.0\,\text{s}$. (a) Draw a sketch of the situation. (b) List the knowns in this problem. (c) How far does the car travel in those $12.0\,\text{s}$? To solve this part, first identify the unknown, and discuss how you chose the appropriate equation to solve for it. After choosing the equation, show your steps in solving for the unknown, check your units, and discuss whether the answer is reasonable. (d) What is the car&rsquo;s final velocity? Solve for this unknown in the same manner as in part (c), showing all steps explicitly.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer24_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram24_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24d_btn">Solution (d)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer24">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(c) $173\,\text{m}$ </p>
                      <p>(d) $104\,\text{km/h}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram24">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch02-p24s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P2.24s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>See Solution Diagram (<b>Figure P2.24s</b>).</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    It is convenient to set the coordinate system such that the car&rsquo;s initial position is at the origin. The car also starts from rest at the initial position. So, we can list the following knowns about the motion
                        \begin{align}
                        x_0 &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        v_0 &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        a &= 2.40\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        t &= 12.0\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    We are looking for the final position $x$ after $t = 12.0\,\text{s}$. Since we know $x_0$, $v_0$, $t$, and $a$, we will use the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-constant-acceleration">kinematic equation</a>
                        \begin{equation}
                        x = x_0 + v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2}\; a t^2
                        \end{equation}
                    where we have
                        \begin{align}
                        x &= \tfrac{1}{2}\; (2.40\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (12.0\,\text{s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 173\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the vehicle travels $173\,\text{m}$ in the first $12.0\,\text{s}$ of its motion.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                    The units are correct as meters are the units of distance. We can verify this as follows
                        \begin{equation}
                        \frac{\text{m}}{\color{blue}{\text{s}^2}} \times \color{blue}{\text{s}^2} = \text{m}
                        \end{equation}
                    A distance of $173\,\text{m}$ is reasonable. If it were only a few meters or an entire kilometer, then the answer wouldn&rsquo;t appear sensible.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24d">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (d)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The final velocity of the car is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + a t\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 + (2.40\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (12.0\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 28.8\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    which can be expressed in kilometers per hour as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= \frac{28.8\,\color{red}{\text{m}}}{\color{blue}{\text{s}}} \times \frac{1\,\text{km}}{1000\,\color{red}{\text{m}}} \times \frac{3600\,\color{blue}{\text{s}}}{1\,\text{h}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 104\,\text{km/h}
                        \end{align}
                    The answer is reasonable since it is close to freeway speeds.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 32 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p32">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 32</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A woodpecker&rsquo;s brain is specially protected from large decelerations by tendon-like attachments inside the skull. While pecking on a tree, the woodpecker&rsquo;s head comes to a stop from an initial velocity of $0.600\,\text{m/s}$ in a distance of only $2.00\,\text{mm}$. (a) Find the acceleration in $\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ and in multiples of $g$ ($g = 9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$). (b) Calculate the stopping time. (c) The tendons cradling the brain stretch, making its stopping distance $4.50\,\text{mm}$ (greater than the head and, hence, less deceleration of the brain). What is the brain&rsquo;s deceleration, expressed in multiples of $g$?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer32_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution32a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution32b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution32c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer32">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $-9.18\,g$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $6.67\,\text{ms}$ </p>
                      <p>(c) $-4.08\,g$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution32a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The stopping distance of the woodpecker&rsquo;s head is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        d_\text{h} &= 2.00\,\color{red}{\text{mm}} \times \frac{1\,\text{m}}{1000\,\color{red}{\text{mm}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.00200\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    Over this distance, the head starts with an initial velocity of $v_0 = 0.600\,\text{m/s}$, and comes to a stop with a final velocity is $v = 0$. To calculate the acceleration ($a_\text{h}$) of the woodpecker&rsquo;s head, we use the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-constant-acceleration">kinematic equation</a>
                        \begin{align}
                        v^2 &= v_0^2 + 2\, a_\text{h}\, d_\text{h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad a_\text{h} &= \frac{v - v_0^2}{2\, d_\text{h}}
                        \end{align}
                    where we have
                        \begin{align}
                        a_\text{h} &= \frac{0 - (0.600\,\text{m/s})^2}{2\, (0.00200\,\text{m})}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -90.0\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    which corresponds to
                        \begin{align}
                        a_\text{h} &= -90.0\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2 \times \frac{g}{9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -9.18\,g
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution32b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Since we know $v_0$, $v$, and $a_\text{h}$, the stopping time is calculated as follows,
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + at\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad t &= \frac{v - v_0}{a} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{0 - 0.600\,\text{m/s}}{-90.0\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.00667\,\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 6.67\,\text{ms}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution32c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Because of the tendons, the woodpecker&rsquo;s brain stops after travelling a distance of
                        \begin{align}
                        d_\text{b} &= 4.50\,\text{mm} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.00450\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    We still have $v_0 = 0.600\,\text{m/s}$ and $v = 0$. So, the brain accelerates at
                        \begin{align}
                        a_\text{b} &= \frac{v^2 - v_0^2}{2\, d_\text{b}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{-(0.600\,\text{m/s})^2}{2\, (0.00450\,\text{m})}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -40.0\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    By converting to multiples of $g$, we get
                        \begin{align}
                        a_b &= -40.0\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2 \times \frac{g}{9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -4.08\,g
                        \end{align}
                    We notice that the brain&rsquo;s deceleration ($4.08\,g$), is significantly less than the skull&rsquo;s deceleration ($9.18\,g$).
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 42 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p42">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 42</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Calculate the displacement and velocity at times of (a) $0.500$, (b) $1.00$, (c) $1.50$, (d) $2.00$, and (e) $2.50\,\text{s}$ for a rock thrown straight down with an initial velocity of $14.0\,\text{m/s}$ from the Verrazano Narrows Bridge in New York City. The roadway of this bridge is $70.0\,\text{m}$ above the water.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer42_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram42_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution42a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution42b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution42c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution42d_btn">Solution (d)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution42e_btn">Solution (e)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer42">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $-8.23\,\text{m},\; -18.9\,\text{m/s}$  </p>
                      <p>(b) $-18.9\,\text{m},\; -23.8\,\text{m/s}$  </p>
                      <p>(c) $-32.0\,\text{m},\; -28.7\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                      <p>(d) $-47.6\,\text{m},\; -33.6\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                      <p>(e) $-65.6\,\text{m},\; -38.5\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram42">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p><img src="./ch02-p42s.svg" alt="image"></p>
                      <p class="centerText"><b>Figure P2.42s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution42a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    We know the the acceleration of the rock ($a = -g = -9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$) and we are given its initial velocity of $v_0 = -14.0\,\text{m/s}$. The height of the bridge above the water is not necessary information to find the velocity at a given time. So, during the first $0.500\,\text{s}$ of its free fall, the rock performs a vertical displacement of
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta y &= v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2} a t^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (-14.0\,\text{m/s})\, (0.500\,\text{s}) + \tfrac{1}{2}\, (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (0.500\,\text{s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -8.23\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    The rock&rsquo;s velocity at $t = 0.500\,\text{s}$ is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + a t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -14.0\,\text{m/s} + (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (0.500\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -18.9\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution42b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    At $t = 1.00\,\text{s}$ we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta y &= v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2} a t^2\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (-14.0\,\text{m/s})\, (1.00\,\text{s}) + \tfrac{1}{2}\; (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (1.00\,\text{s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -18.9\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + a t\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -14.0\,\text{m/s} + (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (1.00\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -23.8\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}

                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution42c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Similarly, at $t = 1.50\,\text{s}$ we calculate
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta y &= v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2} a t^2\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (-14.0\,\text{m/s})\, (1.50\,\text{s}) + \tfrac{1}{2}\, (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (1.50\,\text{s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -32.0\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + a t\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -14.0\,\text{m/s} + (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (1.50\,\text{s})\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -28.7\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution42d">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (d)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Also, at $t = 2.00\,\text{s}$ we calculate
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta y &= v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2} a t^2\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (-14.0\,\text{m/s})\, (2.00\,\text{s}) + \tfrac{1}{2}\, (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.00\,\text{s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -47.6\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + a t\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -14.0\,\text{m/s} + (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.00\,\text{s})\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -33.6\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution42e">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (e)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Finally, at $t = 2.50\,\text{s}$ we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta y &= v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2} a t^2\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (-14.0\,\text{m/s})\, (2.50\,\text{s}) + \tfrac{1}{2}\, (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.50\,\text{s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -65.6\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + a t\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -14.0\,\text{m/s} + (-9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.50\,\text{s})\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -38.5\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p46">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 46</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A swimmer bounces straight up from a diving board and falls feet first into a pool. She starts with a velocity of $4.00\,\text{m/s}$, and her takeoff point is $1.80\,\text{m}$ above the pool. (a) How long are her feet in the air? (b) What is her highest point above the board? (c) What is her velocity when her feet hit the water?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer46_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution46a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution46b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution46c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer46">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1.14\,\text{s}$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $0.816\,\text{m}$ </p>
                      <p>(c) $-7.17\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution46a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    We know that her initial velocity is $v_0 = 4.00\,\text{m/s}$, her initial position is $y_0 = 1.80\,\text{m}$ above the water, her final position is $y = 0$ at water level, and her acceleration is $a = -g$. Since we are looking for the time $t$, we can use the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit02-constant-acceleration">kinematic equation</a>
                        \begin{equation}
                        y = y_0 + v_0 t +\tfrac{1}{2} a t^2
                        \end{equation}
                    or
                        \begin{equation}
                        \tfrac{1}{2} g\, t^2 - v_0 t - y_0 = 0
                        \end{equation}
                    By solving the quadratic equation above for $t$, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= \frac{v_0 \pm \sqrt{v_0^2 + 2 g\, y_0}}{g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{4.00 \pm \sqrt{(4.00)^2 + 2\, (9.80)\, (1.80)}}{9.80} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{4.00 \pm 7.16}{9.80} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.14\,\text{s}\quad \text{or}\quad -0.322\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that units are omitted in intermediate calculation steps for convenience. Since time always advances forward, we omit the negative value and the answer is
                        \begin{equation}
                        t = 1.14\,\text{s}
                        \end{equation}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution46b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The velocity of the swimmer at her highest point is $v = 0$. Note that the question asks about the height above the board (not the water). This is equal to the vertical displacement $\Delta y$ made by the swimmer from the board to the highest elevation. The calculation can proceed by substituting into the kinematic equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        v^2 = v_0^2 + 2\, a\, \Delta y
                        \end{equation}
                    which simplifying to
                        \begin{equation}
                        0 = v_0^2 - 2\, g\, \Delta y
                        \end{equation}
                    By solving for $\Delta y$ we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta y &= \frac{v_0^2}{2 g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(4.00\,\text{m/s})^2}{2\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.816\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution46c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The velocity of the swimmer when her feet hit the water is calculated using the total time of flight, as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + a t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= v_0 - g t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.00\,\text{m/s} - (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (1.14\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -7.17\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that the negative sign indicates that the final velocity of the swimmer is directed downward.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 60 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p60">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 60</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Using approximate values, calculate the slope of the curve in <b>Figure P2.60</b> to verify that the velocity at $t = 10.0\,\text{s}$ is $0.208\,\text{m/s}$. Assume all values are known to $3$ significant figures.
                    <hr>
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch02-p60.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P2.60</b>: Position vs. time graph</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer60_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram60_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution60_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer60" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.208\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram60">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p><img src="./ch02-p60s.svg" alt="svg"></p>
                      <p class="centerText"><b>Figure P2.60s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution60" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Since we have a graph of position versus time, then
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{slope} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \bar{v}
                        \end{equation}
                     The slope at $t = 10.0\,\text{s}$, can be estimated using two data points located just before and just after this time. Let&rsquo;s choose $t_1 = 0$ and $t_2 = 20.0\,\text{s}$. From <b>Figure P2.60s</b>, we can estimate the corresponding positions to be $x_1 = 2.80\,\text{m}$ and $x_2 = 6.95\,\text{m}$. So, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{slope}_{10} &= \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{x_2 - x_1}{t_2 - t_1}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{6.95\,\text{m} - 2.80\,\text{m}}{20.0\,\text{s} - 0}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.208\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 64 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter02-p64">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 2, Problem 64</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) Take the slope of the curve in <b>Figure P2.64a</b> to find the jogger&rsquo;s velocity at $t = 2.5\,\text{s}$. (b) Repeat at $7.5\,\text{s}$. These values must be consistent with the graph in <b>Figure P2.64b</b>.
                    <hr>
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch02-p64p.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P2.64a</b>: Position vs. time graph</p>
                      <hr>
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch02-p64v.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P2.64b</b>: Velocity vs. time graph</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer64_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram64_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution64a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution64b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer64" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $5\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $-4\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram64">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch02-p64s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P2.64s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution64a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The slope for a point on the position vs. time graph is given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{slope} = \frac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}
                        \end{equation}
                    and it is equal to the velocity at the corresponding time.
                    Since we are looking for the slope at the time $t = 2.5\,\text{s}$, we select two points on the graph located before and after this time (see <b>Figure P2.64s</b>). For example, at $t_1 = 1.5\,\text{s}$ the position is approximately $x_1 = 5\,\text{m}$, and at $t_2 = 3.5\,\text{s}$ the position can be estimated to be $x_2= 15\,\text{m}$. So, we calculate
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{slope}_{2.5}  &= \frac{x_2 - x_1}{t_2 - t_1}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{15\,\text{m} - 5\,\text{m}}{3.5\,\text{s} - 1.5\,\text{s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{10\,\text{m}}{2.0\,\text{s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    When we compare with the velocity vs. time graph, we see that this result is consistent with the velocity at time $t = 2.5\,\text{s}$.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution64b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Similarity, at $t = 7.5\,\text{s}$, we find
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{slope}_{7.5} &= \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{x_2 - x_1}{t_2 - t_1}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{6\,\text{m} - 14\,\text{m}}{8.5\,\text{s} - 6.5\,\text{s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{-8\,\text{m}}{2.0\,\text{s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -4\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    This is also consistent with the velocity at $t = 7.5\,\text{s}$ on the velocity vs. time graph.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

                <p class="runhead1"><strong>Physics 200</strong> Introductory Physics I</p>

                <p class="unit"> Unit 3 <span>(Chapter 3)</span></p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03" > <!-- to change: id="***"; this id value is corresponding to the href value in menu_item, without the "#" -->

                  <!-- to change: the following content -->
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Two-Dimensional Kinematics</h1>
                  <hr>

                  <p>Have you closely watched the flight path of a baseball? It follows a curved path, soaring up until it reaches its maximum height&mdash;then descending gracefully, until it hits the ground. If the air resistance is negligible, the path traversed by the baseball is actually a parabola. The flight of the baseball in this case is an example of motion in two dimensions called <em>projectile motion</em>.</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:2.0em;">
                  <div class="learningobjectives">
                    <h3>Learning Objectives</h3>
                    <p>After completing this unit, you should be able to</p>
                    <ul>
                      <li>differentiate between a vector and a scalar quantity.</li>
                      <li>resolve a vector into its rectangular components and express it in unit vector notation.</li>
                      <li>add and subtract vectors using both analytical and geometric methods.</li>
                      <li>calculate the magnitude and direction of the resultant of multiple vectors using the components method.</li>
                      <li>describe the motion (i.e., displacement, velocity, and acceleration) of an object moving in two dimensions.</li>
                      <li>analyze the motion of a projectile into its horizontal and vertical components.</li>
                      <li>determine the horizontal position and velocity of a projectile while in free flight</li>
                      <li>determine the vertical position and velocity of a projectile while in free flight.</li>
                      <li>define relative velocity and explain the significance of a reference frame.</li>
                      <li>solve basic problems involving classical relativity.</li>
                    </ul>
                  </div>

                  <!-- end of content -->

                </div> <!-- end of this section -->

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-vector-concept">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Two-Dimensional Kinematics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>The Vector Concept</h2>

                  <p>We are all very familiar with numbers&mdash;we cannot live without them. You need numbers to purchase your groceries, to tell the time, and to determine who will win in the next municipal election. So, what is a number? For example, what is a four? The number four is an idea in your mind. When you were in school, your teacher showed you collections of four objects&mdash;four books, four toys, four cats, and so on. From these groups of four similar objects you filtered out the idea of fourness, gave it the name four, and stored it in your mind. It is not a physical object&mdash;but you can attach physical objects to it. To communicate about this idea, you give it a graphical representation. You draw a picture (4), which is a symbol to denote the idea of fourness. In another country with a different language, other people have given the same idea of fourness a name of their own, and they draw a different picture. For example, the symbol 8, which we use for the idea of eightness is used by the Bengalese of Calcutta to represent the number four!</p>

                  <p>Certainly, we need numerical values to describe the motion of a body. However, numerical values are not enough; the directions attached to these quantities have crucial roles to play in their behaviour. A body speeds up and continues to move in a straight line when it accelerates in the direction of its initial velocity. If the direction of the acceleration is reversed, the object slows down. Interestingly, if the object is given an <a  href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-constant-acceleration" target="_self">acceleration</a> that is always perpendicular to its <a  href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-velocity-speed" target="_self">velocity</a>, it moves along a circular path. Such observation demonstrates that numerical values alone are not sufficient to describe motion. Therefore, a description that incorporates direction as a component of the relevant physical quantity is necessary. Such description is referred to as <em>vector</em>. If a numerical value is sufficient for the description of a physical quantity (e.g., mass) then it is referred to as <em>scalar</em> </p>

                  <p>At this stage our interest centres around three vector quantities: <a  href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-displacement" target="_self">displacement</a>, velocity, and acceleration. As you get deeper into the subject, you will come across many other vector quantities. Because of their importance in physics, it is essential that you learn how to handle vectors before going any further in the course. In this unit, you will learn the basics of vector algebra.</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit03-vid01.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 3.1</b>: Concept of a vector.
                  </p>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-vector-representation">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Two-Dimensional Kinematics</h1>
                <hr>
                  <h2>Vector Representation</h2>

                  <p>A scalar is a physical quantity whose value, or magnitude, is described by a single number. A physical quantity is said to be a vector if both the magnitude and direction in space are necessary to describe the quantity.</p>

                  <p>Mathematically, a vector can be defined by two pieces of information: a numerical value (the magnitude of the vector), and a statement of direction in space. To represent a vector graphically, we must simultaneously show the magnitude and the direction of the vector quantity. We do so by drawing a directed line segment&mdash;a straight line with an arrowhead at the end of it, as shown in <a href="#unit03-fig01"><b>Figure 3.1</b></a>. The length of the line, in a chosen unit, represents the magnitude of the vector, and the arrowhead indicates the direction. The end with the arrowhead is called the tip of the directed line segment, and the other end is called the tail. In this course, $\bf boldface$ letters are used to denote vector quantities, while $italicized$ letters are used for scalars. As the magnitude of a vector is a scalar quantity, it is common to use $A$ for the magnitude of the vector $\bf A$ (or $\vec{\bf A}$). </p>

                  <p>
                  <figure id="unit03-fig01">
                  <p><img src="./unit03-fig01.svg"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 3.1</b>: Graphical vector representations and color codes used in this course.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                  <p>It is important to note that a directed line segment is not a vector, but a representation of a vector. Similarly, the notation $\$10$ is not a ten-dollar bill. You should think of a vector as a physical entity such as force. We draw a directed line segment to denote a vector quantity on a piece of paper.</p>

                  <p>Two vectors $\bf A$ and $\bf B$ are said to be equal if they have equal magnitudes (i.e. $A = B$) and point in the same direction. This means, the line segments representing the two vectors are parallel and of equal length. This example brings up an interesting point. If the directed line segment is moved from one place to another without changing its length and direction, the vector remains unchanged.</p>

                  <p>A vector whose magnitude is equal to that of $\bf A$ but with reversed direction is labelled with a negative sign and written as $-\bf A$. Graphically, the two directed line segments representing $\bf A$ and $-\bf A$ must have the same length and must be parallel to each other&mdash;with the arrowheads pointing in opposite directions.</p>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-vector-addition">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Two-Dimensional Kinematics</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Vector Addition</h2>

                <h3>Graphical Methods</h3>
                <p> A mathematical operation, such as addition, is a process of combining two mathematical quantities to get a single mathematical quantity of the same kind. In writing $2 + 7 = 9$, we are making the following mathematical statement: combining two numbers $2$ and $7$, through the process of addition, we get the single number $9$. The mathematical operation of addition of vectors is stated the same way.</p>

                <p> If $\bf C$ is the result of adding the vectors $\bf A$ and $\bf B$ then we describe the operation as ${\bf A} + {\bf B} = {\bf C}$. The vector $\bf C$ is called the sum or <em>resultant</em> of $\bf A$ and $\bf B$. Although we use the same notations and terminology as in addition of numbers, the process of adding vectors is a bit more complicated. We do not just add the magnitudes of two vectors to get their sum; instead, vector addition requires a process that combines the magnitudes and directions simultaneously.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit03-fig02">
                  <p><img src="./unit03-fig02.svg"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 3.2</b>: Vector addition and subtraction, using the head-to-tail method.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p> The <em>head-to-tail</em> method defines a convenient graphical process for adding multiple vectors. In this method (see <a href="#unit03-fig02"><b>Figure 3.2</b></a>), the vectors are aligned so that the tail of the second vector is at the tip of the first one, and the tail of the third vector is at the tip of the second one, and so on. The vector drawn from the tail of the first vector to the tip of the last one, gives the magnitude and direction of the sum of the resultant vector. Note that, subtracting vector $\bf B$ from vector $\bf A$ is equivalent to adding vector $\bf A$ to the negative of vector $\bf B$, which can be expressed as ${\bf A} - {\bf B} = {\bf A} + (-{\bf B})$.</p>

                <h3>Analytical Methods</h3>

                <p>Any number can be expressed as the sum of two numbers. For example, the number $9$ can be defined as the sum of $4$ and $5$. It is also the sum of $8$ and $1$. Actually, we can find an infinite number of pairs ($100$ and $-91$, $1.5$ and $7.5$, and so on) whose sum will be $9$.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit03-fig03">
                  <p><img src="./unit03-fig03.svg"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 3.3</b>: Vector decomposition into two perpendicular components.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>We can do the same for vectors&mdash;break up a given vector into the sum of two vectors. The process is called decomposition of the vector into components. This is an extremely useful tools in solving problems involving vectors. In most cases, we choose a pair of components that are perpendicular to each other, from the infinitely many choices available. As we shall see, perpendicular components make life much easier when we must deal with a multiple vectors. Normally, it is more convenient to choose horizontal and vertical directions when we decompose a vector, unless the problem demands that we choose other directions. The components along these two directions (see <a href="#unit03-fig03"><b>Figure 3.3</b></a>) are called the $x$-component and the $y$-component, respectively. The vector sum of the two components is always equal to the original vector.</p>

                <h3>PhET Simulation: Vector Addition</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-3.pdf#page=18" title="Chapter 3" target="_blank">textbook</a>, &ldquo;learn how to add vectors. Drag vectors onto a graph, change their length and angle, and sum them together. The magnitude, angle, and components of each vector can be displayed in several formats.&rdquo;</p>

                <p><div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 197px;"><a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/vector-addition/vector-addition_en.html" target="_blank" style="text-decoration: none;" rel="external"><img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/vector-addition/vector-addition-600.png" alt="Vector Addition" style="border: none;" width="300" height="197"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);"></div><table style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px;"><tr><td style="text-align: center; color: #000; font-size: 24px; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Click to Run</td></tr></table></a></div>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-projectile-motion">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Two-Dimensional Kinematics</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Projectile Motion</h2>

                <p>It is natural to expect the analysis of motion along a curved path to be a little more complicated than the motion along a straight line, considered in <a href="../unit02/index02.html" target="_self">Unit 2</a>. However, as you will see in this unit, projectile motion can be analyzed in a simple and elegant way, requiring no more resources than our knowledge of kinematics of linear motion and vector addition. The procedure is as follows. First, we resolve the initial velocity into two components&mdash;along the horizontal direction and along the vertical direction. Then, we analyze the kinematics in both direction independently. Since the acceleration due to gravity is vertical (directed downward) it will only affect the vertical component of the velocity. The horizontal component, on the other hand, is not affected by gravity and therefore stays constant during the whole motion.</p>

                <p> In an actual situation, both the horizontal and the vertical velocities would be affected by air resistance. However, to make our work as simple as possible, we will consider an ideal atmosphere in which there is no air drag or wind turbulence to complicate our calculations. At this stage, you are learning the principles of kinematics and how to solve simple model problems; visualize an ideal environment where there is no atmosphere to impede the velocity of our imaginary projectile. You can be sure, however, that when <a href="https://www.nasa.gov/" target="_blank">NASA</a> sends a rocket into space, they do take into consideration air resistance, wind velocity, variations in the acceleration due to gravity, and a host of other variables. Our task here is much simpler!</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit03-fig04">
                  <p><img src="./unit03-fig04.svg"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 3.4</b>: A body in projectile motion.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>Consider a body projected with an initial velocity $v_0$ making an angle $\theta$ above the horizontal direction, as shown in <a href="#unit03-fig04"><b>Figure 3.4</b></a>. It is convenient in this case to resolve the velocity into horizontal ($v_{x}$) and vertical ($v_{y}$) components and analyze the motion in each direction separately. The horizontal velocity of the projectile remains constant because of the absence of any acceleration in that direction. The upward vertical velocity, however, decreases in value as time passes due to downward gravitational acceleration. Because of the diminishing $y$-component, the resultant velocity vector ($\bf v$) is gradually tilted toward the $x$-axis, becoming perfectly horizontal when the projectile reaches its maximum height. From that point on, the $y$-component starts increasing in magnitude (moving in the downward direction) while the $x$-component retains its constant value. The resultant velocity thus becomes tilted below the horizontal direction. After twice the time it takes the body to reach its maximum height, the projectile reaches the altitude from which it was projected. Its velocity has a magnitude $v_0$ at this point, and it now makes an angle of $\theta$ below the horizontal direction.</p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit03-vid02.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 3.2</b>: Projectile motion.
                </p>

                <h3>PhET Simulation: Projectile Motion</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-3.pdf#page=26" title="Chapter 3" target="_blank">textbook</a>, &ldquo;learn about projectile motion by firing various objects. Set the angle, initial speed, and mass. Add air resistance. Make a game out of this simulation by trying to hit a target.&rdquo;</p>

                <p><div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 197px;"><a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/projectile-motion/projectile-motion_en.html" style="text-decoration: none;" rel="external"><img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/projectile-motion/projectile-motion-600.png" alt="Projectile Motion" style="border: none;" width="300" height="197"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);"></div><table style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px;"><tr><td style="text-align: center; color: #000; font-size: 24px; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Click to Run</td></tr></table></a></div>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-relative-velocity">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Two-Dimensional Kinematics</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Relative Velocity</h2>

                <p>Consider a very large but slow ship moving east, parallel to the shoreline, with a constant velocity of $3\,\text{km/h}$. A passenger sitting on the deck observes the captain walking straight west at a constant velocity of $3\,\text{km/h}$. Suppose you are standing on the shore and looking straight at the captain. How would your observation of his motion differ from the description given by the passenger?</p>

                <p>After one minute, the passenger would say that the captain has moved a distance of $50\,\text{m}$ to the west. But, as far as you are concerned, you continue to see the captain in the same spot without even moving your eyes. You will probably claim, however, that the ship has moved a distance of $50\,\text{m}$ to the east, slipping under the captain&rsquo;s feet! This thought experiment demonstrates that a reference to the observer should be included in the description of motion to avoid confusion.</p>

                <p>The concept of relative velocity is not different from the definition of velocity we started out with. Whenever we talk about a velocity, we are talking about a relative velocity, because some observer must make those measurements within a specific frame of reference. However, we do not use the definition and notations of relative velocity unless we encounter a situation where two or more observers are describing the same motion.</p>
