                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-examples">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Two-Dimensional Kinematics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Examples</h2>

                    <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of examples relevant to the content of <span style="white-space: nowrap;">Unit 3</span>. Make an attempt to answer each question on your own, before you read through the solution provided.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-e01">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 3, Example 1</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) Give ten examples, from everyday life, of scalar quantities and (b) another ten examples of vector quantities.</div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer-e01a_btn">Answer (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer-e01b_btn">Answer (b)</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Examples of scalar quantities include the distance to the moon, your body&rsquo;s temperature, the speed of sound in air, the mass of an apple, the area of your backyard, the volume of a cup of coffee, the calories in a donut, the price of your 4K TV, the storage capacity of your smartphone and the mark you get on your physics midterm.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Examples of vector quantities include the displacement of a golf ball after the first shot, the velocity of an airplane during takeoff, the acceleration of a rocket launched into space, the force applied to tow your car, the electric field below a high-voltage power line, the Earth&rsquo;s magnetic field at your location, the force of gravity on a hot air balloon, the momentum (to be introduced later) of a truck just before a collision, the velocity of a swimmer in a one-hundred metre freestyle competition, and the change in your position when you take the elevator to the sixth floor.</p>
                    </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-e02">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 3, Example 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A ship leaves <a href="http://www.stjohns.ca/" target="_blank">St. John&rsquo;s</a> Harbour, sails east, and covers a distance of $150\,\text{km}$. It then changes direction to $35.0^\circ$ south of east and travels another $250\,\text{km}$. Determine the final position of the ship.</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer-e02_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram-e02_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution-e02_btn">Solution</button>
                  <p></p>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$383\,\text{km}$, $22.0^\circ$ south of east</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p  class="centerText"><img src="./unit03-e02s.svg" alt="./unit02-e03s.png">
                      <br><br><b>Figure E3.2s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                      The final location of the ship can be described by adding two displacement vectors, as shown in <b>Figure E3.2s</b>: Vector ${\bf D}_1$ that has a magnitude of $150\,\text{km}$ directed east, and vector ${\bf D}_2$ with a magnitude of $250\,\text{km}$ directed $35.0^\circ$ south of east. The angle ${\bf D}_2$ makes with ${\bf D}_1$ is $35.0^\circ$.</p>

                    <p>For convenience, we set the coordinate system such that the origin is at the harbour and the positive $x$-axis is aligned in the east direction, while the positive $y$-axis is aligned in the north direction. With this convention, the $x$-component of the ship&rsquo;s total displacement is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        D_x &= D_{1x} + D_{2x} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 150\,\text{km} + (250\,\text{km} \times \cos 35.0^\circ) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 355\,\text{km}
                        \end{align}
                      Similarly, the $y$-component of the ship&rsquo;s displacement is
                        \begin{align}
                        D_y &= D_{1y} + D_{2y} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 + (- 250\,\text{km} \times \sin 35.0^\circ) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -143\,\text{km}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                      <p>
                      So, at the end of its trip, the ship is located at a distance $D$ away from the harbour in a direction that makes an angle $\theta$ south of east, where (see <b>Figure E3.2s</b>)
                        \begin{align}
                        D &= \sqrt{D_{x}^2 + D_{y}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(355\,\text{km})^2 + (143\,\text{km})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 383\,\text{km}
                        \end{align}
                      and
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta &=  \tan^{-1}{\left(\frac{143}{355}\right)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 22.0^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  </div>

<!-- ****** Example 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-e03">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 3, Example 3</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Consider the four vectors $\bf A$, $\bf B$, $\bf C$, and $\bf D$ in the diagram below. Draw the arrows representing the vectors ${\bf A} + {\bf B}$, ${\bf A} + {\bf B} + {\bf C}$, and ${\bf A} + {\bf B} + {\bf C} + {\bf D}$.
                    <hr>
                    <p  class="centerText"><img src="./unit03-e03.svg" alt="./unit03-e03.png">
                    <br><br><b>Figure E3.3</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram-e03_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <p></p>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit03-e03s.svg" alt="./unit03-e03s.png">
                      <br><br><b>Figure E3.3s</b></p>

<!-- ****** Example 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-e04">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 3, Example 4</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A golf ball is hit with a velocity of $v_0 = 50.0\,\text{m/s}$ at an angle of $\theta = 40.0^\circ$ above a flat golf course. Ignore air drag and calculate the time of flight of the ball.</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer-e04_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram-e04_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution-e04_btn">Solution</button>
                  <p></p>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$6.56\,\text{s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit03-e04s.svg" alt="./unit03-e04s.png">
                      <br><br><b>Figure E3.4s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>Note that the time of flight is twice the time it takes the ball to reach maximum height. So, to answer the question, we can calculate the time for the upward part of the ball&rsquo;s motion, and multiply by two.</p>

                        <p>Since the vertical velocity at maximum height is equal to zero, we can list the information available about the ball&rsquo;s upward motion as follows
                                \begin{align}
                                y_0 &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                v_{0y} &= v_0 \sin\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                v_y &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                a_y &= - g
                                \end{align}
                        Based on this information, the motion of the golf ball during the first half of its flight can be described by the <a  href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-constant-acceleration">kinematic equation</a>
                                \begin{align}
                                v_y &= v_{0y} + a_y\, t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= v_0 \sin\theta - g\, t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= (50.0\,\text{m/s})\, \sin 40.0^\circ - (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, t_\text{m}
                                \end{align}
                        So, the time it takes the ball to reach maximum height is calculated to be
                                \begin{align}
                                t_\text{m} &= \frac{(50.0\,\text{m/s})\, \sin 40.0^\circ}{9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 3.28\,\text{s}
                                \end{align}
                        Since falling back to the ground takes equal time, the total time of flight is equal to
                                \begin{align}
                                t &= 2\, t_\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 2\, (3.28\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 6.56\,\text{s}
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  </div>

<!-- ****** Example 5 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit03-e05">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Unit 3, Example 5</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A ball is shot from the roof of a high-rise building with initial velocity of  $9.00\,\text{m/s}$ at an angle of $20.0^\circ$ above the horizontal. After $4.00\,\text{s}$ in flight, the ball falls into a nearby soccer field. If air resistance is ignored, determine (a) the horizontal distance travelled and (b) the height of the building.</div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer-e05_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram-e05_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution-e05a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution-e05b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="interactive-e05_btn">Interactive Activity</button>
                  <p></p>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $33.8\,\text{m}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $66.1\,\text{m}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit03-e05s.svg" alt="image">
                      <br><br><b>Figure E3.5s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e05a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">

                    <p>The ball leaves the roof of the building with an initial velocity of $v_0 = 9.00\,\text{m/s}$ at $\theta = 20.0^\circ$ above the horizontal, as shown in <b>Figure E3.5s</b>. Since it does not accelerate in the horizontal direction, the ball&rsquo;s horizontal velocity ($v_x$) remains constant. So, the horizontal distance ($x$) travelled by the ball, as measured from the base of the building, is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        x &= v_x\, t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (v_0 \cos\theta)\, t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (9.00\,\text{m/s})\, (\cos{20.0^\circ})\, (4.00\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 33.8\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e05b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                   <p>For the vertical motion of the ball, you have the following information
                        \begin{align}
                        y_0 &= h \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        y &= 0  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        v_{0y} &= v_0\,\sin\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        t &= 4.00\,\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        a &= - g
                        \end{align}
                   So, the height  of the building ($h$) can be calculated by substituting into the appropriate <a  href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-constant-acceleration">kinematic equation</a> as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        y &= y_0 + v_{0y}\, t + \tfrac{1}{2} a\, t^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= h + v_0 \sin\theta\, t - \tfrac{1}{2} g\, t^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= h + (9.00\,\text{m/s})\, (\sin{20.0^\circ})\, (4.00\,\text{s}) - \tfrac{1}{2} (9.80\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2) (4.00)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad h &= 66.1\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                   </p>
                    </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="interactive-e05">
                <div class="panel-heading">Interactive Activity</div>
                <div class="panel-body">

                <div class="panel-body">
                <p  class="centerText"><a href="./unit03-e05i.cdf"><img src="./unit03-e05i.png" alt="image"></a>
                <br><br><b>Figure E3.5i</b></p>
                </div>

                     <p>Use <a href="https://www.wolfram.com/cdf-player/" target="_blank">Wolfram CDF Player</a>
                     to open the interactive diagram <a href="./unit03-e05i.cdf"><b>Figure E3.5i</b></a>.</p>

                     <p>Answer the questions below and use the interactive diagram to check your calculations.</p>

                     <p>
                     <ol>
                     <li>How far from the base of building would the ball fall if it is shot with the same initial speed, but at  $20.0^\circ$ below the horizontal?</li>
                     <li>Repeat the calculation above with the initial speed increased to $13.0\,\text{m}/\text{s}$.</li>
                     <li>Determine the range and the final velocity of the projectile if it is shot horizontally at an initial speed of $15.0\,\text{m}/\text{s}$ from a window located at a height $50.0\,\text{m}$ above the ground.</li>
                      </ol>

                    </div>
                </div>

                </div>

                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Two-Dimensional Kinematics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Conceptual Questions</h2>

                  <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of conceptual questions selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-3.pdf#page=36" title="Chapter 3" target="_blank">Chapter 3</a> in the textbook.</p>

<!-- ****** Question ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-q04">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Question 4</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Two campers in a national park hike from their cabin to the same spot on a lake, each taking a different path, as illustrated below. The total distance traveled along $\text{Path 1}$ is $7.5\,\text{km}$, and that along $\text{Path 2}$ is $8.2\,\text{km}$. What is the final displacement of each camper?
                    <hr>
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-q04.svg" alt="./ch03-q04.png">
                    <br><br><b>Figure Q3.4</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer-q04_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="explanation-q04_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$5.0\,\text{km},\; 40^\circ\;\text{north of east}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Displacement is a vector quantity that describes the difference between the initial and final positions. As shown in <b>Figure Q3.4</b>, both campers perform the same displacement ($\bf S$), which has a magnitude of $5.0\,\text{km}$ and a direction of $40^\circ$ north of east.
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-q09">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Question 9</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose you add two vectors $\bf A$ and $\bf B$ . What relative direction between them produces the resultant with the greatest magnitude? What is the maximum magnitude? What relative direction between them produces the resultant with the smallest magnitude? What is the minimum magnitude?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer-q09_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="explanation-q09_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q09">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0^\circ,\; A+B,\; 180^\circ,\; |A-B|$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q09">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The greatest magnitude results when the two vectors are in the same direction. An example is when both have positive $x$ components with zero $y$ component. The magnitude in this case is the sum of the individual magnitudes, or $A + B$.</p>

                      <p>The smallest magnitude, on the other hand, results when the vectors are directed opposite to each other, resulting in a magnitude of $|A-B|$. Note that if the vectors are of equal magnitudes, then the smallest resultant is equal to zero</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-q10">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Question 10</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Give an example of a nonzero vector that has a component of zero.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer-q10_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="explanation-q10_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Velocity of a car travelling eastward.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>An example would be the velocity ($\bf v$) of a car travelling east at $90\,\text{km/h}$. If this is taken to be the $x$ direction, then the velocity can be described as $v_x = 90\,\text{km/h}$ and $v_y = 0$. In other words, the velocity vector has zero velocity in the north direction. Also, note that the magnitude of the vector in this case is equal to the value of its $x$-component.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>
