                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-problems">
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Two-Dimensional Kinematics</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Solutions of Selected Problems</h2>
                    <p>Next are detailed solutions to a number of problems selected from the end of <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-3.pdf#page=39" title="Chapter 3" target="_blank">Chapter 3</a></span> in the textbook. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve each problem independently, before you read through the solution provided. You are also advised to make a second attempt to solve the problem if your answer is different from the one posted. If you reach an impasse and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p05">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 5</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose you first walk $12.0\,\text{m}$ in a direction $20.0^\circ\, \text{west of north}$ and then $20.0\,\text{m}$ in a direction $40.0^\circ\, \text{south of west}$. How far are you from your starting point, and what is the compass direction of a line connecting your starting point to your final position? (If you represent the two legs of the walk as vector displacements $\bf A$ and $\bf B$, as in <b>Figure P3.5</b>, then this problem finds their sum ${\bf R} = {\bf A} + {\bf B}$.)
                    <hr>
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p05.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.5</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer05_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution05_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer05" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$19.5\,\text{m},\; 4.65^\circ\; \text{south of west}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution05" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    To use the graphical method, we first draw the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit03-vector-representation">vector representation</a> of the problem as in <b>Figure P3.5</b>. After that, we measure the length of the $\bf R$ vector and the angle $\theta$ it forms with the west direction.
                    </p>

                    <p>To use the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit03-vector-addition">analytical method</a>, we set the coordinate system such that the positive $y$-axis corresponds to the north direction. By analyzing the components of the displacement vectors in <b>Figure P3.5</b>, we can calculate the $x$ and $y$ components of the resultant vector to be
                        \begin{align}
                        R_x &= A_x + B_x \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - (12.0\,\text{m})\, \sin 20.0^\circ - (20.0\,\text{m})\, \cos 40.0^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -19.4\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      and
                        \begin{align}
                        R_y &= A_y + B_y \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (12.0\,\text{m})\, \cos 20.0^\circ - (20.0\,\text{m})\, \sin 40.0^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -1.58\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                      <p>
                      So, after the walk, I will be at a distance $R$ from the starting point where
                        \begin{align}
                        R &= \sqrt{R_x^2 + R_y^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(19.4\,\text{m})^2 + (1.58\,\text{m})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 19.5\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      located in the compass direction
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta &=  \tan^{-1} \left(\frac{1.58}{19.4}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.65^\circ\; \text{south of west}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 14 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p14">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 14</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Find the following for path $\text{D}$ in <b>Figure P3.14</b>: (a) the total distance traveled and (b) the magnitude and direction of the displacement from start to finish. In this part of the problem, explicitly show how you follow the steps of the analytical method of vector addition. All blocks are $120\,\text{m}$ on a side.
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p14.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.14</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer14_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram14_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution14a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution14b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer14">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1.56\,\text{km}$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $646\,\text{m},\; 21.8^\circ\,\text{north of east}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram14">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p14s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.14s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                        First, let&rsquo;s break the path in <b>Figure P3.14</b> into four segments. In the first segment, the path moves $2 \,\text{blocks}$ south. In the second segment, the path moves $6\,\text{blocks}$ east. It then moves $4\,\text{blocks}$ north. For the fourth segment, the path moves $1\,\text{block}$ west.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                        The total distance travelled on this path is equal to the total length of the four segments such that
                        \begin{align}
                        d &= 2\,\text{block} + 6\,\text{block} + 4\,\text{block} + 1\,\text{block} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 13\,\text{block} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 13\,\color{red}{\text{block}} \times \frac{120\,\text{m}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{block}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1560\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                      We begin by assigning the vectors ${\bf D}_1$, ${\bf D}_2$, ${\bf D}_3$, and ${\bf D}_4$ to the four path segments, and write
                        \begin{align}
                        D_{1x} &= 0, && D_{1y} = -2\,\text{block}, \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        D_{2x} &= 6\,\text{block}, && D_{2y} = 0, \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        D_{3x} &= 0, && D_{3y} = 4\,\text{blocks}, \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        D_{4x} &= -1\,\text{block}, && D_{4y} = 0,
                        \end{align}
                      If the resultant displacement vector from start to finish (see <b>Figure P3.14s</b>) is defined as
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf R} = {\bf D}_1 + {\bf D}_2 + {\bf D}_3 + {\bf D}_4
                        \end{equation}
                      we can calculate its $x$ component
                        \begin{align}
                        R_x &= D_{1x} + D_{2x} + D_{3x} + D_{4x} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 + 6\,\text{block} + 0 - 1\,\text{block} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5\,\text{block} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 600\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      and also its $y$ component
                        \begin{align}
                        R_y &= D_{1y} + D_{2y} + D_{3y} + D_{4y} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -2\,\text{block} + 0 + 4\,\text{block} + 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2 \,\text{block} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 240\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                      <p>
                      The magnitude of the displacement can be determined using the Pythagorean theorem as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        R &= \sqrt{R_x^2 + R_y^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(600\,\text{m})^2+(240\,\text{m})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 646\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      The direction of the finish point with respect to the start location is
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta &= \tan^{-1}{\left( \frac{R_y}{R_x} \right)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tan^{-1}{\left(\frac{2\,\text{block}}{5\,\text{block}}\right) }\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 21.8^\circ\; \text{north of east}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 18 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p18">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 18</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">You drive $7.50\,\text{km}$ in a straight line in a direction $15^\circ\,\text{east of north}$. (a) Find the distances you would have to drive straight east and then straight north to arrive at the same point. (This determination is equivalent to finding the components of the displacement along the east and north directions.) (b) Show that you still arrive at the same point if the east and north legs are reversed in order.</div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer18_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram18_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution18a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution18b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer18">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1.94\,\text{km},\; 7.24\,\text{km}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram18">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p18s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.18s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                      My displacement vector can be expressed as
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf S} = 7.5\,\text{km},\; 15^\circ\,\text{east of north}
                        \end{equation}
                      By decomposing this displacement into east and north components, we can express the distance travelled east as
                        \begin{align}
                        S_\text{E} &= (7.5\,\text{km})\, \sin{15^\circ } \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.94\,\text{km}
                        \end{align}
                      and the distance travelled north as
                        \begin{align}
                        S_\text{N} &= (7.5\,\text{km})\, \cos{15^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 7.24\,\text{km}
                        \end{align}
                      to arrive at the same point.
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                        From <b>Figure P3.18s</b>, we can see that east and west displacement vectors are commutative. In other words, their sum is independent of the order in which they are added, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf S} = {\bf S}_\text{E} + {\bf S}_\text{N} = {\bf S}_\text{N} + {\bf S}_\text{E}
                        \end{equation}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 20 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p20">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 20</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A new landowner has a triangular piece of flat land she wishes to fence. Starting at the west corner, she measures the first side to be $80.0\,\text{m}$ long and the next to be $105\,\text{m}$. These sides are represented as displacement vectors $\bf A$ from $\bf B$ in <b>Figure P3.20</b>. She then correctly calculates the length and orientation of the third side $C$. What is her result?
                    <hr>
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p20.svg" alt="./ch03-p20.png"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure P3.20</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer20_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution20_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p> $C = 92.2\,\text{m}$, $\theta = 53.6^\circ$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Let&rsquo;s begin by defining the angles we&rsquo;ll be working with. We know that the vector $\bf A$ is $21.0^\circ\,\text{south of east}$. If we use the positive $x$ direction (or eastward) as our axis of reference for angles, then
                        \begin{equation}
                        \theta_A = -21.0^\circ
                        \end{equation}
                    Similarly, since $\bf B$ is $11^\circ\,\text{west of north}$, we can set the direction of this vector from the x-axis to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta_B &= 90^\circ + 11^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 101^\circ \nonumber
                        \end{align}
                    Now, let&rsquo;s break down $\bf A$ into its $x$ and $y$ components,
                        \begin{align}
                        A_x &= A\, \cos{\theta_A} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (80.0\,\text{m})\, \cos{(-21.0^\circ)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 74.7\,\text{m} \\[12pt]
                        A_y &= A\, \sin{\theta_A} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (80.0\,\text{m})\, \sin{(-21^\circ)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -28.7\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    Doing the same for $\bf B$, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        B_x &= B\, \cos{\theta_B} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (105\,\text{m})\, \cos{101^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -20.0\,\text{m} \\[12pt]
                        B_y &= B\, \sin{\theta_B}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (105\,\text{m})\, \sin{101^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 103\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    <p>
                    Note that by adding all three vectors we end up at the same place (the west corner). So, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf A} + {\bf B} + {\bf C}= 0
                        \end{equation}
                    or
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf C} =-({\bf A} + {\bf B})
                        \end{equation}
                    By carrying this addition at the component level, we get
                        \begin{align}
                        C_x &= -(A_x + B_x) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -(74.7\,\text{m} - 20.0\,\text{m})\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -54.7\,\text{m} \\[12pt]
                        C_y &= -(A_y + B_y) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -(-28.7\,\text{m} + 103\,\text{m})\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -74.3\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    By using the Pythagorean theorem, we can calculate the magnitude of $\bf C$ to be equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        C &= \sqrt{C_x^2 + C_y^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(-54.7\,\text{m})^2+(-74.3\,\text{m})^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 92.2\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    The angle $\theta$ in <b>Figure P3.20</b> is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta &= \tan^{-1}{\left( \frac{C_y}{C_x} \right)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tan^{-1}{\left( \frac{74.3\,\text{m}}{54.3\,\text{m}} \right) }\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 53.6^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    which is measured from the negative $x$ axis. Note that it can also be expressed in the standard form as
                    \begin{align}
                        \theta_C &= 180^\circ + 53.6^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 234^\circ \nonumber
                        \end{align}
                    from the positive $x$ direction.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 26 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p26">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 26</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A ball is kicked with an initial velocity of $16\,\text{m/s}$ in the horizontal direction and $12\,\text{m/s}$ in the vertical direction. (a) At what speed does the ball hit the ground? (b) For how long does the ball remain in the air? (c) What maximum height is attained by the ball?</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer26_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram26_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution26a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution26b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution26c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer26">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $20\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $2.4\,\text{s}$ </p>
                      <p>(c) $7.3\,\text{m}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram26">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p26s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.26s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution26a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                      As seen from <b>Figure P3.26s</b>  the ball is kicked with an initial horizontal velocity of $v_{0x} = 16\,\text{m/s}$ and an initial vertical velocity of $v_{0y} = 12\,\text{m/s}$. The horizontal component of the ball&rsquo;s velocity remains constant throughout the trajectory as there is no horizontal acceleration. So, the ball hits the ground with a final horizontal velocity of
                        \begin{equation}
                        v_x = v_{0x}
                        \label{ch03-p26-vx}
                        \end{equation}
                      </p>
                      <p>
                      For the vertical component of the ball&rsquo;s velocity ($v_y$), note that it starts with the initial value $v_{0y}$ and decreases uniformly at the rate $a_y = -g$ until it becomes zero at maximum height. So, the time ($t_\text{m}$) it takes the ball to reach the top of its trajectory is determined as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        0 &= v_{0y} - g\, t_\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad t_\text{m} &= \frac{v_{0y}}{g}
                        \label{ch03_p26_tm}
                        \end{align}
                      Since the ball falls back to the same vertical level (the ground), there should be a symmetry between the ascending and descending halves of the trajectory. So, in the second half of its flight, the ball starts with zero vertical velocity, travels an equal vertical distance, accelerates downward at the same rate, and spends an equal amount of time in the air. So, the final vertical velocity of the ball just before it hits the ground is equal in magnitude to its initial vertical velocity, or
                        \begin{align}
                        v_y &= 0 - g\, t_\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - g \left(\frac{v_{0y}}{g}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - v_{0y}
                        \label{ch03-p26-vy}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>

                      <p>From above, we see that the ball is kicked with an initial speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        v_0 &= \sqrt{v_{0x}^2 + v_{0y}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(16\,\text{m/s})^2 + (12\,\text{m/s})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 20\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                      and hits the ground at a final speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= \sqrt{v_{x}^2 + v_{y}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(16\,\text{m/s})^2 + (-12\,\text{m/s})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 20\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                      From this, we see that the ball hits the ground with the same speed it is kicked with.
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution26b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                      As mentioned earlier, due to symmetric motion, it takes as much time for the ball to reach its maximum height as it does to fall down. So, the total time of flight (see Equation \ref{ch03_p26_tm}) is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        t_\text{tot} &= 2\, t_m \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2 \left(\frac{v_{0y}}{g}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2 \left(\frac{12\,\text{m/s}}{9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.4\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution26c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                      Considering the ascending part of the ball&rsquo;s motion until maximum height ($y = h$), and applying the kinematic equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        v_y^2 = v_{0y}^2 + 2 a_y (y - y_0)
                        \end{equation}
                      we have
                        \begin{align}
                        0 &= v_{0y}^2 - 2 g (h - 0)\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad h &= \frac{v_{0y}^2}{2 g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(12\,\text{m/s})^2}{2\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 7.3\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 30 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p30">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 30</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A rugby player passes the ball $7.00\,\text{m}$ across the field, where it is caught at the same height as it left his hand. (a) At what angle was the ball thrown if its initial speed was $12.0\,\text{m/s}$, assuming that the smaller of the two possible angles was used? (b) What other angle gives the same range, and why would it not be used? (c) How long did this pass take?</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer30_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram30_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution30a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution30b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution30c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer30" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $14.2^\circ$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $75.8^\circ$ </p>
                      <p>(c) $0.603\,\text{s}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p30s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.30s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The ball is thrown with an initial speed of $v_0 = 12.0\,\text{m/s}$ and covers a range of
                        \begin{equation}
                        R = 7.00\,\text{m}
                        \end{equation}
                    Since the ball was caught at the same height as it left the player&rsquo;s hand, we can apply the equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        R = \frac{v_0^2\, \sin{2 \theta_0}}{g}
                        \label{ch03_p30_R}
                        \end{equation}
                    By solving for the initial launch angle $\theta_0$ we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \sin{2 \theta_0} &= \frac{gR}{v_0^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 2\theta_0 &= \sin^{-1}{\left( \frac{gR}{v_0^2} \right) }\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \theta_0 &= \tfrac{1}{2}\; \sin^{-1}{\left( \frac{gR}{v_0^2} \right)}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2}\; \sin^{-1}{\left[ \frac{(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\,(7.00\,\text{m})}{(12.0\,\text{m/s})^2}\right] }\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 14.2^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Using the trigonometric identity
                        \begin{equation}
                        \sin (180^\circ - \phi) = \sin \phi
                        \end{equation}
                    we see that the same range can be produced if the $2\theta_0$ in Equation \ref{ch03_p30_R} is replaced by
                        \begin{equation}
                        2 \theta_1 = 180^\circ - 2 \theta_0
                        \end{equation}
                    So, the angle $\theta_1$, which produces the same range is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta_1 &= 90^\circ - \theta_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 90^\circ - 14.2^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 75.8^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    This angle would not be used as the ball would have a greater maximum height (see <b>Figure P3.30s</b>) and the pass would take longer to complete.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    First, let&rsquo;s find the horizontal component of the velocity.
                        \begin{align}
                        v_x &= v_0 \cos{\theta_0} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=(12.0\,\text{m/s})\, \cos{14.2^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 11.6\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    Since there is no horizontal acceleration, we can easily calculate the duration of the pass to be
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= \frac{R}{v_x} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{7.00\,\text{m}}{11.6\,\text{m/s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.603\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that if the ball was thrown at the other angle ($\theta_1 = 75.8^\circ$), it would then take $2.37\,\text{s}$ to complete the pass.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p34">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 34</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">An arrow is shot from a height of $1.5\,\text{m}$ toward a cliff of height $H$. It is shot with a velocity of $30\,\text{m/s}$ at an angle of $60^\circ$ above the horizontal. It lands on the top edge of the cliff $4.0\,\text{s}$ later. (a) What is the height of the cliff? (b) What is the maximum height reached by the arrow along its trajectory? (c) What is the arrow&rsquo;s impact speed just before hitting the cliff? </div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer34_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram34_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution34a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution34b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution34c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer34">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $27\,\text{m}$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $36\,\text{m}$ </p>
                      <p>(c) $20\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram34">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p34s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.34s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    We begin by finding the initial vertical speed,
                        \begin{align}
                        v_{0y} &= v_0 \sin{\theta}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (30\,\text{m/s})\, \sin{60^\circ}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 26\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    Since we also know the initial vertical position, $y_0 = 1.5\,\text{m}$, and the time it takes for the arrow to reach the top of the cliff, $t = 4.0\,\text{s}$, we can substitute into the kinematic equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        y = y_0 +v_{0y} t + \tfrac{1}{2}\; a_y t^2
                        \end{equation}
                    to calculate the arrow&rsquo;s final vertical position $y = H$. So, the height of the cliff is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        H &= y_0 +v_{0y} t - \tfrac{1}{2}\; g t^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.5\,\text{m} + (26\,\text{m/s})\, (4.0\,\text{s}) - \tfrac{1}{2}\; (9.8\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (4.0\,\text{s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 27\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                 <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The arrow reaches its maximum height ($y = y_\text{max}$) when the vertical component of the velocity becomes equal to zero (i.e., $v_y = 0$). By substituting into the kinematic equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        v_y^2 = v_{0y}^2 + 2 a_y (y - y_0)
                        \end{equation}
                    we can determine the maximum height as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        0 &= v_{0y}^2 - 2 g\, (y_\text{max} - y_0) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 2 g\, (y_\text{max} - y_0) &= v_{0y}^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  y_\text{max} - y_0 &= \frac{v_{0y}^2}{2g}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  y_\text{max} &= \frac{v_{0y}^2}{2g} + y_0\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(26\,\text{m/s}^2)}{2\, (9.8\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)} + 1.5\,\text{m}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 36\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Throughout its flight, the arrow moves with a constant horizontal speed of
                        \begin{align}
                         v_x &= v_0 \cos{\theta}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (30\,\text{m/s})\, \cos{60^\circ}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 15\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    The final vertical speed, $v_y$, as the arrow descends from it&rsquo;s maximum height to the top of the cliff, can be calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v_y^2 &= 0 - 2 g\, (H - y_\text{max}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_y &= \sqrt{2g\, (y_\text{max} - H)}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{2\, (9.8\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (36\,\text{m} - 27\,\text{m})}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 13.22\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that since this is an intermediate step in the calculation, we may defer the rounding to two significant figures to the final (or next) step.
                    Using the Pythagorean theorem, we find an impact speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= \sqrt{v_x^2 + v_y^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(15\,\text{m/s})^2 + (13.22\,\text{m/s})^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 20\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 40 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p40">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 40</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">An eagle is flying horizontally at a speed of $3.00\,\text{m/s}$ when the fish in her talons wiggles loose and falls into the lake $5.00\,\text{m}$ below. Calculate the velocity of the fish relative to the water when it hits the water.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer40_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution40_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer40">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$10.3\,\text{m/s},\; 73.1^\circ\, \text{below the horizontal}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution40">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The initial velocity of the fish is equal to that of the eagle, with a horizontal component of $v_{0x} = 3.00\,\text{m/s}$ and no vertical component ($v_{0y} = 0$). Once the fish wiggles free, it begins to accelerate in the downward direction at a rate of $a_y = -g$ and moves as a <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit03-projectile-motion">projectile</a> until it reaches the surface of the lake. The vertical displacement of the fish while in free fall is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta y &= y - y_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 - 5.00\,\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - 5.00\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the vertical component of the final velocity ($v_y$) is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v_y^2 &= v_{0y}^2 + 2 a_y\, \Delta y \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 - 2 g\, \Delta y \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (5.00\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 98.0\,\text{m}^2/\text{s}^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_y &= -\sqrt{98.0\,\text{m}^2/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -9.90\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                        Note that the negative square root is selected because we know that the vertical component of the final velocity is directed downwards.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                    The $x$ component of the velocity remains unchanged due to the absence of horizontal acceleration. So, we have
                        \begin{equation}
                        v_x = v_{0x} = 3.00\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{equation}
                    Using the Pythagorean theorem, we can find the magnitude of the final velocity to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= \sqrt{v_x^2 + v_y^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(3.00\,\text{m/s})^2 + (-9.90\,\text{m/s})^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{107\,\text{m}^2/\text{s}^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 10.3\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    Since we are looking for a velocity and not a speed, we must also find the direction. This is the angle $\theta$ with the horizontal (or lake surface) at which the fish hits the water,
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta &= \tan^{-1}{\left( \frac{v_y}{v_x} \right) }\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tan^{-1}{\left( \frac{-9.90\,\text{m/s}}{3.00\,\text{m/s}} \right) }\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -73.1^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    So, the fish plunges into the water at an angle $73.1^\circ$ below the horizontal.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 44 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p44">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 44</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The free throw line in basketball is $4.57\,\text{m}$ ($15\,\text{ft}$) from the basket, which is $3.05\,\text{m}$ ($10\,\text{ft}$) above the floor. A player standing on the free throw line throws the ball with an initial speed of $7.15\,\text{m/s}$, releasing it at a height of $2.44\,\text{m}$ ($8\,\text{ft}$) above the floor. At what angle above the horizontal must the ball be thrown to exactly hit the basket? Note that most players will use a large initial angle rather than a flat shot because it allows for a larger margin of error. Explicitly show how you follow the steps involved in solving projectile motion problems. </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer44_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram44_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution44_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer44">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p> $48.8^\circ$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram44">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p44s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.44s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution44">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Let&rsquo;s first consider the vertical component of the throw. The ball leaves the player&rsquo;s hand ($y_0 = 2.44\,\text{m}$) with an initial vertical velocity
                    \begin{align}
                    v_{0y} &= v_0\, \sin\theta_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                    &= (7.15\,\text{m/s})\, \sin\theta_0
                    \end{align}
                    and moves as a <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit03-projectile-motion">projectile</a> until it reaches the basket at $y = 3.05\,\text{m}$, as shown in <b>Figure P3.44s</b>.
                    This allows us to describe the vertical motion of the ball, using one of the <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-constant-acceleration">kinematic equations</a>, as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        y &= y_0 + v_{0y}\, t + \tfrac{1}{2} a_y\, t^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= y_0 + v_0\, \sin\theta_0\, t - \tfrac{1}{2} g\, t^2
                        \label{ch03_p44_y}
                        \end{align}
                    where $t$ is the duration of the throw.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                    Next, we look at the horizontal component of the throw. Since there is no acceleration in this direction, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        v_{0x} &= v_0\, \cos\theta_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (7.15\,\text{m/s})\, \cos\theta_0
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        x &= x_0 + v_{0x}\, t  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 + v_0\, \cos\theta_0\, t
                        \end{align}
                     which allows us to express the time $t$ as
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= \frac{x}{v_0\cos{\theta_0}}
                        \label{ch03_p44_t}
                        \end{align}
                     Note that the axes are drawn with the origin at the player&rsquo;s feet (see <b>Figure P3.44s</b>) and, therefore, $x_0 = 0$.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                    We can substitute from Equation \ref{ch03_p44_t} into Equation \ref{ch03_p44_y} as follows,
                        \begin{align}
                        y &= y_0 + v_0\, \sin\theta_0 \left(\frac{x}{v_0\cos\theta_0}\right) - \tfrac{1}{2}\; g \left(\frac{x}{v_0\cos\theta_0}\right)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= y_0 + x\, \tan\theta_0 - \left(\frac{g\, x^2}{2v_0^2}\right) \sec^2\theta_0
                        \label{ch03_p44_y2}
                        \end{align}
                    A useful trigonometric identity for solving this equation is
                        \begin{equation}
                        \sec^{2}{\phi} = 1 + \tan^{2}{\phi}
                        \label{ch03_p44_sec}
                        \end{equation}
                    which allows expressing Equation \ref{ch03_p44_y2} as
                        \begin{align}
                        y &= y_0 + x\, \tan\theta_0 - \left(\frac{g\, x^2}{2v_0^2}\right) \left(1 + \tan^2\theta_0\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= \left(\frac{g\, x^2}{2v_0^2}\right) \tan^2\theta_0 - x\, \tan\theta_0 + \left(y - y_0 + \frac{g\, x^2}{2v_0^2}\right)
                        \label{ch03_p44_y3}
                        \end{align}
                    By defining
                        \begin{equation}
                        X = \tan\theta_0
                        \end{equation}
                    we can rewrite Equation \ref{ch03_p44_y3} into the quadratic form
                        \begin{equation}
                        0 = a X^2 + b X + c
                        \label{ch03_p44_quadratic}
                        \end{equation}
                        where the the three parameters take the values
                        \begin{align}
                        a &= \frac{g\, x^2}{2v_0^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (4.57\,\text{m})}{2\, (7.15\,\text{m/s})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.00\,\text{m} \\[18pt]
                        b &= -x \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -4.57\,\text{m} \\[18pt]
                        c &= y - y_0 + \frac{g\, x^2}{2v_0^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.05\,\text{m} - 2.44\,\text{m} + \frac{(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (4.57\,\text{m})}{2\, (7.15\,\text{m/s})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.61\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    Using these values, we can set to solve the quadratic equation \ref{ch03_p44_quadratic} as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        X &= \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{4.57 \pm \sqrt{(-4.57)^2 - 4\, (2.00)\, (2.61)}}{2\, (2.00)}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{4.57}{4.00}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that the quantity under the square root is equal to zero within the uncertainties of the given values. In this case, $X$ has a single solution, which corresponds to an initial angle of
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta_0 &= \tan^{-1} \left(\frac{4.57}{4.00}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 48.8^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 52 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p52">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 52</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Bryan Allen pedaled a human-powered aircraft across the English Channel from the cliffs of Dover to Cap Gris-Nez on June 12, 1979. (a) He flew for $169\,\text{min}$ at an average velocity of $3.53\,\text{m/s}$ in a direction $45^\circ\,\text{south of east}$. What was his total displacement? (b) Allen encountered a headwind averaging $2.00\,\text{m/s}$ almost precisely in the opposite direction of his motion relative to the Earth. What was his average velocity relative to the air? (c) What was his total displacement relative to the air mass? </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer52_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram52_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution52a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution52b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution52c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer52">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $35.8\,\text{km},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $5.53\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}$ </p>
                      <p>(c) $56.1\,\text{km},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram52">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p52s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P2.52s</b>: Velocity of Bryan Allen relative to the Earth, and the headwind he encountered.</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution52a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    First, we express the duration of the flight in seconds.
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= 169\,\text{min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 169\,\color{red}{\text{min}}\times\frac{60\,\text{s}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{min}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 10{,}140\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    <p>
                    Since the aircraft flies with a total velocity (relative to the Earth) of
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf v}_\text{tot} = 3.53\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}
                        \end{equation}
                    its total displacement during the flight is
                        \begin{align}
                        {\bf d} &= \big(3.53\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}\big) \big(10{,}140\,\text{s}\big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.58 \times 10^4\,\text{m},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 35.8\,\text{km},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution52b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    As shown in <b>Figure P2.52s</b>, the surrounding air moves with a wind velocity of
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf v}_\text{w} = 2.00\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{north of west}
                        \end{equation}
                    If the velocity of the plane relative to the air is ${\bf v}_\text{B}$, then the three velocities are related by the equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf v}_\text{tot} = {\bf v}_\text{w} + {\bf v}_\text{B}
                        \end{equation}
                    So, the average velocity of Bryan Allen relative to the air is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        {\bf v}_\text{B} &= {\bf v}_\text{tot} - {\bf v}_\text{w} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \big(3.53\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}\big) - \big(2.00\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{north of west}\big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \big(3.53\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}\big) - \big(- 2.00\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}\big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \big(3.53\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}\big) + \big(2.00\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}\big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.53\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution52c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The displacement of Bryan Allen relative to the air mass is, therefore, equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        {\bf d}_\text{B} &= {\bf v}_\text{B}\, t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \big(5.53\,\text{m/s},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}\big) \big(10{,}140\,\text{s}\big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.61\times 10^4 \,\text{m},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 56.1\,\text{km},\; 45^\circ\,\text{south of east}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 54 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p54">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 54</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Near the end of a marathon race, the first two runners are separated by a distance of $45.0\,\text{m}$. The front runner has a velocity of $3.50\,\text{m/s}$, and the second a velocity of $4.20\,\text{m/s}$. (a) What is the velocity of the second runner relative to the first? (b) If the front runner is $250\,\text{m}$ from the finish line, who will win the race, assuming they run at constant velocity? (c) What distance ahead will the winner be when she crosses the finish line?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer54_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution54a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution54b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution54c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer54">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $0.70\,\text{m/s},\; \text{forward}$ </p>
                      <p>(b) Second runner </p>
                      <p>(c) $4.3\,\text{m}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution54a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    Let&rsquo;s denote the first runner as $\text{A}$, and the second runner as $\text{B}$, where
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{A} &= 3.50\,\text{m/s} \\[6pt]
                        v_\text{B} &= 4.20\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    So the velocity of runner $\text{B}$ relative to runner $\text{A}$ is
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{BA} &= v_\text{B} - v_\text{A} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.20\,\text{m/s} - 3.50\,\text{m/s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.70\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    directed forward.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution54b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    The winner is the one who reaches the finish line in less time. Runner $\text{A}$ has to travel a distance of $x_\text{A} = 250\,\text{m}$, while the following runner needs to cover a longer distance of $x_\text{B} = 250\,\text{m} + 45.0\,\text{m} = 295\,\text{m}$ to the finish line. So, runner $\text{A}$ will reach the finish line in
                        \begin{align}
                        t_\text{A} &= \frac{x_\text{A}}{v_\text{A}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{250\,\text{m}}{3.50\,\text{m/s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 71.4\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    while runner $\text{B}$ will be able to meet the same target in a shorter period of
                        \begin{align}
                        t_\text{B} &= \frac{x_\text{B}}{v_\text{B}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{295\,\text{m}}{4.20\,\text{m/s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 70.2\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    Therefore, the second runner ($\text{B}$) will win the race.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution54c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    During the time ($t_\text{B}$) it takes runner $\text{B}$ to reach the finish line, runner $\text{A}$ would have covered a distance of $v_\text{A} t_\text{B}$.
                    So, the winner is ahead by a distance
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta x &= 250\,\text{m} - v_\text{A} t_\text{B} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 250\,\text{m} - (3.50\,\text{m/s})\, (70.2\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.3\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 62 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p62">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 62</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The velocity of the wind relative to the water is crucial to sailboats. Suppose a sailboat is in an ocean current that has a velocity of $2.20\,\text{m/s}$ in a direction $30.0^\circ\; \text{east of north}$ relative to the Earth. It encounters a wind that has a velocity of $4.50\,\text{m/s}$ in a direction of $50.0^\circ\;\text{south of west}$ relative to the Earth. What is the velocity of the wind relative to the water?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer62_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram62_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution62_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer62" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$6.68\,\text{m/s},\; 53.3^\circ\,\text{south of west}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram62">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p62s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.62s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution62" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    If ${\bf v}_\text{w}$ is the velocity of the wind relative to the Earth and ${\bf v}_\text{c}$ is the velocity of the ocean current relative to the Earth, the velocity of the wind relative to the current (${\bf v}_\text{wc}$) is given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf v}_\text{wc} = {\bf v}_\text{w} - {\bf v}_\text{c}
                        \label{ch03-p62-vwc}
                        \end{equation}
                    The magnitudes of the given velocities are
                        \begin{equation}
                        v_\text{w} = 4.50\,\text{m/s} \\[6pt]
                        v_\text{c} = 2.20\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{equation}
                    and the directions are as shown in <b>Figure P3.62s</b>. By working at the component level we have
                        \begin{align}
                        v_{\text{wc}x} &= v_{\text{w}x} - v_{\text{c}x} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \big(-v_\text{w}\, \cos 50.0^\circ\big) - \big(v_\text{c}\, \sin 30.0^\circ\big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - (4.50\,\text{m/s})\, \cos 50.0^\circ - (2.20\,\text{m/s})\, \sin 30.0^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -3.99\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        v_{\text{wc}y} &= v_{\text{w}y} - v_{\text{c}y} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \big(-v_\text{w}\, \sin 50.0^\circ\big) - \big(v_\text{c}\, \cos 30.0^\circ\big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - (4.50\,\text{m/s})\, \sin 50.0^\circ - (2.20\,\text{m/s})\, \cos 30.0^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -5.35\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    <p>
                    So, the relative velocity has a magnitude of
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{wc} &= \sqrt{v_{\text{wc}x}^2 + v_{\text{wc}y}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(-3.99\,\text{m/s})^2 + (-5.35\,\text{m/s})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 6.68\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    and dips below the negative $x$-axis (see <b>Figure P3.62s</b>) by an angle
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta &= \tan^{-1}{\left( \frac{5.35}{3.99} \right) } \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 53.3^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    From above, we can express the velocity of the wind relative to the water as
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf v}_\text{wc} = 6.68\,\text{m/s, } 53.3^\circ,\;\text{south of west}
                        \end{equation}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 65 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter03-p65">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 3, Problem 65</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">An athlete crosses a $25\,\text{m}$-wide river by swimming perpendicular to the water current at a speed of $0.5\,\text{m/s}$ relative to the water. He reaches the opposite side at a distance $40\,\text{m}$ downstream from his starting point. How fast is the water in the river flowing with respect to the ground? What is the speed of the swimmer with respect to a friend at rest on the ground?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="answer65_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solutionDiagram65_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role=”button” id="solution65_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer65" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.8\,\text{m/s},\; 0.9\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram65">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch03-p65s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.65s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution65" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>
                    We first set our coordinate system such that the positive $x$ axis is in the direction of the flowing water as shown in <b>Figure P3.65s</b>.
                    The athlete swims across the river performing a displacement in the $y$ direction equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        d_y = 25\,\text{m}
                        \end{equation}
                    Since he swims perpendicular to the water current at a speed $0.5\,\text{m/s}$ relative to the water, then his velocity in the $y$ direction is equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        v_y = 0.5\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{equation}
                   From this information, we can calculate the duration of the swim to be
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= \frac{d_y}{v_y}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{25\,\text{m}}{0.5\,\text{m/s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 50\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    During that same period, the athlete is carried a distance $d_x = 40\,\text{m}$ downstream by the river. Therefore, the water current has a speed relative to the ground equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        v_x &= \frac{d_x}{t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{40\,\text{m}}{50\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.8\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the resultant speed of the swimmer as seen by a friend at rest on the ground is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= \sqrt{v_x^2 + v_y^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(0.8\,\text{m/s})^2 + (0.5\,\text{m/s})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.9\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that the final answer is rounded to one significant figure.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
