              <article>
                <p class="runhead1"><strong>Physics 200</strong> Introductory Physics I</p>

                <p class="unit"> Unit 4 <span>(Chapter 4)</span></p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04" >

                  <!-- to change: the following content -->
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</h1>
                  <hr>

                  <p>In our studies of kinematics, we avoided the question, &ldquo;What causes motion?&rdquo; Why does a body move the way it does?
                  What causes a stationary body to start to move? What causes a moving body to slow down and come to rest?
                  We will begin to look for answers to these questions in this unit, our starting point in the study of dynamics.</p>

                  <p>We owe our insight into this field to the great seventeenth-century scientist, Sir Isaac Newton (1642&ndash;1727).
                  Newton was born in the same year that another great scientist, Galileo, died.
                  In the summer of 1665, the Great (bubonic) Plague was devastating England, and the universities and schools were closed to prevent its spread.
                  Newton, then a 22-year-old student at <a href="http://www.trin.cam.ac.uk/" target="_blank">Trinity College of Cambridge University</a>,
                  returned to his mother&rsquo;s farm in Lincolnshire and spent the next eighteen months studying mathematics, mechanics, and optics.
                  So began one of the most productive periods of achievement by a single individual in the history of science.
                  The period culminated about 22 years later, with the publication of Newton&rsquo;s major work, <em>Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica</em>, in 1687.
                  During this relatively short time, Newton had invented differential and integral calculus, developed a new theory of light,
                  discovered the universal law of gravitation, and put together the ideas of his three laws of motion.</p>

                  <p>These three laws, the subject matter of this unit, over three centuries later, still serve as the basis of dynamics.
                  In the early twentieth century it was discovered that Newtonian mechanics did not precisely explain the motion of atomic and subatomic particles.
                  A new theory, called quantum mechanics was developed to explain the motion and behaviour of such particles.
                  The development of quantum mechanics, however, does not invalidate Newtonian mechanics.
                  For the macroscopic world, where the objects of interest are large compared to the atomic and subatomic objects of the microscopic world,
                  Newton&rsquo;s laws form a very convenient and practical tool for understanding and describing the motion of objects.</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:2.0em;">
                  <div class="learningobjectives">
                    <h3>Learning Objectives</h3>
                    <p>After completing this unit, you should be able to</p>
                    <ul>
                        <li>explain the concept of force.</li>
                        <li>define the concepts of inertia, mass, and weight of a body.</li>
                        <li>define and apply Newton&rsquo;s first law of motion.</li>
                        <li>define and apply Newton&rsquo;s second law of motion.</li>
                        <li>define and apply Newton&rsquo;s third law of motion.</li>
                        <li>distinguish between action and reaction forces.</li>
                        <li>analyze the forces on an object using the free-body diagram technique.</li>
                        <li>calculate the acceleration of a body experiencing multiple external forces.</li>
                    </ul>
                  </div>

                  <!-- end of content -->

                </div> <!-- end of this section -->

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04-force-concept">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>The Force Concept</h2>

                <p>In Newton&rsquo;s description of nature, force plays the crucial role in determining the motion of a body. In an ordinary sense, we think of a force as a push or a pull. That notion works quite well, but as physicists we should be more precise. Newton&rsquo;s three laws of motion allow us to do just that&mdash;they provide a precise mathematical definition (and understanding) of force, the cause of motion. In this unit we will learn the definitions of the three laws, known as Newton&rsquo;s first, second, and third laws of motion. In the following units, we will see applications of these laws in solving problems of dynamics.</p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">Chapter 4</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf#page=3" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">4.1.&nbsp; Development of Force Concept</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04-newton-first-law">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Newton&rsquo;s First Law of Motion</h2>

                <p>From our experience, we know that if we leave a book on a tabletop and it is not disturbed, it will stay there forever.
                Imagine a spaceship moving with constant speed in the vacuum of outer space and distant from any celestial object.
                Can you think of any reason why it would ever slow down and eventually come to a stop? </p>

                <p>Newton probably thought along the same lines while formulating his first law, which can be stated as
                        <blockquote><b>A body at rest will remain at rest until a net external force acts on it. A body moving with a constant velocity along a straight line will maintain the same velocity until a net external force cause it to speed up, slow down, or change the direction of motion.</b></blockquote>
                This implies that in the absence of a net external force, a body will continue in its state of rest or of uniform motion forever.

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit04-vid01.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 4.1</b>: Newton&rsquo;s first law of motion.
                </p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">Chapter 4</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul>
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf#page=4" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">4.2.&nbsp; Newton&rsquo;s First Law of Motion: Inertia</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04-newton-second-law">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Newton&rsquo;s Second Law of Motion</h2>

                <p>As we saw in previous units, in order for a body to move from rest, it must experience
                <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-constant-acceleration" target="_self">acceleration</a>.
                Also, when a moving body is left undisturbed, it will continue with the same
                <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-velocity-speed" target="_self">velocity</a> along a straight line.
                Any change to the magnitude or direction of velocity requires the body to accelerate. By careful observation of related phenomena, we conclude that applied forces are the causes of acceleration.</p>

                <p>We can use common sense to figure out how this causal relationship works. On a given body, a larger force would cause greater acceleration than a smaller force. In particular, if the net force applied on the body is doubled, its acceleration will be doubled, and if the force is tripled the acceleration will be tripled too, and so on. The acceleration ($a$) is then said to be proportional to the applied force ($F$), a description that is represented mathematically as
                \begin{equation}
                a \propto F
                \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>Now consider applying the same force on two bodies, one heavier than the other. Once again, from our common sense and experience, we know that the heavier body would experience less acceleration than the lighter one. Actually, with careful measurements, we will find that if the mass ($m$) is doubled, the acceleration is reduced to one-half and it becomes one third if the mass is tripled, without changing the applied force. Mathematically, this means
                \begin{equation}
                a \propto \frac{1}{m}
                \end{equation}
                The relationship between $a$, $F$ and $m$ can then be written as
                \begin{equation}
                a = \text{constant} \times \frac{F}{m}
                \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>The unit of force is called newton, abbreviated by $\text{N}$. It is defined such that, a force of $1\,\text{N}$ acting on a body of mass $1\,\text{kg}$ produces an acceleration of $1\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$. In this definition, the constant that appears in the equation above becomes equal to $1$. So, after rearrangement, we have
                \begin{equation}
                F = m\, a
                \end{equation}
                This formula is the mathematical form of <em>Newton&rsquo;s second law of motion</em>.
                </p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit04-vid02.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 4.2</b>: Newton&rsquo;s second law of motion.
                </p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">Chapter 4</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf#page=4" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">4.3.&nbsp; Newton&rsquo;s Second Law of Motion: Concept of a System</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04-newton-third-law">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Newton&rsquo;s Third Law of Motion</h2>

                <p>The one of Newton&rsquo;s laws that is most often quoted outside of physics is <em>Newton&rsquo;s third law of motion</em> which can be stated as
                <blockquote><b>To every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.</b></blockquote>
                The statement appears to be quite simple, but do not be fooled! This law requires some thinking every time you want to use it. The point to remember is that the action and reaction forces always act on different bodies&mdash;never on the same one. If you apply a force on the wall, it reacts with an equal and opposite force on you. The action force is experienced by the wall and the reaction force is experienced by you.

                <p>An alternative statement of the third law, to stress the point that action and reaction forces act on different bodies, is as follows:
                <blockquote><b>Whenever an object exerts a force on a second object, the second object exerts an equal and opposite force on the first.</b></blockquote>
                To see this point clearly, let us analyze what goes on when a book is placed on a tabletop, as shown in <a href="#unit04-fig01"><b>Figure 4.1</b></a>. First, there is the force of gravity (or weight $\bf w$), which acts on the book in the downward direction. When placed on the table, the book presses downward with equal force (${\bf F} = {\bf w}$) on the tabletop, which in turn exerts an upward reaction force (called the normal force $\bf N$) on the book. According to Newton&rsquo;s third law, The two forces, $\bf F$ and $\bf N$, form an action-reaction pair and have equal magnitudes (i.e. $F = N$), while the directions are exactly opposite as shown.

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit04-fig01">
                  <p><img src="./unit04-fig01.svg" alt="./unit04-fig01.png"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 4.1</b>: Action and reaction forces on a book at rest on a tabletop.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>Note that $\bf w$ and $\bf N$ do not form an action-reaction pair because they both act on the same body (the book).
                Actually, the book&rsquo;s weight forms an action-reaction pair with a force not shown in the diagram,
                which is the upward force of gravity applied by the book on the Earth! Newton&rsquo;s universal law of gravitation will be covered in
                <a href="../unit06/index06.html" target="_self">Unit 6</a>.</p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit04-vid03.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 4.3</b>: Newton&rsquo;s third law of motion.
                </p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">Chapter 4</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf#page=10" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">4.4.&nbsp; Newton&rsquo;s Third Law of Motion: Symmetry in Forces</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04-normal-force">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Normal Force</h2>

                <p>Consider three identical books placed on a table, as shown in <a href="#unit04-fig02"><b>Figure 4.2</b></a>. The book in the middle does not experience any force external to the book-table system. However, a relatively small upward force (${\bf F}_\text{a}$) is applied on the book placed near the left edge, while the book close to the right edge is pressed down with a force ${\bf F}_\text{a}$. The normal force applied by the table on each book varies as shown in the corresponding free-body diagrams. In each situation, the book is at rest, which means that the net force acting on it is equal to zero. So, the magnitude of the normal force in each case is given by</p>
                        \begin{align}
                        N &= w - F_\text{a}\quad (\text{Book on the left})\\[6pt]
                        N &= w\quad (\text{Book in the middle})\\[6pt]
                        N &= w + F_\text{a}\quad (\text{Book on the right})
                        \end{align}
                <p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit04-fig02">
                  <p><img src="./unit04-fig02.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 4.2</b>: Normal forces on identical books with different applied forces.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>Note that the normal force, in each of the three situations shown in <a href="#unit04-fig02"><b>Figure 4.2</b></a>,
                is equal to the contact force between the table and the book. If the table is replaced by a bathroom scale,
                it would measure the magnitude of the normal force $N$, not the true weight $w = mg$ of the book.
                This is why $N$ is called the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-apparent-weight">apparent weight</a>, in this case.</p>

                <h3>PhET Simulation: Forces in 1 Dimension</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf#page=21" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">textbook</a>,
                &ldquo;explore the forces at work when you try to push a filing cabinet. Create an applied force and see the resulting friction force and total force
                acting on the cabinet. Charts show the forces, position, velocity, and acceleration vs. time. View a free-body diagram of all the forces
                (including gravitational and normal forces).&rdquo;</p>

                <p><div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 197px;">
                <a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/forces-1d/forces-1d_en.jnlp" style="text-decoration: none;">
                <img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/forces-1d/forces-1d-600.png" alt="Forces in 1 Dimension" style="border: none;" width="300" height="197"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);">

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04-apparent-weight">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Apparent Weight</h2>

                <p>Normally, the weight of a person standing on a bathroom scale is as indicated by its reading. However, this is not always true! There are special circumstances when a properly functioning scale overestimates or underestimates one&rsquo;s weigh. This is because the scale actually measures the contact (normal) force with the person&rsquo;s feet, which could be different from the actual weight.</p>

                <p>Consider a person who stands on a bathroom scale inside an elevator, which is either at rest or moves at a constant speed (i.e. $a = 0$).
                The person experiences two forces in this case (see <a href="#unit04-fig03"><b>Figure 4.3</b></a>),
                the downward weight ($\bf w$) and the upward normal force ($\bf N$). Since the system does not accelerate,
                the net force on the person must be equal to zero. By applying <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law</a>, we can write
                \begin{align}
                N - w &= F_\text{net} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                \Rightarrow\quad N &= w
                \end{align}
                 So in this case, the bathroom scale measures the person&rsquo;s true weight ($w = mg$).
                </p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit04-fig03">
                  <p><img src="./unit04-fig03.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 4.3</b>: Apparent weight of a person standing on a bathroom scale inside a moving elevator.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>During the acceleration phase of the elevator&rsquo;s motion (i.e. $a \neq 0$), the person experiences a net vertical force and we can write
                \begin{align}
                N - w &= F_\text{net} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                &= m a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                \Rightarrow\quad N &= w + m a
                \label{ch04_Nwma}
                \end{align}
                As mentioned earlier, the bathroom scale is sensitive to the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-normal-force">normal force</a> $N$, which can be referred to as the apparent weight.
                From Equation \ref{ch04_Nwma}, we see that the apparent weight is greater than the true weight when the acceleration is directed upward
                ($a \gt 0$). This is why a person feels heavier near the lower floor, at the beginning of an upward trip or near the end of a downward trip.
                On the other hand, when the acceleration is directed downward ($a \lt 0$)
                near the upper floor, a person riding the elevator will feel to have momentarily lost some weight.</p>

                <p>For the special case when the elevator falls downward with the acceleration due to gravity ($a = -g$), we have
                \begin{align}
                N &= w + m a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                &= (m g) + m (-g) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                &= 0
                \end{align}
                So, a person riding the elevator in this situation feels weightless! This is actually how zero gravity is simulated on Earth. In what is popularly know as the &ldquo;vomit comet,&rdquo; astronaut trainees ride a special aircraft designed to fall down in a regulated manner for brief periods of time.
                </p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">Chapter 4</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf#page=23" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">4.7.&nbsp; Further Applications of Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04-examples">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Examples</h2>

                    <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of examples relevant to the content of <span style="white-space: nowrap;">Unit 4</span>. Make an attempt to answer each question on your own, before you read through the solution provided.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04-e01">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 4, Example 1</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A box of mass $m_1$ accelerates at $2.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ when a force $F$ is applied on it.
                When an equal force is applied on a second box of mass $m_2$, it accelerates at $0.500\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$.
                (a) Determine the mass ratio $m_2/m_1$. (b) If the smaller box is placed inside the larger box,
                and the same force $F$ is applied, what is the acceleration of the combined object?</div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e01_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01a_btn">Solution (a) </button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01b_btn">Solution (b) </button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $4.00$</p>
                      <p>(b) $0.400\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>From <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law</a>, we can describe the relation between applied force and acceleration for each box by the equations
                        \begin{equation}
                        F =  m_1 \left(2.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\right)
                        \label{unit04_e01_Fm1a}
                        \end{equation}
                and
                        \begin{equation}
                        F =  m_2 \left(0.500\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\right)
                        \label{unit04_e01_Fm2a}
                        \end{equation}
                where $F$ is the magnitude of the applied force. By equating Equations \ref{unit04_e01_Fm1a} and \ref{unit04_e01_Fm2a}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        m_1 \left(2.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\right) &= m_2 \left(0.500\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\right)  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \frac{m_2}{m_1} &= 4.00
                        \label{unit04_e01_m1m2}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>When the same force $F$ is applied on the combined object, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        F &=  (m_1 + m_2)\, a  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  \left(1 + \frac{m_2}{m_1}\right) m_1\, a  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  (1 + 4.00)\, m_1\, a  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  (5.00)\, m_1\, a
                        \end{align}
                and the resulting acceleration is
                        \begin{align}
                        a &= \frac{1}{5.00} \left(\frac{F}{m_1}\right)  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1}{5.00}\, (2.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.400\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                Note that the ratio $F/m_1$ is equal to the acceleration of the first box, as seen from Equation \ref{unit04_e01_Fm1a}.
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04-e02">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 4, Example 2</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A block of mass $6.00\,\text{kg}$ is placed on a smooth tabletop. A hanging bag, of mass $2.00\,\text{kg}$, is connected to the block by a cord passing over a massless and frictionless pulley, as shown in <b>Figure E4.2</b>. Determine, (a) the acceleration of the system, and (b) the tension in the cord.
                <hr>
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit04-e02.svg" alt="image"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure E4.2</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e02_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e02_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02a_btn">Solution (a) </button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02b_btn">Solution (b) </button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $2.45\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                      <p>(b) $14.7\,\text{N}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit04-e02s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E4.2s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>From <b>Figure E4.2s</b>, we see that the block experience a single horizontal force ($T$) due to the tension in the cord.
                        So, from <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law</a> of motion, we can write
                                \begin{equation}
                                T =  m_\text{block}\, a
                                \label{unit04_e02_block}
                                \end{equation}
                        where $a$ is the acceleration of the system. The bag, however, experiences two vertical forces: the tension ($T$) in the upward direction and the weight ($w = m_\text{bag}\, g$) in the downward direction. So, the net vertical force ($w - T$) causes the bag to accelerate downwards, such that
                                \begin{equation}
                                w - T =  m_\text{bag}\, a
                                \label{unit04_e02_bag}
                                \end{equation}
                        By adding Equations \ref{unit04_e02_block} and \ref{unit04_e02_bag}, we have
                                \begin{align}
                                w &= m_\text{block}\, a + m_\text{bag}\, a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                \Rightarrow\quad m_\text{bag}\, g &= (m_\text{block} + m_\text{bag})\, a
                                \end{align}
                        We can now calculate the acceleration of the system as follows
                                \begin{align}
                                a &= \left(\frac{m_\text{bag}}{m_\text{block} + m_\text{bag}}\right) g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \left(\frac{2.00\,\text{kg}}{6.00\,\text{kg} + 2.00\,\text{kg}}\right) \times (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 2.45\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \label{unit04_e02_a}
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>By substituting the calculated acceleration (Equation \ref{unit04_e02_a}) into Equation \ref{unit04_e02_block}, we find the tension in the cord to be
                                \begin{align}
                                T &=  m_\text{block}\, a  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &=  (6.00\,\text{kg})\, (2.45\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &=  14.7\,\text{N}
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit04-e03">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 4, Example 3</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A passenger tows her $16.0\,\text{kg}$ suitcase and walks at a constant speed in an airport terminal.
                She pulls on the strap with a force of $33.0\,\text{N}$ against a horizontal frictional force of $18.0\,\text{N}$.
                (a) Draw a free-body diagram, which shows all the forces on the suitcase.
                (b) At what angle ($\theta$) above the horizontal does the strap extend?
                (c) Calculate the upward normal force on the suitcase.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e03_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e03_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03a_btn">Solution (a) </button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03b_btn">Solution (b) </button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03c_btn">Solution (c) </button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="interactive-e03_btn">Interactive Activity</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(b) $56.9^\circ$</p>
                      <p>(c) $129\,\text{N}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit04-e03s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E4.3s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>See the free-body diagram in <b>Figure E4.3s</b>.
                        </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the passenger walks at a constant speed (with no acceleration), the net horizontal force on the suitcase is equal to zero.
                    So, from <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law</a>, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        T\,\cos{\theta} - f &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \cos\theta & = \frac{f}{T}
                        \end{align}
                    where $T = 33.0\,\text{N}$ is the tension in the strap and $f = 18.0\,\text{N}$ is the force of friction resisting the motion of the suitcase.
                    So, the angle that the extended strap makes with the horizontal is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta &= \cos^{-1} \left(\frac{f}{T}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \cos^{-1} \left(\frac{18.0\,\text{N}}{33.0\,\text{N}}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 56.9^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03c">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the suitcase does not move vertically, the net force in this direction is also equal to zero. So, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        T\,\sin\theta + N - m g = 0
                        \end{equation}
                    where $m$ is the mass of the suitcase. The magnitude of the upward normal force exerted on the suitcase by the ground is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        N &= m g - T\sin\theta  \nonumber\\[3pt]
                        &= (16.0\,\text{kg})\,(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) - (33.0\,\text{N})\,\sin 56.9^\circ  \nonumber\\[3pt]
                        &= 129\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="interactive-e03">
                <div class="panel-heading">Interactive Activity</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p class="centerText"><a href="./unit04-e03i.cdf"><img  src="unit04-e03i.png" alt="unit04-e03i.png"></a><br>
                    <br><b>Figure E4.3i</b></p>
                </div>

                    <p>Use <a href="https://www.wolfram.com/cdf-player/" target="_blank">Wolfram CDF Player</a>
                    to open the interactive diagram <a href="./unit04-e03i.cdf"><b>Figure E4.3i</b></a>.</p>

                    <p>Answer the questions below and use the interactive diagram to check your calculations.</p>

                        <p>
                        <ol>
                        <li>If the passenger pulls on the strap at a lower angle with the horizontal,
                        would she require apply smaller or greater force to maintain a constant speed?</li>
                        <li>Determine the applied force ($T$) and the normal force ($N$) when the strap make an angle of
                        $\theta = 45.0^\circ$ above the horizontal. Assume the force of friction is independent of the normal force.</li>
                        <li>Repeat the calculation for $\theta = 70.0^\circ$ above the horizontal.</li>
                      </ol>

                    </div>
                </div>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-conceptual-questions">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Conceptual Questions</h2>

                  <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of conceptual questions selected from the end of <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf#page=36" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">Chapter 4</a></span> in the textbook.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 5 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-q05">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Question 5</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Which statement is correct? (a) Net force causes motion. (b) Net force causes change in motion.
                    Explain your answer and give an example.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q05_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q05_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Statement (b)</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                        According to <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law</a>, when an object experiences
                        a net force ${\bf F}_\text{net}$ it experiences acceleration equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf a} = \frac{{\bf F}_\text{net}}{m}
                        \end{equation}
                        So, if there is net force, there is acceleration, and if there is no net force, there is no acceleration.
                        Since, <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-constant-acceleration" target="_self">acceleration</a> causes change in velocity, then a net force causes change in motion. An object can continue to move at constant velocity in the absence of a net external force.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                        Think of a skater on smooth ice. While gliding, there is no net force, yet there is still motion. When the skater sets to skate, she applies a force to the ice and accelerates forwards, thus there is a change in motion caused by a net force.
                      </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 8 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-q08">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Question 8</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Describe a situation in which the net external force on a system is not zero, yet its speed remains constant.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q08_btn">Answer</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q08">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Consider a satellite in orbit around the Earth. While a gravitational force is exerted on the satellite, its speed remains constant. Note, however, that the velocity is not constant, because the direction of motion continuously changes.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 10 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-q10">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Question 10</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A rock is thrown straight up. What is the net external force acting on the rock when it is at the top of its trajectory?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q10_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q10_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Downward force of gravity ($-mg$).</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>When the rock reaches the top of its trajectory, it momentarily stops. During this brief period there is zero drag force because there is no motion. This means that the only external force on the rock is due to gravity, which causes the rock to accelerate downwards.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 15 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-q15">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Question 15</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">When you take off in a jet aircraft, there is a sensation of being pushed back into the seat. Explain why you move backward in the seat&mdash;is there really a force backward on you? (The same reasoning explains whiplash injuries, in which the head is apparently thrown backward.)
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q15_btn">Answer</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q15">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>On takeoff, the engine of the jet aircraft generates thrust, which accelerates the aircraft forward. This of course causes the seat to accelerate forward too. As a result, the seat exerts a force on your back, which in turn exerts an equal reaction force (directed backwards) on the seat. So the sensation of being pushed back into the seat is due to the increased contact force between your back and the seat.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                </div>
