                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-problems">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Dynamics: Force and Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Solutions of Selected Problems</h2>
                    <p>Next are detailed solutions to a number of problems selected from the end of
                    <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-4.pdf#page=38" title="Chapter 4" target="_blank">Chapter 4</a></span> in the textbook. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve each problem independently, before you read through the solution provided. You are also advised to make a second attempt to solve the problem if your answer is different from the one posted. If you reach an impasse and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p03">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 3</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A cleaner pushes a $4.50\,\text{kg}$ laundry cart in such a way that the net external force on it is $60.0\,\text{N}$. Calculate its acceleration.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer03_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution03_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer03" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$13.3\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution03" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Here, the laundry cart has a mass of $m = 4.50\,\text{kg}$, and experiences a net external force of $F_\text{net} = 60.0\,\text{N}$.
                    By applying <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law</a>, we calculate the acceleration of the laundry cart to be
                        \begin{align}
                        a &= \frac{F_\text{net}}{m}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{60.0\,\text{N}}{4.50\,\text{kg}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 13.3\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p04">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 4</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Since astronauts in orbit are apparently weightless, a clever method of measuring their masses is needed to monitor their mass gains or losses to adjust diets. One way to do this is to exert a known force on an astronaut and measure the acceleration produced. Suppose a net external force of $50.0\,\text{N}$ is exerted and the astronaut&rsquo;s acceleration is measured to be $0.893\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$. (a) Calculate her mass. (b) By exerting a force on the astronaut, the vehicle in which they orbit experiences an equal and opposite force. Discuss how this would affect the measurement of the astronaut&rsquo;s acceleration. Propose a method in which recoil of the vehicle is avoided.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer04_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution04a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution04b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $56.0\,\text{kg}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution04a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>There is a net external force of $F_\text{net} = 50.0\,\text{N}$ exerted on the astronaut, resulting in an acceleration of $a = 0.893\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$. By applying Newton&rsquo;s second law, we can calculate her mass to be
                        \begin{align}
                        m &= \frac{F_\text{net}}{a} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{50.0\,\text{N}}{0.893\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 56.0\,\text{kg}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution04b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If an internal force from within the spaceship system is exerted on the astronaut, then the vehicle must experience an equal
                    force of $50.0\,\text{N}$ in the opposite direction, according to <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-newton-third-law">Newton&rsquo;s third law</a>.
                    As a result, the vehicle also experiences an acceleration ($a_\text{v}$) in the opposite direction of the astronaut. The magnitude of this acceleration is determined as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        a_\text{v}\, m_\text{v} &= m\, a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad a_\text{v} &= \left(\frac{m}{m_\text{v}}\right) a
                        \end{align}
                      where ($m/m_\text{v}$) is the astronaut and vehicle mass ratio, which should be relatively small.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                    Since the astronaut&rsquo;s acceleration is measured relative to the vehicle, then such measurement overestimates the value of $a$, compared to that of an external observer. This can be avoided by firing thrusters in the opposite direction of the recoil. Alternatively, if the mass of the vehicle is known, then its acceleration can be calculated and accounted for.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                    </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 10 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p10">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 10</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A powerful motorcycle can produce an acceleration of $3.50\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ while traveling at $90.0\,\text{km/h}$. At that speed the forces resisting motion, including friction and air resistance, total $400\,\text{N}$. (Air resistance is analogous to air friction. It always opposes the motion of an object.) What force does the motorcycle exert backward on the ground to produce its acceleration if the mass of the motorcycle with rider is $245\,\text{kg}$?</div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer10_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution10_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$1{,}258\,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>
                      Since we are given the total mass ($m = 245\,\text{kg}$) of the motorcycle-rider system and also its acceleration
                      ($a = 3.50 \,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$), we can calculate the net force on the system to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{net} &= m a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \big(245\,\text{kg}\big)\, \big(3.50\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 858\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                      <p>If the motorcycle exerts a backward force ($F_\text{mortorcycle}$) on the ground, then according to
                      <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-newton-third-law">Newton&rsquo;s third law</a>, the ground exerts an equal force on the motorcycle in the forward direction. Since it also experiences air resistance of $F_\text{air} = 400\,\text{N}$ in the backward direction, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{net} = F_\text{motorcycle} - F_\text{air}
                        \end{equation}
                      So, the force exerted by the motorcycle on the ground is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{motorcycle} &= F_\text{net} + F_\text{air} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 858\,\text{N} + 400\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1{,}258\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 14 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p14">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 14</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose the mass of a fully loaded module in which astronauts take off from the Moon is $10{,}000\,\text{kg}$. The thrust of its engines is $30{,}000\,\text{N}$. (a) Calculate its acceleration in a vertical takeoff from the Moon. (b) Could it lift off from Earth? If not, why not? If it could, calculate its acceleration.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer14_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution14a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution14b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer14">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1.33\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ </p>
                      <p>(b) No. </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>During takeoff, the module experiences a downward force due to its weight ($w_\text{moon}$) and an upward thrust force ($F_\text{thrust} = 30{,}000\,\text{N}$) produced by the engines. Since the acceleration due to gravity near the Moon&rsquo;s surface is
                        \begin{equation}
                        g_\text{moon} = 1.67\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{equation}
                    the downward force of gravity opposing the upward thrust is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        w_\text{moon} &= m\, g_\text{moon} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \big(10,000\,\text{kg}\big) \big(1.67\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 16{,}700 \,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    <p>The net force on the module in this situation is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{net} &= F_\text{thrust} - w_\text{moon} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 30{,}000\,\text{N} - 16{,}700 \,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 13{,}300 \,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      which corresponds to an upward acceleration of
                        \begin{align}
                        a &= \frac{F_\text{net}}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{13{,}300 \,\text{N}}{10{,}000\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.33\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The same engines will not be able to left the module above the Earth&rsquo;s surface. This is because the thrust force is less than the module&rsquo;s weight on Earth,
                        \begin{align}
                        w &= m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \big(10{,}000\,\text{kg}\big) \big(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 98{,}000\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 16 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p16">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 16</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A brave but inadequate rugby player is being pushed backward by an opposing player who is exerting a force of $800\,\text{N}$ on him. The mass of the losing player plus equipment is $90.0\,\text{kg}$, and he is accelerating at $1.20\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ backward. (a) What is the force of friction between the losing player&rsquo;s feet and the grass? (b) What force does the winning player exert on the ground to move forward if his mass plus equipment is $110\,\text{kg}$? (c) Draw a sketch of the situation showing the system of interest used to solve each part. For this situation, draw a free-body diagram and write the net force equation.</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer16_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram16_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution16a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution16b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution16c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer16">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $692\,\text{N}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $932\,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram16">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p16s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P4.16s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution16a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Let us use $\text{A}$ to label the winning rugby player, and $\text{B}$ for the losing player. Since we know the mass ($m_\text{B} = 90.0\,\text{kg}$) and acceleration ($a = 1.20\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$) of the losing player, we can calculate the net force on him to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{Bnet} &= m_\text{B}\, a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (90.0\,\text{kg})\, (1.20\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 108\, \text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      As player $\text{B}$ is pushed back with a force ($F = 800\,\text{N}$), his feet drag along the grass producing a force of friction ($f$) in the opposite direction. The difference between these two forces is equal to the net force on the losing player. So, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{Bnet} = F - f
                        \end{equation}
                      By solving for $f$, we calculate the force of friction to be
                        \begin{align}
                        f &= F - F_\text{Bnet} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 800\,\text{N} - 108\, \text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 692\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution16b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Note that the winning player, of mass $m_\text{A} = 110\,\text{kg}$, moves with his opponent at the same acceleration. This allows us to calculate a net force on player $\text{A}$ to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{Anet} &= m_\text{A}\, a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (110\,\text{kg})\, (1.20\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 132\, \text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      Note that the net force on the winning player is the sum of two reaction forces. As he exerts a force $F_\text{ground}$ on the ground, it reacts by exerting an equal (but opposite) force on his feet. Also, as the winning player pushes his opponent with a force $F$, an equal reaction force is also exerted on player $\text{A}$, as shown in <b>Figure P4.16s</b>. So, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{Anet} = F_\text{ground} - F
                        \end{equation}
                      The force the winning player exerts on the ground is, therefore, equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{ground} &= F_\text{Anet} + F \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 132\,\text{N} + 800\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 932\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution16c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>See Solution Diagram (<b>Figure P4.16s</b>).</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 20 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p20">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 20</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose a $60.0\,\text{kg}$ gymnast climbs a rope. (a) What is the tension in the rope if he climbs at a constant speed? (b) What is the tension in the rope if he accelerates upward at a rate of $1.50\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$?</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer20_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram20_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer20" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $588\,\text{N}$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $678\,\text{N}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p20s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P4.20s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>When a climber pulls down on a rope, it reacts by exerting an equal force on the climber in the upward direction, as shown in <b>Figure P4.20s</b>. The force is also equal to the tension created in the rope. If the gymnast climbs the rope at a constant speed (i.e. zero acceleration), then the net force ($F_\text{net}$) on the gymnast must also be equal to zero. This means that the upward force ($T$) exerted on the gymnast by the rope, must be equal to his weight ($w$) and we write
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{net} = T - w = 0
                        \end{equation}
                    So, the tension in the rope is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        T &= w \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (60.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 588\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If he accelerates upwards at a rate of $ a = 1.50\,\text{m}/{\text{s}^2}$, the net force on the gymnast must be
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{net} &= m\, a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (60.0\,\text{kg})\, (1.50\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 90.0\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    Since
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{net} = T - w
                        \end{equation}
                    the tension in the rope is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        T &= F_\text{net} + w \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 90.0\,\text{N} + 588\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 678\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 22 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p22">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 22</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Consider the baby being weighed in <b>Figure P4.22</b>. (a) What is the mass of the child and basket if a scale reading of $55\,\text{N}$ is observed? (b) What is the tension $T_1$ in the cord attaching the baby to the scale? (c) What is the tension $T_2$ in the cord attaching the scale to the ceiling, if the scale has a mass of $0.500\,\text{kg}$? (d) Draw a sketch of the situation indicating the system of interest used to solve each part. The masses of the cords are negligible.
                    <hr>
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p22.svg" alt="image"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure P4.22</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer22_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram22_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution22a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution22b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution22c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution22d_btn">Solution (d)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer22">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $5.6\,\text{kg}$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $55\,\text{N}$ </p>
                      <p>(c) $60\,\text{N}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram22">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p22s.svg" alt="./ch04-p22s.png"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure P4.22s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution22a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The scale should be calibrated to measure the weight of the hanging object. Since the cords are considered massless, the weight of the baby and basket is equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        w_\text{b}  = 55\,\text{N}
                        \end{equation}
                    which corresponds to a mass of
                        \begin{align}
                        m_\text{b} &= \frac{w_\text{b} }{g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{55\,\text{N}}{9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.6\,\text{kg}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                 <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution22b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>In the absence of any acceleration in the system, the net force on the baby must be equal to zero. So, from the free-body diagram in <b>Figure P4.22s</b>, the tension ($T_1$) in the lower cord must be equal to the weight of the baby. So, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        T_1 &= w_\text{b} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 55\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution22c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>As shown in <strong>Figure P4.22s</strong>, the scale experiences three forces: its weight ($w_\text{s}$), the tension ($T_1$) in the lower string, and the tension ($T_2$) in the upper string. Since the net force on the stationary scale is equal to zero, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        T_2 - T_1 - w_\text{s} = 0
                        \end{equation}
                    So, the tension in the upper cord, attaching the scale to the ceiling, is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        T_2 &=T_1 + w_\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 55\,\text{N} + (0.500\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 60\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution22d">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>See Solution Diagram (<b>Figure P4.22s</b>).</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 24 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p24">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 24</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The wheels of a midsize car exert a force of $2{,}100\,\text{N}$ backward on the road to accelerate the car in the forward direction. If the force of friction including air resistance is $250\,\text{N}$ and the acceleration of the car is $1.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ , what is the mass of the car plus its occupants? Explicitly show how you follow the steps in the Problem-Solving Strategy for Newton&rsquo;s laws of motion. For this situation, draw a free-body diagram and write the net force equation.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer24_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram24_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer24">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$1,030\,\text{kg}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram24">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p24s.svg" alt="./ch04-p24s.png"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure P4.24s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">

                    <p>We start by drawing a free-body diagram as shown in <b>Figure P4.24s</b>, where the positive $x$ axis is in the direction of motion and the positive $y$ axis is in the upward direction perpendicular to the road&rsquo;s surface. In the diagram, we include the force exerted onto the wheel by the road ${\bf F}_\text{road}$, the force of friction $\bf f$, the weight $\bf w$, and the normal force $\bf N$, as these are the external forces experienced by the car.</p>

                    <p>The next step is to apply Newton&rsquo;s second law in each direction. Since there is no acceleration perpendicular to the road&rsquo;s surface
                    ($a_y = 0$), the net vertical force on the car (of mass $m$) is equal to zero, or
                        \begin{align}
                        F_{\text{net}\,y} &= m\, a_y \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0
                        \end{align}
                    Also, from the free-body diagram we see that
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_{\text{net}\,y} =  N - w
                        \end{equation}
                    So, we conclude that the magnitude of <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-normal-force"> normal force</a> is equal to the car&rsquo;s weight, or
                    \begin{equation}
                    N = w
                    \end{equation}
                    </p>

                    <p>Since we are given the car&rsquo;s acceleration parallel to the road&rsquo;s surface ($a_x = 1.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$), we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_{\text{net}\,x} = m\, a_x
                        \end{equation}
                    However, the net horizontal force can be calculated from the known forces in that direction (see the free-body diagram) such that
                        \begin{align}
                        F_{\text{net}\,x} &= F_\text{road} - f \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2{,}100\,\text{N} - 250\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1{,}850\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the mass of the car plus its occupants is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        m &= \frac{F_{\text{net}\,x}}{a_x} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1{,}850\,\text{N}}{1.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1{,}030\,\text{kg}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>It is always a good idea to check if our answer makes sense. We calculated a mass that is roughly $1000\,\text{kg}$, which is about what we can expect for a midsized car. Had our answer been something like $100\,\text{kg}$ or $8000\,\text{kg}$, then we could say that the answer was not reasonable.</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 30 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p30">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 30</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) Find the magnitudes of the forces ${\bf F}_1$ and ${\bf F}_2$ that add to give the total force ${\bf F}_\text{tot}$ shown in <b>Figure P4.30</b>. This may be done either graphically or by using trigonometry. (b) Show graphically that the same total force is obtained independent of the order of addition of ${\bf F}_1$ and ${\bf F}_2$. (c) Find the direction and magnitude of some other pair of vectors that add to give ${\bf F}_\text{tot}$. Draw these to scale on the same drawing used in part (b) or a similar picture.
                    <hr>
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p30.svg" alt="./ch04-p30.png"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure P4.30</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer30_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram30_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution30a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution30b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution30c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $16\,\text{N},\; 11\,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p30s.svg" alt="./ch04-p30s.png"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P4.30s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>From the vector diagram in <b>Figure P4.30</b> it is obvious that
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf F}_\text{tot} = {\bf F}_1 + {\bf F}_2
                        \end{equation}
                    We can set the coordinate system such that the ${\bf F}_1$ force acts in the positive $x$ direction and the ${\bf F}_2$ force acts in the positive $y$ direction. In this case, ${\bf F}_1$ and ${\bf F}_2$ are actually the $x$ and $y$ components, respectively, of the total force ${\bf F}_\text{tot}$, which is directed at an angle $\theta = 35^\circ$ above the positive $x$ axis. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        F_1 &= F_{\text{tot}\,x} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= F_\text{tot} \cos{\theta} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (20\,\text{N}) \cos{35^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 16\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        F_2 &= F_{\text{tot}\,y} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= F_\text{tot} \sin{\theta} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (20\,\text{N}) \sin{35^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 11\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>See Solution Diagram (<b>Figure P4.30s</b>).</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Now we are looking for two new force vectors, ${\bf F}_a$ and ${\bf F}_b$, where
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf F}_\text{tot} = {\bf F}_a + {\bf F}_b
                        \label{ch04_p30_vectot}
                        \end{equation}
                    We can arbitrarily choose ${\bf F}_a$ such that it has a magnitude of $12\,\text{N}$ and a direction of $23^\circ$ bellow the positive $x$ axis, as shown in <b>Figure P4.30s</b>.
                    </p>
                    <p>From Equation \ref{ch04_p30_vectot}, we see that ${\bf F}_b$ must be equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf F}_b = {\bf F}_\text{tot} - {\bf F}_a
                        \end{equation}
                    This allows us to calculate the $x$ and $y$ components of ${\bf F}_b$ as follows,
                        \begin{align}
                        F_{bx} &= F_{\text{tot}\,x} - F_{ax}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  (20\,\text{N}\times \cos{35^\circ}) - (12\,\text{N}\times \cos{23^\circ}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.3\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        F_{by} &= F_{\text{tot}\,y} - F_{ay}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  (20\,\text{N}\times \sin{35^\circ}) - (-12\,\text{N}\times \sin{23^\circ}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  (20\,\text{N}\times \sin{35^\circ}) + (12\,\text{N}\times \sin{23^\circ}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 16.2\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    From above, we see that the ${\bf F}_b$ force then has a magnitude of
                        \begin{align}
                        F_b &= \sqrt{F_{bx}^2 + F_{by}^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(5.3\,\text{N})^2 + (16.2\,\text{N})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 17\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    and a direction that makes an angle of
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta_b &= \tan^{-1}{\left( \frac{F_{by}}{F_{bx}} \right)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tan^{-1}{\left( \frac{16.2\,\text{N}}{5.3\,\text{N}} \right)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 72^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    above the positive $x$ axis, as shown in <b>Figure P4.30s</b>
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 32 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p32">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 32</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose your car was mired deeply in the mud and you wanted to use the method illustrated in <b>Figure P4.32</b> to pull it out. (a) What force would you have to exert perpendicular to the center of the rope to produce a force of $12{,}000\,\text{N}$ on the car if the angle is $2.00^\circ$? In this part, explicitly show how you follow the steps in the Problem-Solving Strategy for Newton&rsquo;s laws of motion. (b) Real ropes stretch under such forces. What force would be exerted on the car if the angle increases to $7.00^\circ$ and you still apply the force found in part (a) to its center?
                    <hr>
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p32.svg" alt="image"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure P4.32</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer32_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram32_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution32a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution32b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer32">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $838\,\text{N}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $3{,}440\,\text{N}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram32">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p32s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P2.32s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution32a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>We begin by drawing a free-body diagram for the middle section of the rope, as shown in <b>Figure P4.32s</b>, where
                        \begin{align}
                        T &= 12{,}000\, \text{N} \\[6pt]
                        \theta &= 2.00^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    Since the net force on this piece of the rope is equal to zero, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        T \sin{\theta} + T \sin{\theta} - F_\bot &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 2\, T \sin{\theta} - F_\bot &= 0
                        \label{ch04_p32_TTF}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the magnitude of the applied force is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\bot &= 2\, T \sin{\theta} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2\, (12{,}000\,\text{N})\, \sin{2.00^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 838\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    To see if this answer is reasonable, let&rsquo;s compare it to the weight of a person. The average weight of an adult person is approximately $(80\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) = 784\,\text{N}$, which is comparable to the force needed to pull the car.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution32b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Here, we are looking for the tension ($T$) in the rope when $\theta = 7.00^\circ$, and while still applying a perpendicular force of $F_\bot = 838\,\text{N}$. By referring back to Equation \ref{ch04_p32_TTF}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        T &= \frac{F_\bot}{2\, \sin{\theta}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{838\,\text{N}}{2\, \sin{7.00^\circ}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3{,}440\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                        This is far less than the $12{,}000\,\text{N}$ produced for the smaller angle (of $2.00^\circ$).
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 35 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p35">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 35</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A nurse pushes a cart by exerting a force on the handle at a downward angle $35.0^\circ$ below the horizontal. The loaded cart has a mass of $28.0\,\text{kg}$, and the force of friction is $60.0\,\text{N}$. (a) Draw a free-body diagram for the system of interest. (b) What force must the nurse exert to move at a constant velocity?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer35_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram35_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution35a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution35b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer35">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(b) $73.2\,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram35">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p35s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P4.35s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution35a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>See Solution Diagram (<b>Figure P4.35s</b>).</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution35b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>When it moves at a constant velocity (i.e., no acceleration) the net force on the cart must be equal to zero. This means all the forces shown in the free-body diagram cancel out in the horizontal and in the vertical directions. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        F_{\text{net}\, x} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_{\text{nurse}\, x} - f &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_\text{nurse}\, \cos\theta - f &= 0
                        \label{ch04_p35_Fnetx}
                        \end{align}
                        where $f = 60.0\,\text{N}$ is the magnitude of the force of friction, and $\theta = 35.0^\circ$ is the angle below the horizontal at which the nurse pushes the cart. So, by substituting into Equation \ref{ch04_p35_Fnetx} we calculate the magnitude of the applied force to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{nurse} &= \frac{f}{\cos{\theta}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{60.0\,\text{N}}{\cos{35.0^\circ}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 73.2\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 42 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p42">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 42</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $76.0\,\text{kg}$ person is being pulled away from a burning building as shown in <b>Figure P4.42</b>. Calculate the tension in the two ropes if the person is momentarily motionless. Include a free-body diagram in your solution.
                    <hr>
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p42.svg" alt="image"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure P4.42</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer42_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram42_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution42_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer42" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$736\,\text{N},\; 194\,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram42">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch04-p42s.svg" alt="./ch04-p42s.png"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P3.42s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution42" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>We begin by drawing a free-body diagram as shown in <b>Figure P3.42s</b>. From the diagram, we see that the person experiences a downward force due to her weight ($\bf w$) and the two forces provided by the tension in the supporting rope. Since ${\bf T}_1$ is directed at an angle of $15^\circ$ with the vertical and ${\bf T}_2$ is applied at an angle of $10^\circ$ above the horizontal, we can express the corresponding $x$ and $y$ components as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        T_{1x} &= - T_1\, \sin{15^\circ} \\[6pt]
                        T_{1y} &= T_1\, \cos{15^\circ} \\[6pt]
                        T_{2x} &= T_2\, \cos{10^\circ} \\[6pt]
                        T_{2y} &= T_2\, \sin{10^\circ} \\[6pt]
                        \end{align}

                      <p>While the person is momentarily stationary (i.e. no motion and no acceleration), she experiences a zero net force in both the $x$ or the $y$ directions. By referring to the free-body diagram, we can then write
                        \begin{align}
                        F_{\text{net}\,x} &= T_{1x} + T_{2x} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - T_1\, \sin{15^\circ} + T_2\, \cos{10^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow &\quad T_2 = \left(\frac{\sin{15^\circ}}{\cos{10^\circ}}\right) T_1
                        \label{ch04_p42_Fnetx}
                        \end{align}
                      Similarly, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        F_{\text{net}\,y} &= T_{1y} + T_{2y} - w \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= T_1\, \cos{15^\circ} + T_2\, \sin{10^\circ} - w \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow &\quad T_1\, \cos{15^\circ} + T_2\, \sin{10^\circ} = m g
                        \label{ch04_p42_Fnety}
                        \end{align}
                      where $m = 76.0\,\text{kg}$ is the mass of the person being rescued. If we now substitute from Equation \ref{ch04_p42_Fnetx} into equation \ref{ch04_p42_Fnety}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        T_1\, \cos{15^\circ} + \left(\frac{\sin{15^\circ}}{\cos{10^\circ}}\right) T_1\, \sin{10^\circ} &= m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad T_1 \left( \cos{15^\circ} + \sin{15^\circ}\times \tan{10^\circ} \right) &= m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \end{align}
                      So, the tension in the section of the rope attached to the wall is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        T_1 &= \frac{m g}{\cos{15^\circ} + (\sin{15^\circ}\times \tan{10^\circ})} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(76.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)}{\cos{15^\circ} + (\sin{15^\circ}\times \tan{10^\circ})} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 736\,\text{N}
                        \label{ch04_p42_T1}
                        \end{align}
                      By substituting from Equation \ref{ch04_p42_T1} into equation \ref{ch04_p42_Fnetx}, we find the tension in the section of the rope held by the firefighter to be
                        \begin{align}
                        T_2 &= \left(\frac{\sin{15^\circ}}{\cos{10^\circ}}\right) \times 736\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 194\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 44 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter04-p44">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 4, Problem 44</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">When starting a foot race, a $70.0\,\text{kg}$ sprinter exerts an average force of $650\,\text{N}$ backward on the ground for $0.800\,\text{s}$. (a) What is his final speed? (b) How far does he travel?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer44_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution44a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution44b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer44" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $7.43\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $2.97\,\text{m}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution44a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Here, we know that the sprinter (of mass $m = 70.0\,\text{kg}$) pushes the ground backward with a force $F = 650\,\text{N}$.
                    According to <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit04-newton-third-law">Newton&rsquo;s third law</a>, the ground simultaneously exerts an equal force
                    on the sprinter in the forward direction. As a result, he experiences a forward acceleration of magnitude
                        \begin{align}
                        a &= \frac{F}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{650\,\text{N}}{70.0\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9.29\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>Since the sprinter starts from rest ($v_0 = 0$), and accelerates for a duration of $t = 0.800\,\text{s}$, his final speed, $v$ is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= v_0 + a t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 + (9.29\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (0.800\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 7.43\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution44b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If the sprinter&rsquo;s starting position is at $x_0 = 0$, the distance traveled during the acceleration period is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        x &= x_0 + v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2} a t^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 + 0 + \tfrac{1}{2}\, (9.29\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (0.800\,\text{s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.97\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>


<!--  *********************************  -->

Time spent solving problems of various degrees of difficulty, provides a good test of your understanding of the main concepts and increases your efficiency in answering exam questions. Discuss with your tutor any discrepancies between your answers and those provided.</p>

                <p class="runhead1"><strong>Physics 200</strong> Introductory Physics I</p>

                <p class="unit"> Unit 5 <span>(Chapter 5)</span></p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit05" >

                  <!-- to change: the following content -->
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Further Applications of Newton&rsquo;s Laws: Friction, Drag, and Elasticity</h1>
                  <hr>

                  <p>In this unit, we apply Newton&rsquo;s laws to the motion of a bodies. We will be using Newton&rsquo;s laws throughout the course, but since you have just learned them, it is appropriate to look at some simple problems at this time, such as why it takes more effort to push a car uphill than along a horizontal surface, how friction affects the motion of bodies, what type of force is generated by a compressed spring, and so on. We will use Newton&rsquo;s laws in more complex situations as we progress in the course.</p>

                  <p>In applying <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law</a>, ${\bf F} = m\, {\bf a}$, we should note that the force $\bf F$ is equal to the vector sum (or resultant) of all external forces acting on the body. These include gravitational, frictional, reaction, and applied forces. So, an unambiguous expression of the second law would be
                  \begin{equation}
                   {\bf F}_\text{net} = m\, {\bf a}
                  \end{equation}
                  </p>

                  <p style="margin-top:2.0em;">
                  <div class="learningobjectives">
                    <h3>Learning Objectives</h3>
                    <p>After completing this unit, you should be able to</p>
                    <ul>
                        <li>distinguish between the forces of static and kinetic friction.</li>
                        <li>solve problems involving the coefficients of static and kinetic friction.</li>
                        <li>discuss the meaning and implications of the drag force.</li>
                        <li>define terminal velocity and solve simple problems involving drag forces.</li>
                        <li>State <em>Hooke&rsquo;s law</em> and solve simple problems involving such variable force.</li>
                        <li>define the terms <em>Young&rsquo;s modulus</em>, <em>shear modulus</em>, <em>bulk modulus</em>, <em>stress</em>, and <em>strain</em>.</li>
                        <li>apply the elastic properties of materials to problems from a variety of disciplines.</li>
                    </ul>
                  </div>

                  <!-- end of content -->

                </div> <!-- end of this section -->

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit05-friction">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Further Applications of Newton&rsquo;s Laws: Friction, Drag, and Elasticity</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Forces of Friction</h2>

                <p>Suppose you give a push to a book on a horizontal tabletop. The book will slide over some distance on the tabletop, then come to rest. The book doesn&rsquo;t keep on sliding because, after you stop pushing it, the force of friction continues to oppose the motion, and eventually brings it to a stop. If there were no friction, the book would keep on moving with constant velocity.</p>

                <p>The term <em>friction</em> refers to the resistance force generated parallel to the surface of contact of two objects moving, or attempting to move, against each other. Experience tells us that moving a piece of furniture over a polished surface is much easier than over carpet. The reason, we say, is that the force of friction between the furniture and the carpet is much larger than the force of friction between the same piece of furniture and a polished floor.</p>

                <p>We can think of the imperfections of the surfaces as the cause of the resistive force of friction. When two surfaces are in contact, the tiny protrusions of the imperfections push against each other, opposing the motion of one surface over another. The sum of all these forces can be thought of as the net frictional force. Although the model is quite simple, it allows us to visualize why frictional forces between rough surfaces are larger than those between comparatively smooth surfaces.</p>

                <h3>Static Friction</h3>

                <p>Suppose we apply a force to a wooden box in an effort to make it move across a floor. If the applied force is relatively small, the box will not move. This observation indicates that an equal (but opposite) resistive force is instantly generated, making the net force on the box equal to zero. Because the body remains motionless, the resistive force thus generated is called the <em>force of static friction</em>. As we push harder, the frictional force also increases, keeping the box at rest. Therefore, the force of static friction is not constant, but changes with the applied force. Eventually, when the applied force is sufficiently large, the box will start to move. We, therefore, conclude that the force of static friction cannot increase beyond a certain maximum value, after which a nonzero net force causes the box to accelerate.</p>

                <p>It has been verified experimentally that the maximum force of static friction is proportional to the <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-normal-force">normal force</a> ($N$) between the surfaces in contact. This relationship is expressed mathematically as
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{maximum}\, f_\text{s} = \mu_\text{s}\, N
                        \end{equation}
                where $f_\text{s}$ represents the force of static friction. The constant of proportionality $\mu_\text{s}$ is called the <em>coefficient of static friction</em>, and its value depends on the nature of the surfaces in contact. Remember that the equation above is true only for the maximum value of the static frictional force between the two surfaces. If the applied force is smaller than $\mu_\text{s} N$ then the force of static friction is equal to the applied force. However, if the applied force is greater than $\mu_\text{s} N$, then there will be a net force on the object, which causes it to accelerate. An alternative mathematical expression for static friction is then
                        \begin{equation}
                        f_\text{s} \le \mu_\text{s}\, N
                        \end{equation}
                with the equality sign holding when the body is on the verge of motion.</p>

                <h3>Kinetic Friction</h3>

                <p>Once the box starts moving, static friction vanishes and a new force, called the <em>force of kinetic friction</em>, comes into the picture. You may have noticed that it takes less effort to keep a body moving on a rough surface than to start the body moving from rest. In other words, kinetic friction is relatively weaker than static friction. The force of kinetic friction also depends on the normal force and has the mathematical form
                        \begin{equation}
                        f_\text{k} = \mu_\text{k}\, N
                        \end{equation}
                where $\mu_\text{k}$ is the <em>coefficient of kinetic friction</em> whose value depends on the surfaces in contact.
                </p>

                <h3>PhET Simulation: Forces and Motion Basics</h3>

                <p>Explore the forces at work when you try to push different bodies and objects of different masses. Vary the applied force and observe the effect of friction forces on the speed and acceleration of the moving objects.</p>

                <p><div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 200px;"><a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/html/forces-and-motion-basics/latest/forces-and-motion-basics_en.html" target="_blank" style="text-decoration: none;"><img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/html/forces-and-motion-basics/latest/forces-and-motion-basics-600.png" alt="Forces and Motion: Basics" style="border: none;" width="300" height="200"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 60px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);"></div><table style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 60px;"><tr><td style="text-align: center; color: #000; font-size: 24px; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Click to Run</td></tr></table></a></div>

                <div class="source">Source: <a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/forces-and-motion-basics" target="_blank">PhET Interactive Simulations</a>, University of Colorado Boulder.</div>


<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Chapter 5</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf#page=2" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">5.1.&nbsp; Friction</a> </li>
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf#page=7" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">5.2.&nbsp; Drag Forces</a> </li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit05-elasticity">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Further Applications of Newton&rsquo;s Laws: Friction, Drag, and Elasticity</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Elasticity</h2>

                <p>When the vector sum of the forces on a body is equal to zero, it stays in equilibrium. However, the applied forces tend to deform the body by changing its shape. The degree of deformity is determined by the internal elastic properties of its material.</p>

                <h3>Elastic Modulus</h3>

                <p>Consider a simple case&mdash;a thin wire of length $L_0$ and cross-sectional area $A$ pulled by a force $F$ at one end, the other end being attached to a support. The support will exert an equal and opposite force, keeping the wire in equilibrium. Since we are considering a thin wire, we are assuming that its weight is negligible. Because of the tensile force $F$, the wire stretches by a small amount $\Delta L$. Experimentally, we notice that the increase in length $\Delta L$ is directly proportional to the original length $L_0$ and to the applied force $F$, and inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area $A$ of the wire. This relation is expressed mathematically as
                        \begin{equation}
                        \Delta L = \frac{1}{Y}\, \frac{F}{A}\, L_0
                        \label{unit05_DL_FL0AY}
                        \end{equation}
               where $Y$ is a constant called the <em>elastic modulus</em> or <em>Young&rsquo;s modulus</em>. The value of this constant, a property of the internal structure of the material, is different for different objects; some materials stretch more easily than others. Consequently, a copper wire and a similar steel wire will stretch differently under the same force.</p>

               <p>By defining
                       \begin{equation}
                       \text{stress} = \frac{F}{A}
                       \end{equation}
               and
                       \begin{equation}
                       \text{strain} = \frac{\Delta L}{L}
                       \end{equation}
               we can rewrite Equation \ref{unit05_DL_FL0AY} as
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{stress} = Y\times \text{strain}
                        \end{equation}
               </p>

               <p>It is obvious that a body cannot deform indefinitely under increasing force. Eventually, the body will break or sustain irreversible deformation. The maximum force that can be applied to a certain material, without causing it to fracture or permanently deform, is called the <em>tensile strength</em> of the material.</p>

               <h3>Bulk Modulus</h3>

               <p>When a body is subjected to forces on all sides, its volume $V_0$ will decrease by an amount $\Delta V$ determined by the <em>bulk modulus</em> ($B$). The corresponding relation is written as
                        \begin{equation}
                        \Delta V = \frac{1}{B}\, \frac{F}{A}\, V_0
                        \end{equation}
               where $F$ is the magnitude of the force perpendicular to the surface area $A$ of the body. Note that ($F/A$) corresponds to the pressure on the outer surface caused by the applied force. </p>

               </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit05-hookes-law">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Further Applications of Newton&rsquo;s Laws: Friction, Drag, and Elasticity</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Hooke&rsquo;s Law</h2>

                <p>The tensile stress formula (Equation \ref{unit05_DL_FL0AY}) can be re-written as
                        \begin{equation}
                        F = \left(\frac{Y\, A}{L_0}\right) \Delta L
                        \end{equation}
                An important characteristic of the relation above is the linear dependence of the change in length on the applied force. For example, if $F$ is doubled, $\Delta L$ doubles. This behaviour is common among elastic objects, such as springs. A convenient expression in this regard, called <em>Hooke&rsquo;s law</em>, is
                        \begin{equation}
                        F = k\, \Delta L
                        \end{equation}
                The proportionality constant depends on the material and shape of the body being stretched or compressed. When used to describe the elastic properties of a spring, $k$ is called the <em>spring constant</em></p>.

                <h3>PhET Simulation: Hooke&rsquo;s Law</h3>

                <p>Apply different forces on the spring (or spring combination) and observe the resulting extension (or compression) and the stored elastic potential energy.</p>
