                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit05-examples">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Further Applications of Newton&rsquo;s Laws: Friction, Drag, and Elasticity</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Examples</h2>

                    <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of examples relevant to the content of <span style="white-space: nowrap;">Unit 5</span>. Make an attempt to answer each question on your own, before you read through the solution provided.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit05-e01">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 5, Example 1</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A block of mass $m_1 = 6.00\,\text{kg}$ is placed on a table next to a larger block of mass $m_2 = 9.00\,\text{kg}$. The system is pushed by applying a force of $65.0\,\text{N}$ on the smaller block, as shown in <b>Figure E5.1</b>. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the blocks and the table is $0.130$. (a) What is the acceleration of the system? (b) Find the contact force that each block exerts on the other.
                <hr>
                <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit05-e01.svg" alt="image"><br>
                <br><b>Figure E5.1</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e01_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e01_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01a_btn">Solution (a) </button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01b_btn">Solution (b) </button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $3.06\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                      <p>(a) $39.0\,\text{N}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit05-e01s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E5.1s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>To calculate the acceleration of the system, we assume that the two blocks in <b>Figure E5.1</b> are glued together into a single object of mass
                        \begin{equation}
                        (m_1 + m_2) = 15.0\,\text{kg}
                        \end{equation}
                Since, the weight ($w$) and the <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-normal-force">normal force</a> ($N$) are the only two forces that act on the system in the vertical direction, and because they do not cause any vertical acceleration, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        N - w & = 0  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad N &=  w  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (m_1 + m_2)\, g  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  (15.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 147\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>Knowing the normal force, we can calculate the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit05-friction">force of kinetic friction</a> on the system as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        f_\text{k} & = \mu_\text{k}\, N \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  (0.130)\, (147\,\text{N})  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 19.1\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                So, the net horizontal force on the two-block system is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{net} &= 65.0\,\text{N} -  f_\text{k} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 65.0\,\text{N} - 19.1\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 45.9\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>By applying Newton&rsquo;s second law to the horizontal motion, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{net} = (m_1 + m_2)\, a
                        \end{equation}
                So, the acceleration of the system as it moves across the table is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        a & = \frac{F_\text{net}}{(m_1 + m_2)}  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        & = \frac{45.9\,\text{N}}{15.0\,\text{kg}}  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.06\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>Note that the $65.0\,\text{N}$ force is applied directly at the first block. The two blocks, however, move together with the same acceleration. This means the first block exerts a force on the second block in the forward direction. According to <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-third-law">Newton&rsquo;s third law</a>, the second block must react by applying equal force back on the first block. These contact forces ($F_\text{c}$) are visible in the free-body diagrams of the individual blocks, shown in <b>Figure E5.1s</b>.</p>

                <p>If $f_{2\text{k}}$ is the resistive force of kinetic friction on the second block, then from <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law</a> of motion we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{c} - f_{2\text{k}} &= m_2\, a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_\text{c} - \mu_\text{k}\, N_2 &= m_2\, a
                        \end{align}
                where $N_2 = m_2\, g$ is the normal force on the larger block. So, the contact force that each block exerts on the other is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{c} &= \mu_\text{k}\, N_2 + m_2\, a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \mu_\text{k}\, m_2\, g + m_2\, a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m_2\, (\mu_\text{k}\, g + a) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (9.00\,\text{kg})\, (0.130 \times 9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2 + 3.06\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 39.0\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                 </p>

                <p>As an exercise, show that you will get the same answer by applying Newton&rsquo;s second law to the first block.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit05-e02">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 5, Example 2</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A $4.00$-$\text{kg}$ block is tied to the wall and placed on a $7.00$-$\text{kg}$ block, which sits on a tabletop, as shown in <b>Figure 5.2</b>. The heavier block is pulled by a horizontal force of $F = 40.0\,\text{N}$, away from the wall. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between all sliding surfaces is $0.250$, determine (a) the tension in the cord, and (b) the acceleration of the heavier block.
                <hr>
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit05-e02.svg" alt="image"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure E5.2</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e02_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e02_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02a_btn">Solution (a) </button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02b_btn">Solution (b) </button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $9.80\,\text{N}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $0.464\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit05-e02s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E5.2s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>We begin by drawing free-body diagrams for the two blocks, as shown in <b>Figure E5.2s</b>. From the diagram, we see that the smaller block at the top ($m_1 = 4.00\,\text{kg}$) experiences a <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit05-friction">force of kinetic friction</a> directed to the right with magnitude of
                        \begin{align}
                        f_{1\text{k}} &= \mu_\text{k}\, N_1 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \mu_\text{k}\, m_1 g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.250)\,(4.00\,\text{kg})\,(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9.80\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                where $N_1 = m_1 g$ is the upward normal force exerted on the upper block.</p>

                <p>Since the upper block does not move, the net force on it must be equal to zero. More specifically, the horizontal force of kinetic friction ($f_{1\text{k}}$), which attempts to push the upper block away from the wall, is balanced by the tension ($T$) in the cord, such that
                        \begin{equation}
                        f_{1\text{k}} - T = 0
                        \end{equation}
                So, the tension in the cord is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        T &=  f_{1\text{k}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9.80\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>As shown in <b>Figure E5.2s</b>, the heavier block ($m_2 = 7.00\,\text{kg}$) experiences two forces of kinetic friction, both directed to the left. The first one ($f_{1\text{k}}$) is generated at the upper surface, while the second one is generated at lower surface and has a magnitude of
                        \begin{align}
                        f_{2\text{k}} &= \mu_\text{k}\,N_2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \mu_\text{k}\, (m_1 + m_2) g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.250)\,(11.0\,\text{kg})\,(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 26.95\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                        Note that $N_2 = (m_1 + m_2) g$ is the upward normal force exerted on the lower block by the table.
                        </p>

                        <p>The net force on the lower block causes it to accelerate, according to Newton&rsquo;s second law, which can be expressed as
                                \begin{equation}
                                F - f_{1\text{k}} - f_{2\text{k}} = m_2\, a
                                \end{equation}
                        So, the acceleration is calculated to be
                                \begin{align}
                                a &= \frac{F - f_{1\text{k}} - f_{2\text{k}}}{m_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{40.0\,\text{N} - 9.80\,\text{N} - 26.95\,\text{N}}{7.00\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 0.464\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit05-e03">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 5, Example 3</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A marble pillar is $3.00\,\text{m}$ long and $30.0\,\text{cm}$ in diameter. By how much does the pillar shrink if it supports a load $12.0\,\text{kN}$?
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e03_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03_btn">Solution</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.00849\,\text{mm}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>The marble pillar, in this example, has an initial length of
                        \begin{equation}
                        L_0 = 3.00\,\text{m}
                        \end{equation}
                 and a cross-sectional area of
                        \begin{align}
                        A &= \pi\, r^2  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  \pi\, (0.150\,\text{m})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.0707\,\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                 where $r = 15.0\,\text{cm}$ is the cross-sectional radius. With the Young&rsquo;s modulus for marble $Y = 6.0\times 10^{10}\,\text{N}/\text{m}^2$, a force $F = 1.20\times 10^4\,\text{N}$ would compress the pillar by
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta L &= \frac{1}{Y}\, \frac{F}{A}\, L_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{1}{6.0\times 10^{10}\,\text{N}/\text{m}^2}\right) \left(\frac{1.20\times 10^4\,\text{N}}{0.0707\,\text{m}^2}\right) (3.00\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.49\times 10^{-6}\,\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.00849\,\text{mm}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit05-e04">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 5, Example 4</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A block starts from rest and slides $2.40\,\text{m}$ down a smooth incline of $\theta = 22.0^\circ$. (a) Show the forces on the block using a free-body diagram. Calculate (b) the acceleration of the block and (c) the travel time.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e04_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e04_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e04a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e04b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e04c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="interactive-e04_btn">Interactive Activity</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(b) $3.67\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                      <p>(c) $1.14\,\text{s}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit05-e04s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E5.4s</b></p>
                    </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the inclined plane is frictionless, the block experiences two forces: the force of gravity in the downward direction and the normal force perpendicular to the incline. See the free-body diagram in <b>Figure E5.4s</b>.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The force of gravity on the block can be resolved into two components (see <b>Figure E5.4s</b>): one perpendicular to the incline, with a magnitude of $m g \cos\theta$, and one parallel to the incline with a magnitude of $m g \sin\theta$. Since, the component perpendicular to the incline is balanced by the <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-normal-force">normal force</a>, the net force on the block acts down the inclined plane and has a magnitude of
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{net} =  m g\, \sin\theta
                        \end{equation}
                    So, the acceleration of the block down the incline is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        a &=  \frac{F_\text{net}}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  g\, \sin\theta  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, \sin 22.0^\circ  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.67\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04c">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the block starts from rest ($v_0 = 0$) and moves a distance of $d = 2.40\,\text{m}$ down the incline, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        d &= v_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2} a t^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad d & = \tfrac{1}{2} a t^2
                        \end{align}
                    So, the time it takes the block to slide down the incline is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= \sqrt{\frac{2 d}{a}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{\frac{2\, (2.40\,\text{m})}{3.67\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.14\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="interactive-e04">
                <div class="panel-heading">Interactive Activity</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p class="centerText"><a href="./unit05-e04i.cdf"><img  src="unit05-e04i.png" alt="image"></a><br>
                    <br><b>Figure E5.4i</b></p>
                </div>

                    <p>Use <a href="https://www.wolfram.com/cdf-player/" target="_blank">Wolfram CDF Player</a>
                    to open the interactive diagram <a href="./unit05-e04i.cdf"><b>Figure E5.4i</b></a>.</p>

                    <p>Answer the questions below and use the interactive diagram to check your calculations.</p>

                        <p>
                        <ol>
                        <li>What would be the acceleration of the block and the travel time if the inclination angle is reduced to $10.0^\circ$?</li>
                        <li>Calculate the final velocity of the block at $\theta = 45.0^\circ$.</li>
                      </ol>

                    </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-conceptual-questions">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Further Applications of Newton&rsquo;s Laws: Friction, Drag, and Elasticity</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Conceptual Questions</h2>

                  <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of conceptual questions selected from the end of <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf#page=21" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Chapter 5</a></span> in the textbook.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-q04">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Question 4</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">When you push a piece of chalk across a chalkboard, it sometimes screeches because it rapidly alternates between slipping and sticking to the board. Describe this process in more detail, in particular explaining how it is related to the fact that kinetic friction is less than static friction. (The same slip-grab process occurs when tires screech on pavement.)
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q04_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>To write on a chalkboard, you push the chalk against the surface and start applying a force ($F_\parallel$) parallel to the board. Then, you increase $F_\parallel$ until it overcomes the force of static friction. At this instant, static friction disappears and kinetic friction comes into play. Since this is a relatively weaker force, the chalk experiences a sudden jump in acceleration. As a result, the parallel force $F_\parallel$ is monetarily reduced causing the force of kinetic friction to decelerate the chalk and it comes to a stop. The cycle then repeats.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 6 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-q06">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Question 6</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Two expressions were used for the drag force experienced by a moving object in a liquid. One depended upon the speed, while the other was proportional to the square of the speed. In which types of motion would each of these expressions be more applicable than the other one?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q08_btn">Answer</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q08">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The expression in which the drag force is proportional to the square of the velocity is best used for larger objects moving in air at medium or high speeds. Otherwise, the drag force is better described by a linear dependence on the speed of the moving object.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 16 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-q16">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Question 16</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">When a glass bottle full of vinegar warms up, both the vinegar and the glass expand, but vinegar expands significantly more with temperature than glass. The bottle will break if it was filled to its tightly capped lid. Explain why, and also explain how a pocket of air above the vinegar would prevent the break. (This is the function of the air above liquids in glass containers.)
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q16_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q16">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>When the bottle is heated, the vinegar inside begins to expand. Since the volume of the vinegar increases faster than the volume of the glass, the liquid begins to exert an outward force on its surrounding. Since air is highly compressible, the pocket of air at the top responds more easily to the growing pressure, shrinking in size and giving more room to the vinegar. This relieves the pressure inside the bottle keeping it below the breaking point of the glass.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>
