                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-problems">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Further Applications of Newton&rsquo;s Laws: Friction, Drag, and Elasticity</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Solutions of Selected Problems</h2>
                    <p>Next are detailed solutions to a number of problems selected from the end of <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf#page=23" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Chapter 5</a></span> in the textbook. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve each problem independently, before you read through the solution provided. You are also advised to make a second attempt to solve the problem if your answer is different from the one posted. If you reach an impasse and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p02">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">When rebuilding her car&rsquo;s engine, a physics major must exert $300\,\text{N}$ of force to insert a dry steel piston into a steel cylinder. What is the normal force between the piston and cylinder? (b) What force would she have to exert if the steel parts were oiled?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer02_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution02a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution02b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer02" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1{,}000\,\text{N}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $30 \,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution02a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If a minimum force of $300\,\text{N}$ is required to move the piston into place, then it must be equal to the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit05-friction">force of friction</a> ($f_\text{k}$) involved. Since the coefficient of kinetic friction for steel on steel is $\mu_\text{k} = 0.3$ (refer to <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf#page=3" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Table 5.1</a></span> in the textbook), we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        f_\text{k} &= \mu_\text{k}\, N \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 300\,\text{N} &= 0.3\times N
                        \end{align}
                    So, the <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-normal-force">normal force</a> between the piston and cylinder is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        N &= \frac{300\,\text{N}}{0.3}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1{,}000\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution02b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>When oiled, the coefficient of kinetic friction for steel on steel drops to $\mu_\text{k oiled} = 0.03$. The normal force remains the same, as the sizes of piston and cylinder are not altered. So the force necessary to overcome the force of kinetic friction decreases to
                      \begin{align}
                      f_\text{k oiled} &= \mu_\text{k oiled}\, N \nonumber\\[6pt]
                      &= (0.03)\, (1{,}000\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                      &= 30 \,\text{N}
                      \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p04">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 4</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose you have a $120\,\text{kg}$ wooden crate resting on a wood floor. (a) What maximum force can you exert horizontally on the crate without moving it? (b) If you continue to exert this force once the crate starts to slip, what will its acceleration then be?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer04_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution04a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution04b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $588\,\text{N}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $1.96\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution04a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Since the crate (of mass $m = 120\,\text{kg}$) does not experience any vertical acceleration, the normal force is simply equal to the weight, or
                                \begin{align}
                                N &= m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= (120\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 1{,}176\,\text{N}
                                \end{align}
                      With the coefficient of static friction of wood on wood equal to $\mu_\text{s} = 0.5$, the maximum force of static friction is calculated to be
                                \begin{align}
                                f_\text{s max} &= \mu_\text{s}\, N \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= (0.5)\, (1{,}176\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 588\,\text{N}
                                \end{align}
                      This means we cannot apply a greater force without causing the crate to move.
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution04b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If you continue to exert a force $F = 588\,\text{N}$ after the crate starts to move, the net force becomes
                                \begin{align}
                                F_\text{net} &= F - f_\text{k} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= F - \mu_\text{k}\, N
                                \end{align}
                      Since the coefficient of kinetic friction of wood on wood is equal to $\mu_\text{k} = 0.3$, we calculate the net force
                                \begin{align}
                                F_\text{net} &= 588\,\text{N} - (0.3)\, (1{,}176\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 235.2\,\text{N}
                                \end{align}
                      From Newton&rsquo;s second law, we determine the acceleration to be
                                \begin{align}
                                a &= \frac{f_\text{net}}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{235.2\,\text{N}}{120\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 1.96\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                    </div>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 8 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p08">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 8</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Show that the acceleration of any object down a frictionless incline that makes an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal is $a = g\, \sin\theta$ . (Note that this acceleration is independent of mass.)</div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram08_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution08_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram08">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch05-p08s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P5.8s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution08">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Consider a block of mass $m$ placed on an inclined plane that makes an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal, as show in <b>Figure P5.8s</b>. From the free-body diagram, we see that the downward force of gravity ($w = m g$) can be resolved into a component parallel to the incline
                                \begin{equation}
                                w_\parallel = m g \sin{\theta}
                                \end{equation}
                      and a component perpendicular to the incline
                                \begin{equation}
                                w_\bot= m g \cos{\theta}
                                \end{equation}
                      Note that the perpendicular component ($m g \cos{\theta}$) is cancelled by the normal force ($N$). As a result, the block experiences a net force of magnitude $m g \sin{\theta}$ directed down the incline. By applying Newton&rsquo;s second law, we have
                                \begin{equation}
                                F_\text{net} = m g \sin{\theta} = m a
                                \end{equation}
                      So, the acceleration of the block is given by
                                \begin{equation}
                                a = g \sin{\theta}
                                \end{equation}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 10 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p10">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 10</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Calculate the deceleration of a snowboarder going up a $5.0^\circ$ slope, assuming the coefficient of friction for waxed wood on wet snow. Be careful to consider the fact that the snowboarder is going uphill. Explicitly show how you follow the steps in Problem-Solving Strategies.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer10_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram10_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution10_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$1.8\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch05-p10s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P5.10s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>We begin by drawing a free-body diagram for the snowboarder as shown in <b>Figure P5.10s</b>). From the diagram, we see that the normal force ($N$) is equal to the component of the snowboarder&rsquo;s weight perpendicular to the slope. So, we write
                                \begin{equation}
                                N = m g \cos\theta
                                \end{equation}
                      </p>
											
											<p>where $\theta = 5.0^\circ$ is the inclination angle.</p>

                      <p>As the snowboarder moves up the slope, he experiences two forces parallel, but opposite, to his direction of motion. These are the component of his weight down the slope ($m g \sin\theta$) and the force of kinetic friction ($f_\text{k} = \mu_\text{k}\, N$). So, the net force on the snowboarder is directed down the slope, and can be expressed as
                                \begin{align}
                                F_\text{net} &= -m g\, \sin\theta - \mu_\text{k}\, N \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= -m g\, \sin\theta - \mu_\text{k}\, m g\, \cos\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= -m g\, (\sin\theta + \mu_\text{k}\, \cos\theta)
                                \end{align}
                      where $\mu_\text{k} = 0.10$ is the coefficient of kinetic friction for waxed wood on wet snow. By taking uphill to be the positive direction, the negative sign indicates that the net force acts downhill.</p>

                      <p>By applying Newton&rsquo;s second law in the direction parallel to the slope, we write
                                \begin{equation}
                                F_\text{net} = m a
                                \end{equation}
                      So, the acceleration of the snowboarder is calculated as follows
                                \begin{align}
                                a &= \frac{F_\text{net}}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{-m g\, (\sin\theta + \mu_\text{k}\, \cos\theta)}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= -g\, (\sin\theta + \mu_\text{k}\, \cos\theta) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= -(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (\sin{5.0^\circ} + 0.1 \times \cos{5.0^\circ}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= - 1.8\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                    So, while moving uphill, the snowboarder decelerates at the rate of $1.8\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 13 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p13">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 13</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Calculate the maximum deceleration of a car that is heading down a $6^\circ$ slope (one that makes an angle of $6.0^\circ$ with the horizontal) under the following road conditions. You may assume that the weight of the car is evenly distributed on all four tires and that the coefficient of static friction is involved&mdash;that is, the tires are not allowed to slip during the deceleration. (Ignore rolling.) Calculate for a car: (a) On dry concrete. (b) On wet concrete. (c) On ice, assuming that $\mu_s = 0.10$ , the same as for shoes on ice.</div>
                  </div>
                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer13_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram13_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution13a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution13b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution13c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer13">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $8.7\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\; \text{uphill}$</p>
                      <p>(a) $5.8\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\; \text{uphill}$</p>
                      <p>(a) $0.050\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2\; \text{downhill}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram13">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch05-p13s.png" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P5.13s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution13a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>When moving down the slope ($\theta = 6.0^\circ$) the car experiences a zero net force in the direction perpendicular to the road, or
                                \begin{align}
                                F_{\text{net}\,\bot} = N - w_\bot = 0
                                \end{align}
                     So, the a normal force is written as
                                \begin{align}
                                N &= w_\bot \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= m g\, \cos\theta
                                \end{align}
                     where $m$ is the car&rsquo;s mass.
                      </p>

                      <p>While applying the brakes, the tires rotation begins to slow down and the car attempts to skid forward. However, the force of static friction ($f_\text{s}$) between the tires and the road prevents the tries from slipping and provides a resistive force in the backward direction. The maximum deceleration (without slipping) is achieved when the force of static friction is at its maximum value. As a result, the net force on the car parallel to the road (see <b>Figure P5.13s</b>) is given by
                                \begin{align}
                                F_{\text{net}\,\parallel} &= w_\parallel - f_\text{s max} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= w\, \sin{\theta} - \mu_\text{s}\, N \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= m g\, \sin{\theta} - \mu_\text{s}\, m g\, \cos\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= m g\, (\sin{\theta} - \mu_\text{s}\, \cos\theta)
                                \end{align}
                      In this case, the acceleration of the car on dry concrete ($\mu_s = 1.0$) is calculated to be
                                \begin{align}
                                a &= \frac{F_{\text{net}\,\parallel}}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                a &= g\, (\sin{\theta} - \mu_\text{s}\, \cos\theta) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (\sin{6.0^\circ} - 1.0\times \cos{6.0^\circ}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= -8.7\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                      So, the maximum deceleration of the car, heading down this slope in dry conditions, is $8.7\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$.
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution13b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>For wet concrete ($\mu_s = 0.70$), we have
                                \begin{align}
                                a &= (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (\sin{6.0^\circ} - 0.70\times \cos{6.0^\circ}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= -5.8\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                      So, the maximum deceleration downhill, in wet conditions, is $5.8\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$.
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution13c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>For an icy slope ($\mu_s = 0.10$), the acceleration is calculated to be
                                \begin{align}
                                a &= (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (\sin{6.0^\circ} - 0.10\times \cos{6.0^\circ}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 0.050\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                      Note that the acceleration is positive in this case. This means, under icy conditions, the force of friction is weaker than the force of gravity down the slope. As a result, the car&rsquo;s speed will continue to increase downhill.</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 18 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p18">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 18</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A contestant in a winter sporting event pushes a $45.0\,\text{kg}$ block of ice across a frozen lake as shown in <b>Figure P5.18</b>. (a) Calculate the minimum force $F$ he must exert to get the block moving. (b) What is its acceleration once it starts to move, if that force is maintained?
                    <hr>
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch05-p18.svg" alt="image"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure P5.18</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer18_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram18_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution18a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution18b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer18" > <!-- to change: id="***". This id is corresponding to the button id, cutting off the "_btn" -->
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $51.0\,\text{N}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $0.719\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram18">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch05-p18s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P4.18s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>To get the block moving, the contestant must be able to overcome the force of static friction between the block of ice and the frozen lake (see <b>Figure P4.18s</b>). So, when the block is on the verge of sliding, the force of static friction is at its maximum value
                        \begin{equation}
                        f_\text{s max} = \mu_\text{s}\, N
                        \end{equation}
                    where $N$ is the normal force, and the coefficient of static friction of ice on ice is $\mu_\text{s} = 0.100$. In this state, the block experiences zero net force in all directions. So, by adding the forces in the vertical direction, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        N - m g - F\, \sin\theta &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  N &= m g + F\, \sin\theta
                        \label{ch05_NmgFsin}
                        \end{align}
                    where $m = 45.0\,\text{kg}$ is the mass of the block, and $\theta = 25.0^\circ$ is the direction of the applied force below the horizontal. Similarly, in the horizontal direction, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        F\, \cos\theta - f_\text{s max} &=0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  F\, \cos\theta - \mu_\text{s}\, N &=0
                        \label{ch05_FcodnuN}
                        \end{align}
                  </p>

                  <p>By substituting from Equation \ref{ch05_NmgFsin} into Equation \ref{ch05_FcodnuN}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        F\cos\theta - \mu_s\, (m\, g + F\, \sin\theta) &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad   F\, (\cos\theta - \mu_s \sin\theta) &= \mu_s\, m g
                        \end{align}
                    So, the minimum force the contestant must exert, at the specified angle, to get the block moving is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= \frac{\mu_s\, mg}{\cos\theta - \mu_s \sin\theta} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(0.100)\, (45.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)}{\cos 25^\circ - (0.100\times \sin 25^\circ)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 51.0\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Once it starts to move, the force of static friction disappears and it is replaced by the force of kinetic friction ($f_\text{k}$). In this case, the net horizontal force on the block is no longer zero, which causes it to accelerate. So, from Newton&rsquo;s second law, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        F\, \cos\theta - f_\text{k} = m\, a
                        \end{equation}
                    where $a$ is the magnitude of the acceleration parallel to the lake&rsquo;s surface. If the force $\bf F$ is maintained, the normal force magnitude is still equal to (see Equation \ref{ch05_NmgFsin})
                        \begin{align}
                        N &= m g + F\, \sin\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (045.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) + (51.0\,\text{N})\, \sin{25^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 462.6\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    With the coefficient of kinetic friction of ice on ice is $\mu_\text{k} = 0.0300$, the acceleration of the ice block is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        a &= \frac{F\, \cos\theta - f_\text{k}}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{F\, \cos\theta - \mu_\text{k}\, N}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(51.0\,\text{N})\, \cos{25^\circ} - (0.0300)\,(462.6\,\text{N})}{45.0\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.719\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 20 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p20">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 20</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The terminal velocity of a person falling in air depends upon the weight and the area of the person facing the fluid. Find the terminal velocity (in meters per second and kilometers per hour) of an $80.0\,\text{kg}$ skydiver falling in a pike (headfirst) position with a surface area of $0.140\,\text{m}^2$.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer20_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$115\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The drag force on a person ($m = 80.0\,\text{kg}$), moving through air with velocity $v$, can be described by the equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{D} = \tfrac{1}{2}\, C\, \rho\, A\, v^2
                        \label{ch5_p20_FD}
                        \end{equation}
                    where $\rho =  1.21\,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3$ is the density of air. Since the person is falling head first, her surface area facing the fluid is $A = 0.140\,\text{m}^2$ and the drag coefficient (refer to <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf#page=9" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Table 5.2</a></span> in the textbook) is equal to $C = 0.70$. The skydiver stops accelerating and reaches a terminal velocity ($v_\text{t}$) when the net vertical force on her becomes equal to zero. In this case, the person&rsquo;s weight is balanced by the drag force, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        \tfrac{1}{2}\, C\, \rho\, A\, v_\text{t}^2 = m g
                        \end{equation}
                    So, the terminal velocity in this case is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{t} &= \sqrt{\frac{2 m g}{C \rho A}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{\frac{2\, (80.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)}{(0.70)\, ( 1.21\,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3)\, (0.140\,\text{m}^2)}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 115\,\text{m/s} \quad (\text{or}\;\; 414\,\text{km/h})
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 25 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p25">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 25</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Calculate the velocity a spherical rain drop would achieve falling from $5.00\,\text{km}$ (a) in the absence of air drag (b) with air drag. Take the size across of the drop to be $4.00\,\text{mm}$, the density to be $1.00\times 10^3\,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3$, and the surface area to be $\pi r^2$.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer25_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution25a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution25b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer25">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $313\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $9.80\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution25a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">

                    <p>In the absence of air drag, we simply use the kinematic equation of motion
                        \begin{equation}
                        v^2 = v_0^2 - 2 g\,  (y - y_0)
                        \end{equation}
                    So, if the rain drop falls from rest ($v_0 = 0$) at an initial height of $y_0 = 5,000\,\text{m}$, the final velocity just before it hits the ground (at $y = 0$) is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v^2 &= 0 - 2\, g\, (0 - y_0) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2 g\, y_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v &= \sqrt{2\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (5.00\times 10^3\,\text{m})} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 313\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution25b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">

                    <p>Here, we assume the rain drop to be large enough to use the quadratic relation for drag
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{D} = \tfrac{1}{2}\, C\, \rho_\text{air} \, A\, v^2
                        \end{equation}
                    So, as in <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#chapter05-p20">Problem 20</a>, the terminal velocity can be expressed as
                        \begin{equation}
                        v_\text{t} = \sqrt{\frac{2\, g\, (m/A)}{C \rho_\text{air}}}
                        \label{ch05_p25_vtmg}
                        \end{equation}
                    where the density of air is taken to be $\rho_\text{air} = 1.21\,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3$.</p>

                    <p>If we model the raindrop as a sphere ($C = 0.45$) of radius $r = 2.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{m}$, the ratio of its mass to cross-sectional area can be expressed in the simple form
                        \begin{align}
                        m/A &= (\rho_\text{water}\, V)/A \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \big( \rho_\text{water}\,  \tfrac{4}{3} \pi r^3 \big)/\big( \pi r^2 \big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{4}{3} r\, \rho_\text{water}
                        \label{ch05_p25_mA}
                        \end{align}
                    where the density of water is equal to $\rho_\text{water} = 1000\,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3$.</p>

                    <p>By substituting from Equations \ref{ch05_p25_mA} into Equation \ref{ch05_p25_vtmg}, we can calculate the terminal velocity with air drag as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{t} &= \sqrt{\frac{8\, g\, r\, \rho_\text{water}}{3\, C\, \rho_\text{air}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{\frac{8\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{m})\, (1000\,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3)}{3\, (0.45)\, (1.21\,\text{kg/m}^3)}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9.80\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 28 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p28">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 28</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Stokes&rsquo; law describes sedimentation of particles in liquids and can be used to measure viscosity. Particles in liquids achieve terminal velocity quickly. One can measure the time it takes for a particle to fall a certain distance and then use Stokes&rsquo; law to calculate the viscosity of the liquid. Suppose a steel ball bearing (density $7.8\times 10^3\,\text{kg/m}^3$, diameter $3.0\,\text{mm}$) is dropped in a container of motor oil. It takes $12\,\text{s}$ to fall a distance of $0.60\,\text{m}$. Calculate the viscosity of the oil.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer28_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution28_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer28">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.76\,\text{kg}/\text{m} \cdot \text{s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution28">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The mass of the steel ball bearing, of radius $r = 1.5\times 10^{-3}\,\text{m}$ and density $\rho = 7.8\times 10^3\,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3$, is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        m &= \rho\times \left(\tfrac{4}{3} \pi r^3\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{4}{3}\, \pi\, \rho\, r^3 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{4}{3}\, \pi\, (7.8\times 10^3 \,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3)\, (1.5\times 10^{-3}\,\text{m})^3 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.1\times 10^{-4}\,\text{kg}
                        \end{align}
                    Also, knowing the distance travelled ($\Delta y = 0.60\,\text{m}$) and the time interval ($\Delta t = 12\,\text{s}$), we can calculate the (constant) terminal velocity of the falling ball to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{t} &= \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{0.60\,\text{m}}{12\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.050\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>The terminal velocity of the ball bearing is achieved when it&rsquo;s weight is balanced by the upward drag force ($F_\text{s}$) described by Stokes&rsquo; law. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        mg &= F_\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 6\, \pi\, r\, \eta\, v_\text{t}
                        \end{align}
                    By solving for $\eta$, the viscosity of the liquid is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \eta &= \frac{mg}{6\, \pi\, r\, v_\text{t}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \eta &= \frac{(1.1\times 10^{-4}\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)}{6\, \pi\, (1.5\times 10^{-3}\,\text{m})\, (0.050\,\text{m/s})} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.76\,\text{kg}/\text{m} \cdot \text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 30 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p30">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 30</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">During a wrestling match, a $150\,\text{kg}$ wrestler briefly stands on one hand during a maneuver designed to perplex his already moribund adversary. By how much does the upper arm bone shorten in length? The bone can be represented by a uniform rod $38.0\,\text{cm}$ in length and $2.10\,\text{cm}$ in radius.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer30_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution30_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.0448\,\text{mm}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the wrestler stands on one hand, his entire weight is applied onto the bone in his upper arm. So, the force that pushes down on it is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (150\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1{,}470\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    The upper arm bone can be modeled as a cylindrical rod of initial length $L_0 = 0.380\,\text{m}$, radius $r = 0.0210\,\text{m}$, and Young&rsquo;s modulus (refer to <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf#page=14" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Table 5.3</a></span> in the textbook) $Y = 9.00\times 10^9 \,\text{N}/\text{m}^2$. So the decrease in the bone&rsquo;s length is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta L &= \frac{1}{Y}\, \frac{F}{A}\, L_0\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1}{Y}\, \frac{F}{\pi r^2}\, L_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1}{9.00\times 10^9 \,\text{N}/\text{m}^2} \times \frac{1{,}470\,\text{N}}{\pi\, (0.0210\,\text{m})^2} \times (0.380\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.48\times 10^{-5}\,\text{m} \quad (\text{or}\;\; 0.0448\,\text{mm})
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 34 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p34">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 34</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $20.0\,\text{m}$ tall hollow aluminum flagpole is equivalent in strength to a solid cylinder $4.00\,\text{cm}$ in diameter. A strong wind bends the pole much as a horizontal force of $900\,\text{N}$ exerted at the top would. How far to the side does the top of the pole flex?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer34_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram34_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution34_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer34">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.573\,\text{mm}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram34">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch05-p34s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P5.34s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The flagpole here can be modeled as a solid aluminum cylinder of initial length $L_0 = 20.0\,\text{m}$ and cross-sectional radius of $r = 0.0200\,\text{m}$. The strong wind exerts a horizontal force of magnitude $F = 900\,\text{N}$ at the top end, as shown in <b>Figure P5.34s</b>. Referring to <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf#page=14" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Table 5.3</a></span> in the textbook, the shear modulus for aluminum is $S = 25.0\times 10^9\, \text{N}/\text{m}^2$. So, we can calculate how much the pole flexes to the side as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta x &= \frac{1}{S}\, \frac{F}{A}\, L_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1}{S}\, \frac{F}{\pi r^2}\, L_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1}{25.0\times 10^9 \, \text{N}/\text{m}^2}\times \frac{900\,\text{N}}{\pi\, (0.0200\,\text{m})^2} \times (20.0\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.73\times 10^{-4}\,\text{m} \quad (\text{or}\;\; 0.573\,\text{mm})
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 35 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p35">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 35</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">As an oil well is drilled, each new section of drill pipe supports its own weight and that of the pipe and drill bit beneath it. Calculate the stretch in a new $6.00\,\text{m}$ length of steel pipe that supports $3.00\,\text{km}$ of pipe having a mass of $20.0\,\text{kg/m}$ and a $100\,\text{kg}$ drill bit. The pipe is equivalent in strength to a solid cylinder $5.00\,\text{cm}$ in diameter.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer35_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution35_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer35" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$8.59\,\text{mm}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution35" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>To calculate the stretch of the new pipe, of length $L_0 = 6.00\,\text{m}$ and effective radius $r = 0.0250\,\text{m}$, we need to find the total mass ($m_\text{total}$) supported. This includes, the mass of the upper pipe, the mass of the pipes underneath, and the mass of the drill bit. So, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        m_\text{total} &=  (6.00\,\text{m})\,(20.0\,\text{kg/m}) + (3{,}000\,\text{m})\,(20.0\,\text{kg/m}) + 100\,\text{kg} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 60{,}220\,\text{kg}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>The force pulling down on the new pipe piece is equal to the total weight, which is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        w_\text{total} &= m_\text{total}\times g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (60{,}220\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 590{,}156\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}

                     With the <a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf#page=14" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Young&rsquo;s modulus</a> for steel is $Y = 210\times 10^9\,\text{N}/\text{m}^2$, we calculate the stretch in the uppermost pipe as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta L &= \frac{1}{Y}\, \frac{F}{A}\, L_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1}{Y}\, \frac{w_\text{total}}{\pi r^2}\, L_0\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1}{210\times 10^9\,\text{N}/\text{m}^2}\times \frac{590{,}156\,\text{N}}{\pi\, (0.0250\,\text{m})^2}\times (6.00\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.59\times 10^{-3}\,\text{m} \quad (\text{or}\;\; 8.59\,\text{mm})
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 42 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter05-p42">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 5, Problem 42</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) When water freezes, its volume increases by $9.05\,\text{%}$ (that is, $\Delta V / V_0 = 9.05 \times 10^{-2}$). What force per unit area is water capable of exerting on a container when it freezes? (It is acceptable to use the bulk modulus of water in this problem.) (b) Is it surprising that such forces can fracture engine blocks, boulders, and the like?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer42_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution42a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution42b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer42" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $2.0\times 10^8 \,\text{N}/\text{m}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution42a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Consider a closed constrainer of volume $V_0$, that is filled completely with water. When placed under freezing conditions, the water inside tends to expand by an amount equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        \Delta V = 0.0905\, V_0
                        \end{equation}
                    However, if the container walls are strong enough, the expansion is prevented. In other words, the walls apply the required pressure ($F/A$) to compress the ice by $9.05\,\text{%}$. Since ice has a <a href="../textbook/chapter-5.pdf#page=14" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">bulk modulus</a> of $B = 2.2\times10^9 \,\text{N}/\text{m}^2$, the applied pressure is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta V &= \frac{1}{B}\, \frac{F}{A}\, V_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \frac{F}{A} &= B \left(\frac{\Delta V}{V_0}\right)\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (2.2\times 10^9\,\text{N}/\text{m}^2)\, (0.0905) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.0\times 10^8\,\text{N}/\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution42b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>This is approximately two thousand times the atmospheric pressure at sea level! So, it is not surprising that such forces can fracture engine blocks. It is by the expansion of freezing water that concrete cracks and potholes form.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

If you have any difficulty or require assistance, please contact your tutor.</p>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-ex_btn">Answers</button>
                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-ex">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answers to End-of-Chapter Practice Problems</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <ol>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="1"> <span style="color:black">$5.00\,\text{N}$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="5"> <span style="color:black">(a) $4.90\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$, (b) No, (c) $9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="6"> <span style="color:black">(a) $3.29\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$, (b) $3.52\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ (c) $980\,\text{N}$, $945\,\text{N}$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="14"> <span style="color:black">(a) $4.20\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$, (b) $2.74\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ (c) $-0.195\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="17"> <span style="color:black">(a) $512\,\text{N}$, $272\,\text{N}$ (b) $0.268$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="19"> <span style="color:black">(a) $46.5\,\text{N}$, (b) $0.656\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="21"> <span style="color:black">$49.2\,\text{s}$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="24"> <span style="color:black">$1.9$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="27"> <span style="color:black">$2.40\times 10^{-6}\,\text{m/s}$ (Note: water viscosity $1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{kg}/\text{m}\cdot\text{s}$ at $20^\circ$).</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="31"> <span style="color:black">(a) $1\,\text{mm}$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="33"> <span style="color:black">(a) $9.0\,\text{cm}$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="37"> <span style="color:black">$1.49\times 10^{-7}\,\text{m}$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="39"> <span style="color:black">(a) $3.99\times 10^{-7}\,\text{m}$ (b) $9.67\times 10^{-8}\,\text{m}$</span> </li>
                        <li class="listGreenColor" value="41"> <span style="color:black">(a) $400\,\text{N}/\text{cm}^2$</span> </li>
                      </ol>
                    </div>
                  </div>
                </div>
