              <article>
                <p class="runhead1"><strong>Physics 200</strong> Introductory Physics I</p>

                <p class="unit"> Unit 6 <span>(Chapter 6)</span></p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06" >

                  <!-- to change: the following content -->
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Uniform Circular Motion and Gravitation</h1>
                  <hr>

                  <p>Circular motion is all around us. As you are reading this material (if you&rsquo;re in Windsor, Ontario) you are spinning with the Earth around its axis at a supersonic speed of $1{,}235\,\text{km/h}$. A person living close to the equator, is moving even faster! In addition, we are rotating, along with our planet, around the Sun at an astonishing speed close to $110{,}000\,\text{km/h}$!</p>

                  <p>In this unit, we explore aspects of uniform circular motion, including general characteristics, acceleration, force, and the physics of road curves. We will also discuss Newton&rsquo;s universal law of gravitation and satellite motion.</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:2.0em;">
                  <div class="learningobjectives">
                    <h3>Learning Objectives</h3>
                    <p>After completing this unit, you should be able to</p>
                    <ul>
                        <li>describe the motion of a body in a circular path.</li>
                        <li>define <em>centripetal acceleration</em> and <em>centripetal force</em>, and use them to solve problems of a body moving along a circular path.</li>
                        <li>explain the meaning of <em>centrifugal force</em>.</li>
                        <li>solve problems involving banked and unbanked curves.</li>
                        <li>state <em>Newton&rsquo;s universal law of gravitation</em>.</li>
                        <li>apply Newton&rsquo;s universal law of gravitation to solve problems related to the orbital motion of planets and satellites.</li>
                    </ul>
                  </div>

                  <!-- end of content -->

                </div> <!-- end of this section -->

<!--  *********************************  -->
				
		<div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-angular-quantities">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Uniform Circular Motion and Gravitation</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Angular Quantities</h2>

                <p>Opening a door is an activity we perform countless times a day without consciously thinking about it. However, as you will see in this unit, and in <a href="../unit10/index10.html" target="_self">Unit 10</a>, the simple operation of opening a door has very interesting interpretation in physics.</p>

               <h3>Linear Velocity</h3>

                <p>Consider a door attached to a hinge as shown in <a href="#unit06-fig01"><b>Figure 6.1</b></a>. The motion of the door as a whole and the motions of parts of the door&mdash;the door knob, a nail hammered into the door, atoms and molecules that make up the door&mdash;move in arcs of different radii with a common center at the hinge. Assume that, as the door swings open, it rotates uniformly during a time interval $\Delta t$. As shown in the diagram, point $\text{A}$ on the door moves to point $\text{B}$ along a circular arc of length $\Delta s$ and radius $r$. The linear speed of this point is, therefore, equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        v= \frac{\Delta s}{\Delta t}
                        \label{ch06_v_Ds_Dt}
                        \end{equation}
                Note that a point located at a greater distance from the hinge traces a longer arc during the same time interval. This indicates that $v$ increases with $r$. Note also that the velocity vector continuously changes direction as it is always tangent to the circular path.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit06-fig01">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit06-fig01.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 6.1</b>: Top view of a door rotated by an angle $\Delta\theta$ about the hinge during a time interval $\Delta t$.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


               <h3>Angular Velocity</h3>

               <p>Life becomes somewhat simpler in such cases if we choose to work with <em>angular displacement</em> instead of linear displacement. In <a href="#unit06-fig01"><b>Figure 6.1</b></a>, point $\text{A}$ performs an angular displacement $\Delta \theta$ during the time interval $\Delta t$. Since the door is a rigid body, then all parts of the door rotate by the same angle during the same time interval. The relationship between the angular displacement $\Delta \theta$ and the linear displacement $\Delta s$ is given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        \Delta \theta = \frac{\Delta s}{r}
                        \label{ch06_Dtheta_Ds_r}
                        \end{equation}
               where the unit of $\Delta\theta$ is radians (denoted by $\text{rad}$).
               </p>

               <p>As a body completes one revolution, it travels a linear distance equal to the circumference of the circular path ($2\pi r$). The corresponding angular displacement is then $(2\pi r)/r = 2\pi\,\text{rad}$. There are two other common units for angular displacement: degrees (denoted by $^\circ$), and revolutions (denoted by $\text{rev}$). These different units are related as follows:
                        \begin{align}
                        1\,\text{rev} &= 2\pi\,\text{rad} = 360^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        1\,\text{rad} &\approx 57.3^\circ \approx 0.159\,\text{rev} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        1^\circ &\approx 0.00278\,\text{rev} \approx 0.0174\,\text{rad} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \end{align}
               </p>

               <p>The <em>angular velocity</em> of the door as it rotates uniformly by an angle $\Delta\theta$ during a time interval $\Delta t$ is defined as
                        \begin{equation}
                        \omega = \frac{\Delta\theta}{\Delta t}
                        \label{ch06_Dpnega_Dtheta_Dt}
                        \end{equation}
               The units of angular velocity are obviously $\text{rad}/\text{s}$, $\text{rev/s}$, and so on. By substituting from Equations \ref{ch06_v_Ds_Dt} and \ref{ch06_Dtheta_Ds_r} into Equation \ref{ch06_Dpnega_Dtheta_Dt}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= \frac{\left(\Delta s/r\right)}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{\left(\Delta s/\Delta t\right)}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{v}{r}
                        \label{unit06_omega_vr}
                        \end{align}
               or
                        \begin{equation}
                        v = \omega\, r
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit06-vid01.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 6.1</b>: Angular velocities of the clock hands.
                </p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">Chapter 6</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf#page=2" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">6.1.&nbsp; Rotation Angle and Angular Velocity</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-circular-motion">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Uniform Circular Motion and Gravitation</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Dynamics of Circular Motion</h2>

                <p>When you tie a rock, or some other object, to the end of a string and swing it around, you feel a pull on your fingers. The faster you rotate the piece of rock, the stronger the pull. If you let go of the string, the rock flies away&mdash;in a straight line, forgetting the circular path along which it had been rotating.</p>

                <h3>Centripetal Force and Centripetal Acceleration</h3>

                <p>A change in either the speed or the direction of motion of a body, causes a change in the velocity, and we say that the body accelerates. According to <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law of motion</a>, a force is required to generate such acceleration. If the force is applied in the direction of the velocity, then its magnitude changes, without affecting the direction of motion. On the other hand, if the applied force is perpendicular to the direction of motion, the body turns while maintaining the same speed. In all other situations, where the applied force is at an angle with the velocity, both the speed and the direction of motion will change.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit06-fig02">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit06-fig02.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 6.2</b>: A body in a uniform circular motion in a horizontal plane.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>To see what goes on when a body moves along a circular path, let us look into the circular motion in <a href="#unit06-fig02"><b>Figure 6.2</b></a>. When the body is at point $\text{A}$, the direction of the velocity is tangent to the circular path, as shown in the diagram. According to <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-first-law">Newton&rsquo;s first law of motion</a>, in the absence of any applied force, the body tends to move in a straight line in the direction of the tangent to the circle at $\text{A}$. For the body to remain on the circular path and reach point $\text{B}$, a force must be applied in a direction different from that of the velocity to cause deflection.</p>

                <p>The motion of a body traveling with constant speed along a circular path is called uniform circular motion. The period of the motion is the time it takes the body to complete one revolution. The speed $v$ of the body is related to the period $T$ by the equation
                        \begin{equation}
                       v = \frac{2 \pi r}{T}
                        \end{equation}
                where $r$ is the radius of the circular path. Even though, the magnitude of the velocity is constant, the direction changes continuously with time, indicating continuous acceleration perpendicular to the direction of motion. Since the velocity is tangent to the circular path at all times, the acceleration always points towards the centre of the circular path, as shown in <a href="#unit06-fig02"><b>Figure 6.2</b></a>. Such acceleration is referred to as <em>centripetal acceleration</em> and its magnitude is equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        a_\text{c} = \frac{v^2}{r}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>The force exerted on the rotating body (of mass $m$) also points towards the centre, and it is called the <em>centripetal force</em>. According to Newton&rsquo;s second law of motion, the magnitude of the centripetal force is given by
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{c} &= m\, a_\text{c} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{m v^2}{r}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit06-vid02.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 6.2</b>: Projectile motion versus uniform circular motion.
                </p>

                <h3>Centrifugal Force</h3>

                <p>You may have heard of the concept of <em>centrifugal force</em>, which supposedly pushes outward from the centre of an object in circular motion. There is a common misconception that the centrifugal force makes the rock fly away when you let go of the string. Actually, the rock at the end of the string never experiences centrifugal force. So what happens when you let go of the string? The moment you do so, the source of the centripetal force, which is the tension in the string, becomes non-existent. Since the force deflecting the motion disappears, the rock continues to move in the direction of its velocity, according to Newton’s first law of motion. Since the velocity is always tangent to the circular path, the rock flies in a direction tangent to the circle at the point of release&mdash;it does not continue along the radius.</p>

                <h3>PhET Simulation: Ladybug Motion 2D</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf#page=10" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">textbook</a>, &ldquo;learn about position, velocity and acceleration vectors. Move the ladybug by setting the position, velocity or acceleration, and see how the vectors change. Choose linear, circular or elliptical motion, and record and playback the motion to analyze the behavior.&rdquo;</p>

                <p><div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 197px;"><a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/ladybug-motion-2d/ladybug-motion-2d_en.jnlp" style="text-decoration: none;"><img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/ladybug-motion-2d/ladybug-motion-2d-600.png" alt="Ladybug Motion 2D" style="border: none;" width="300" height="197"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);"></div><table style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px;"><tr><td style="text-align: center; color: #000; font-size: 24px; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Click to Run</td></tr></table></a></div>

                <div class="source">Source: <a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/legacy/ladybug-motion-2d" target="_blank">PhET Interactive Simulations</a>, University of Colorado Boulder.</div>


<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">Chapter 6</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf#page=6" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">6.2.&nbsp; Centripetal Acceleration</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-curves">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Uniform Circular Motion and Gravitation</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Banked and Unbanked Curves</h2>

                <p>You have probably noticed that when you are driving on a highway, within the speed limit and under normal driving conditions, you are able to negotiate most of the curves without the need to reduce your speed. This is because civil engineers perform careful calculations, while designing each curve of the road, so that a vehicle will experience the centripetal force needed to allow it to turn the curve while staying on track.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit06-fig03">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit06-fig03.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 6.3</b>: A car moves into the page and negotiates a smooth left turn banked at an angle $\theta$.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>In an unbanked curve, the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-circular-motion">centripetal force</a> causing a car to turn is provided by the force of static friction between the tires and the road. In a banked curve, the centripetal force can be provided totally by the normal force ($N$) without the need for friction. In <a href="#unit06-fig03"><b>Figure 6.3</b></a>, a car of mass $m$ moves at a constant speed $v$ and negotiates a smooth curve of radius $r$ banked at an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal. To stay on track, the car should not accelerate either vertically or sideways. In other words, the following equations are satisfied
                        \begin{align}
                        N\, \sin\theta &= \frac{m v^2}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        N\, \cos\theta &=  m g
                        \end{align}
                By taking the ratio of the two equations above, we derive the following relation for the ideal velocity of a car negotiating a frictionless banked curve
                        \begin{equation}
                        \tan\theta = \frac{v^2}{r g}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">Chapter 6</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf#page=10" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">6.3.&nbsp; Centripetal Force</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-gravitation">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Uniform Circular Motion and Gravitation</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Universal Law of Gravitation</h2>

                <p>Newton reasoned that a planet follows a closed orbit because some force makes it fall from the straight-line path it would follow in absence of the force&mdash;and that successive falls from intended straight-line paths make the resultant path a closed orbit. And when he observed an apple fall, he wondered if the force that made the apple fall was also responsible for the fall of the planets from their intended straight-line paths. These thoughts eventually came together and resulted in <em>Newton&rsquo;s Universal Law of Gravitation</em>.</p>

                <p>Newton&rsquo;s discovery of the universal law of gravitation provides an interesting insight into the world of scientific activity. Observations, theories, and ideas from various scientists and philosophers float around for centuries as pieces of a puzzle, until a scientist arrives at the right time in history, puts the various pieces together, and makes the picture complete&mdash;and a great theory is born. Of course, Newton did not suddenly stumble on the law of gravitation one fine morning! Ideas of attractive forces between different bodies had been there from the early days of scientific reasoning, and several scientists, mathematicians and philosophers, before and during Newton&rsquo;s time, had ideas that could have led to the law of gravitation.</p>

                <p>Newton&rsquo;s universal law of gravitation, which is considered the crowning achievement of his work, states that
                <blockquote><b>Every particle in the universe attracts every other particle with a force, along the line joining them, that is proportional to the product of the their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.</b></blockquote>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit06-fig04">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit06-fig04.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 6.4</b>: Attractive forces of gravity between two spherical bodies of masses $m_1$ and $m_2$ separated by a distance $r$.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>So, if two masses $m_1$ and $m_2$ are separated by a distance $r$, then each one exerts an attractive force $F$ on the other along the line joining them, as shown in <a href="#unit06-fig04"><b>Figure 6.4</b></a>. The magnitude of the force is given by the equation
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= G\, \frac{m_1\, m_2}{r^2}
                        \end{align}
                where $G$ is known as the gravitational constant. Its value has been determined to be
                        \begin{align}
                        G &= 6.674 \times 10^{-11}\, \text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>For example, the force of gravity applied on the Moon by Earth (refer to <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/appendices.pdf#page=12" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Table C3</a></span> in the textbook) is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= ( 6.674\times 10^{-11}\, \text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2 )\times \frac{(5.9736\times 10^{24}\,\text{kg})\, (7.35\times 10^{22}\,\text{kg})}{(3.84\times 10^8\,\text{m})^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.99\times 10^{20}\, \text{N}
                        \end{align}
                directed towards Earth. The Moon applies an equal force on Earth, but it is directed towards the Moon. The separation $r = 3.84\times 10^8\,\text{m}$ is equal to the distance between the centre of Earth and the centre of the Moon.
                </p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit06-vid03.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 6.3</b>: Concept of gravity.
                </p>

                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf#page=17" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">6.5.&nbsp; Newton&rsquo;s Universal Law of Gravitation</a></li>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-satellites">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Uniform Circular Motion and Gravitation</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Satellites</h2>

                <p>To understand orbital motions of satellites, here is a fictitious example. A soldier is stationed at the top of a high cliff, close to the shore, to test a new and very powerful artillery that has adjustable projectile velocity. The soldier directs the barrel in the horizontal direction and fires shells into the ocean. He starts with a relatively small firing speed and gradually increases it. </p>

                <p>When the firing range is small, relative to the size of the Earth, an observer would see normal projectiles as shown in <a href="#unit06-fig05"><b>Figure 6.5a</b></a>. However, as the firing speed increases, an expert evaluating the test must take the curvature of Earth in consideration, as in <a href="#unit06-fig05"><b>Figure 6.5b</b></a>. </p>

                <p>If the soldier keeps increasing the projectile velocity, the shell would travel a relatively large distance around the globe before it reaches sea level. Eventually, when the shell is given the right initial velocity, it will remain at the same altitude above the ocean while traveling in a circular path. In such case, the soldier has actually placed a satellite in orbit, which (neglecting air resistance) would continue to rotate around the planet as shown in <a href="#unit06-fig05"><b>Figure 6.5c</b></a>. The soldier must be careful here, because if he does not change his location at the right time, the shell would come from the back and destroys his expensive artillery!</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit06-fig05">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit06-fig05.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 6.5</b>: Motion of an artillery shell shot horizontally at different initial velocities.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <h3>PhET Simulation: Gravity And Orbits</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf#page=14" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">textbook</a>, &ldquo;move the sun, earth, moon and space station to see how it affects their gravitational forces and orbital paths. Visualize the sizes and distances between different heavenly bodies, and turn off gravity to see what would happen without it!&rdquo;</p>

                <p><div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 200px;"><a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/html/gravity-and-orbits/latest/gravity-and-orbits_en.html" target="_blank" style="text-decoration: none;"><img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/html/gravity-and-orbits/latest/gravity-and-orbits-600.png" alt="Gravity And Orbits" style="border: none;" width="300" height="200"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 60px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);"></div><table style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 60px;"><tr><td style="text-align: center; color: #000; font-size: 24px; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Click to Run</td></tr></table></a></div>

                <div class="source">Source: <a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/gravity-and-orbits" target="_blank">PhET Interactive Simulations</a>, University of Colorado Boulder.</div>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-examples">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Uniform Circular Motion and Gravitation</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Examples</h2>

                    <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of examples relevant to the content of <span style="white-space: nowrap;">Unit 6</span>. Make an attempt to answer each question on your own, before you read through the solution provided.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-e01">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 6, Example 1</div>
                <div class="panel-body">Makoua is a town in the Republic of the Congo that lies directly on the equator. (a) Determine the linear speed of a person living in Makoua, due to Earth&rsquo;s rotation about its axis? Compare your answer to the linear speeds of a person in (b) New York City (latitude $40.71^\circ\,\text{N}$), and a person in (c) Yellowknife (latitude $62.45^\circ\,\text{N}$).
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e01_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e01_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01a_btn">Solution (a) </button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01b_btn">Solution (b) </button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01c_btn">Solution (c) </button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $463.7\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $351.5\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                      <p>(c) $214.5\,\text{m/s}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit06-e01s.png" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E6.1s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>We know that Earth spins uniformly about its axis making a complete rotation in one day. In other words, a body fixed to Earth performs an angular displacement of $\Delta\theta = 2\pi$ in a time interval $\Delta t = 24.00\,\text{h}$. So, the angular velocity of the body is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega & = \frac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{2\pi}{24.00\,\text{h}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{2\pi}{24.00\,\color{red}{\text{h}}} \times \frac{1\,\color{red}{\text{h}}}{3{,}600\,\text{s}}  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 7.272 \times 10^{-5}\,\text{rad/s}
                        \end{align}
                For the <a href="../textbook/appendices.pdf#page=12" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">radius of Earth</a>, we take the average value
                        \begin{equation}
                        R_\text{E} = 6.376 \times 10^6\,\text{m}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>The linear distance covered per day is equal to the length of the circular path traced by the body. This is equal to the circumference of the circle whose radius is the perpendicular distance between the body and the axis of rotation, as shown in <b>Figure E6.1s</b>. From the diagram, it is obvious that locations at higher latitudes move in smaller circles than points at lower latitudes. Therefore, the linear speed of a point near the equator is much larger than the linear speed of a point close to either pole.</p>

                <p>Since Makoua lies on the equator, a person living in this town rotates about Earth&rsquo;s axis in a circle whose radius is equal to that of Earth, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        R_\text{Makoua} = R_\text{E}
                        \end{equation}
                So, the linear speed of the person is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{Makoua} & = R_\text{Makoua} \times \omega \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        & = \left(6.376 \times 10^6\,\text{m}\right) \left(7.272 \times 10^{-5}\,\text{rad/s}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 463.7\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p><a href="http://www1.nyc.gov/" target="_blank">New York City</a>, at latitude $40.71^\circ\,\text{N}$, rotates about Earth&rsquo;s axis (see <b>Figure E6.1s</b>) in a circle of radius
                        \begin{align}
                        R_\text{NY} & = R_\text{E} \times \cos 40.71^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.833 \times 10^6\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                So, a person in the city has a linear speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{NY} & = R_\text{NY} \times \omega \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 351.5\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                 </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01c">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>For the northern <a href="https://www.yellowknife.ca/" target="_blank">city of Yellowknife</a>, at latitude $62.45^\circ\,\text{N}$, the radius of rotation about Earth&rsquo;s axis is
                        \begin{align}
                        R_\text{Yellowknife} & = R_\text{E} \times \cos 62.45^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.949 \times 10^6\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                which corresponds to a linear speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{Yellowknife} & = R_\text{Yellowknife} \times \omega \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 214.5\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                 </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-e02">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 6, Example 2</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A merry-go-round is $2.30\,\text{m}$ in diameter. Calculate the centripetal acceleration of a child, sitting close to the edge, when the merry-go-round makes $20.0\,\text{rev/min}$.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e02_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02_btn">Solution</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$5.04\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>Here, the child rotates in a horizontal circle, of radius $r = 1.15\,\text{m}$, with uniform <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-angular-quantities">angular velocity</a> of
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= 20.0\,\text{rev/min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  \frac{20.0\,\color{red}{\text{rev}}}{\color{blue}{\text{min}}} \times \frac{2\pi\, \text{rad}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{rev}}} \times \frac{1\,\color{blue}{\text{min}}}{60\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.09\,\text{rad/s}
                        \end{align}
                The <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-circular-motion">centripetal acceleration</a> of the child is, therefore, equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        a_\text{c} &= r\, \omega^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(1.15\,\text{m}\right) \left(2.09\,\text{rad/s}\right)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.04\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-e03">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 6, Example 3</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A level (unbanked) curve of radius $93.0\,\text{m}$ is designed so that a car at a speed of $97.2\,\text{km/h}$ can turn safely in normal conditions. What is the coefficient of static friction between the tires and the road?
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e03_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e03_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03_btn">Solution</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.800$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit06-e03s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E6.3s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>According to <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-first-law">Newton&rsquo;s first law of motion</a>, the car has the tendency to keep moving in a straight line and go off track when the road bends. However, this requires the car to slide sideways on the road. Actually that is what sometimes happens during icy road conditions. During normal driving conditions, however, the <a href="../unit05/index05.html#unit05-friction">force of static friction</a> between the tires and the road resists the sliding motion, so that the tires continue to roll forward. In this case, the force of static friction provides the required <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-circular-motion">centripetal force</a>, which allows the car to turn while staying in the same lane. Note that if the speed is too high, the required centripetal acceleration will become larger than that which the maximum force of static friction can provide. The car will slide off the road in this case.</p>

                <p>The car in <b>Figure E6.3s</b> moves forward (into the page) at a speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= 97.2\, \text{km/h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{97.2\,\color{red}{\text{km}}}{\color{blue}{\text{h}}} \times \frac{1000\, \text{m}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{km}}} \times \frac{1\,\color{blue}{\text{h}}}{3{,}600\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 27.0\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                The car also negotiates a level curve of radius $r = 93.0\,\text{m}$ bending to the left. To remain on track, the car must experience a centripetal acceleration, directed towards the centre of the curve, with a magnitude of
                        \begin{align}
                        a_\text{c} &= \frac{v^2}{r}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(27.0\,\text{m/s})^2}{93.0\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 7.84\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \label{unit06_e03_ac}
                        \end{align}
                The necessary centripetal force, in this case, is provided by the force of static friction ($f_\text{s}$), which is directed perpendicular to the direction of motion (towards the centre of the curve) as shown in <b>Figure E6.3s</b>.</p>

                <p>For the car to complete the turn safely, the required centripetal force cannot exceed the maximum force of static friction between the tires and the road. So, when the car is on the verge of slipping, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{c} &= f_\text{s max}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad m\, a_\text{c} &= \mu_\text{s}\, N \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad m\, a_\text{c} &= \mu_\text{s}\, m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad a_\text{c} &= \mu_\text{s}\, g
                        \label{unit06_e03_Fc}
                        \end{align}
                where $N$ is the <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-normal-force">normal force</a> applied by the road on the car in the upward direction. So, the coefficient of static friction must then have a minimum value equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \mu_\text{s} &= \frac{a_\text{c}}{g}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{7.84\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2}{9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.800
                        \end{align}
                <p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-e04">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 6, Example 4</div>
                <div class="panel-body">Two celestial bodies  form an isolated system in a remote region in space. When they are separated by a distance of $5.00\,\text{km}$ the two bodies attract each other with a gravitational force of magnitude $2.67\,\text{N}$. If the total mass of the system is $2.50\times 10^9\,\text{kg}$, calculate the mass of each body.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e04_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e04_btn">Solution</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.500\times 10^9\, \text{kg},\; 2.00\times 10^9\, \text{kg}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>The two bodies (of masses $m_1$ and $m_2$) exert a gravitational force of magnitude $F = 2.67\,\text{N}$ on one another, when they are separated by a distance of $r = 5.00\times 10^3 \,\text{m}$. By applying <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-gravitation">Newton&rsquo;s universal law of gravitation</a>,
                        \begin{equation}
                        F = G\, \frac{m_1\, m_2}{r^2}
                        \end{equation}
                we have
                        \begin{align}
                        2.67\,\text{N} &= (6.674\times 10^{-11}\, \text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2) \times \frac{m_1\, m_2}{(5.00\times 10^3 \,\text{m})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad m_2 &= \frac{1.00\times 10^{18}\, \text{kg}^2}{m_1}
                        \label{unit06_e04_m2}
                        \end{align}
                We also know that the sum of the individual masses of the two bodies is equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        m_1 + m_2 = 2.50\times 10^9\,\text{kg}
                        \label{unit06_e04_m1_plus_m2}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>By substituting from Equation \ref{unit06_e04_m2} into Equation \ref{unit06_e04_m1_plus_m2} we have
                        \begin{align}
                        m_1 + \left(\frac{1.00\times 10^{18}\, \text{kg}^2}{m_1}\right) &= 2.50\times 10^9\,\text{kg} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad m_1^2 - (2.50\times 10^9\,\text{kg})\, m_1 + 1.00\times 10^{18}\,\text{kg}^2 &= 0
                        \end{align}
                The two solutions of the quadratic equation above are
                        \begin{equation}
                        m_1 = 5.00\times 10^8\, \text{kg} \quad \text{and} \quad 2.00\times 10^9\, \text{kg}
                        \end{equation}
                By substituting either solution into Equation \ref{unit06_e04_m2}, we find that the masses of the two objects are
                $0.500\times 10^9\, \text{kg}$ and $2.00\times 10^9\, \text{kg}$.
                <p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 5 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-e05">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 6, Example 5</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A solid sphere of mass $m_1 = 5.00\,\text{kg}$ has the $xy$ coordinates $(0, 3.00\,\text{m})$ and another sphere of mass $m_2 = 13.0\,\text{kg}$ has the coordinates $(4.00\,\text{m}, 0)$, as shown in <b>Figure E6.5</b>. Calculate the magnitude and direction of the net gravitational force, due to both spheres, on a particle of mass $m_\text{p} = 270\,\text{g}$ located at the origin.
                        <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit06-e05.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure E6.5</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e05_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e05_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e05_btn">Solution</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="interactive-e05_btn">Interactive Activity</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$1.77\times 10^{-11}\,\text{N},\; 34.4^\circ$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit06-e05s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E6.5s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e05">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>As indicated in <b>Figure E6.5s</b>, Sphere 1 applies a gravitational force on the particle in the positive $y$ direction. According to Newton&rsquo;s universal law of gravitation, the magnitude of this force is equal to
                                \begin{equation}
                                F_1 = G\, \frac{m_1\, m_\text{p}}{r_1^2}
                                \end{equation}
                        where $r_1 = 3.00\,\text{m}$ is the distance between Sphere 1 and the particle. So, we calculate
                                \begin{align}
                                F_1 &= (6.674\times 10^{-11}\, \text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2)\times \frac{(5.00\,\text{kg})\, (0.270\,\text{kg})}{(3.00\,\text{m})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 1.00\times 10^{-11}\,\text{N}
                                \end{align}
                        Similarly, Sphere 2 applies a gravitational force on the particle, in the positive $x$ direction, of magnitude
                                \begin{align}
                                F_2 &= G\, \frac{m_2\, m_\text{p}}{r_2^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= (6.674\times 10^{-11} \text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2)\times \frac{(13.0\,\text{kg})\, (0.270\,\text{kg})}{(4.00\,\text{m})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 1.46\times 10^{-11}\,\text{N}
                                \end{align}
                        where $r_2 = 4.00\,\text{m}$ is the distance between Sphere 2 and the particle.</p>

                        <p>As shown in <b>Figure E6.5s</b>, the two forces are perpendicular to each other and the net force of gravity on the particle has a magnitude of
                                \begin{align}
                                F_\text{net} &= \sqrt{F_1^2 + F_2^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 1.77\times 10^{-11}\,\text{N}
                                \end{align}
                        and makes an angle of
                                \begin{align}
                                \theta &= \tan^{-1}\left( \frac{F_1}{F_2} \right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 34.4^\circ
                                \end{align}
                        with the positive $x$ direction.
                        <p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="interactive-e05">
                <div class="panel-heading">Interactive Activity</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p class="centerText"><a href="./unit06-e05i.cdf"><img  src="unit06-e05i.png" alt="image"></a><br>
                    <br><b>Figure E6.5i</b></p>
                </div>

                    <p>Use <a href="https://www.wolfram.com/cdf-player/" target="_blank">Wolfram CDF Player</a>
                    to open the interactive diagram <a href="./unit06-e05i.cdf"><b>Figure E6.5i</b></a>.</p>

                    <p>Answer the questions below and use the interactive diagram to check your calculations. Click an drag the particle to different locations.</p>

                        <p>
                        <ol>
                        <li>Calculate the magnitude and direction of the net gravitational force, due to both spheres, on the particle if it is located at the coordinates $(-1.00\,\text{m}, 0)$.</li>
                        <li>Repeat the calculation, when the particle is located at the coordinates $(3.00\,\text{m}, 3.50\,\text{m})$.</li>
                      </ol>

                    </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 6 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit06-e06">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 6, Example 6</div>
                <div class="panel-body">What is the altitude and the speed of a satellite that completes four revolutions per day around Earth?
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e06_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e06_btn">Solution</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$10{,}400\, \text{km},\; 4.88\, \text{km/s}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e06">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>To perform a uniform circular motion (of radius $r$) around Earth, the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-gravitation">force of gravity</a> must be equal to the required centripetal force, or
                                \begin{equation}
                                \frac{m\, v^2}{r} = G\, \frac{m\, M_\text{E}}{r^2}
                                \end{equation}
                        where $M_\text{E} = 5.9736\times 10^{24}\, \text{kg}$ is Earth&rsquo;s mass. In the equation above, the mass ($m$) of the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-satellites">satellite</a> cancels out and its speed is expressed as
                                \begin{equation}
                                v^2 = \frac{G\, M_\text{E}}{r}
                                \label{ch06_e06_v2}
                                \end{equation}
                        Since the satellite&rsquo;s speed is equal to the distance traveled in one revolution divided by the period of rotation ($T$), we can write
                                \begin{equation}
                                v = \frac{2 \pi r}{T}
                                \label{ch06_e06_v}
                                \end{equation}
                        By substituting from Equation \ref{ch06_e06_v} into Equation \ref{ch06_e06_v2}, we can derive the following expression
                                \begin{align}
                                \left(\frac{2 \pi r}{T}\right)^2 &= \frac{G\, M_\text{E}}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                \Rightarrow\quad r^3 &= \frac{G\, M_\text{E}\, T^2}{4 \pi^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                \Rightarrow\quad r &= \left( \frac{G\, M_\text{E}\, T^2}{4 \pi^2} \right)^{1/3}
                                \label{ch06_e06_rt}
                                \end{align}
                        </p>

                        <p>Since the satellite completes four revolutions per day, it has a period of rotation
                                \begin{align}
                                T &= \frac{24.0\,\text{h}}{4} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 6.00\,\text{h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 2.16\times 10^4\,\text{s}
                                \label{ch06_e06_T}
                                \end{align}
                        By substituting from Equation \ref{ch06_e06_T} into Equation \ref{ch06_e06_rt}, we calculate the radius of the satellite&rsquo;s orbit to be
                                \begin{align}
                                 r&= \left[ \frac{(6.674\times 10^{-11} \,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2)\, (5.9736\times 10^{24}\, \text{kg})\, (2.16\times 10^4\,\text{s})^2}{4 \pi^2} \right]^{1/3} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 1.68 \times 10^7\, \text{m}
                                \label{ch06_e06_r}
                                \end{align}
                        By subtracting Earth&rsquo;s radius ($R_\text{E} = 6.376\times 10^6\,\text{m}$), the altitude of the satellite is calculated to be
                                \begin{align}
                                 h&= r - R_\text{E} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 1.04 \times 10^7\, \text{m} \quad (\text{or}\; 10{,}400\, \text{km})
                                \end{align}
                        </p>

                        <p>We can now calculate the satellite&rsquo;s speed by substituting from Equation \ref{ch06_e06_r} into Equation \ref{ch06_e06_v}. So, we have
                                \begin{align}
                                v &= \frac{2\pi\, (1.68 \times 10^7\, \text{m})}{2.16\times 10^4\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 4.88 \times 10^3\, \text{m/s} \quad (\text{or}\; 4.88\, \text{km/s})
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-conceptual-questions">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Uniform Circular Motion and Gravitation</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Conceptual Questions</h2>

                  <p>Following, are detailed solutions of a number of conceptual questions selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf#page=31" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">Chapter 6</a> in the textbook.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-q01">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Question 1</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">There is an analogy between rotational and linear physical quantities. What rotational quantities are analogous to distance and velocity?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q01_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q01_btn">Explanation</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$\Delta \theta,\; \omega$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>In rotational kinematics, the rotation angle $\Delta \theta$ is analogue to distance in linear kinematics, while the angular velocity $\omega$ corresponds to linear velocity. The analogy becomes clearer when we write the corresponding equation for average velocity in each case
                                \begin{equation}
                                v = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}
                                \end{equation}
                      and
                                \begin{equation}
                                \omega = \frac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t}
                                \end{equation}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-q02">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Question 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Can centripetal acceleration change the speed of circular motion? Explain.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q02_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q02_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>No</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>By definition, <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-circular-motion">centripetal acceleration</a> is directed towards the centre of the circular path. As a result, the change in velocity is always perpendicular to the direction of motion, which causes velocity to change direction without affecting its magnitude.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 6 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-q06">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Question 6</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Race car drivers routinely cut corners as shown in <b>Figure Q6.6</b>. Explain how this allows the curve to be taken at the greatest speed.
                    <hr>
                    <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch06-q06.svg" alt="image"><br>
                    <br><b>Figure Q6.6</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q06_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The maximum speed at which a car can negotiate a curve safely is when the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-circular-motion">centripetal force</a> is equal to the maximum force of <a href="../unit05/index05.html#unit05-friction">static friction</a> between the tires and the road. If the car travels faster, it will begin to slip. By cutting the corner, the car effectively travels in a an arc with larger radius, requiring less centripetal force. So, if the two vehicles experience the maximum centripetal force allowed by static friction, the car cutting the corner travels faster.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 21 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-q21">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Question 21</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Draw a free body diagram for a satellite in an elliptical orbit showing why its speed increases as it approaches its parent body and decreases as it moves away.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-q21_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q21_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-q21">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch06-q21s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure Q6.21s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q21">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>For an elliptical orbit, the force of gravity is not always perpendicular to the velocity of the satellite. From <b>Figure Q6.21s</b>, we see that as the satellite moves closer to the parent body the force of gravity has a component in the direction of the velocity which causes the speed to increase. However, as the satellite moves away from the parent body, a component of the gravitational force acts in the opposite direction of motion which slows the satellite.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-problems">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Uniform Circular Motion and Gravitation</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Solutions of Selected Problems</h2>
                    <p>Next are detailed solutions to a number of problems selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf#page=35" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">Chapter 6</a> in the textbook. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve each problem independently, before you read through the solution provided. You are also advised to make a second attempt to solve the problem if your answer is different from the one posted. If you reach an impasse and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p02">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Microwave ovens rotate at a rate of about $6\,\text{rev/min}$. What is this in revolutions per second? What is the angular velocity in radians per second?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer02_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution02_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer02" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.1\,\text{rev/s},\; 0.6\,\text{rad/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution02" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since there is $60\,\text{seconds}$ in one minute, the rotation rate of the microwave oven tray can be expressed as
                                \begin{align}
                                \omega &= 6\,\text{rev/min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &=  \frac{6\,\text{rev}}{\color{red}{\text{min}}} \times \frac{1\,\color{red}{\text{min}}}{60\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 0.1\,\text{rev/s}
                                \end{align}
                       Also, since there is $2\pi\,\text{rad}$ in one revolution, the angular velocity can also be expressed in radians per seconds as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= \frac{0.1\,\color{red}{\text{rev}}}{\text{s}} \times \frac{2\pi\, \text{rad}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{rev}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.6\,\text{rad/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 6 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p06">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 6</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">In lacrosse, a ball is thrown from a net on the end of a stick by rotating the stick and forearm about the elbow. If the angular velocity of the ball about the elbow joint is $30.0\,\text{rad/s}$ and the ball is $1.30\,\text{m}$ from the elbow joint, what is the velocity of the ball?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer06_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram06_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution06_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$39.0\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch06-p06s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P6.6s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution06" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Just before it is released, the ball has an angular velocity $\omega = 30.0\,\text{rad/s}$, and a radius of rotation $r = 1.30\,\text{m}$, as shown in <b>Figure P6.6s</b>. So, the ball leaves the stick with a linear velocity of
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= r\, \omega \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (1.30\,\text{m})\, (30.0\,\text{rad/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 39.0\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 10 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p10">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 10</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A fairground ride spins its occupants inside a flying saucer-shaped container. If the horizontal circular path the riders follow has an $8.00\,\text{m}$ radius, at how many revolutions per minute will the riders be subjected to a centripetal acceleration $1.50$ times that due to gravity?</div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer10_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution10_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$12.9\, \text{rev/min}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The riders rotate uniformly near the walls of the saucer-shaped container and follow a circular path of radius $r = 8.00\,\text{m}$. The centripetal acceleration ($a_\text{c}$) of the riders is related to their angular velocity ($\omega$) by the equation
                                \begin{equation}
                                 a_\text{c} = r\, \omega ^2
                                 \end{equation}
                      So, a centripetal acceleration of
                                \begin{equation}
                                a_\text{c} = 1.50\, g
                                \end{equation}
                      is generated when the fairground ride spins with angular velocity equal to
                                \begin{align}
                                \omega &= \sqrt{\frac{a_\text{c}}{r}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \sqrt{\frac{1.50 \times 9.80\,\text{m/s}^2}{8.00\,\text{m}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 1.355\,\text{rad/s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &=  \frac{1.355\,\color{red}{\text{rad}}}{\color{blue}{\text{s}}} \times \frac{1\,\text{rev}}{2\pi\,\color{red}{\text{rad}}} \times \frac{60\,\color{blue}{\text{s}}}{1\,\text{min}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 12.9\, \text{rev/min}
                                \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 14 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p14">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 14</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">An ordinary workshop grindstone has a radius of $7.50\,\text{cm}$ and rotates at $6500\,\text{rev/min}$. (a) Calculate the centripetal acceleration at its edge in meters per second squared and convert it to multiples of $g$. (b) What is the linear speed of a point on its edge?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer14_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution14a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution14b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer14">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $3.55\times 10^3\, g$</p>
                      <p>(b) $51.1\, \text{m/s}$<p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The grindstone, of radius $r = 0.0750\,\text{m}$, rotates about its central axis with angular velocity
                                \begin{align}
                                \omega &= 6{,}500\,\text{rev/min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{6{,}500\,\color{red}{\text{rev}}}{\color{blue}{\text{min}}} \times \frac{2\pi\, \text{rad}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{rev}}} \times \frac{1\,\color{blue}{\text{min}}}{60\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 681\,\text{rad/s}
                                \end{align}
                        Using this information, we can calculate the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-circular-motion">centripetal acceleration</a> of a point on the edge of the grindstone to be
                                \begin{align}
                                a_\text{c} &= r\, \omega^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= (0.0750\,\text{m})\, (681\,\text{rad/s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 3.47 \times 10^4 \,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                        The answer can be expressed as multiples of $g$ as follows
                                \begin{align}
                                a_\text{c} &= (3.47 \times 10^4\, \color{red}{\text{m}/\text{s}^2}) \times \frac{g}{9.80\, \color{red}{\text{m}/\text{s}^2}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 3.55\times 10^3\, g
                                \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Since we know the angular velocity and radius of the grindstone, we calculate the linear velocity of a point on the edge to be
                                \begin{align}
                                v &= r\, \omega \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= (0.0750\,\text{m})\, (681\,\text{rad/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 51.1\, \text{m/s}
                                \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 19 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p19">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 19</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A rotating space station is said to create &ldquo;artificial gravity&rdquo;&mdash;a loosely-defined term used for an acceleration that would be crudely similar to gravity. The outer wall of the rotating space station would become a floor for the astronauts, and centripetal acceleration supplied by the floor would allow astronauts to exercise and maintain muscle and bone strength more naturally than in non-rotating space environments. If the space station is $200\,\text{m}$ in diameter, what angular velocity would produce an &ldquo;artificial gravity&rdquo; of $9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ at the rim?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer19_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution19_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer19">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.313\,\text{rad/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution19">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>A circular space station, of radius of $r = 100\,\text{m}$ and angular velocity $\omega$, can produce &ldquo;artificial gravity&rdquo; when the centripetal acceleration at the walls is equal to $g$, or
                                \begin{equation}
                                g =  r\, \omega^2
                                \end{equation}
                    By solving for $\omega$, we have
                                \begin{align}
