                                \omega &= \sqrt{\frac{g}{r}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \sqrt{\frac{9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2}{100\,\text{m}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 0.313\,\text{rad/s} \quad (\approx 3\,\text{rev}/\text{min})
                                \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 20 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p20">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 20</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">At takeoff, a commercial jet has a $60.0\,\text{m/s}$ speed. Its tires have a diameter of $0.850\,\text{m}$. (a) At how many $\text{rev/min}$ are the tires rotating? (b) What is the centripetal acceleration at the edge of the tire? (c) With what force must a determined $1.00\times10^{-15}\,\text{kg}$ bacterium cling to the rim? (d) Take the ratio of this force to the bacterium&rsquo;s weight.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer20_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20d_btn">Solution (d)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer20" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1.35 \times 10^3 \,\text{rev/min}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $8.47 \times 10^3 \,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                      <p>(c) $8.47\times 10^{-12}\, \text{N}$</p>
                      <p>(d) $864$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Before it takes off, the commercial jet covers a distance of $60.0\,\text{m}$ on the runway in one second. With a tire radius of $r = 0.425\,\text{m}$, each wheel makes a number of revolutions (during the same period) equal to
                                \begin{align}
                                \text{Tire revolutions in one second} &= \frac{60.0\,\text{m}}{2 \pi r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{60.0\,\text{m}}{2 \pi\, (0.425\,\text{m})} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 22.5\, \text{rev}
                                \end{align}
                    So, the tires rotate with angular velocity of
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= 22.5\, \text{rev/s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{22.5\, \text{rev}}{\color{red}{\text{s}}} \times \frac{60\,\color{red}{\text{s}}}{1\,\text{min}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.35 \times 10^3 \,\text{rev/min}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The linear velocity ($v$) of a point on the edge of the tire, relative to its centre, is equal to the forward speed of the plane. So, the centripetal acceleration at the edge of the tire can be calculated as follows
                                \begin{align}
                                a_\text{c} &= \frac{v^2}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{(60.0\,\text{m/s})^2}{0.425\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 8.47 \times 10^3 \,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the bacterium ($m = 1.00 \times 10^{-15}\,\text{kg}$) will have the same centripetal acceleration as the edge of the tire, the centripetal force produced by clinging to the rim will be
                                \begin{align}
                                F_\text{c} &= m\, a_\text{c} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= (1.00\times 10^{-15}\,\text{kg})\, (8.47 \times 10^3 \,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 8.47\times 10^{-12}\, \text{N}
                                \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20d" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (d)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The weight of the bacterium is equal to
                                \begin{align}
                                w &= mg\nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= (1.00\times 10^{-15}\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m/s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 9.80\times 10^{-15}\, \text{N}
                                \end{align}
                         By taking the ratio of $F_\text{c}$ to $w$, we find
                                \begin{align}
                                \frac{F_\text{c}}{w} &= \frac{8.47\times 10^{-12}\, \text{N}}{9.80\times 10^{-15}\, \text{N}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 864
                                \end{align}
                         So, to remain on the edge of tire, the bacterium need to hold on with force that is $864$ times greater that its weight!
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 22 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p22">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 22</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A mother pushes her child on a swing so that his speed is $9.00\, \text{m/s}$ at the lowest point of his path. The swing is suspended $2.00\, \text{m}$ above the child&rsquo;s center of mass. (a) What is the centripetal acceleration of the child at the low point? (b) What force does the child exert on the seat if his mass is $18.0\,\text{kg}$? (c) What is unreasonable about these results? (d) Which premises are unreasonable or inconsistent?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer22_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram22_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution22a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution22b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution22cd_btn">Solution (c & d)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer22">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $40.5\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                        <p>(b) $905\,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram22">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch06-p22s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P6.22s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution22a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>At the lowest point, the child has a linear velocity of $v = 9.00\,\text{m/s}$, and his axis of mass is at a distance $r = 2.00\,\text{m}$ from the center of rotation. This means the child experiences a centripetal acceleration of
                        \begin{align}
                        a_\text{c} &= \frac{v^2}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(9.00\,\text{m/s})^2}{2.00\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 40.5\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution22b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>From the free-body diagram in <b>Figure P6.22s</b>, we see that the child experiences two vertical forces: His weight ($w = mg$) in the downward direction and the upward force ($T$) exerted by the seat. Note that the later force is equal to the tension in the rope, assuming the seat to have negligible mass. So, at the low point, the child experiences a net upward force  given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{c} = T - w
                        \end{equation}
                    which actually provides the required centripetal force to rotate the child about the axis of the swing. Therefore, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{c} = m\, a_\text{c}
                        \end{equation}
                    </p>

                    <p>From <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-third-law">Newton&rsquo;s third law</a> of motion, if the seat exerts an upward force $T$ on the child, he must react by exerting an equal downward force on the seat. The magnitude of this force is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        T &= F_\text{c} + w \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m\, a_\text{c} + m\, g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m\, (a_\text{c} + g) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (18.0\,\text{kg})\, (40.5\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2 + 9.80\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 905\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution22cd">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c & d)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The contact force between the child and the seat is too large, more than five times his weight! In addition, the high speed of the swing at the low point can carry the child over the top! This makes the situation in this problem not safe and, therefore, unreasonable.</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 25 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p25">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 25</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">What is the ideal banking angle for a gentle turn of $1.20\,\text{km}$ radius on a highway with a $105 \,\text{km/h}$ speed limit (about $65\,\text{mi/h}$), assuming everyone travels at the limit?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer25_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram25_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution25_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer25">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$4.14^\circ$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram25">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch06-p25s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P6.25s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution25">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The free-body diagram in <b>Figure P6.25s</b> shows a car on the highway moving into the page and turning to our left on the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit06-curves">banked curve</a> of radius $r = 1{,}200\,\text{m}$. If the car is to turn at a speed $v$ without slipping (i.e., staying in the same lane), it requires a centripetal force
                                \begin{equation}
                                F_\text{c} = \frac{m\, v^2}{r}
                                \label{ch06_p25_Fc}
                                \end{equation}
                    where $m$ is the mass of the car. Note that this force is directed to the left (in the horizontal direction) towards the center of the curve.</p>

                    <p>Assuming no friction between the tires and the road, the centripetal force required to complete the turn must be provided by the horizontal component of the normal force. So, we have
                                \begin{equation}
                                N\, \sin\theta = F_\text{c}
                                \label{ch06_p25_Nsin}
                                \end{equation}
                    If the car is not to slip sideways (up or down the inclined road), the net vertical force must be equal to zero. So, the vertical component of the normal force is balanced by the car&rsquo;s weight, or
                                \begin{equation}
                                N\, \cos\theta =  m g
                                \label{ch06_p25_Ncos}
                                \end{equation}
                    By dividing Equation \ref{ch06_p25_Nsin} by Equation \ref{ch06_p25_Ncos}, we have
                                \begin{equation}
                                \tan\theta = \frac{F_\text{c}}{m g}
                                \label{ch06_p25_tan}
                                \end{equation}
                    If we now substitute from Equation \ref{ch06_p25_Fc} into Equation \ref{ch06_p25_tan}, we see that the equation for an ideally banked curve is
                                \begin{equation}
                                \tan\theta = \frac{v^2}{rg}
                                \label{ch06_p25_thanv2g}
                                \end{equation}
                    </p>

                    <p>The speed of vehicles taking this turn is assumed to be that of the speed limit, which is
                                \begin{align}
                                v &= 105\, \text{km/h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{105\,\color{red}{\text{km}}}{\color{blue}{\text{h}}} \times \frac{1000\, \text{m}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{km}}} \times \frac{1\,\color{blue}{\text{h}}}{3{,}600\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 29.2\,\text{m/s}
                                \end{align}
                    So, the ideal banking angle is calculated as follows
                                \begin{align}
                                \tan\theta &= \frac{(29.2\,\text{m/s})^2}{(1{,}200\,\text{m})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                \Rightarrow\quad \theta &= 4.14^\circ
                                \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 30 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p30">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 30</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">If a car takes a banked curve at less than the ideal speed, friction is needed to keep it from sliding toward the inside of the curve (a real problem on icy mountain roads). (a) Calculate the ideal speed to take a $100\,\text{m}$ radius curve banked at $15.0^\circ$. (b) What is the minimum coefficient of friction needed for a frightened driver to take the same curve at $20.0\,\text{km/h}$?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer30_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram30_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution30a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution30b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $58.3\,\text{km/h}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $0.234$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch06-p30s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P6.30s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Referring to the solution of <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#chapter06-p25">Problem 25</a>, we see that the ideal speed to take a banked curve, without the need for friction, is given by (Equation \ref{ch06_p25_thanv2g}) or
                                \begin{equation}
                                \tan\theta = \frac{v^2}{rg}
                                \end{equation}
                    So, for a curve of radius $r = 100\,\text{m}$ banked at $\theta = 15.0^\circ$, we can calculate the ideal speed to round the curve safely, even in extremely slippery conditions, to be
                                \begin{align}
                                v &= \sqrt{r g\, \tan{\theta}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \sqrt{(100\,\text{m})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, \tan{15.0^\circ}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 16.2\,\text{m/s} \quad (\text{or}\; 58.3\,\text{km/h})
                                \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>A driver taking the same curve at a speed of $v = 20.0\,\text{km/h} = 5.56\,\text{m/s}$, which is much less than the ideal speed, will have the tendency to slide towards the centre of the curve (or to our left in <b>Figure P6.30s</b>). This is actually what happens when the road becomes a smooth icy surface. In this case, the horizontal component of the normal force is greater than the required centripetal force.</p>

                    <p>To stay on track, static friction needs to act up the inclined road to prevent slipping, as shown in the free-body diagram in <b>Figure P6.30s</b>.The magnitude of the force of friction is given by
										\begin{equation}
f_\text{s} = \mu_\text{s}\, N
\end{equation}
where $N$ is the normal force. If no slipping occurs, the car remains in the same lane and experiences zero net force in the vertical direction, or

                                \begin{align}
                               N\, \cos\theta + f_\text{s}\, \sin\theta - m g &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
															 \Rightarrow\quad N\, (\cos\theta + \mu_\text{s} \sin\theta) &=  m g
                                \label{ch06_p30_Fnety}
                                \end{align}
                  Note that the centripetal force required to complete the turn is equal to the net horizontal force on the car. So, referring to <b>Figure P6.30s</b>, we can also write
                                \begin{align}
                                N\, \sin\theta - f_\text{s}\, \cos\theta &= \frac{m\, v^2}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
																\Rightarrow\quad N\, (\sin\theta - \mu_\text{s} \cos\theta) &= \frac{m v^2}{r}
																\label{ch06_p30_Fnetx}
                                \end{align}</p>
																
<p>If we divide Equation \ref{ch06_p30_Fnety} by Equation \ref{ch06_p30_Fnetx}, we have
	\begin{align}
\frac{\cos\theta + \mu_\text{s} \sin\theta}{\sin\theta - \mu_\text{s} \cos\theta} &= \frac{r g}{v^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
\Rightarrow\quad \frac{\cos 15.0^\circ + \mu_\text{s} \sin 15.0^\circ}{\sin 15.0^\circ - \mu_\text{s} \cos 15.0^\circ}&= \frac{(100\,\text{m})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)}{(5.56\,\text{m/s})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
&= 31.752
\end{align}
By solving for $\mu_\text{s}$, we determine the minimum safe value of the coefficient of static friction to be
\begin{equation}
\mu_\text{s} = 0.234
\end{equation}</p>


                  

                  
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 34 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p34">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 34</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) Calculate the magnitude of the acceleration due to gravity on the surface of Earth due to the Moon. (b) Calculate the magnitude of the acceleration due to gravity at Earth due to the Sun. (c) Take the ratio of the Moon&rsquo;s acceleration to the Sun&rsquo;s and comment on why the tides are predominantly due to the Moon in spite of this number.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer34_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution34a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution34b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution34c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer34">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $3.33\times 10^{-5}\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2$ </p>
                      <p>(b) $5.93\times 10^{-3}\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2$ </p>
                      <p>(c) $178$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The Moon, of mass $M_\text{M} = 7.35\times 10^{22}\,\text{kg}$, is a distance $r_\text{M} = 3.84\times 10^8\,\text{m}$ from the Earth (refer to <span style="white-space: nowrap;"><a href="../textbook/appendices.pdf#page=12" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Table C3</a></span> in the textbook). So, the acceleration due to gravity at Earth due to the Moon is calculated to be
                                \begin{align}
                                a_\text{M} &= \frac{G\, M_\text{M}}{r_\text{M}^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{(6.674\times 10^{-11} \,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2)\, (7.35\times 10^{22}\,\text{kg})}{(3.84\times 10^8\,\text{m})^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 3.33\times 10^{-5}\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>The Sun has a mass of $M_\text{S} = 1.99\times 10^{30}\,\text{kg}$, and the average distance to Earth is $r_\text{S} = 1.496\times 10^{11}\,\text{m}$. So, the gravitational acceleration at Earth due to the Sun is
                                \begin{align}
                                a_\text{S} &= \frac{G\, M_\text{S}}{r_\text{S}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{(6.674\times 10^{-11} \,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2)\, (1.99\times 10^{30}\,\text{kg})}{(1.496\times 10^{11}\,\text{m})^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 5.93\times 10^{-3}\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>On Earth, the gravitational accelerations due to the Sun and the Moon have the ratio
                                \begin{align}
                                \frac{a_\text{S}}{a_\text{M}} &= \frac{5.93\times 10^{-3} \,\text{m}/\text{s}^2}{3.33\times 10^{-5} \,\text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 178
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                        <p>Although an object on Earth experiences a solar pull that is $178$ times stronger than the lunar pull, the Moon has greater effect on ocean tides! This is because the tide phenomena is caused by the difference in the gravitational field between the near and far sides of the Earth&rsquo;s surface. Since the Moon is relatively very close to Earth, its size becomes more significant. Note that Earth&rsquo;s diameter is about $3.3\%$ of the distance to the Moon, and only $0.0085\%$ the distance to the Sun!</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 36 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p36">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 36</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) Calculate the acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the Sun. (b) By what factor would your weight increase if you could stand on the Sun? (Never mind that you cannot.)
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer36_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution36a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution36b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer36">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $274\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $28.0$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution36a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>The mass of the Sun is $M_\text{S} = 1.99\times 10^{30}\,\text{kg}$ and its average radius is $R_\text{S} = 6.96\times 10^8 \,\text{m}$. So, the acceleration due to gravity at the surface is equal to
                                \begin{align}
                                g_\text{S} &= \frac{G\, M_\text{S}}{R_\text{S}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{(6.674\times 10^{-11} \,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2)\, (1.99\times 10^{30}\,\text{kg})}{(6.96\times 10^8 \,\text{m})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 274\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution36b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>If you have a mass $m$, your weight on Earth&rsquo;s surface is equal to
                                \begin{equation}
                                w = m\, g
                                \end{equation}
                        On the surface of the Sun, however, your weight becomes
                                \begin{equation}
                                w_\text{S} = m\, g_\text{S}
                                \end{equation}
                        So, your weight increases by a factor of
                                \begin{align}
                                \frac{w_\text{S}}{w} &= \frac{m\, g_\text{S}}{m\, g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{g_\text{S}}{g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{274\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2}{9.80\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 28.0
                                \end{align}
                        This means you would feel $28$ times heavier on the surface of the Sun!
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 40 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p40">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 40</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The existence of the dwarf planet Pluto was proposed based on irregularities in Neptune&rsquo;s orbit. Pluto was subsequently discovered near its predicted position. But it now appears that the discovery was fortuitous, because Pluto is small and the irregularities in Neptune&rsquo;s orbit were not well known. To illustrate that Pluto has a minor effect on the orbit of Neptune compared with the closest planet to Neptune: (a) Calculate the acceleration due to gravity at Neptune due to Pluto when they are $4.50\times 10^{12}\,\text{m}$ apart, as they are at present. The mass of Pluto is $1.4\times 10^{22}\,\text{kg}$. (b) Calculate the acceleration due to gravity at Neptune due to Uranus, presently about $2.50\times 10^{12}\,\text{m}$ apart, and compare it with that due to Pluto. The mass of Uranus is $8.62\times 10^{25}\,\text{kg}$.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer40_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution40a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution40b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer40" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $4.61\times 10^{-14}\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $9.20\times 10^{-10}\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2,\; 20000\,\text{times}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution40a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>With a mass of $M_\text{P} = 1.4\times 10^{22}\,\text{kg}$ for Pluto, and a Neptune-Pluto distance of $r_\text{NP} = 4.50\times 10^{12}\,\text{m}$, the acceleration due to gravity at Neptune due to Pluto is calculated to be
                                \begin{align}
                                a_\text{NP} &= \frac{G\, M_\text{P}}{r_\text{NP}^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{(6.674\times 10^{-11} \,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2)\, (1.4\times 10^{22}\,\text{kg})}{(4.50\times 10^{12}\,\text{m})^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 4.61\times 10^{-14}\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution40b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>Uranus has a mass of $M_\text{U} = 8.62\times 10^{25}\,\text{kg}$, and is at a distance $r_\text{NU} = 2.50\times 10^{12}\,\text{m}$ from Neptune. So the acceleration due to gravity at Neptune due to Uranus is
                                \begin{align}
                                a_\text{NU} &= \frac{G\, M_\text{U}}{r_\text{NU}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{(6.674\times 10^{-11} \,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2)\, (8.62\times 10^{25}\,\text{kg})}{(2.50\times 10^{12}\,\text{m})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 9.20\times 10^{-10}\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                        The ratio of the accelerations at Neptune due to Uranus and Pluto is
                                \begin{align}
                                \frac{a_\text{NU}}{a_\text{NP}} &= \frac{9.20\times 10^{-10}\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2}{4.61\times 10^{-14}\, \text{m}/\text{s}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 2.00\times 10^4
                                \end{align}
                        So, the gravitation effect of Uranus on Neptune&rsquo;s orbit is twenty thousand times stronger than that of Pluto!
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 46 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter06-p46">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 6, Problem 46</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Find the ratio of the mass of Jupiter to that of Earth based on data in <a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf#page=28" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">Table 6.2</a> (in the textbook).
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer46_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram46_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution46_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer46" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$320$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram46">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch06-p46s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P6.46s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution46" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>To perform a uniform circular motion (of radius $r$) around a planet (of mass $M$), a satellite (or moon) must have the right speed $v$ so that the required centripetal force is equal to the gravitational pull due to the planet (see <b>Figure P6.46s</b>). Mathematically, this is written as
                                \begin{equation}
                                \frac{m\, v^2}{r} = G\, \frac{m\, M}{r^2}
                                \end{equation}
                        In this equation, the mass ($m$) of the satellite cancels out and the equation simplifies to
                                \begin{equation}
                                v^2 = G\, \frac{M}{r}
                                \label{ch06_p46_v2}
                                \end{equation}
                        Since we assume uniform circular motion, the speed is equal to the distance traveled in one complete rotation divided by period of rotation ($T$), or
                                \begin{equation}
                                v = \frac{2 \pi r}{T}
                                \label{ch06_p46_v}
                                \end{equation}
                        By substituting from Equation \ref{ch06_p46_v} into Equation \ref{ch06_p46_v2}, we have
                                \begin{align}
                                \left(\frac{2 \pi r}{T}\right)^2 &= G\, \frac{M}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                \Rightarrow\quad \frac{r^3}{T^2} &= \frac{G\, M}{4\pi ^2}
                                \label{ch06_p46_r3T2}
                                \end{align}
                        </p>

                        <p>From Equation \ref{ch06_p46_r3T2} we see that the quantity $(r^3/T^2)$ is a constant value that depends on the mass of the parent body. This is also confirmed by a quick look at the data in <a href="../textbook/chapter-6.pdf#page=28" title="Chapter 6" target="_blank">Table 6.2</a> in the textbook, where for the single Earth&rsquo;s satellite (the Moon) we have
                                \begin{equation}
                                \left(\frac{r^3}{T^2}\right)_\text{E} = 1.01\times 10^{19}\, \text{km}^3/\text{y}^2
                                \end{equation}
                        Also, for the four moons of Jupiter
                                \begin{equation}
                                \left(\frac{r^3}{T^2}\right)_J = 3.2\times 10^{21}\, \text{km}^3/\text{y}^2
                                \end{equation}
                        If we express Equation \ref{ch06_p46_r3T2} as
                                \begin{equation}
                                M = \frac{4\pi ^2}{G} \left(\frac{r^3}{T^2}\right)
                                \label{ch06_p46_M}
                                \end{equation}
                        we can calculate the ratio of the mass of Jupiter to that of Earth as follows
                                \begin{align}
                                \frac{M_\text{J}}{M_\text{E}} &= \frac{\left( 4\pi ^2/G \right) \left(r^3/T^2\right)_\text{J}}{\left( 4\pi ^2/G \right) \left(r^3/T^2\right)_\text{E}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{\left(r^3/T^2\right)_\text{J}}{\left(r^3/T^2\right)_\text{E}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{3.2\times 10^{21}\, \text{km}^3/\text{y}^2}{1.01\times 10^{19}\, \text{km}^3/\text{y}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 320
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>


<!--  *********************************  -->

Discuss with your tutor any discrepancies between your answers and those provided.</p>

            <div class="page-signature">
              <article>
                <p class="runhead1"><strong>Physics 200</strong> Introductory Physics I</p>

                <p class="unit"> Unit 7 <span>(Chapter 7)</span></p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07" >

                  <!-- to change: the following content -->
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</h1>
                  <hr>

                  <p>A fossil-fuel power plant converts the chemical energy stored in coal, oil, or natural gas into electrical energy. A nuclear power plant converts the nuclear energy stored inside a uranium nucleus into electrical energy. A hydropower plant converts the gravitational potential energy stored in the large reservoir behind the dam into electrical energy. A wind power plant converts the kinetic energy in moving air into electrical energy. However, the knowledge that energy is convertible from one form into another does not answer the question; what is energy?</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:2.0em;">
                  <div class="learningobjectives">
                    <h3>Learning Objectives</h3>
                    <p>After completing this unit, you should be able to</p>
                    <ul>
                        <li>define and calculate the work done by a constant force on an object.</li>
                        <li>explain the process for calculating the work done by a varying force on an object.</li>
                        <li>define kinetic energy.</li>
                        <li>state the work-energy theorem and use it to solve problems of motion.</li>
                        <li>define gravitational potential energy and use it to solve relevant problems.</li>
                        <li>differentiate between conservative and nonconservative forces.</li>
                        <li>state the relationship between conservative forces and potential energy.</li>
                        <li>describe an isolated system.</li>
                        <li>explain the law of conservation of energy.</li>
                        <li>solve problems of motion using the law of conservation of mechanical energy.</li>
                        <li>define power and use it to solve problems of motion.</li>
                    </ul>
                  </div>

                  <!-- end of content -->

                </div> <!-- end of this section -->

<!--  *********************************  -->

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-work-energy">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Work and Energy</h2>

                <p>The two main concepts in this unit are <em>work</em> and <em>energy</em>. The terms are not new to you&mdash;they are part of our everyday vocabulary. However, they have definitions and meanings in physics that are different from those of day-to-day life. In our common usage, energy refers to resources that are capable of producing energy&mdash;physical entities, such as natural gas, oil, coal, etc. In physics, energy is not a substance, but a property of a physical system.</p>

                <p>Energy can be defined as the capacity for doing work. As energy changes from one form to another, part of the available energy is transformed into work. The relationship between work and energy is embodied in the Work-Energy Theorem, a cornerstone of physics. The theorem states that work done on a system by an external force increases the energy of the system, and that energy can be used to do work.</p>

                <p>If a body moves when a force is applied to it, a physicist would say that work is done on the body by the force. If the body does not move, no work is done, no matter how large the force applied. So, the important thing to remember is that, in physics, a body must move through a distance for work to be done. You may spend the whole day trying to move a big rock from the edge of your yard, pushing and shoving it every which way, and finally decide that you have done enough work for the day. But if the rock has not moved from where it was at the beginning, a physicist would have to conclude that you had done no work at all!</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit07-fig01">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-fig01.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 7.1</b>: A block makes a horizontal displacement $d$ under the influence of a constant force $F$ that makes an angle $\theta$ with the direction of motion.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


               <p>By definition, work is equal to the scalar product of two vector quantities: <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-force-concept">force</a> and <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-displacement">displacement</a>. In other words, work is the product of displacement of a body and the component of the force acting in the direction of the displacement. To represent work in a more mathematical form, consider the block in <a href="#unit07-fig01"><b>Figure 7.1</b></a> and assume that a constant force $F$ is applied to the block at an angle $\theta$ above the horizontal. While the force is applied, the block makes a displacement of magnitude $d$ in the horizontal direction. The work ($W$) done on the block is equal to</p>
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= d \times F \cos\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= F d \cos\theta
                        \end{align}
                From this equation we see that three conditions must be met before we can say that work has been done on a body: A force <span style="white-space: nowrap;">($F \neq 0$)</span> is applied, the body changes its position <span style="white-space: nowrap;">($d \neq 0$)</span>, and the displacement is not perpendicular to the direction of the applied force <span style="white-space: nowrap;">($\theta \neq 90^\circ$)</span>. Note that the force of gravity ($mg$) does zero work on the block, in this case.

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit07-vid01.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 7.1</b>: Work and energy concept.
                </p>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-kinetic-energy">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Kinetic Energy</h2>

                <p>Consider a block of mass $m$ that moves at a uniform velocity $v_0$ on a smooth surface, as shown in <a href="#unit07-fig02"><b>Figure 7.2</b></a>. If an external force $F$ is applied in the direction of motion, the block experiences a constant acceleration $a = F/m$, as described by <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law of motion</a>. As a result, the block&rsquo;s velocity increases steadily with time. If the block moves a distance $d$ while being pushed, the final velocity <span style="white-space: nowrap;">($v$)</span> is given by the kinematic equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        v^2 = v_0^2 + 2 \left( \frac{F}{m} \right) d
                        \end{equation}
                which can be rearranged in the form
                        \begin{equation}
                        F\, d = \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 - \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2
                        \label{unit07_Fd}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit07-fig02">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-fig02.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 7.2</b>: A block makes a horizontal displacement $d$, on a smooth surface, under the influence of a constant force $F$ that acts in the direction of motion.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>Note that the left-hand-side in Equation \ref{unit07_Fd} is basically the work ($W=Fd$) done on the block by the applied force. For the right-hand-side, one can see the change in a quantity of the form
                        \begin{equation}
                        \tfrac{1}{2}\times (\text{mass}) \times (\text{velocity})^2
                        \end{equation}
                This quantity, a property of a body in motion, is called the <em>kinetic energy</em> ($\text{KE}$). With this definition, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 \quad (\text{initial kinetic energy}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \text{KE}_\text{f} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 \quad (\text{final kinetic energy})
                        \end{align}
                So, Equation \ref{unit07_Fd} can be expressed as
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= \text{KE}_\text{f} - \text{KE}_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \Delta\text{KE} \quad (\text{change in kinetic energy})
                        \end{align}
                This important relationship is known as the <em>work-energy theorem</em>. It says that the net work done on a body by external forces is equal to the change in the body&rsquo;s kinetic energy.
                </p>

                <p>The work-energy theorem should be used with caution! When multiple forces act on a body, the total work done by all the forces is equal to the change in the body&rsquo;s kinetic energy. For example, if the block slides on a rough surface, as in <a href="#unit07-fig03"><b>Figure 7.3</b></a>, the work done by the force of friction ($f_\text{k}$) is given by
                        \begin{align}
                        W_\text{fr} &= f_\text{k}\, d \cos 180^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -f_\text{k}\, d
                        \end{align}
                Note that the resistive force of friction acts opposite to the displacement, which produces negative work. The net (or total) work done on the block is, therefore, equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        W_\text{net} &= F_\text{net}\, d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (F -f_\text{k})\, d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \Delta\text{KE}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit07-fig03">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-fig03.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 7.3</b>: A block makes a horizontal displacement $d$, on a rough surface, under the influence of a constant force $F$ that acts in the direction of motion.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">Chapter 7</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf#page=4" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">7.2.&nbsp; Kinetic Energy and the Work-Energy Theorem</a></li>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-potential-energy">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Potential Energy</h2>

                <p>Suppose a block of mass $m$ is at rest on a tabletop, as shown in <a href="#unit07-fig04"><b>Figure 7.4</b></a>. To lift the block, sufficient force ($F$) must be exerted&mdash;in the upward direction&mdash;to overcome the downward force of gravity. So, the minimum required force is equal to the weight of the block, or $F = mg$. In this case, the net vertical force on the block is equal to zero, which allows it to rise steadily without acceleration.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit07-fig04">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-fig04.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 7.4</b>: A block displaced a vertical distance $h$ above a tabletop by the minimum force required.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>Assume that the block is displaced a vertical distance $h$, above its initial position on the tabletop. The displacement vector, in this case, is directed upward and has a magnitude equal to $h$. The work done on the block by the upward force is given by
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= F\, h\, \cos \theta \nonumber\\[6pt]<br>
                        &= (m g)\, h\, \cos 0^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  m g h
                        \label{unit07_Wmgh}
                        \end{align}
                Note that the angle ($\theta$) between applied force and displacement vector is equal to zero.
                </p>

                <p>Now we ask the question; What about gravity? Does it do work on the block? The answer is yes. However, we have to be careful about the sign here, because the downward force of gravity acts opposite to the displacement ($\theta = 180^\circ$), which results in negative work such that
                        \begin{align}
                        W_\text{g} &= (m g)\, h\, \cos 180^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  - m g h
                        \end{align}
                The net work on the block is, therefore, equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        W_\text{net} &= W + W_\text{g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  mgh + (- m g h) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0
                        \end{align}
                With zero net work, the block does not experience a change in its <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit07-kinetic-energy">kinetic energy</a>, according to work energy theorem. So, what happened to the work done by the applied force?
                </p>

                <p>In the search for an answer to this question, let us think of what happens when the block is released at a hight $h$ above the tabletop. The block accelerates downward, as a free-falling object, and gains kinetic energy. Does this gain in kinetic energy have any relation to the work that was done to lift the block? The final velocity ($v$) of the block just before it touches the tabletop is given by the equation
                        \begin{align}
                        v^2 &= v_0^2 + 2 a\, d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  0 + 2 (-g)\, (0 - h) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2 g h
                        \end{align}
                So, the kinetic energy of the block when it reaches the table is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  \tfrac{1}{2} m\, (2 g h) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m g h
                        \end{align}
                Note that this is equal to the work done on the block to raise it to a height $h$ above the tabletop!
                </p>

                <p>From the argument above, we see that the work done to raise an body is not lost. It is recovered in the form of kinetic energy when the body is released and allowed to return to its original position. To put things together, scientists introduced the concept of <em>potential energy</em>. So, the work done in lifting a body of mass $m$ through a vertical displacement $h$, against the force of gravity, is preserved as <em>gravitational potential energy</em> given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        \Delta\text{PE}_\text{g} = m g h
                        \end{equation}
                This potential energy can be kept in storage for an indefinite time without any loss. When we let go of the body, the potential energy is converted into kinetic energy of motion.
                </p>

                <p>In working with potential energy, we must be aware of some of its characteristics. Potential energy is always related to a force—gravitational potential energy arises out of gravitational force, electrical potential energy comes about only when electrical forces are present, and elastic forces give rise to elastic potential energy. Thus, potential energy can be defined as the energy of a body by virtue of its position in relation to a specific force. So, the gravitational potential energy introduced in this section is different from the energy stored in a car battery, for example.</p>

                <p>Another characteristic of potential energy is that it does not have an absolute value, like kinetic energy. It is always measured relative to a reference point, such as the tabletop in the example above. If we imagine that each body has a bank account, then the amount of potential energy in the account when the body is at a particular position is not very important. It is the amount of energy deposited or withdrawn (i.e., $\Delta\text{PE}$) from the account during the displacement of a body that is physically meaningful, and that can be related to the work done on the body.
                </p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit07-vid02.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 7.2</b>: Potential energy and kinetic energy.
                </p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-conservative-forces">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Conservative and Nonconservative Forces</h2>

                <p>Gravitational, electrical, and elastic forces are all examples of <em>conservative forces</em>; that is, the work done on an object moving under the action of these forces is not lost, but is always stored (or conserved) in the form of potential energy. Frictional forces, on the other hand, are not conservative forces, and the concept of potential energy cannot be applied to them.</p>

                <p>The work done against the force of gravity to raise a body of mass $m$, by a vertical distance $h$ above the ground, is equal to (see Equation \ref{unit07_Wmgh})
                        \begin{equation}
                        W = m g h
                        \end{equation}
                This work is stored in the form of gravitational potential energy, and we say that the potential energy of the body increases by the amount
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta\text{PE}_\text{g} &= \text{PE}_\text{f} - \text{PE}_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m g h
                        \label{unit07_DPE_mgh}
                        \end{align}
                Note that the quantity above is also equal to the work done by the force of gravity, on the body, when it falls a vertical distance $h$ towards the ground. Actually, Equation \ref{unit07_DPE_mgh} is more general than that and can be used to calculate the work done by the force of gravity on a body when it transitions between two vertical heights, regardless of the path. The work done by the force of gravity is the same in the four situations shown in <a href="#unit07-fig05"><b>Figure 7.5</b></a>.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit07-fig05">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-fig05.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 7.5</b>: A ball displaced a vertical distance $h$ under the influence of gravity.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>The force of gravity is an example of conservative forces whose work depends only on the initial and final positions. Therefore, a body which moves in a closed path, that is, returns to its initial position, experiences zero work if it is subjected to conservative forces only. Nonconservative forces, such as the force of kinetic friction, do not have this property and no potential energy is associated with them.</p>

                <h3>PhET Simulation: The Ramp</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf#page=22" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">textbook</a>, &ldquo;explore forces, energy and work as you push household objects up and down a ramp.                 <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-energy-conservation">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Conservation of Energy</h2>

                <p>In physics, conservation refers to unchangeability, or constancy. Physicists believe that if a quantity that is a characteristic of a system remains unchanged, while the system itself undergoes change, then the quantity has some fundamental significance in nature. Physicists have been successful in finding a number of such conserved quantities&mdash;mass and energy, momentum, angular momentum, electric charge, to name a few—and they are still finding new ones.</p>

                <p>One of the most celebrated laws of physics is the <em>law of conservation of energy</em>. The popular version states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed. A physicist may say the same thing in a somewhat different way:
                <blockquote><b>The total energy of an isolated system is constant.</b></blockquote>

                <h3>Mechanical Energy</h3>

                <p>The total mechanical energy of a body, at a particular time, is defined as the summation of the kinetic and potential energies of that body. In the absence of nonconservative (also called dissipative) forces, the total mechanical energy is conserved and does not change with time or location. This is called the <em>law of conservation of mechanical energy</em>, and it is written as
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{KE} + \text{PE} = \text{constant}
                        \end{equation}
                 or
                        \begin{equation}
                        \Delta\text{KE} + \Delta\text{PE} = 0
                        \label{unit07_KEPE_0}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit07-fig06">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-fig06.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 7.6</b>: A ball shot up with initial vertical velocity $v_0$.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>To see how the law works, let us consider the motion of a free-falling object. Suppose a ball of mass $m$ is projected straight up with an initial velocity $v_0$ from the ground, as shown in <a href="#unit07-fig06"><b>Figure 7.6</b></a>. If we take the ground level as our reference for measuring potential energy, the total mechanical energy of the ball at the time it is shot is given by
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} + \text{PE}_\text{i} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 + 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>As the ball rises, it slows down and loses kinetic energy. The ball, however, gains gravitational potential energy with increased elevation above the reference level ($y_0 = 0$). When the ball is at the vertical position $y$, its velocity ($v$) is given by the kinematic equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        v^2 = v_0^2 - 2 g y
                        \label{unit07_v2v0gy}
                        \end{equation}
                So, the total mechanical energy of the ball at this position is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE} + \text{PE} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 + m g y \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} m\, (v_0^2 - 2 g y) + m g y \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2
                        \label{unit07_KEPE_mv02}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>From Equation \ref{unit07_KEPE_mv02}, we see that the kinetic energy lost by the ball is gained as potential energy, and the total mechanical energy remains constant. This continues until all the kinetic energy is converted to potential energy at the maximum height ($y = h$), where the ball momentarily stops ($v = 0$). So, Equation \ref{unit07_v2v0gy} becomes
                        \begin{align}
                        0 &= v_0^2 - 2 g h \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad h &= \frac{v_0^2}{2g}
                        \end{align}

                The total mechanical energy at this instant is, therefore, equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{f} + \text{PE}_\text{f} &= 0 + mgh \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 + mg \left( \frac{v_0^2}{2g} \right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>So, we see that the total mechanical energy of the ball does not change as it moves up against gravity. It is always equal to the amount of energy the ball had at the start of the motion. When the ball falls back after reaching maximum height, its total mechanical energy is also conserved. In this case, however, potential energy is converted to kinetic energy, until the ball hits the ground with the same initial speed.</p>

                <h3>Total Energy</h3>

                <p>In the analysis above, of the free falling object in <a href="#unit07-fig06"><b>Figure 7.6</b></a>, we ignored air resistance. In a more realistic treatment, the work done by the nonconservative drag force ($W_\text{nc}$) appears in the form of thermal energy and does not contribute to the potential energy of the ball. As a result, the total mechanical energy of the system is not conserved. However, the total energy, which accounts for all types of energy involved, is conserved. So, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} + \text{PE}_\text{i} + W_\text{nc} = \text{KE}_\text{f} + \text{PE}_\text{f}
                        \label{unit07_energy_conservation}
                        \end{equation}
                 or
                        \begin{equation}
                        \Delta\text{KE} + \Delta\text{PE} = W_\text{nc}
                        \label{unit07_KEPE_Wnc}
                        \end{equation}
                 Note that in the absence of nonconservative forces (i.e., $W_\text{nc} = 0$), Equation \ref{unit07_KEPE_Wnc} above reduces to the special case of Equation \ref{unit07_KEPE_0}.
                </p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit07-vid03.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 7.3</b>: Conservation of mechanical energy.
                </p>
