                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-power">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Power</h2>

                <p>Consider a block of mass $m$ pushed by a constant force $F$ on a smooth surface, as shown in <a href="#unit07-fig07"><b>Figure 7.7</b></a>. As the block advances a small distance $\Delta x$, the applied force does work on the block equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        W = F\, \Delta x
                        \label{unit07_W_FDx}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit07-fig07">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-fig07.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 7.7</b>: A block makes a horizontal displacement $\Delta x$ during a small time interval $\Delta t$, on a smooth surface, under the influence of a horizontal force $F$.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>The <em>Power</em> delivered to the block is defined as the rate of doing work. So, if the work is done during a time interval $\Delta t$, the power is given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        P = \frac{W}{\Delta t}
                        \label{unit07_P_WDt}
                        \end{equation}
                By substituting from Equation \ref{unit07_W_FDx} into Equation \ref{unit07_P_WDt}, we can express the power as
                        \begin{align}
                        P &= \frac{F\, \Delta x}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= F \left(\frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= F v
                        \label{unit07_P_Fv}
                        \end{align}
                where $v$ is the instantaneous velocity of the block.
                </p>

                <p>Since work and energy are measured in joules, in SI units, the unit of power is joules/second. This unit is called the <em>watt</em> ($\text{W}$), where
                        \begin{equation}
                        1\, \text{W} = 1\, \text{J}/\text{s}
                        \end{equation}
                In the British system, power is measured in units of <em>horsepower</em>, written as $\text{hp}$. The two units are related by the equation
                        \begin{equation}
                        1\, \text{hp} = 746\, \text{W}
                        \end{equation}
                The unit of horsepower is still widely used in North American society. Whereas the watt is used as a measure of power for most electrical equipment, from microwaves to electric stoves to light bulbs, horsepower seems to be the norm if mechanical motion is involved. A hardware store may have a hard time selling garage door openers with 373 watts of power on the label</p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following sections from <a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">Chapter 7</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf#page=26" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">7.7.&nbsp; Power</a></li>
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf#page=30" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">7.8.&nbsp; Work, Energy, and Power in Humans</a></li>
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf#page=32" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">7.9.&nbsp; World Energy Use</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-examples">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Examples</h2>

                    <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of examples relevant to the content of <span style="white-space: nowrap;">Unit 7</span>. Make an attempt to answer each question on your own, before you read through the solution provided.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-e01">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 7, Example 1</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A $55.0\,\text{kg}$ box is pushed horizontally, at a constant speed, a distance of $3.80\,\text{m}$ along the floor. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the floor is $0.420$, determine the work done on the box by the applied force.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e01_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e01_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01_btn">Solution</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$860\,\text{J}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-e01s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E7.1s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>Since it moves at a constant velocity (i.e., no acceleration), the box experiences zero net force, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{net} = F - f_\text{k} = 0
                        \end{equation}
                So, the applied force is equal to the opposing force of <a href="../unit05/index05.html#unit05-friction">kinetic friction</a> (see <b>Figure E7.1s</b>), which is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= f_\text{k} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \mu_\text{k}\, m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.420)\, (55.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 226\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
												Note that the normal force on the box is equal to its weight.
                </p>

                <p>The <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit07-work-energy">work</a> done by the applied force on the box, as it moves a horizontal distance $d = 3.80\,\text{m}$, is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= F\, d\, \cos 0^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (226\,\text{N})\, (3.80\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 860\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-e02">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 7, Example 2</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A truck of mass $4{,}500\,\text{kg}$ travels on the highway at $108\,\text{km/h}$. How much work must be done on the truck to bring it to a complete stop?
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e02_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02_btn">Solution</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$- 2.02\, \text{MJ}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>The truck travels at the initial speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        v_0 &= 108\,\text{km/h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 30.0\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                which corresponds to an initial <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit07-kinetic-energy">kinetic energy</a> of
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2}\, (4{,}500\,\text{kg})\, (30.0\,\text{m/s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.02\times 10^6\, \text{J} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.02\, \text{MJ}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>When the truck comes to a complete stop, its final kinetic energy becomes equal to zero. So the change in the truck’s kinetic energy is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta\text{KE} &= \text{KE}_\text{f} - \text{KE}_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 -  2.02\, \text{MJ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - 2.02\, \text{MJ}
                        \end{align}
                According to the work-energy theorem, this quantity $\Delta\text{KE}$ is equal to the work done to stop the truck. Note that the work is negative, because the force applied by the braking system acts in the opposite direction of the displacement.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-e03">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 7, Example 3</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A student lifts a $1.25\,\text{kg}$ book from a $75.0\,\text{cm}$ high desk to $1.65\,\text{m}$ high shelf. Calculate the work done on the book by the student.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e03_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e03_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03_btn">Solution</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$11.0\,\text{J}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-e03s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E7.3s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>By taking the ground level as our reference (see <b>Figure E7.3s</b>), we can calculate the gravitational potential energy of the book at the initial height $h_\text{i} = 0.750\,\text{m}$ and at the final height $h_\text{f} = 1.65\,\text{m}$, as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{PE}_\text{i} &= m g\, h_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (1.25\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (0.750\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9.19\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                and
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{PE}_\text{f} &= m g\, h_\text{f} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (1.25\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (1.65\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 20.2\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>The work ($W$) done by the student to lift the book is stored in the form of <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit07-potential-energy">gravitational potential energy</a>. So, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= \Delta\text{PE} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \text{PE}_\text{f} - \text{PE}_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (20.2\,\text{J}) - (9.19\,\text{J}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 11.0\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                <p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-e04">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 7, Example 4</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A block slides $2.00\,\text{m}$ down a smooth ramp that makes an angle of $20.0^\circ$ with the horizontal, as shown in <b>Figure E7.4</b>. If the block starts from rest, determine its final speed.
                <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-e04.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure E7.4</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e04_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e04_btn">Solution</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$3.66\,\text{m/s}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>Since the block (of mass $m$) slides on a smooth surface, we assume no energy is lost due to friction. As a result, the total mechanical energy of the block is conserved. In other words, the potential energy plus the the kinetic energy remains constant during the motion. So, we write,
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{PE}_\text{i} + \text{KE}_\text{i} = \text{PE}_\text{f} + \text{KE}_\text{f}
                        \label{unit07_e04_PEKE}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>By taking the bottom of the ramp as our reference, the final potential energy of the block is equal to zero, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{PE}_\text{f} = 0
                        \label{unit07_e04_PEf}
                        \end{equation}
                The initial potential energy, however, is given by
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{PE}_\text{i} &= m g\, h_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m g\, d \sin\theta
                        \label{unit07_e04_PEi}
                        \end{align}
                where $d = 2.00\,\text{m}$ is the distance traveled by the block down the ramp, and $\theta = 20.0^\circ$ is the inclination angle. Since, it starts from rest, the block has no initial kinetic energy, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} = 0
                        \label{unit07_e04_KEi}
                        \end{equation}

                <p>By substituting from Equations \ref{unit07_e04_PEf}, \ref{unit07_e04_PEi}, and \ref{unit07_e04_KEi} into Equation \ref{unit07_e04_PEKE}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        m g\, d \sin\theta + 0 &= 0 + \text{KE}_\text{f} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad m g\, d \sin\theta &= \text{KE}_\text{f}
                        \label{unit07_e04_KEf}
                        \end{align}
                which allows for the calculation of the final speed of the block as shown below
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{f} &= m g\, d \sin\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tfrac{1}{2} m v_\text{f}^2 &= m g\, d \sin\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_\text{f} &= \sqrt{2 g\, d \sin\theta} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{2\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.00\,\text{m})\, \sin 20.0^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.66\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                Note that $v_\text{f}$ is independent of the block&rsquo;s mass.
                </p>

                <p>As an exercise, determine the acceleration of the block and then use the kinematics equations to find the final velocity. You should arrive at the same answer.<p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 5 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-e05">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 7, Example 5</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A car of mass $900\,\text{kg}$ can maintain a maximum speed of $105\,\text{km/h}$ on a $6.0^\circ$ hill. What constant speed could the car maintain on a hill with a slope of $12^\circ$? Assume that the resistive force due to air drag and friction is $600\,\text{N}$ and that it does not vary with speed.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e05_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e05_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e05_btn">Solution</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$65.7\,\text{km/h}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-e05s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E7.5s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e05">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>In the first situation ($\theta_1 = 6.0^\circ$) the engine pushes the car uphill with a constant force $F_1$. Since the car maintains a constant speed (no acceleration), we conclude that the applied force is balanced by resistive and gravitational forces down the incline (see <b>Figure E7.5s</b>). So, we can write
                                \begin{equation}
                                F_1 = m g\, \sin\theta_1 + f
                                \label{unit07_e05_F1_mgf}
                                \end{equation}
                        where $m = 900\,\text{kg}$ is the mass of the car, and $f = 600\,\text{N}$ is the magnitude of the drag force. By substituting the known values into Equation \ref{unit07_e05_F1_mgf}, we find
                                \begin{align}
                                F_1 &=  (900\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, \sin 6.0^\circ  + 600\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 1.52\times 10^3\, \text{N}
                                \label{unit07_e05_F1}
                                \end{align}
                        </p>

                        <p>Since $v_1 = 29.2\,\text{m/s}$ is the maximum speed on this hill, we assume that the car&rsquo;s engine works at maximum power, which is equal to
                                \begin{align}
                                P_\text{max} &= F_1\, v_1 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= (1.52\times 10^3\, \text{N})\, (29.2\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 4.44\times 10^4\, \text{W}
                                \label{unit07_e05_Pmax}
                                \end{align}
                        </p>

                        <p>On the steeper hill, the engine works against a stronger force of (see <b>Figure E7.5s</b>)
                                \begin{align}
                                F_2 &=  m g\, \sin\theta_2 + f \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 2.43\times 10^3\, \text{N}
                                \label{unit07_e05_F2}
                                \end{align}
                        </p>

                        <p>If the engine here also works at maximum power, we then have
                                \begin{equation}
                                P_\text{max} = F_2\, v_2
                                \end{equation}
                        So, on the steeper hill, the car can maintain a maximum speed of
                                \begin{align}
                                v_2 &= \frac{P_\text{max}}{F_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{4.44\times 10^4\, \text{W}}{2.43\times 10^3\, \text{N}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 18.2\, \text{m/s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 65.7\,\text{km/h}
                                \end{align}
                        </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 6 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit07-e06">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 7, Example 6</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A $2.00$-$\text{kg}$ block is held against a horizontal spring ($k = 30.0\,\text{N/m}$) that is compressed by $60.0\,\text{cm}$ from its normal length. When released, the block slides on a rough surface ($\mu_\text{k} = 0.150$) and moves beyond the spring&rsquo;s unstretched position. Calculate (a) the initial elastic potential energy stored in the spring, (b) the speed of the block as it looses contact with the spring, and (c) the total distance traveled by the block.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e06_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e06_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e06a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e06b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e06c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="interactive-e06_btn">Interactive Activity</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $5.40\,\text{J}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $1.91\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                      <p>(c) $1.84\,\text{m}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit07-e06s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E7.6s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e06a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>While compressed (see <b>Figure E7.6s</b>) by $x = 0.600\,\text{m}$, the elastic potential energy stored in the spring is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{PE}_\text{i} &= \tfrac{1}{2} k\, x^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2}\, (30.0\,\text{N/m})\, (0.600\,\text{m})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.40\,\text{J}
                        \label{unit07_PEi}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e06b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>When released, the block (of mass $m = 2.00\, \text{kg}$) begins to move as the spring relaxes (see <a href="./unit07-e06i.cdf"><b>Figure E7.6i</b></a>). While still in contact with the spring, the stored elastic potential energy is converted into kinetic energy and into heat energy, due to the work done by the force of friction. If $v$ is the block&rsquo;s speed at the unstretched position of the spring, then according to the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit07-energy-conservation">law of conservation of energy</a> we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{initial potential energy} &= \text{work done by friction} + \text{kinetic energy} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \text{PE}_\text{i} &= f_\text{k}\, x + \tfrac{1}{2} m\, v^2
                        \label{unit07_Eunstretched}
                        \end{align}
                    where the opposing force of kinetic friction is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        f_\text{k} &= \mu_\text{k}\, m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.15)\, (2.00\, \text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.94\,\text{N}
                        \label{unit07_fk}
                        \end{align}
                    By substituting from Equations \ref{unit07_PEi} and \ref{unit07_fk} into Equation \ref{unit07_Eunstretched}, we can calculate the speed of the block as it looses contact with the spring, as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        5.40\,\text{J} &= (2.94\,\text{N})\, (0.600\,\text{m}) + \tfrac{1}{2}\, (2.00\, \text{kg})\, v^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v &= 1.91\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e06c">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The block comes to rest ($\text{KE}_\text{f} = 0$) when all its initial elastic potential energy is converted into heat due to frictional forces. Since the total energy of the system is conserved, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{initial potential energy} &= \text{work done by friction} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \text{PE}_\text{i} &= f_\text{k}\, d
                        \label{unit07_Ef}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the total distance traveled by the block, before it comes to rest, is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        d &= \frac{\text{PE}_\text{i}}{f_\text{k}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{5.40\,\text{J}}{2.94\,\text{N}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.84\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="interactive-e06">
                <div class="panel-heading">Interactive Activity</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p class="centerText"><a href="./unit07-e06i.cdf"><img  src="unit07-e06i.png" alt="image"></a><br>
                    <br><b>Figure E7.6i</b></p>
                </div>

                    <p>Use <a href="https://www.wolfram.com/cdf-player/" target="_blank">Wolfram CDF Player</a>
                    to open the interactive diagram <a href="./unit07-e06i.cdf"><b>Figure E7.6i</b></a>.</p>

                    <p>Answer the questions below and use the interactive diagram to check your calculations.</p>

                        <p>
                        <ol>
                        <li>How much elastic potential energy is stored in the spring after the block has moved a distance of $40.0\,\text{cm}$?</li>
                        <li>What is the speed of the block when it is at this position?</li>
                        <li>Determine the speed of the block after it has moved a distance of $1.00\,\text{m}$.</li>
                        <li>How much heat is produced when the block is at this position?</li>
                      </ol>

                    </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-conceptual-questions">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Conceptual Questions</h2>

                  <p>Following, are detailed solutions of a number of conceptual questions selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf#page=38" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">Chapter 7</a> in the textbook.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-q02">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Question 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Give an example of a situation in which there is a force and a displacement, but the force does no work. Explain why it does no work.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q02_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q02_btn">Explanation</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The upward force you apply to carry a shopping bag while walking on a level ground.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>To carry the shopping bag you apply an upward force ($\bf F$) whose magnitude is equal to the bag&rsquo;s weight. When you walk through the parking lot towards your car, no work is done by this force on the bag. This is because the upward force $\bf F$ is perpendicular to the horizontal displacement $\bf d$. Mathematically, this is expressed as
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= F\, d\, \cos 90^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  F\, d\times (0) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 8 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-q08">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Question 8</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Does the work you do on a book when you lift it onto a shelf depend on the path taken? On the time taken? On the height of the shelf? On the mass of the book?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q08_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q08_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q08">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Work done depends on the height of the shelf and on the mass of the book.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q08">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The upward force you apply to lift a book acts to balance the force of gravity, which is a conservative force. Therefore, the work done depends on the mass and on the change in height, regardless of the path and the time taken to put the book on the shelf.</p>

                      <p>Referring to <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit07-e03">Example 3</a>, we see that
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= \text{PE}_\text{f} - \text{PE}_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m g\, h_\text{f} - m g\, h_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  m g\, (h_\text{f} - h_\text{i})
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 9 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-q09">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Question 9</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">What is a conservative force?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q09_btn">Answer</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q09">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The work done by a conservative force on a body can be determined by its initial and final positions, regardless of the path taken. This important characteristic results in a net work of zero when the body returns to the starting point after moving in closed loop.</p>

                      <p><a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit07-conservative-forces">Conservative forces</a>, such as the force gravity and the force of an ideal spring, store energy without loss. So, the total mechanical energy (kinetic plus potential) of a body that moves under the influence of conservative forces only, is conserved.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 14 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-q14">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Question 14</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Describe the energy transfers and transformations for a javelin, starting from the point at which an athlete picks up the javelin and ending when the javelin is stuck into the ground after being thrown.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q14_btn">Answer</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q14">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>As the javelin is picked up from the ground, the athlete&rsquo;s muscles do work and store it in the form of gravitational potential energy. When it is in a position to be thrown, the athlete runs, giving the javelin some kinetic energy. In the process, his hand also does work on the javelin by applying a force at an angle above the horizontal. The javelin leaves the athlete&rsquo;s hand with an initial kinetic energy and an initial gravitations potential energy.</p>

                      <p>Since it is thrown at an angle above the horizon, the javelin moves as a projectile. So after it leaves the athlete&rsquo;s hand, the javelin starts to gains height, in addition to its forward motion. In this stage of flight, kinetic energy converts into potential energy. After it reaches maximum height, the javelin begins to fall and its potential energy converts into kinetic energy. Just before it hits the ground, the javelin loses all its gravitational potential energy because it has all been converted into kinetic energy. It is important to note that, while in air, the total mechanical energy (kinetic plus potential) of the javelin remains constant.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 18 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-q18">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Question 18</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Most electrical appliances are rated in watts. Does this rating depend on how long the appliance is on? (When off, it is a zero-watt device.) Explain in terms of the definition of power.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q18_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q18_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q18">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>No, it does not.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q18">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The power rating in this case, refers to the amount of electric energy consumed per unit time. When turned on for an extended period, the appliance will consume a large amount of energy (joules), but at the same constant rate (watts).
                      </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>
