                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-problems">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Work, Energy, and Energy Resources</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Solutions of Selected Problems</h2>
                    <p>Next are detailed solutions to a number of problems selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf#page=41" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">Chapter 7</a> in the textbook. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve each problem independently, before you read through the solution provided. You are also advised to make a second attempt to solve the problem if your answer is different from the one posted. If you reach an impasse and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p02">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $75.0\,\text{kg}$ person climbs stairs, gaining $2.50\,\text{m}$ in height. Find the work done to accomplish this task.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer02_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution02_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer02" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$1.84\,\text{kJ}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution02" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>As a person of mass $m$ climbs the stairs, work is done against the force of gravity. The vertical displacement ($\Delta y$) is relevant to the work done. Note that any horizontal displacement is perpendicular to the applied force and, therefore, does not result in any work. So, for $m = 75.0\,\text{kg}$ and $\Delta y = 2.50\,\text{m}$, the work done to climb the stairs is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= F\, \Delta y\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m g\, \Delta y\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (75.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.50\,\text{m})\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.84\times 10^3\,\text{J} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.84\,\text{kJ}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 5 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p05">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 5</div>
                    <div class="panel-body"> Calculate the work done by an $85.0\,\text{kg}$ man who pushes a crate $4.00\,\text{m}$ up along a ramp that makes an angle of $20.0^\circ$ with the horizontal. (See <b>Figure P7.5</b>.) He exerts a force of $500\,\text{N}$ on the crate parallel to the ramp and moves at a constant speed. Be certain to include the work he does on the crate and on his body to get up the ramp.
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch07-p05.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P7.5</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer05_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution05_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$3.14\,\text{kJ}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution05" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The man applies a force $F = 500\,\text{N}$ on the crate parallel to the ramp. Since he moves with the carate, the man makes an additional effort to overcome the force of gravity on his body (of mass $m = 85.0\,\text{kg}$). So, the total force applied by the man to push the crate at a constant speed is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{total} &= m g\, \sin\theta + F \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (85.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m/s}^2)\, \sin20.0^\circ + 500\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 785\, \text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      So, the work done by the man to push the crate a distance $d = 4.00\,\text{m}$ up the ramp, is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= F_\text{total}\, d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (785\, \text{N})\, (4.00\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.14\times 10^3\, \text{J} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.14\,\text{kJ}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 6 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p06">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 6</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">How much work is done by the boy pulling his sister $30.0\,\text{m}$ in a wagon as shown in <b>Figure P7.6</b>? Assume no friction acts on the wagon.
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch07-p06.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P7.6</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer06_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution06_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$1.30\,\text{kJ}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>A force $F = 50.0\,\text{N}$ is exerted by the boy on the wagon in a direction $\theta = 30.0^\circ$ above the horizontal, as shown in <b>Figure P7.6</b>. If it is displaced a distance $d = 30.0\,\text{m}$ on level ground, the work done on the wagon by the boy is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= F\, d\, \cos{\theta} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (50.0\,\text{N})\, (30.0\,\text{m})\, \cos 30.0^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.30\times 10^3\,\text{J} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.30\,\text{kJ}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 7 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p07">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 7</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A shopper pushes a grocery cart $20.0\,\text{m}$ at constant speed on level ground, against a $35.0\,\text{N}$ frictional force. He pushes in a direction $25.0^\circ$ below the horizontal. (a) What is the work done on the cart by friction? (b) What is the work done on the cart by the gravitational force? (c) What is the work done on the cart by the shopper? (d) Find the force the shopper exerts, using energy considerations. (e) What is the total work done on the cart?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer07_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram07_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution07a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution07b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution07c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution07d_btn">Solution (d)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution07e_btn">Solution (e)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer07">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $-700\,\text{J}$</p>
                      <p>(b) Zero.<p>
                      <p>(c) $700\,\text{J}$</p>
                      <p>(d) $38.6\,\text{N}$<p>
                      <p>(e) Zero.<p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram07">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch07-p07s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P7.7s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution07a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Since the force of friction ($f = 35.0\,\text{N}$) acts in the opposite direction of the cart&rsquo;s displacement ($d = 20.0\,\text{m}$), the work done by friction is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        W_f &= f\, d\, \cos 180^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -(35.0\,\text{N})\, (20.0\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -700\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution07b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The downward force of gravity ($w$) is perpendicular to the direction of motion and, therefore, does not contribute to the work done on the cart. This is expressed mathematically as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        W_\text{g} &= w\, d\, \cos 90^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= w\, d\times (0) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution07c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Since it is pushed at a constant velocity, the cart experiences zero net horizontal force. This means the resistive force of friction is equal in magnitude to the horizontal component of the applied force, or (see <b>Figure P7.7s</b>)
                         \begin{align}
                         F \cos\theta - f &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         \Rightarrow\quad F \cos\theta &= f
                         \label{ch07_p07_Fx}
                         \end{align}
                      So, the work done on the cart by the shopper is written as
                        \begin{align}
                        W_F &= F\, d\, \cos\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (F \cos\theta)\, d
                        \label{ch07_p07_WF}
                        \end{align}
                      By substituting from Equation \ref{ch07_p07_Fx} into Equation \ref{ch07_p07_WF} we find
                        \begin{align}
                        W_F &= f\, d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (35.0\,\text{N})\, (20.0\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 700\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution07d">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (d)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Referring back to Equation \ref{ch07_p07_Fx}, we determine the magnitude of the applied force to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= \frac{f}{\cos\theta} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{35.0\,\text{N}}{\cos 25.0^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 38.6\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution07e">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (e)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The total work done on the cart is equal to
                         \begin{align}
                         W &= W_F + W_f \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 700\,\text{J} + (- 700\,\text{J}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 0
                         \end{align}
                      Note that no work is done on the cart by the gravitational and normal forces because the cart does not perform any vertical displacement.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 12 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p12">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 12</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) Calculate the force needed to bring a $950\,\text{kg}$ car to rest from a speed of $90.0\,\text{km/h}$ in a distance of $120\,\text{m}$ (a fairly typical distance for a non-panic stop). (b) Suppose instead the car hits a concrete abutment at full speed ($90.0\,\text{km/h}$) and is brought to a stop in $2.00\,\text{m}$. Calculate the force exerted on the car and compare it with the force found in part (a).
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer12_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution12a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution12b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer12">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $2.47\, \text{kN}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $148\, \text{kN}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution12a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The car (of mass $m = 950\,\text{kg}$) moves with initial velocity
                        \begin{align}
                        v_0 &= 90.0\, \text{km/h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 25.0\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    which corresponds to an initial kinetic energy of
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.97\times 10^5 \text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    To bring the car to rest ($\text{KE}_\text{f} = 0$), over a distance of $d = 120\,\text{m}$, the braking force ($F$) does work on the car equal to the change in its kinetic energy, or
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= \Delta \text{KE} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F\, d\, \cos 180^\circ &= \text{KE}_\text{f} - \text{KE}_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad - F\, d &= 0 - \text{KE}_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F\, d &= \text{KE}_\text{i}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the magnitude of the force exerted on the car, opposite to the direction of motion, is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F & = \frac{\text{KE}_\text{i}}{d} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{2.97\times 10^5 \text{J}}{120\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.47\times 10^3\, \text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.47\, \text{kN}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution12b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If it stops over the relatively short distance of $d_2 = 2.00\,\text{m}$, the car experiences a force equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F & = \frac{\text{KE}_\text{i}}{d_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{2.97\times 10^5 \text{J}}{2.00\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 148\, \text{kN}
                        \end{align}
                    This is sixty times larger than the force found in part (a)
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 16 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p16">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 16</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A hydroelectric power facility (see <a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf#page=42" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">Figure 7.38</a> in the textbook) converts the gravitational potential energy of water behind a dam to electric energy. (a) What is the gravitational potential energy relative to the generators of a lake of volume $50.0\,\text{km}^3$ (mass = $5.00\times 10^{13}\,\text{kg}$), given that the lake has an average height of $40.0\,\text{m}$ above the generators? (b) Compare this with the energy stored in a $9$-megaton fusion bomb.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer16_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution16a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution16b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer16" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1.96\times 10^{16}\,\text{J}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $52\%$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution16a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The gravitational potential energy of a body of water of mass $m = 5.00\times10^{13}\,\text{kg}$ at a height of $h = 40.0\,\text{m}$ is
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{PE}_\text{water} &= m g h \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (5.00\times10^{13}\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (40.0\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.96\times 10^{16}\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution16b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The energy released by a $9$-megaton fusion bomb is (see <a href="../textbook/chapter-7.pdf#page=25" title="Chapter 7" target="_blank">Table 7.1</a> in the textbook)
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{E}_\text{bomb}= 3.8\times 10^{16}\,\text{J}
                        \end{equation}
                    So the ratio of gravitational potential energy of the body of water to the energy of a fusion bomb is
                        \begin{align}
                        \frac{\text{PE}_\text{water}}{\text{E}_\text{bomb}} &= \frac{1.96\times 10^{16}\,\text{J}}{3.8\times 10^{16}\,\text{J}}  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.52 \quad (\text{or}\; 52\%)
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 18 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p18">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 18</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose a $350$-$\text{g}$ kookaburra (a large kingfisher bird) picks up a $75$-$\text{g}$ snake and raises it $2.5\,\text{m}$ from the ground to a branch. (a) How much work did the bird do on the snake? (b) How much work did it do to raise its own centre of mass to the branch?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer18_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution18a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution18b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer18">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $1.8\,\text{J}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $8.6\,\text{J}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The work done by the bird on the snake ($m_\text{s} = 0.075\,\text{kg}$) is equal to the change in its potential energy. If the branch is at a height $h = 2.5\,\text{m}$ above the ground, we can calculate the work done on the snake to be
                        \begin{align}
                        W_\text{s} &= \Delta \text{PE}_\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m_\text{s}\, g\, h - 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.075\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.5\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.8\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Similarly, the work done to raise its own centre of mass, from the ground to the branch, is equal to the change in the bird&rsquo;s potential energy. Since the kookaburra has a mass of $m_\text{k} = 0.350\,\text{kg}$, the work done is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        W_\text{k} &= \Delta \text{PE}_\text{k} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m_\text{k}\, g\, h - 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.350\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.5\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.6\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 22 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p22">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 22</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $5.00\times 10^5\,\text{kg}$ subway train is brought to a stop from a speed of $0.500\,\text{m/s}$ in $0.400\,\text{m}$ by a large spring bumper at the end of its track. What is the force constant $k$ of the spring?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer22_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram22_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution22_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer22">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$7.81\times 10^5\,\text{N/m}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram22">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch07-p22s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P7.22s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution22">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The subway train has a mass of $m = 5.00\times 10^5 \,\text{kg}$ and an initial speed of $v_0 = 0.500\,\text{m/s}$. It is brought to a stop ($v = 0$) by a spring of force constant $k$, over a distance of $x = 0.400\,\text{m}$ (see <b>Figure P7.22s</b>). If we ignore friction, the train is slowed down by the restoring force provided by the spring. Since this is a conservative force, the mechanical energy of the system remains constant, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} + \text{PE}_\text{i} = \text{KE}_\text{f} + \text{PE}_\text{f}
                        \label{ch07_p22_KEPE}
                        \end{equation}
                    </p>

                    <p>Initially, when the spring is relaxed, there is no elastic potential energy ($\text{PE}_\text{i} = 0$), and the train moves with initial kinetic energy
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} = \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2
                        \end{equation}
                    When the train comes to a stop ($\text{KE}_\text{f} = 0$), the final potential energy stored in the compressed spring is given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{PE}_\text{f} = \tfrac{1}{2} k x^2
                        \end{equation}
                    </p>

                    <p>By substituting into Equation \ref{ch07_p22_KEPE}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 + 0 &= 0 + \tfrac{1}{2} k x^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad m v_0^2 &= k x^2
                        \end{align}
                        So, the force constant is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        k &= \frac{m v_0^2}{x^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(5.00\times 10^5\,\text{kg})\, (0.500\,\text{m/s})^2}{(0.400\,\text{m})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 7.81\times 10^5\,\text{N/m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 24 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p24">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 24</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $60.0$-$\text{kg}$ skier with an initial speed of $12.0\,\text{m/s}$ coasts up a $2.50$-$\text{m}$-high rise as shown in <b>Figure P7.24</b>. Find her final speed at the top, given that the coefficient of friction between her skis and the snow is $0.0800$. (Hint: Find the distance traveled up the incline assuming a straight-line path as shown in the figure.)
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch07-p24.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P7.24</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer24_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer24">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$9.46\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The skier, of mass $m = 60.0\,\text{kg}$, moves with an initial speed of $v_\text{i} = 12.0\,\text{m/s}$, and goes up a $\theta = 35.0^\circ$ slope to a plateau at a height $h = 2.50\,\text{m}$ above the initial level. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the skis and the snow is $\mu_\text{k} = 0.0800$.</p>

                    <p>BY applying the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit07-energy-conservation">law of conservation of energy</a> on the system, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} + \text{PE}_\text{i} + W_f = \text{KE}_\text{f} + \text{PE}_\text{f}
                        \label{ch07_p24_KEPEW}
                        \end{equation}
                    where the skier has initial kinetic energy
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} = \tfrac{1}{2}m v_\text{i}^2
                        \label{ch07_p24_KEi}
                        \end{equation}
                    and initial potential energy
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{PE}_\text{i} = 0
                        \label{ch07_p24_PEi}
                        \end{equation}
                    The work done by the force of kinetic friction, as the skier moves up the slope, is given by
                        \begin{align}
                        W_f &= f_\text{k}\, d\, \cos 180^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - \mu_\text{k}\, N\, d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -\mu_\text{k}\, (m g \cos\theta)\, d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -\mu_\text{k}\, m g\, d\, \cos\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -\frac{\mu_\text{k}\, m g\, h}{\tan\theta}
                        \label{ch07_p24_Wf}
                        \end{align}
                    where the distance ($d$) the skier travels up the incline (see <b>Figure P7.24</b>) is given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        d = \frac{h}{\sin\theta}
                        \end{equation}
                    </p>

                    <p>When the skier is at the higher plateau, she has a final kinetic energy of
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{KE}_\text{f} = \tfrac{1}{2} m v_\text{f}^2
                        \label{ch07_p24_KEf}
                        \end{equation}
                    and a final potential energy
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{PE}_\text{f} = m g h
                        \label{ch07_p24_PEf}
                        \end{equation}
                    <p>

                    <p>By substituting from Equations \ref{ch07_p24_KEi}, \ref{ch07_p24_PEi}, \ref{ch07_p24_Wf}, \ref{ch07_p24_KEf}, and \ref{ch07_p24_PEf} into Equation \ref{ch07_p24_KEPEW}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \tfrac{1}{2}m v_\text{i}^2 + 0 -\frac{\mu_\text{k}\, m g h}{\tan\theta} &=  \tfrac{1}{2} m v_\text{f}^2 + m g h \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_\text{i}^2 - \frac{2 \mu_\text{k}\, g h}{\tan\theta} &=  v_\text{f}^2 + 2 g h
                        \end{align}
                    By solving for the final speed, we find
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{f} &= \sqrt{v_\text{i}^2 - \frac{2 \mu_\text{k}\, g h}{\tan\theta} - 2 g h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{v_\text{i}^2 - 2 g h \left(\frac{\mu_\text{k}}{\tan\theta} + 1\right)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(12.0\,\text{m/s})^2 - 2\, (9.80\,\text{m/s}^2)(2.50\,\text{m}) \left(\frac{0.0800}{\tan 35.0^\circ} + 1\right)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9.46\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 34 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p34">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 34</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A large household air conditioner may consume $15.0\,\text{kW}$ of power. What is the cost of operating this air conditioner $3.00\,\text{h}$ per day for $30.0\,\text{d}$ if the cost of electricity is $\$ 0.110$ per $\text{kW}\cdot\text{h}$?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer34_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution34_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer34">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$\$ 149$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The air conditioner operates for $3.00\,\text{h}$ per day for $30.0\,\text{d}$. This is a total time of
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= 3.00\,\text{h/d} \times 30.0\,\text{d} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 90.0\,\text{h}
                        \end{align}
                    With a <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit07-power">power</a> consumption of $P = 15.0\,\text{kW}$, the AC unit withdraws a total electric energy, over the same period, equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= P\, t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (15.0\,\text{kW})\, (90\,\text{h}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1{,}350\,\text{kW}\cdot\text{h}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that this corresponds to
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= 1{,}350\,\text{kW}\cdot\text{h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1{,}350\times 10^3\, \text{J}}{\text{s}} \times \text{h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1.350\times 10^6\, \text{J}}{\color{red}{\text s}} \times 3{,}600\,\color{red}{\text s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.86\times 10^9\, \text{J} \quad (\text{or}\; 4.86\,\text{billion joules})
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>The total cost of running the unit is, therefore, equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{cost} &= (1{,}350\,\text{kW}\cdot\text{h})\times \$ 0.110\, (\text{kW}\cdot\text{h})^{-1} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \$ 149
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 37 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p37">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 37</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $500\,\text{kg}$ dragster accelerates from rest to a final speed of $110\,\text{m/s}$ in $400\,\text{m}$ (about a quarter of a mile) and encounters an average frictional force of $1200\,\text{N}$. What is its average power output in watts and horsepower if this takes $7.30\,\text{s}$?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer37_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution37_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer37">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$4.80\times 10^5\,\text{W},\; 644\,\text{hp}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution37">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Assuming a level road, the dragster does not experience a change in its gravitational potential energy during the trip, or
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta\text{PE} &= \text{PE}_\text{f} - \text{PE}_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0
                        \end{align}
                     As the dragster starts from rest ($\text{KE}_\text{i} = 0$), the law of conservation of energy (Equation \ref{unit07_energy_conservation}) reduces to
                        \begin{equation}
                        W = \text{KE}_\text{f}
                        \label{ch07_p37_WKE}
                        \end{equation}
                    where $W$ is the work done on the dragster and $\text{KE}_\text{f}$ is its final kinetic energy.</p>

                    <p>As the dragster accelerates over a distance $d = 400\,\text{m}$ the engine does a positive work ($W_\text{E}$), while frictional and drag forces ($f = 1{,}200\,\text{N}$) do a negative work equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        W_f &= f\, d\, \cos 180^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - (1{,}200\,\text{N})\, (400\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - 4.80\times 10^5\,\text{J}
                        \label{ch07_p37_Wf}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the total work done on the dragster is given by
                        \begin{align}
                        W &=  W_\text{E} + W_f \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= W_\text{E} - 4.80\times 10^5\,\text{J}
                        \label{ch07_p37_W}
                        \end{align}
                    Since the dragster, of mass $m = 500\,\text{kg}$, reaches a final speed $v_\text{f} = 110\,\text{m/s}$, we can calculate the final kinetic energy to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{f} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_\text{f}^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} (500\,\text{kg})\, (110\,\text{m/s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.02\times 10^6\,\text{J}
                        \label{ch07_p37_KEf}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>By substituting from Equations \ref{ch07_p37_W} and \ref{ch07_p37_KEf} into Equation \ref{ch07_p37_WKE}, we can calculate the work done by the engine as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        W_\text{E} - 4.80\times 10^5\,\text{J} &= 3.025\times 10^6\,\text{J} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad W_\text{E} &= 3.02\times 10^6\,\text{J} + 4.80\times 10^5\,\text{J} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.50\times 10^6\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    If this energy is produced by the engine over a time period of $\Delta t = 7.30\,\text{s}$, then its average power output is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        P &= \frac{W_\text{E}}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{3.50\times 10^6\,\text{J}}{7.30\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.80\times 10^5\,\text{W}
                        \end{align}
                    In horsepower, the average power output is expressed as
                        \begin{align}
                        P &= 4.80\times 10^5\,\color{red}{\text W} \times \frac{1\,\text{hp}}{746\,\color{red}{\text W}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 644\,\text{hp}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 40 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p40">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 40</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) What is the available energy content, in joules, of a battery that operates a $2.00\,\text{W}$ electric clock for $18.0\,\text{months}$? (b) How long can a battery that can supply $8.00\times 10^4\,\text{J}$ run a pocket calculator that consumes energy at the rate of $1.00\times 10^{−3}\,\text{W}$?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer40_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution40a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution40b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer40" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $9.47\times 10^7\,\text{J}$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $2.54\,\text{year}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution40a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Here, the battery supplies energy at the rate $P_\text{a} = 2.00\,\text{J/s}$ for a period of
                        \begin{align}
                        t_\text{a} &= 18.0\,\text{month} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 18.0\,\color{red}{\text{month}} \times \frac{1\,\text{year}}{12\,\color{red}{\text{month}}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.50\,\text{year}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.50\,\color{red}{\text{year}} \times \frac{365.25\,\color{blue}{\text{day}}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{year}}} \times \frac{24\,\color{green}{\text{h}}}{1\,\color{blue}{\text{day}}} \times \frac{3{,}600\,\text{s}}{1\,\color{green}{\text{h}}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.73\times 10^7\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the total supplied energy over this period is
                        \begin{align}
                        E_\text{a} &= P_\text{a}\, t_\text{a} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (2.00\,\text{J/s})\, (4.73\times 10^7\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9.47\times 10^7\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution40b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>A battery that can supply a total energy of $E_\text{b} = 8.00\times 10^4\,\text{J}$, can run a calculator that has an energy consumption of $P_\text{b} = 1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{W}$ for
                        \begin{align}
                        t_\text{b} &= \frac{W_\text{b}}{P_\text{b}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{8.00\times 10^4\,\text{J}}{1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{J/s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.00\times 10^7\,\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.00\times 10^7\,\color{red}{\text s} \times \frac{1\,\color{green}{\text{h}}}{3600\,\color{red}{\text s}} \times \frac{1\,\color{blue}{\text{day}}}{24\,\color{green}{\text{h}}} \times \frac{1\,\text{year}}{365.25\,\color{blue}{\text{day}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.54\,\text{year}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 42 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p42">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 42</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Calculate the power output needed for a $950\,\text{kg}$ car to climb a $2.00^\circ$ slope at a constant speed of $30.0\,\text{m/s}$ while encountering wind resistance and friction totaling $600\,\text{N}$. Explicitly show how you follow the steps in the Problem-Solving Strategies for Energy.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer42_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram42_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution42_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer42" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$27.7\,\text{kW}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram42">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch07-p42s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P7.42s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution42" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The car, of mass of $m = 950\,\text{kg}$, moves up a $\theta = 2.00^\circ$ slope at a constant speed of $v = 30.0\,\text{m/s}$, as shown in <b>Figure P7.42s</b>. Since there is no acceleration, the net force on the car must be equal to zero. This means the force ($F_\text{e}$) generated by the engine up the incline is balanced by the gravitational ($m g \sin\theta$) and frictional ($f = 600\,\text{N}$) forces down the incline, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{e} - m g \sin\theta - f = 0
                        \end{equation}
                   So, the car is pushed forward with a force
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{e} &= m g \sin\theta + f \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (950\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, \sin 2.00^\circ + 600\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 925\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                   The power output of the engine is, therefore, equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        P &= F\, v \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (925\,\text{N})\, (30.0\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.77\times 10^4\,\text{W}
                        \end{align}
                   </p>
                   </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 56 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p56">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 56</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The swimmer shown in <b>Figure P7.56</b> exerts an average horizontal backward force of $80.0\,\text{N}$ with his arm during each $1.80\,\text{m}$ long stroke. (a) What is his work output in each stroke? (b) Calculate the power output of his arms if he does $120$ strokes per minute.
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch07-p56.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P7.56</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer56_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution56a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution56b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer56" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $144\,\text{J}$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $288\,\text{W}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution56a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The swimmer&rsquo;s hand exerts an average force of $F = 80.0\,\text{N}$ in the horizontal direction, as it moves backward a horizontal distance $d = 1.80\,\text{m}$. So, the work done by the hand in a single stroke is
                        \begin{align}
                        W &= F\, d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (80.0\,\text{N})\, (1.80\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 144\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution56b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>In a time period of
                       \begin{align}
                        t &= 1\,\text{min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 60\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    the swimmer does $120$ strokes, which corresponds to a total work output of
                        \begin{align}
                        W_\text{1 min} &= 120\times W \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 120\times (144\,\text{J}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.728\times 10^4\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the power output of the swimmer&rsquo;s arm is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        P &= \frac{W_\text{1 min}}{t}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1.728\times 10^4\,\text{J}}{60\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 288\,\text{W}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 74 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p64">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 64</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) What force must be supplied by an elevator cable to produce an acceleration of $0.800\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ against a $200\,\text{N}$ frictional force, if the mass of the loaded elevator is $1500\,\text{kg}$? (b) How much work is done by the cable in lifting the elevator $20.0\,\text{m}$? (c) What is the final speed of the elevator if it starts from rest? (d) How much work went into thermal energy?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer64_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram64_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution64a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution64b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution64c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution64d_btn">Solution (d)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer64" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $1.61\times 10^4\,\text{N}$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $3.22\times 10^5\,\text{J}$</p>
                        <p>(c) $5.66\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                        <p>(d) $4.00\times 10^3\,\text{J}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram64">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch07-p64s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P7.64s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution64a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The loaded elevator has a mass of $m = 1500\,\text{kg}$ and accelerates upward at $a = 0.800\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$. The forces which act on the elevator (see <b>Figure P7.64s</b>) are the upward force supplied by the cable ($F_\text{c}$), the downward force of gravity ($m g$) and the frictional force ($f = 200\,\text{N}$) opposing the motion. The net force produced is, therefore, given by
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{net} &= F_\text{c} - m g - f
                        \label{ch07_p64_Fnet}
                        \end{align}
                    From Newton&rsquo;s second law of motion, we also have
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{net} &= m a
                        \label{ch07_p64_Fma}
                        \end{align}
                   By substituting from Equation \ref{ch07_p64_Fnet} into Equation \ref{ch07_p64_Fma}, we can calculate the tension in the cable as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{c} - m g - f &= m a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_\text{c} &= m\, (a + g) + f \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=(1500\,\text{kg})\, (0.800\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2 + 9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) + 200\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.61\times 10^4\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution64b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>As the elevator moves up a distance $d = 20.0\,\text{m}$, the work done by the cable is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        W_\text{c} &= F_\text{c}\, d\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (1.61\times 10^4\,\text{N})\, (20.0\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.22\times 10^5\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution64c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If the elevator starts from rest ($v_0 = 0$), we can calculate its final speed as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v^2 &= 0 + 2\, a\, d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v &= \sqrt{2\, a\, d} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{2\, (0.800\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (20.0\,\text{m})} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.66\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution64d" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (d)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The work done by frictional forces appears as thermal energy, which is equal to
                         \begin{align}
                         W_f &= f\, d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= (200\,\text{N})\, (20.0\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 4.00\times 10^3\,\text{J}
                         \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 69 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter07-p69">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Problem 69</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $105\,\text{kg}$ basketball player crouches down $0.400\,\text{m}$ while waiting to jump. After exerting a force on the floor through this $0.400\,\text{m}$, his feet leave the floor and his centre of gravity rises $0.950\,\text{m}$ above its normal standing erect position. (a) Using energy considerations, calculate his velocity when he leaves the floor. (b) What average force did he exert on the floor? (Do not neglect the force to support his weight as well as that to accelerate him.) (c) What was his power output during the acceleration phase?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer69_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution69a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution69b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution69c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer69" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $4.32\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $3.47\,\text{kN}$</p>
                        <p>(c) $7.49\,\text{kW}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution69a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The player, of mass $m = 105\,\text{kg}$, leaves the floor with initial speed $v_0$ and moves a vertical distance $h = 0.950\,\text{m}$ to maximum height. In this process the player&rsquo;s kinetic energy changes by
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta\text{KE} &= \text{KE}_\text{f} - \text{KE}_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 - \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2
                        \label{ch07_p69_DKE}
                        \end{align}
                    whereas the change in the potential energy is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta\text{PE} &= \text{PE}_\text{f} - \text{PE}_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m g h - 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m g h
                        \label{ch07_p69_DPE}
                        \end{align}
                   </p>

                   <p>When ignoring any effect due to friction or air resistance, the total mechanical energy of the player is conserved. This can be expressed as (see <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit07-energy-conservation">Equation \ref{unit07_KEPE_0}</a>)
                        \begin{equation}
                        \Delta\text{KE} + \Delta\text{PE} = 0
                        \label{ch07_p69_DKEPE}
                        \end{equation}
                  By substituting from Equations \ref{ch07_p69_DKE} and \ref{ch07_p69_DPE} into Equation \ref{ch07_p69_DKEPE}, we can calculate the player&rsquo;s initial velocity when he leaves the floor, as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        - \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 + m g h &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_0^2 &= 2 g h \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_0 &= \sqrt{2 g h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{2\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (0.950\,\text{m})} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.32\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution69b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The player&rsquo;s feet remain in contact with the floor as his centre of gravity rises a vertical distance $\Delta y = 0.400\,\text{m}$ to the normal standing erect position. In this case, the work ($W_\text{floor}$) done on the player by the contact force ($F_\text{floor}$) is equal to the change in his mechanical energy during this stage of his motion. This can expressed as
                        \begin{equation}
                        \Delta\text{KE} + \Delta\text{PE} = W_\text{floor}
                        \end{equation}
                    or
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} + \text{PE}_\text{i} + W_\text{floor} = \text{KE}_\text{f} + \text{PE}_\text{f}
                        \label{ch07_p69_KEPEW}
                        \end{equation}
                    By substituting (into Equation \ref{ch07_p69_KEPEW}) the appropriate values for this phase of the player&rsquo;s jump, we can determine the work done by the contact force as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        0 + 0 + W_\text{floor} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 + m g\, \Delta y \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad W_\text{floor} &= \tfrac{1}{2} (105\,\text{kg})\, (4.32\,\text{m/s})^2 + (105\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (0.400\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.39\times 10^3\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the average force exert by the floor on the player&rsquo;s feet is
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{floor} &= \frac{W_\text{floor}}{\Delta y} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1.39\times 10^3\,\text{J}}{0.400\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.47\times 10^3\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution69c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Assuming a constant contact force, the duration ($\Delta t$) of the acceleration phase can be calculated (see <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-constant-acceleration">kinematic equations</a>) by dividing the distance traveled ($\Delta y$) by the average speed ($\bar{v} = v_0/2$). So, we have
                        \begin{align}
                         \Delta t &= \frac{\Delta y}{\bar{v}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= \frac{2 \Delta y}{v_0} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= \frac{2\, (0.400\,\text{m})}{4.32\,\text{m/s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 0.185\,\text{s}
                         \end{align}
                    So, the power output of the player&rsquo;s muscles during the acceleration phase is calculated to be
                         \begin{align}
                         P &= \frac{W_\text{floor}}{\Delta t}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= \frac{1.39\times 10^3\,\text{J}}{0.185\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 7.49\times 10^3\,\text{W}
                         \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit08" >

                  <!-- to change: the following content -->
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Linear Momentum and Collisions</h1>
                  <hr>

                  <p>If you throw a tennis ball at your bedroom wall it should bounce back. However, if you try it with a bowling ball you will make a big hole in the drywall! In these cases, even if the two balls move at the same speed, the bowling ball has much greater momentum.</p>

                  <p>An important subject that utilizes the concept of momentum is the interaction of two (or more) particles. Physicists perform collision experiments in the advanced research of nuclear and particle physics. In such experiments, highly energetic particles (electrons, protons or atoms nuclei) are smashed together for the purpose of studying the structure of matter at the subatomic level and understand the fundamental interactions between the elementary particles in nature. Such experiments, which are done at the microscopic level, require highly sophisticated equipment and more involved theoretical calculations due to the complications of relativistic and quantum effects. In this unit, we will study collisions at the macroscopic level using only the principles of Newtonian mechanics.</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:2.0em;">
                  <div class="learningobjectives">
                    <h3>Learning Objectives</h3>
                    <p>After completing this unit, you should be able to</p>
                    <ul>
                        <li>define linear momentum of a moving body.</li>
                        <li>explain the relationship between impulse and momentum.</li>
                        <li>calculate the impulse given to a body due to a known force.</li>
                        <li>state the conservation of momentum principle.</li>
                        <li>explain the difference between elastic and inelastic collisions.</li>
                        <li>solve elastic and inelastic collision problems in one dimension.</li>
                        <li>solve elastic and inelastic collision problems in two dimensions.</li>
                    </ul>
                  </div>

                  <!-- end of content -->

                </div> <!-- end of this section -->

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit08-linear-momentum">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Linear Momentum and Collisions</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Linear Momentum</h2>

                <p>In this unit, we will introduce one of the most important concepts in physics, <em>linear momentum</em>. It is simply defined as the product of mass and velocity. So, the linear momentum of a body of mass $m$ moving with velocity $v$, in one dimension, is given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        p = m v
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>To see how the concept of linear momentum, commonly referred to as momentum, fits into the Newtonian scheme, we will take another look at <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-second-law">Newton&rsquo;s second law of motion</a>. Mathematically, the law can be expressed as
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= m a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m\, \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{\Delta (m v)}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \end{align}
                where $a$ is the linear acceleration of the body, and $F$ is the net force that acts on it.
                </p>

                <p>In general, velocity is a vector quantity, and so is linear momentum. This is because the multiplication of a vector ($\bf v$) by a scalar ($m$) results in a vector ($\bf p$), or
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf p} = m {\bf v}
                        \end{equation}
                The corresponding form of Newton’s second law,
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf F} = \frac{\Delta \bf p}{\Delta t} \quad (\text{or}\; {\Delta \bf p} = {\bf F}\, \Delta t)
                        \end{equation}
                takes on a new interpretation in light of the new relationship. When an unbalanced force acts on a body for a time period $\Delta t$, the body experiences a change in momentum (also called <em>impulse</em>) equal to ${\bf F} \Delta t$. Alternatively, we can say that the rate of change of momentum is equal to the net force on the body. In Newtonian mechanics, the two statements, ${\bf F} = m\, {\bf a}$ and ${\bf F} = {\Delta \bf p}/{\Delta t}$ are equivalent.
                </p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit08-vid01.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 8.1</b>: Concept of linear momentum.
                </p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>

                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-8.pdf#page=2" title="Chapter 8" target="_blank">8.1.&nbsp; Linear Momentum and Force</a></li>
