<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit08-momentum-conservation">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Linear Momentum and Collisions</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Conservation of Momentum</h2>

                <p>From Newton’s second law, ${\bf F} = {\Delta \bf p}/{\Delta t}$, it is evident that, in the absence of a force, the rate of change of momentum is equal to zero. In other words the momentum remains constant. The generalization of this relationship, which states that the total momentum of an isolated system is constant, is the celebrated <em>conservation of momentum principle</em>.
                </p>

                <p>Consider a system (or a collection) of particles interacting in space. In this case we need to differentiate between two types of forces acting on the particles. The first type involves internal forces, which are applied by the different particles in the system on each other. Examples are: gravitational attractions between the particles, elastic forces due to collisions, or electrical forces if the particles are charged. The second type refers to external forces, which are applied on the particles by sources that exist outside the system. For example, the system could be in the vicinity of a large planet and is affected by its gravitational field.</p>

                <p>Particles of different masses may collide with each other within an isolated system, and may change velocities, resulting in changes in the momentum of the individual particles. However, the total linear momentum of the system remains a constant as long as no external forces act on it. Assume that such a system consists of the masses $m_1$, $m_2$, $m_3$, etc., with the corresponding velocities ${\bf v}_1$, ${\bf v}_2$, ${\bf v}_3$, etc. at a specific instant in time. The total momentum of the system can be written as
                        \begin{align}
                        {\bf p} &= {\bf p}_1 + {\bf p}_2 + {\bf p}_3 + \ldots \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m_1 {\bf v}_1 + m_2 {\bf v}_2 + m_3 {\bf v}_3 + \ldots
                        \end{align}
                If, at a later instant in time, the velocities of the particles change to ${\bf v}'_1$, ${\bf v}'_2$, ${\bf v}'_3$, etc., the total momentum becomes
                        \begin{align}
                        {\bf p}' &= {\bf p}'_1 + {\bf p}'_2 + {\bf p}'_3 + \ldots \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m_1 {\bf v}'_1 + m_2 {\bf v}'_2 + m_3 {\bf v}'_3 + \ldots
                        \end{align}
                According to the conservation of momentum principle, the total momentum of this isolated system is conserved, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        {\bf p} = {\bf p}' = \text{constant}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>As is the  law of conservation of energy, the conservation of momentum principle is a cornerstone of physics; together, the two form a powerful tool for analyzing motion.
                </p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-8.pdf" title="Chapter 8" target="_blank">Chapter 8</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-8.pdf#page=6" title="Chapter 8" target="_blank">8.3.&nbsp; Conservation of Momentum</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit08-collisions">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Linear Momentum and Collisions</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Collisions</h2>

                <p>When two bodies collide, they experience equal (but opposite) forces during the short period of interaction. As a result, one body receives impulse in one direction, while the other body receives equal impulse in the opposite direction. In other words, if the first body gains momentum as a result of the collision, the second body looses momentum by exactly the same amount. So, the linear momentum of the system is conserved during the collision.</p>

                <p>It should be mentioned here that collisions are divided into two main categories&mdash;<em>elastic</em> and <em>inelastic</em>&mdash;based on kinetic energy considerations. Total energy and total momentum are always conserved in a collision, but if kinetic energy is also conserved, the collision is called elastic.</p>

                <h3>Collisions in One Dimension</h3>

                <p>Consider two masses, $m_1$ and $m_2$, which move on the same line and approach each other with velocities ${\bf v}_1$ and ${\bf v}_2$, respectively. The two masses collide, head-on, and bounce with velocities ${\bf v}'_1$ and ${\bf v}'_2$ as shown in <a href="#unit08-fig01"><b>Figure 8.1</b></a>. Since the total momentum of the system, before and after the collision, remains constant, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        m_1\, {\bf v}_1 + m_2\, {\bf v}_2 = m_1\, {\bf v}'_1 + m_2\, {\bf v}'_2
                        \label{unit08_pnet}
                        \end{equation}
                This equation applies to all kinds of collisions, in the absence of external forces. If the collision is elastic, then the kinetic energy is conserved and the following equation is also satisfied
                        \begin{equation}
                        \tfrac{1}{2} m_1 v^2_1 + \tfrac{1}{2} m_2 v^2_2 = \tfrac{1}{2} m_1 v'^2_1 + \tfrac{1}{2} m_2 v'^2_2
                        \label{unit08_KEnet}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit08-fig01">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit08-fig01.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 8.1</b>: Two masses undergo collision in one dimension.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>It is important to note that the conservation of momentum equation (\ref{unit08_pnet}) and the conservation of kinetic energy equation (\ref{unit08_KEnet}), describe a perfectly elastic collision. If the kinetic energy is not conserved, then it is only the conservation of momentum equation that applies, and the collision is referred to as inelastic.</p>

                <p>We should also mention that in Equation \ref{unit08_pnet} velocities appear as vector quantities. However, for motion in one dimension we only have two directions (e.g., right or left). Therefore, it is usually convenient to assign positive values for velocities directed to the right and negative values for velocities directed to the left.
                </p>

                <h3>Collisions in Two Dimension</h3>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit08-fig02">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit08-fig02.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 8.2</b>: Two masses undergo collision in two dimensions.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>If the two masses, after the collision, are scattered in directions that are not along the original line of motion, as in <a href="#unit08-fig02"><b>Figure 8.2</b></a>, then we have a collision in two dimensions. The law of conservation of momentum also applies in this case. However, we need to be careful here and pay close attention to the vector nature of velocity and momentum. To be specific, both the horizontal and the vertical components of momentum are separately conserved. So, the equation representing conservation of momentum is resolved into two scalar equations along the mutually perpendicular $x$ and $y$ axes as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        m_1\, v_{1x} + m_2\, v_{2x} &= m_1\, v'_{1x}+ m_2\, v'_{2x} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        m_1\, v_{1y} + m_2\, v_{2y} &= m_1\, v'_{1y}+ m_2\, v'_{2y}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>The equation representing conservation of kinetic energy, in the case of elastic collisions, is of the same form as Equation \ref{unit08_KEnet}, where
                        \begin{align}
                        v_1 &= \sqrt{v_{1x}^2 + v_{1y}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        v_2 &= \sqrt{v_{2x}^2 + v_{2y}^2}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <h3>PhET Simulation: Collision Lab</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-8.pdf#page=12" title="Chapter 8" target="_blank">textbook</a>, &ldquo;investigate collisions on an air hockey table. Set up your own experiments: vary the number of discs, masses and initial conditions. Is momentum conserved? Is kinetic energy conserved? Vary the elasticity and see what happens.</p>

                <p>
                <div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 197px;"><a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/collision-lab/collision-lab_en.html" target="_blank" style="text-decoration: none;" rel="external"><img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/collision-lab/collision-lab-600.png" alt="Collision Lab" style="border: none;" width="300" height="197"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);"></div><table style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px;"><tr><td style="text-align: center; color: #000; font-size: 24px; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Click to Run</td></tr></table></a></div>

                <div class="source">Source: <a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/legacy/collision-lab" target="_blank">PhET Interactive Simulations</a>, University of Colorado Boulder.</div>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit08-examples">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Linear Momentum and Collisions</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Examples</h2>

                    <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of examples relevant to the content of <span style="white-space: nowrap;">Unit 8</span>. Make an attempt to answer each question on your own, before you read through the solution provided.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit08-e01">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 8, Example 1</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A block of mass $m = 6.00\,\text{kg}$ moves on a horizontal surface and experiences a net force of $F = 15.0\,\text{N}$ in the direction of motion. What is the block&rsquo;s change in velocity after $\Delta t = 10.0\,\text{s}$?
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e01_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e01_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01_btn">Solution</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$25.0\,\text{m/s}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit08-e01s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E8.1s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>One way to solve this problem is to determine the acceleration ($a$) of the block caused by the applied force, and calculate the change in velocity using one of the kinematic equations as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta v & = v - v_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= a t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{F}{m}\right) \Delta t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{15.0\,\text{N}}{6.00\,\text{kg}}\right) (10.0\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 25.0\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>The problem can also be solved using the form of Newton&rsquo;s second law introduced in this unit. This is because the applied force and the duration of the applied force are known. So, during the specified time interval, the block experiences a change in momentum equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta p &= F\, \Delta t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (15.0\,\text{N})\, (10.0\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 150\,\text{N}\cdot\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>Since momentum is defined as mass times velocity, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        \Delta p = m\, \Delta v
                        \end{equation}
                The increase in the block&rsquo;s velocity is therefore calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta v &= \frac{\Delta p}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{150\,\text{N}\cdot\text{s}}{6.00\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 25.0\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit08-e02">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 8, Example 2</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A young skater of mass $27.0\,\text{kg}$ stands on a smooth ice rink and throws a $600$-$\text{g}$ bag horizontally with a speed of $9.00\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the recoil velocity of the skater immediately after the throw. Ignore friction between ice and the skates.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e02_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02_btn">Solution</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$- 0.200\, \text{m/s}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>The system in this problem consists of the skater (mass $m_\text{s} = 27.0\,\text{kg}$) and the bag (mass $m_\text{b} = 0.600\,\text{kg}$). Before the skater throws the bag, all components of the system are at rest. So, the initial momentum of the system is equal to zero. In order for the skater to throw the bag, she must apply a horizontal force on it. According to <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-third-law">Newton&rsquo;s third law of motion</a>, an equal reaction force is also applied on the skater in the opposite direction. However, since these are internal forces, the total momentum of the system is conserved. This means, the momentum of the skater plus that of the bag remains equal to zero even while the bag is moving away from the skater. So, we write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{initial momentum} &= \text{final momentum} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad p_\text{i} &= p_\text{f} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= m_\text{b}\, v_\text{b} + m_\text{s}\, v_\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \end{align}
                where $v_\text{b} = 9.00\,\text{m/s}$ is the speed of the bag and $v_\text{s}$ is the recoil velocity of the skater. By solving for $v_\text{s}$, we find
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{s} &= - \left(\frac{m_\text{b}}{m_\text{s}}\right) v_\text{b} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - \left(\frac{0.600\,\text{kg}}{27.0\,\text{kg}}\right) (9.00\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - 0.200\, \text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                The negative sign indicates that the skater moves backward opposite to the direction of the thrown bag.
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit08-e03">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 8, Example 3</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A billiard ball moves to the right at a velocity of $2.00\,\text{m/s}$ and collides with an identical ball that moves at a velocity of $1.00\,\text{m/s}$ in the same direction and along the same line. If the collision is perfectly elastic, determine the velocities of the balls after the collision?
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e03_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e03_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03_btn">Solution</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$1.00\,\text{m/s},\; 2.00\,\text{m/s}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit08-e03s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E8.3s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>This is a collision in one dimension, where the two balls (see <b>Figure E8.3s</b>) move along the same line before and after impact. Since no external forces are involved, the total momentum of the system is conserved.</p>

                <p>Ball $\text{A}$, before the collision, moves to the right at a velocity of $v_\text{A} = 2.00\,\text{m/s}$ behind ball $\text{B}$, which moves at the slower speed of $v_\text{B} = 1.00\,\text{m/s}$. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        p_\text{i} &= p_\text{f} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  m v_\text{A} + m v_\text{B} &= m v'_\text{A} +  m v'_\text{B}
                        \label{unit08_e03_p}
                        \end{align}
                where $v'_\text{A}$ and $v'_\text{B}$ are the velocities of balls $\text{A}$ and $\text{B}$, respectively, after the collision.</p>

                <p>The problem mentions that the collision between the two billiard balls is elastic. This means that the kinetic energy of the system is also conserved, or
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} &= \text{KE}_\text{f} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  \tfrac{1}{2} m v_\text{A}^2 +  \tfrac{1}{2} m v_\text{B}^2 &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_\text{A}^{\prime 2} + \tfrac{1}{2} m v_\text{B}^{\prime 2}
                        \label{unit08_e03_KE}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>Since the balls are of equal mass ($m$), Equations \ref{unit08_e03_p} and \ref{unit08_e03_KE} reduce to
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{A} + v_\text{B} &= v'_\text{A} +  v'_\text{B} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        v_\text{A}^2 + v_\text{B}^2 &= v_\text{A}^{\prime 2} + v_\text{B}^{\prime 2}
                        \end{align}
                Here we have two equations with two unknowns ($v'_\text{A}$ and $v'_\text{B}$) that need to be solved simultaneously. As a first step, we rearrange the terms in the two equations above as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{A} - v'_\text{A} &=  v'_\text{B} - v_\text{B} \label{unit08_e03_vAB}\\[6pt]
                        v_\text{A}^2 - v_\text{A}^{\prime 2} &= v_\text{B}^{\prime 2} - v_\text{B}^2 \label{unit08_e03_vAB2}
                        \end{align}
                The algebraic identity $(x^2 - y^2) = (x-y) (x+y)$, allows us to factor Equation \ref{unit08_e03_vAB2} above, which becomes
                        \begin{align}
                        (v_\text{A} - v'_\text{A})\, (v_\text{A} + v'_\text{A}) &= (v'_\text{B} - v_\text{B})\, (v'_\text{B} + v_\text{B}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_\text{A} + v'_\text{A} &= v_\text{B} + v'_\text{B}
                        \label{unit08_e03_vAABB}
                        \end{align}
                Note that the terms $(v_\text{A} - v'_\text{A})$ and $(v'_\text{B} - v_\text{B})$ cancelled out because they are equal according to Equation \ref{unit08_e03_vAB}.<p>

                <p>By substituting for $v'_\text{B}$ from Equation \ref{unit08_e03_vAB} into Equation \ref{unit08_e03_vAABB}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{A} + v'_\text{A} &= v_\text{B} + (v_\text{A} - v'_\text{A} + v_\text{B}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v'_\text{A} &= v_\text{B}
                        \label{unit08_e03_vAf}
                        \end{align}
                If we now substitute from Equation \ref{unit08_e03_vAf} into Equation \ref{unit08_e03_vAB}, we find
                        \begin{equation}
                        v'_\text{B} = v_\text{A}
                        \end{equation}
                The final velocities after the collision are, therefore
                        \begin{align}
                        v'_\text{A} &= 1.00\,\text{m/s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        v'_\text{B} &= 2.00\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>So the two balls simply exchanged velocities after the collision. Note that this general result applies to elastic head-on collisions (in one dimension) between two bodies of equal mass.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit08-e04">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 8, Example 4</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A blue minivan (of mass $1{,}300\,\text{kg}$) travels east and approaches an intersection with a speed of $30.0\,\text{km/h}$. A red minivan (of mass $1{,}600\,\text{kg}$) travels north and approaches that same intersection. Due to an extremely icy road condition, the two vehicles fail to stop and collide in the middle of the intersection and then skid together at an angle of $65.0^\circ$ north of east (see interactive <a href="./unit08-e04i.cdf"><b>Figure E8.4i</b></a>). Determine the initial speed of the red minivan.

                <p class="centerText"><a href="./unit08-e04i.cdf"><img  src="unit08-e04i.png" alt="image"></a><br>
                <br><b>Figure E8.4i</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e04_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e04_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e04_btn">Solution</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$52.3\,\text{km/h}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit08-e04s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E8.4s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>In this inelastic collision, the total momentum of the two-vehicle system is conserved in the east-west and in the north-south directions. Initially, the blue minivan has a velocity of $v_\text{b} = 8.33\,\text{m/s}$ directed eastward, while the initial velocity ($v_\text{r}$) of the red minivan is directed northward. After the collision, both vehicles move together with a final speed $v'$ directed at an angle $\theta = 65.0^\circ$ north of east, as shown in <b>Figure E8.4s</b>.</p>

                <p>Considering momenta in the east-west direction only, we can write
                        \begin{equation}
                        m_\text{b}\, v_\text{b} + 0 = (m_\text{b}+ m_\text{r})\, v' \cos\theta
                        \end{equation}
                where $m_\text{b} = 1{,}300\,\text{kg}$ and $m_\text{r} = 1{,}600\,\text{kg}$ are the masses of the blue and red minivans, respectively. So, directly after the collision, the two vehicles skid together at a speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        v' &= \left(\frac{m_\text{b}}{m_\text{b} + v_\text{r}}\right)\times \frac{v_\text{b}}{\cos\theta} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{1{,}300\,\text{kg}}{1{,}300\,\text{kg} + 1{,}600\,\text{kg}}\right)\times \frac{8.33\,\text{m/s}}{\cos 65.0^\circ}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.84\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>Considering momenta in the north-south direction only, we can calculate the initial speed of the red minivan as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        0 + m_\text{r}\, v_\text{r} &= (m_\text{b}+ m_\text{r})\, v' \sin\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_\text{r} &= \left(\frac{m_\text{b} + m_\text{r}}{m_\text{r}}\right) v'\, \sin\theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{1{,}300\,\text{kg} + 1{,}600\,\text{kg}}{1{,}600\,\text{kg}}\right)\times (8.84\,\text{m/s})\, \sin 65.0^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 14.5\,\text{m/s} \quad (\text{or}\; 52.3\,\text{km/h})
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-conceptual-questions">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Linear Momentum and Collisions</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Conceptual Questions</h2>

                  <p>Following, are detailed solutions of a number of conceptual questions selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-8.pdf#page=24" title="Chapter 8" target="_blank">Chapter 8</a> in the textbook.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-q01">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Question 1</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">An object that has a small mass and an object that has a large mass have the same momentum. Which object has the largest kinetic energy?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q01_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q01_btn">Explanation</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The object with the small mass will have larger kinetic energy.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Since the two objects have the same <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit08-linear-momentum">momentum</a>, the object with the smaller mass will have a higher velocity. While momentum is proportional to the mass and velocity, <a href="../unit07/index07.html#unit07-kinetic-energy">kinetic energy</a> is proportional to the mass and the square of the velocity. Therefore, the object with the smaller mass, but higher velocity will have a larger kinetic energy.
                    </p>

                    <p>In a more mathematical argument, we can express the kinetic energy of a object of mass $m$ and velocity $v$ as
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE} &= \frac{m v^2}{2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(m v)^2}{2 m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{p^2}{2 m}
                        \end{align}
                    where $p$ is the object&rsquo;s momentum. It is obvious from the equation above that increasing the mass causes the kinetic energy to decrease, if the momentum is kept constant.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-q05">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 7, Question 5</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Explain in terms of impulse how padding reduces forces in a collision. State this in terms of a real example, such as the advantages of a carpeted vs. tile floor for a day care centre.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q05_btn">Explanation</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>When a body hits a padded surface, say a child falling on a daycare floor, the change in momentum of the impact occurs over a greater period of time as the padding (or carpet) compresses. As a result, the impulse given to the child occurs over a relatively greater time interval, which reduces the force of impact and the possibility of injury.
                      </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 9 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-q09">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Question 9</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Under what circumstances is momentum conserved?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q09_btn">Answer</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q09">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Total momentum is conserved when the net external force on the system is equal to zero. Note that internal forces may cause the momenta of individual components of the system to change, but not the overall momentum. </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 13 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-q13">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Question 13</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Can objects in a system have momentum while the momentum of the system is zero? Explain your answer.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q13_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q13_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q13">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Yes.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q13">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>A simple example would be two objects moving in opposite directions with the same momentum. So, if each object has a momentum of magnitude $p$, the net momentum of the two-object system is
                        \begin{align}
                        p_\text{net} &= p + (-p) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= p - p \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 16 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-q16">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Question 16</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">What is an inelastic collision? What is a perfectly inelastic collision?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q16_btn">Answer</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q16">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>An inelastic collision is a collision where the kinetic energy of the system is not conserved. In a perfectly inelastic collision, the colliding objects stick together after impact.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 20 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-q20">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Question 20</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose a fireworks shell explodes, breaking into three large pieces for which air resistance is negligible. How is the motion of the centre of mass affected by the explosion? How would it be affected if the pieces experienced significantly more air resistance than the intact shell?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q20_btn">Answer</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>If air resistance is negligible, the motion of the centre of mass is unaffected and continues to behave like a <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-free-fall">free falling object</a>. If the pieces experience more air resistance than the intact shell, the centre of mass would move slower than expected. Some pieces may reach terminal velocity on their way down.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-problems">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Linear Momentum and Collisions</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Solutions of Selected Problems</h2>
                    <p>Next are detailed solutions to a number of problems selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-8.pdf#page=26" title="Chapter 8" target="_blank">Chapter 8</a> in the textbook. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve each problem independently, before you read through the solution provided. You are also advised to make a second attempt to solve the problem if your answer is different from the one posted. If you reach an impasse and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p01">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 1</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) Calculate the momentum of a $2000$-$\text{kg}$ elephant charging a hunter at a speed of $7.50\,\text{m/s}$. (b) Compare the elephant&rsquo;s momentum with the momentum of a $0.0400$-$\text{kg}$ tranquilizer dart fired at a speed of $600\,\text{m/s}$. (c) What is the momentum of the $90.0$-$\text{kg}$ hunter running at $7.40\,\text{m/s}$ after missing the elephant?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer01_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution01a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution01b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution01c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer01" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1.50\times 10^4 \,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $625 \,\text{times greater}$</p>
                      <p>(c) $666\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution01a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit08-linear-momentum">momentum</a> of an elephant of mass $m_\text{e} = 2000\,\text{kg}$ running at a speed of $v_\text{e} = 7.50\,\text{m/s}$ is
                        \begin{align}
                        p_\text{e} &= m_\text{e}\, v_\text{e} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (2000\,\text{kg})\, (7.50\,\text{m/s})\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.50\times 10^4 \,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution01b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The momentum of a tranquilizer dart of mass $m_\text{d} = 0.0400\,\text{kg}$ and a speed of $v_\text{d} = 600\,\text{m/s}$ is
                        \begin{align}
                        p_\text{d} &= m_\text{d}\, v_\text{d} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.0400\,\text{kg})\, (600\,\text{m/s})\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 24.0\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the elephant&rsquo;s momentum is $625$ times greater than that of the tranquilizer dart.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution01c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>After missing the elephant, the hunter&rsquo;s momentum is
                        \begin{align}
                         p_\text{h} &= m_\text{h}\, v_\text{h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= (90.0\,\text{kg})\, (7.40\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 666\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}
                         \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p04">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 4</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) What is the momentum of a garbage truck that is $1.20\times 10^4 \,\text{kg}$ and is moving at $10.0\,\text{m/s}$ ? (b) At what speed would an $8.00\,\text{kg}$ trash can have the same momentum as the truck?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer04_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution04a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution04b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1.20\times 10^5 \,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $1.50\times 10^4 \,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution04a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The garbage truck, of mass $m_\text{t} = 1.20\times 10^4\,\text{kg}$ and a speed of $v_\text{t} = 10.0\,\text{m/s}$, has a momentum of
                        \begin{align}
                        p &= m_\text{t}\, v_\text{t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (1.20\times 10^4\,\text{kg})\, (10.0\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.20\times 10^5 \,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution04b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>In order for a trash can of mass $m_\text{c} = 8.00\,\text{kg}$ to have the same momentum ($p$), it would have to move at a speed $v_\text{c}$, as calculated below.
                        \begin{align}
                        p &= m_\text{c}\, v_\text{c} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_\text{c} &= \frac{p}{m_\text{c}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1.20\times 10^5 \,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}}{8.00\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.50\times 10^4 \,\text{m/s} \quad (\text{or}\; 54{,}000\,\text{km/h})
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 5 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p05">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 5</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A runaway train car that has a mass of $15{,}000\,\text{kg}$ travels at a speed of $5.4\,\text{m/s}$ down a track. Compute the time required for a force of $1{,}500\,\text{N}$ to bring the car to rest.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer05_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution05_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$54\,\text{s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The train car has a mass of $m = 1.5\times 10^4\,\text{kg}$ and an initial speed of $v_\text{i} = 5.4\,\text{m/s}$. So, its initial momentum is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        p_\text{i} &= m\, v_\text{i}  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (1.5\times 10^4\,\text{kg})\, (5.4\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.1\times 10^4 \,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                      The car decelerates to rest ($p_\text{f} = 0$) under the influence of a constant force of $F = -1.5\times 10^3\,\text{N}$, which acts opposite to the direction of motion. To find the time ($\Delta t$) required to stop the car, we apply Newton&rsquo;s second law as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \Delta t &= \frac{\Delta p}{F} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{p_\text{f} - p_\text{i}}{F} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{0 - 8.1\times 10^4 \,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}}{-1.5\times 10^3\,\text{N}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 54\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 7 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p07">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 7</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A bullet is accelerated down the barrel of a gun by hot gases produced in the combustion of gun powder. What is the average force exerted on a $0.0300\,\text{kg}$ bullet to accelerate it to a speed of $600\,\text{m/s}$ in a time of $2.00\,\text{ms}$ (milliseconds)?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer07_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution07_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer07">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$9{,}000\,\text{N}$<p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution07">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The bullet, of mass $m = 0.0300\,\text{kg}$, accelerates from rest ($v_0 = 0$) to a speed of $v = 600\,\text{m/s}$, which corresponds to a change in momentum (or impulse) of
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta p &= m\, \Delta v \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m\, (v - v_0) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.0300\,\text{kg})\, (600\,\text{m/s} - 0) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 18.0 \,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    Since the bullet is accelerated in a time period of $\Delta t = 0.00200\,\text{s}$, the average force exerted by the hot gases is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{18.0 \,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}}{0.00200\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9{,}000\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>Alternatively, the problem can be solved by finding the acceleration of the bullet, using on of the kinematic equations, and then applying the initial form of Newton&rsquo;s second law. The calculation is left for you as an exercise.</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 11 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p11">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 11</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose a child drives a bumper car head on into the side rail, which exerts a force of $4000\,\text{N}$ on the car for $0.200\,\text{s}$. (a) What impulse is imparted by this force? (b) Find the final velocity of the bumper car if its initial velocity was $2.80\,\text{m/s}$ and the car plus driver have a mass of $200\,\text{kg}$. You may neglect friction between the car and floor.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer11_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram11_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution11a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution11b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer11">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $-800\, \text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $-1.20\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram11">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch08-p11s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P8.11s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution11a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If the initial direction of motion of the bumper car is taken as positive, then the force exerted by the side rail during impact is expressed as $F = -4{,}000\,\text{N}$ directed backwards. Since this occurs over a period of $\Delta t = 0.200\,\text{s}$, the impulse imparted by the force is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta p &= F\, \Delta t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (-4{,}000\,\text{N})\, (0.200\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -800\, \text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}
                        \label{ch08_p11_impulse}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution11b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The impulse ($\Delta p$) imparted by the impact force causes equal change in the momentum of the car-driver system. Since the initial velocity is $v_\text{i} = 2.80\,\text{m/s}$ and the mass of the car plus driver is $m = 200\,\text{kg}$, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta p &= p_\text{f} - p_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m v_\text{f} - m v_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m\, (v_\text{f} - v_\text{i})
                        \end{align}
                    The final velocity of the bumper car is, then, calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{f} &= v_\text{i} + \frac{\Delta p}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.80\,\text{m/s} + \frac{(-800\, \text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s})}{200\,\text{kg}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -1.20\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the bumper car (and the child) bounce back at a speed of $1.20\,\text{m/s}$.
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 12 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p12">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 12</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">One hazard of space travel is debris left by previous missions. There are several thousand objects orbiting Earth that are large enough to be detected by radar, but there are far greater numbers of very small objects, such as flakes of paint. Calculate the force exerted by a $0.100\,\text{mg}$ chip of paint that strikes a spacecraft window at a relative speed of $4.00\times10^3\,\text{m/s}$ , given the collision lasts $6.00\times 10^{–8}\,\text{s}$.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer12_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution12_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer12" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$6.67\,\text{kN}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution12" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The mass of the chip of paint is
                        \begin{align}
                        m &= 0.100\,\text{mg} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.00\times 10^{-4}\,\color{red}{\text{g}} \times \frac{1\,\text{kg}}{1000\,\color{red}{\text{g}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.00\times 10^{-7}\,\text{kg}
                        \end{align}
                    and it travels towards the spacecraft with a relative speed of $v_\text{i} = 4.00 \times 10^3\,\text{m/s}$. The chip of paint strikes and sticks ($v_\text{f} = 0$) to the spacecraft window during a very short period of $\Delta t = 6.00\times 10^{-8}\,\text{s}$. So, in this case
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{impulse on window} &= - (\text{impulse on chip of paint}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - \Delta p \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - m\, (v_\text{f} - v_\text{i}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -(1.00\times 10^{-7}\,\text{kg})\, (0 - 4.00 \times 10^3\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.00\times 10^{-4}\, \text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    The force exerted on the window due the impact is then calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= \frac{\text{impulse on window}}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{4.00\times 10^{-4}\, \text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}}{6.00^{-8}\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 6.67\times 10^3 \,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 13 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p13">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 13</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $75.0\,\text{kg}$ person is riding in a car moving at $20.0\,\text{m/s}$ when the car runs into a bridge abutment. (a) Calculate the average force on the person if he is stopped by a padded dashboard that compresses an average of $1.00\,\text{cm}$. (b) Calculate the average force on the person if he is stopped by an air bag that compresses an average of $15.0\,\text{cm}$.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer13_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution13a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution13b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer13">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $1.50\times 10^6 \,\text{N}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $1.00\times 10^5 \,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution13a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The car moves with initial velocity $v_0 = 20.0\,\text{m/s}$ and comes to rest ($v = 0$) upon impact, after travelling a distance $d = 0.0100\,\text{m}$. Assuming constant deceleration, the average speed of the car while stopping is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \bar{v} &= \frac{v_0 + v}{2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{20.0\,\text{m/s} + 0}{2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 10.0\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the duration of the impact is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta t &= \frac{d}{\bar{v}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{0.0100\,\text{m}}{10.0\,\text{m/s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    Using Newton&rsquo;s second law, we find the average force on the person to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{m \Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{m\, (v - v_0)}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(75.0\,\text{kg})\, (0 - 20.0\,\text{m/s})}{1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -1.50\times 10^6 \,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    The minus sign indicates that the force exerted on the person is backward, opposite to the direction of motion.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution13b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If the person riding the car stops over a greater distance of $d_2 = 0.150\,\text{m}$, due to the cushioning of the airbag, the duration of the impact increases to
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta t_2 &= \frac{d_2}{\bar{v}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{0.150\,\text{m}}{10.0\,\text{m/s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.0150\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    which corresponds to an average force of
                        \begin{align}
                        F_2 &= \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(75.0\,\text{kg})\, (0 - 20.0\,\text{m/s})}{0.0150\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -1.00\times 10^5 \,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that the magnitude of the force on the person drops by more than $93\%$ in the presence of the airbag.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 20 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p20">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 20</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A ball with an initial velocity of $10\,\text{m/s}$ moves at an angle $60^\circ$ above the <span style="white-space: nowrap;">$+x$-direction.</span> The ball hits a vertical wall and bounces off so that it is moving $60^\circ$ above the <span style="white-space: nowrap;">$−x$-direction</span> with the same speed. What is the impulse delivered by the wall?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer20_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram20_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$- m\, (10\,\text{m/s})$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch08-p20s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P8.20s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>As seen from <b>Figure P8.20s</b>, the $y$ component of the ball&rsquo;s velocity is not affected by the bounce. The $x$ component, however, experiences a change of
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta v_x &= v_{\text{f}x} - v_{\text{i}x} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (- v\cos{\theta}) - (v\cos{\theta}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -2v\cos{\theta}
                        \end{align}
                    where $v = 10\,\text{m/s}$ is the magnitude of ball&rsquo;s velocity and $\theta = 60^\circ$ is the angle it makes with the $x$-axis. So, the impulse delivered to the ball (by the wall) is along the $x$-direction, and it is equal to the change the ball&rsquo;s momentum <span style="white-space: nowrap;">($\Delta p_x$).</span> So, we find
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta p_x &= m\, \Delta v_x \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m\, (-2 v \cos{\theta}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - m\, (2 \times 10\,\text{m/s} \times \cos 60^\circ) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - m\, (10\,\text{m/s})
                        \end{align}
                    where $m$ is the mass of the ball.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 23 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p23">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 23</div>
                    <div class="panel-body"> Train cars are coupled together by being bumped into one another. Suppose two loaded train cars are moving toward one another, the first having a mass of $150{,}000\,\text{kg}$ and a velocity of $0.300\,\text{m/s}$, and the second having a mass of $110{,}000\,\text{kg}$ and a velocity of $−0.120\,\text{m/s}$. (The minus indicates direction of motion.) What is their final velocity?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer23_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram23_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution23_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer23">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$0.122\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram23">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch08-p23s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P8.23s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution23">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The first train car has a mass of $m_1 = 1.50\times 10^5\,\text{kg}$ and moves to the right (see <b>Figure P8.23s</b>) at an initial velocity of $v_1 = 0.300\,\text{m/s}$. The second train car has a mass of $m_2 = 1.10\times 10^5\,\text{kg}$ and moves to the left with initial velocity of $v_2 = -0.120\,\text{m/s}$. The two cars couple together after the collision and move as one body with a final velocity of $v'$.</p>

                    <p>In the absence of external forces, the total momentum of the two-car system is conserved during the collision, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        m_1\, v_1 + m_2\, v_2 = (m_1 + m_2)\, v'
                        \end{equation}
                    So, the final velocity of the two cars after they couple together is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v' &= \frac{m_1\, v_1 + m_2\, v_2}{m_1 + m_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(1.50\times 10^5\,\text{kg})\, (0.300\,\text{m/s}) + (1.10\times 10^5\,\text{kg})\, (-0.120\,\text{m/s})}{(1.50\times 10^5\,\text{kg}) + (1.10\times 10^5\,\text{kg})} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.122\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 27 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p27">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 27</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $1.80\,\text{kg}$ falcon catches a $0.650\,\text{kg}$ dove from behind in midair. What is their velocity after impact if the falcon&rsquo;s velocity is initially $28.0\,\text{m/s}$ and the dove&rsquo;s velocity is $7.00\,\text{m/s}$ in the same direction?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer27_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution27_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer27">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$22.4\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution27">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The falcon, of mass $m_\text{f} = 1.80\,\text{kg}$, flies with an initial velocity of $v_\text{fi} = 28.0\,\text{m/s}$. The dove, of mass $m_\text{d} = 0.650\,\text{kg}$, flies ahead at a slower velocity of $v_\text{di} = 7.00\,\text{m/s}$. Since the total momentum of the falcon-dove system is conserved, the final velocity <span style="white-space: nowrap;">($v'$)</span> of the two birds after impact is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        m_\text{f}\, v_\text{fi} + m_\text{d}\, v_\text{di} &= (m_\text{f} + m_\text{d})\, v' \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v' &= \frac{m_\text{f}\, v_\text{fi} + m_\text{d}\, v_\text{di}}{m_\text{f} + m_\text{d}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(1.80\,\text{kg})\, (28.0\,\text{m/s}) + (0.650\,\text{kg})\, (7.00\,\text{m/s})}{1.80\,\text{kg} + 0.650\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 22.4\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 30 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p30">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 30</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $70.0\,\text{kg}$ ice hockey goalie, originally at rest, blocks a $0.150\,\text{kg}$ hockey puck slapped at him at a velocity of $35.0\,\text{m/s}$. Suppose the goalie and the puck have an elastic collision and the puck is reflected back in the direction from which it came. What would their final velocities be in this case?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer30_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram30_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution30_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$0.150\,\text{m/s},\; -34.9\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch08-p30s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P8.30s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution30">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The goalie, of mass $m_\text{g} = 70.0\,\text{kg}$, is initially at rest ($v_\text{g} = 0$). The puck has a mass of $m_\text{p} = 0.150\,\text{kg}$ and moves with initial velocity of $v_\text{p} = 35.0\,\text{m/s}$ towards the goalie, as shown in <b>Figure P8.30s</b>. In the absence of external frictional forces, the total momentum of the goalie-puck system is conserved. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        m_\text{p}\, v_\text{p} &= m_\text{p}\, v'_\text{p} + m_\text{g}\, v'_\text{g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_\text{p} &= v'_\text{p} + \left(\frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) v'_\text{g}
                        \label{ch08_p30_p}
                        \end{align}
                    where $v'_\text{g}$ and $v'_\text{p}$ are the final velocities of the goalie and the puck, respectively. Since the collision is elastic, kinetic energy is also conserved, and we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \tfrac{1}{2} m_\text{p} v_\text{p}^2 &= \tfrac{1}{2} m_\text{p} v_\text{p}^{\prime 2} + \tfrac{1}{2} m_\text{g} v_\text{g}^{\prime 2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_\text{p}^2 &= v_\text{p}^{\prime 2} + \left(\frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) v_\text{g}^{\prime 2}
                        \label{ch08_p30_KE}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>By substituting for $v'_\text{p}$ from Equation \ref{ch08_p30_p} into Equation \ref{ch08_p30_KE}, we can find an expression for the goalie&rsquo;s final velocity, as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{p}^2 &= \left[ v_\text{p} - \left(\frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) v'_\text{g} \right]^2 + \left(\frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) v_\text{g}^{\prime 2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_\text{p}^2 &= v_\text{p}^2 - 2 \left(\frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) v_\text{p} v'_\text{g} + \left(\frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right)^2 v_\text{g}^{\prime 2} + \left(\frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) v_\text{g}^{\prime 2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= - 2\, \left(\frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) v_\text{p} v'_\text{g} + \left(\frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) \left(1 + \frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) v_\text{g}^{\prime 2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= - 2 v_\text{p} + \left(1 + \frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) v'_\text{g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v'_\text{g} &= \left(\frac{2 m_\text{p}}{m_\text{g} + m_\text{p}}\right) v_\text{p}
                        \label{ch08_p30_vgf}
                        \end{align}
                    If we substitute from Equation \ref{ch08_p30_vgf} into Equation \ref{ch08_p30_p}, we can find an expression for the final velocity of the puck as shown below
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{p} &= v'_\text{p} + \left(\frac{m_\text{g}}{m_\text{p}}\right) \left(\frac{2 m_\text{p}}{m_\text{g} + m_\text{p}}\right) v_\text{p} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v'_\text{p} &= \left(\frac{m_\text{p} - m_\text{g}}{m_\text{g} + m_\text{p}}\right) v_\text{p}
                        \label{ch08_p30_vpf}
                        \end{align}
