                    </p>

                    <p>By substituting the known values into Equations \ref{ch08_p30_vgf} and \ref{ch08_p30_vpf}, we find
                        \begin{align}
                        v'_\text{g} &= \left(\frac{2 \times 0.150\,\text{kg}}{0.150\,\text{kg} + 70.0\,\text{kg}} \right) (35.0\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.150\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        v'_\text{p} &= \left(\frac{0.150\,\text{kg} - 70.0\,\text{kg}}{0.150\,\text{kg} + 70.0\,\text{kg}} \right) (35.0\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -34.9\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 31 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p31">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 31</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $0.240\,\text{kg}$ billiard ball that is moving at $3.00\,\text{m/s}$ strikes the bumper of a pool table and bounces straight back at $2.40\,\text{m/s}$ ($80\%$ of its original speed). The collision lasts $0.0150\,\text{s}$. (a) Calculate the average force exerted on the ball by the bumper. (b) How much kinetic energy in joules is lost during the collision? (c) What percent of the original energy is left?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer31_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution31a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution31b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution31c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer31" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $-86.4\, \text{N}$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $0.389\,\text{J}$ </p>
                        <p>(c) $64.0\%$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution31a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The billiard ball has a mass of $m = 0.240\,\text{kg}$, an initial velocity of $v = 3.00\,\text{m/s}$, and a final velocity of $v' = -2.40\,\text{m/s}$. The collision lasts for a time period of $\Delta t = 0.0150\,\text{s}$. Using Newton&rsquo;s second law, we calculate the average force exerted on the ball by the bumper to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{m\, \Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{m\, (v' - v)}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(0.240\,\text{kg})\, (-2.40\,\text{m/s} - 3.00\,\text{m/s})}{0.0150\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -86.4\, \text{N}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution31b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>To find how much kinetic energy is lost during the collision, we take the difference between the initial and final kinetic energies.
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{lost} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 - \tfrac{1}{2} m v'^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} m (v^2 - v'^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} \left(0.240\,\text{kg}\right) \left[(3.00\,\text{m/s})^2 - (2.40\,\text{m/s})^2 \right] \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.389\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution31c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the billiard ball velocity drops to $80.0\%$ of its original speed (i.e. $v' = 0.800\, v$), the final kinetic energy ($\text{KE}'$) compared to the initial kinetic energy ($\text{KE}$) becomes
                         \begin{align}
                         \frac{\text{KE}'}{\text{KE}} &= \frac{\tfrac{1}{2} m v'^2}{\tfrac{1}{2} m v^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= \left(\frac{v'}{v}\right)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= (0.800)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 0.640
                         \end{align}
                    So, $64.0\%$ of the original energy is left.
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 32 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p32">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 32</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">During an ice show, a $60.0\,\text{kg}$ skater leaps into the air and is caught by an initially stationary $75.0\,\text{kg}$ skater. (a) What is their final velocity assuming negligible friction and that the $60.0\,\text{kg}$ skater&rsquo;s original horizontal velocity is $4.00\,\text{m/s}$? (b) How much kinetic energy is lost?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer32_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution32a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution32b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer32" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $1.78\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $267\,\text{J}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution32a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The leaping skater has a mass of $m_1 = 60.0\,\text{kg}$ and initial horizontal velocity of $v_1 = 4.00\,\text{m/s}$. The stationary skater has a mass of $m_2 = 75.0\,\text{kg}$. Since external forces are neglected, the total momentum of the two-skater system is conserved. So, we can determine the final velocity ($v$) of both skaters as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        m_1\, v_1 &= (m_1 + m_2)\, v' \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v' &= \frac{m_1\, v_1}{m_1 + m_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(60.0\,\text{kg})\, (4.00\,\text{m/s})}{60.0\,\text{kg} + 75.0\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.78\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                   </p>
                   </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution32b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The kinetic energy lost is equal to the difference between initial and final kinetic energies, which is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{lost} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m_1 v_1^2 - \tfrac{1}{2} (m_1 + m_2) v'^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2}(60\,\text{kg})(4.00\,\text{m/s})^2 - \tfrac{1}{2}(60.0\,\text{kg} + 75.0\,\text{kg}) (1.78\,\text{m/s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 267\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                   </p>
                   </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 34 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p34">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 34</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A battleship that is $6.00\times 10^7\,\text{kg}$ and is originally at rest fires a $1100$-$\text{kg}$ artillery shell horizontally with a velocity of $575\,\text{m/s}$. (a) If the shell is fired straight aft (toward the rear of the ship), there will be negligible friction opposing the ship&rsquo;s recoil. Calculate its recoil velocity. (b) Calculate the increase in internal kinetic energy (that is, for the ship and the shell). This energy is less than the energy released by the gunpowder—significant heat transfer occurs.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer34_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution34a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution34b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer34" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $0.0105\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $1.82\times 10^8 \,\text{J}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The battleship, of mass $m_\text{b} = 6.00\times 10^7\,\text{kg}$, is  initially at rest. The artillery shell, of mass $m_\text{a} = 1.10\times 10^3\,\text{kg}$, is fired with a horizontal velocity of $v'_\text{a} = - 575\,\text{m/s}$ toward the rear of the ship. Since the shell is also at rest within the battleship&rsquo;s cannon, the initial momentum of the (ship-shell) system is equal to zero. Because of momentum conservation, the final net momentum after firing is also equal to zero. So, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        p_\text{i} &= p_\text{f} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        0 &= m_\text{b}\, v'_\text{b} + m_\text{a}\, v'_\text{a}
                        \end{align}
                   and the battleship&rsquo;s recoil velocity ($v'_\text{b}$) is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v'_\text{b} &= - \left(\frac{m_\text{a}}{m_\text{b}}\right) v'_\text{a} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - \left(\frac{1.10\times 10^3\,\text{kg}}{6.00\times 10^7 \,\text{kg}}\right) (- 575\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.05\times 10^{-2}\,\text{m/s} \quad (\text{in the forward direction})
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The increase in internal kinetic energy is equal to the sum of the final kinetic energies of the shell and the ship, which is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta \text{KE} &= \text{KE}_\text{f} - 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= \tfrac{1}{2} m_\text{a}\, v_\text{a}^{\prime 2} + \tfrac{1}{2} m_\text{b}\, v_\text{b}^{\prime 2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} (1.10\times 10^3\,\text{kg}) (575\,\text{m/s})^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} (6.00 \times 10^7\,\text{kg}) (0.0105\,\text{m/s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.82\times 10^8 \,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 36 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p36">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 36</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $30{,}000\,\text{kg}$ freight car is coasting at $0.850\,\text{m/s}$ with negligible friction under a hopper that dumps $110{,}000\,\text{kg}$ of scrap metal into it. (a) What is the final velocity of the loaded freight car? (b) How much kinetic energy is lost?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer36_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram36_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution36a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution36b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer36" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $0.182\,\text{m/s}$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $8.52\, \text{kJ}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram36">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch08-p36s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P8.36s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution36a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The system of interest, in this problem, consists of the freight car and the dumped load of scrap metal, as shown in <b>Figure P8.36s</b>. Since the load falls vertically down, the initial horizontal momentum of the system is equal to that of the moving car. Since no external forces are involved, the momentum of the system is conserved. This means, the final momentum of the system (loaded car) is the same as the initial momentum. It is true that the load has an initial velocity in the downward direction. However, this will only affect the vertical momentum of the system which is of no concern to us in this problem.</p>

                    <p>The freight car, of mass $m_\text{c} = 3.00\times 10^4\,\text{kg}$, moves with initial velocity of $v_\text{c} = 0.850\,\text{m/s}$. A load of scrap metal, of mass $m_\text{m} = 1.10\times 10^5\,\text{kg}$, is dumped on it. Using the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit08-momentum-conservation">conservation of momentum principle</a>, we can calculate the the final velocity ($v'$) of the loaded freight car as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        m_\text{c}\, v_\text{c} &= (m_\text{c} + m_\text{m})\, v' \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow v' &= \frac{m_\text{c}\, v_\text{c}}{m_\text{c} + m_\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(3.00\times 10^4\,\text{kg})\, (0.850\,\text{m/s})}{1.40\times 10^5\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.182\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution36b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The amount of kinetic energy lost is the difference between initial and final kinetic energies, which is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{lost} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m_\text{c} v_\text{c}^2 - \tfrac{1}{2} (m_\text{c} + m_\text{m}) v^{\prime 2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} (3.00\times 10^4\,\text{kg}) (0.850\,\text{m/s})^2 - \tfrac{1}{2} (1.40\times 10^5\,\text{kg}) (0.182\,\text{m/s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.52\times 10^3\, \text{J}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 39 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p39">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 39</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">One of the waste products of a nuclear reactor is plutonium-239 $\left({}^{239}\text{Pu}\right)$. This nucleus is radioactive and decays by splitting into a helium-4 nucleus and a uranium-235 nucleus $\left({}^{4}\text{He} + {}^{235}\text{U}\right)$, the latter of which is also radioactive and will itself decay some time later. The energy emitted in the plutonium decay is $8.40\times10^{–13} \,\text{J}$ and is entirely converted to kinetic energy of the helium and uranium nuclei. The mass of the helium nucleus is $6.68\times10^{– 27}\,\text{kg}$ , while that of the uranium is $3.92\times10^{–25}\,\text{kg}$ (note that the ratio of the masses is $4$ to $235$). (a) Calculate the velocities of the two nuclei, assuming the plutonium nucleus is originally at rest. (b) How much kinetic energy does each nucleus carry away? Note that the data given here are accurate to three digits only.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer39_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram39_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution39a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution39b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer39" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $2.68\times 10^5 \,\text{m/s},\; -1.57\times 10^7\, \text{m/s}$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $1.41\times 10^{-14}\,\text{J},\; 8.23\times 10^{-13}\, \text{J}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram39">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch08-p39s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P8.39s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution39a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>A plutonium-239 nucleus is initially at rest, and decays into a uranium-235 nucleus of mass $m_\text{U} = 3.92\times 10^{-25}\,\text{kg}$ and a helium-4 nucleus of mass $m_\text{He} = 6.68\times 10^{-27}\,\text{kg}$, as shown in <b>Figure P8.39s</b>. After the decay, the total kinetic energy of the uranium and helium nuclei is given by
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{f} & = \tfrac{1}{2}\, m_\text{U}\, v_\text{U}^2 + \tfrac{1}{2}\, m_\text{He}\, v_\text{He}^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
												& = 8.40\times10^{-13}\,\text{J}
                        \label{ch08_p39_KEf}
                        \end{align}
                    where $v_\text{U}$ and $v_\text{He}$ are the velocities of the uranium-235 and helium-4 nuclei, respectively. Since the total linear momentum during the nuclear reaction is conserved, we write
                        \begin{align}
                        p_\text{i} &= p_\text{f} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        0 &= m_\text{U}\, v_\text{U} + m_\text{He}\, v_\text{He} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_\text{He} &= - \frac{m_\text{U}\, v_\text{U}}{m_\text{He}}
                        \label{ch08_p39_pif}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>By substituting from Equation \ref{ch08_p39_pif} into Equation \ref{ch08_p39_KEf}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{f} &= \tfrac{1}{2}\, m_\text{U}\, v_\text{U}^2 + \tfrac{1}{2}\, m_\text{He}\, \left(- \frac{m_\text{U}\, v_\text{U}}{m_\text{He}}\right)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2}\, m_\text{U}\, v_\text{U}^2 + \frac{m_\text{U}^2\, v_\text{U}^2}{2\, m_\text{He}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 2\, m_\text{He}\, \text{KE}_\text{f} &= (m_\text{He} + m_\text{U})\, m_\text{U}\, v_\text{U}^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \end{align}
                    We can now solve for the velocity of the uranium nucleus as
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{U} &= \sqrt{\frac{2\, m_\text{He}\, \text{KE}_\text{f}}{(m_\text{He} + m_\text{U})\, m_\text{U}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{\frac{2\, \left(6.68\times 10^{-27}\,\text{kg}\right) \left(8.40\times10^{-13}\,\text{J}\right)}{\left(6.68\times 10^{-27}\,\text{kg} + 3.92\times 10^{-25}\,\text{kg}\right) \left(3.92\times 10^{-25}\,\text{kg}\right)}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.68\times 10^5 \,\text{m/s}
                        \label{ch08_p39_vU}
                        \end{align}
                    By substituting from Equation \ref{ch08_p39_vU} into Equation \ref{ch08_p39_pif}, we determine the velocity of the alpha particle (helium-4 nucleus) as
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{He} &= - \frac{\left(3.92\times 10^{-25}\,\text{kg}\right) \left(2.68\times 10^5 \,\text{m/s}\right)}{6.68\times 10^{-27}\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -1.57\times 10^7\, \text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution39b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The kinetic energies of the uranium-235 and helium-4 nuclei are calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{U} &= \tfrac{1}{2}\, m_\text{U}\, v_\text{U}^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} \left(3.92\times 10^{-25}\,\text{kg}\right) \left(2.68\times 10^5 \,\text{m/s}\right)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.41\times 10^{-14}\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{He} &= \tfrac{1}{2}\, m_\text{He}\, v_\text{He}^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} \left(6.68\times 10^{-27}\,\text{kg}\right) \left(-1.57\times 10^7 \,\text{m/s}\right)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.23\times 10^{-13}\, \text{J}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 45 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p45">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 45</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Two identical pucks collide on an air hockey table. One puck was originally at rest. (a) If the incoming puck has a speed of $6.00\,\text{m/s}$ and scatters to an angle of $30.0^\circ$, what is the velocity (magnitude and direction) of the second puck? (You may use the result that $\theta_1 − \theta_2 = 90^\circ$ for elastic collisions of objects that have identical masses.) (b) Confirm that the collision is elastic.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer45_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram45_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution45a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution45b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer45" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $3.00\,\text{m/s},\; -60.0^\circ$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram45">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch08-p45s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P8.45s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution45a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>An air hockey puck (of mass $m$) moves with an initial velocity of $v_1 = 6.00\,\text{m/s}$, along the $x$ axis, and collides with an identical puck placed at the origin. After the collision, the first puck scatters at an angle of $\theta_1 = 30.0^\circ$ with the positive direction of the $x$ axis, while the other puck moves at an angle of
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta_2 &= \theta_1 - 90^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 30.0^\circ - 90^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -60.0^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    as shown in <b>Figure P8.45s</b>.</p>

                    <p>Since the total momentum of the system along the $x$ and $y$ directions are separately conserved, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        p_x &= p'_x \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad m v_1 + 0 &= m v'_1 \cos{\theta_1} + m v'_2 \cos{\theta_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_1 &= v'_1 \cos{\theta_1} + v'_2 \cos{\theta_2}
                        \label{ch08_p45_px}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        p_y &= p'_y \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 + 0 &= m v'_1 \sin{\theta_1} + m v'_2 \sin{\theta_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= v'_1 \sin{\theta_1} + v'_2 \sin{\theta_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v'_1 &= -\frac{v'_2 \sin{\theta_2}}{\sin{\theta_1}}
                        \label{ch08_p45_py}
                        \end{align}
                     where $v'_1$ and $v'_2$ are the speeds of the first and second pucks, respectively, after the collision.</p>

                     <p>If we substitute for $v'_1$ from Equation \ref{ch08_p45_py} into Equation \ref{ch08_p45_px}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        v_1 &= \left(-\frac{v'_2 \sin{\theta_2}}{\sin{\theta_1}}\right) \cos{\theta_1} + v'_2 \cos{\theta_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad v_1 \sin{\theta_1} &= v'_2\, (\sin{\theta_1} \cos{\theta_2} - \cos{\theta_1} \sin{\theta_2}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= v'_2\, \sin{(\theta_1 - \theta_2)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= v'_2\, \sin 90^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= v'_2
                        \end{align}
                     Note that in the calculation above we used the trigonometric identity $\sin(\alpha \pm \beta) = \sin \alpha \cos \beta \pm \cos \alpha \sin \beta$.
                     So, the second puck scatters with a velocity of magnitude
                        \begin{align}
                        v'_2 &= v_1 \sin{\theta_1} \label{ch08_p45_v2f}\\[6pt]
                        &= (6.00\,\text{m/s}) \sin 30.0^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.00\,\text{m/s} \nonumber
                        \end{align}
                     directed at an angle $60.0^\circ$ below the positive direction of the $x$ axis.
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution45b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>By substituting from Equation \ref{ch08_p45_v2f} into Equation \ref{ch08_p45_py} we can determine the magnitude of the final velocity of the first puck to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v'_1 &= -\frac{v'_2 \sin{\theta_2}}{\sin{\theta_1}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -\frac{(v_1 \sin{\theta_1})\, \sin{\theta_2}}{\sin{\theta_1}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - v_1 \sin{\theta_2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - v_1 \sin(\theta_1 - 90^\circ) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= v_1 \cos\theta_1
                        \label{ch08_p45_v1f}
                        \end{align}
                    where we used the trigonometric identity $\sin({\alpha - 90^\circ}) = -\cos\alpha$.</p>

                    <p>To verify that the collision is elastic, we need to compare the initial and final total kinetic energies of the system. Before the collision, we have
                        \begin{equation}
                        \text{KE}_\text{i} = \tfrac{1}{2} m v_1^2
                        \end{equation}
                    After the collision, and using the Equations \ref{ch08_p45_v2f} and \ref{ch08_p45_v1f}, the total kinetic energy of the two-puck system is found to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{f} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_1^{\prime 2} + \tfrac{1}{2} m v_2^{\prime 2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} m\, (v_1 \cos{\theta_1})^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} m\, (v_1 \sin{\theta_1})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} m\, v_1^2\, (\cos^2 \theta_1 + \sin^2 \theta_1) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v_1^2
                        \end{align}
                    where we used the trigonometric identity $\cos^2 \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha = 1$. Since $\text{KE}_\text{i} = \text{KE}_\text{f}$, the collision is elastic.</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 47 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p47">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 47</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $3000$-$\text{kg}$ cannon is mounted so that it can recoil only in the horizontal direction. (a) Calculate its recoil velocity when it fires a $15.0$-$\text{kg}$ shell at $480\,\text{m/s}$ at an angle of $20.0^\circ$ above the horizontal. (b) What is the kinetic energy of the cannon? This energy is dissipated as heat transfer in shock absorbers that stop its recoil. (c) What happens to the vertical component of momentum that is imparted to the cannon when it is fired?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer47_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram47_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution47a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution47b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution47c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer47" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $-2.26\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $7.63\times 10^3\,\text{J}$</p>
                        <p>(c) Transferred to Earth.</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram47">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch08-p47s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P8.47s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution47a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The shell (mass $m_\text{s} = 15.0\,\text{kg}$) and the cannon (mass $m_\text{c} = 3.00\times 10^3\,\text{kg}$) are at rest before firing. So, the initial momentum of the cannon-shell system is equal to zero. After firing, the shell travels with a velocity of $v_\text{s} = 480\,\text{m/s}$ at an angle $\theta = 20.0^\circ$ above the horizontal. Since the cannon can recoil horizontally, we consider <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit08-momentum-conservation">momentum conservation</a> in this direction, where
                        \begin{align}
                        p_x &= p'_x \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= m_\text{s}\, v_{\text{s}x} + m_\text{c}\, v_\text{c} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  0 &= m_\text{s}\, v_\text{s} \cos\theta + m_\text{c}\, v_\text{c}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the recoil velocity of the cannon ($v_\text{c}$) in the horizontal direction, is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v_\text{c} &= - \frac{m_\text{s}\, v_\text{s} \cos\theta}{m_\text{c}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -\frac{(15.0\,\text{kg})\, (480\,\text{m/s}) \cos{20.0^\circ}}{3.00\times 10^3\,\text{kg}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -2.26\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution47b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>After firing, the cannon&rsquo;s kinetic energy is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{c} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m_\text{c} v_\text{c}^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2}\, (3.00\times 10^3\,\text{kg})\, (-2.26\,\text{m/s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 7.63\times 10^3\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution47c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The momentum in the vertical direction is transferred to Earth. In this respect, the total momentum of the shell-cannon-Earth system is conserved.</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 54 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p54">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 54</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">What is the acceleration of a $5000$-$\text{kg}$ rocket taking off from the Moon, where the acceleration due to gravity is only $1.6\,\text{m/s}^2$, if the rocket expels $8.00\,\text{kg}$ of gas per second at an exhaust velocity of $2.20\times 10^3\,\text{m/s}$?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer54_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution54_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer54" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$1.92\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution54" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The rocket engine provides an internal force ($F_\text{j}$) that pushes the hot gases downward and the rocket body upward. The magnitude of the downward momentum gained by the expelled gasses, during a period of $\Delta t = 1\, \text{s}$, is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta p_\text{g} &= (8.00 \,\text{kg})\, (2.20\times 10^3\,\text{m/s} - 0) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.76\times 10^4\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    By applying Newton&rsquo;s second law, we can calculate the force exerted by the jet engine as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{j} & = \frac{\Delta p_\text{g}}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1.76\times 10^4\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}}{1\, \text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.76\times 10^4\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that $F_\text{j}$ is equal in magnitude to the upward force exerted on the rocket (of mass $m = 5.00\times 10^3\,\text{kg}$) by the rocket engine. Because it takes off against lunar gravity ($g_\text{M} = 1.6\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$), the rocket experiences a net force of
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{net} &= F_\text{j} - m\, g_\text{M} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (1.76\times 10^4\,\text{N}) - (5.00\times 10^3\,\text{kg})\, (1.6\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9.60\times 10^3\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    By applying the more common form of Newton&rsquo;s second law, we calculate the acceleration of the rocket to be
                        \begin{align}
                        a &= \frac{F_\text{net}}{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{9.60\times 10^3\,\text{N}}{5.00\times 10^3\,\text{kg}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.92\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 56 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter08-p56">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 8, Problem 56</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Ion-propulsion rockets have been proposed for use in space. They employ atomic ionization techniques and nuclear energy sources to produce extremely high exhaust velocities, perhaps as great as $8.00\times10^6\,\text{m/s}$ . These techniques allow a much more favourable payload-to-fuel ratio. To illustrate this fact: (a) Calculate the increase in velocity of a $20{,}000\,\text{kg}$ space probe that expels only $40.0\,\text{kg}$ of its mass at the given exhaust velocity. (b) These engines are usually designed to produce a very small thrust for a very long time&mdash;the type of engine that might be useful on a trip to the outer planets, for example. Calculate the acceleration of such an engine if it expels $4.50\times 10^{−6} \,\text{kg/s}$ at the given velocity, assuming the acceleration due to gravity is negligible.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer56_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution56a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution56b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer56" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $1.60\times 10^4 \,\text{m/s}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $1.80\times 10^{-3}\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution56a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>A spacecraft of mass $m = 20{,}000\,\text{kg}$ is accelerated by an ion-propulsion engine that has an exhaust velocity of $v_\text{e} = 8.00\times 10^6\,\text{m/s}$. After it expels $\Delta m = 40.0\,\text{kg}$ of its mass, the spacecraft experiences an increase in velocity equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta v &= v_\text{e}\, \ln{\left( \frac{m}{m - \Delta m} \right)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (8.00\times 10^6 \,\text{m/s})\, \ln{\left(\frac{20{,}000\,\text{kg}}{20{,}000\,\text{kg} - 40.0\,\text{kg}} \right)}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (8.00\times 10^6 \,\text{m/s})\, (0.002002) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.60\times 10^4 \,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution56b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If the engine ejects mass at the rate of $4.50\times 10^{−6} \,\text{kg/s}$, then the time it takes to expel a total mass of $40.0\,\text{kg}$ is
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta t &= \frac{40.0\,\text{kg}}{4.50\times 10^{−6} \,\text{kg/s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.89\times 10^6 \,\text{s} \quad (\text{or}\; 103\, \text{days})
                        \end{align}
                    So, the average acceleration of the spacecraft is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \bar{a} &= \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1.60\times 10^4 \,\text{m/s}}{8.89\times 10^6 \,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.80\times 10^{-3}\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

              <article>
                <p class="runhead1"><strong>Physics 200</strong> Introductory Physics I</p>

                <p  class="unit">Unit 9 (Chapter 9)</p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit09" >

                  <!-- to change: the following content -->
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Statics and Torque</h1>
                  <hr>

                  <p>Economists talk about equilibrium between supply and demand; stockbrokers discuss market equilibrium; physicists lecture on thermodynamic equilibrium. Whatever the context, we associate the word equilibrium with balance and stability. We imagine situations where objects do not move around, although we expect them to. The <a href="http://www.cntower.ca/" target="_blank">CN Tower</a> stays at the same location for the same reason a picture stays suspended on your living room wall. Buildings are designed to stand still and resist any type of motion. Engineers make sure that the forces and torques on every part of the building always add up to zero. Absence of motion seems to be an ideal picture of equilibrium.</p>

                  <p>The study of equilibrium is of substantial interest to physicists. Insight acquired in this area through the laws of physics has provided the foundations for a variety of disciplines&mdash;from engineering to social sciences to medicine. The level of this course will not allow a thorough study of this important concept. We will confine ourselves to the basic analysis of objects in static equilibrium and applications of such analyses in real-life situations.</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:2.0em;">
                  <div class="learningobjectives">
                    <h3>Learning Objectives</h3>
                    <p>After completing this unit, you should be able to</p>
                    <ul>
                        <li>define static equilibrium.</li>
                        <li>state the conditions of equilibrium for a rigid body.</li>
                        <li>define torque.</li>
                        <li>calculate the torque due to a force on a rigid body.</li>
                        <li>use the conditions of equilibrium to solve problems involving stable rigid bodies.</li>
                        <li>describe stable and unstable equilibriums.</li>
                    </ul>
                  </div>

                  <!-- end of content -->

                </div> <!-- end of this section -->

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit09-torque">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Statics and Torque</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Torque</h2>

                <p>What causes rotational motion? We have one obvious answer&mdash;we need a force. You must have noticed that opening a door by pushing at a point close to the hinges takes a superhuman effort&mdash;so we normally push near the edge on the other side of the hinges. The distance between the axis of rotation and the point at which the force is applied is also a critical factor in the resulting rotational motion.</p>

                <p>Suppose we apply a force $\bf F$ at the edge of the door, such that the direction of the applied force goes through the hinge, as shown in <a href="#unit09-fig01"><b>Figure 9.1</b></a>. In this case, the door will not move&mdash;the hinge exerts an equal and opposite reaction force on the door. We can safely conclude that if the line of action of the applied force passes through the axis of rotation, it does not produce a rotational motion.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit09-fig01">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-fig01.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 9.1</b>: Force exerted at the edge of the door directed towards the hinge.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>What happens if the force $\bf F$ is applied at an angle $\theta$, with respect to the door? For this case, let us first resolve the applied force into a component parallel to the door ($F_\parallel$) and a component perpendicular to the door ($F_\bot$), as shown in <a href="#unit09-fig02"><b>Figure 9.2</b></a>. It is clear that the component $F_\parallel = F \cos\theta$ has no effect on the rotational motion of the door, because its line of action passes through the axis of rotation $O$. So, it is only $F_\bot = F \sin\theta$ that is effective in opening and closing the door.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit09-fig02">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-fig02.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 9.2</b>: Force exerted at the edge of the door directed at an angle $\theta$.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>The quantity
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau &= r\, F_\bot \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= r\, (F \sin\theta) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (r \sin\theta)\, F \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= r_\bot\, F
                        \end{align}
                is called the <em>torque</em> of the force $\bf F$, which is acts on the body at a distance $r$ from the axis of rotation. From <a href="#unit09-fig02"><b>Figure 9.2</b></a> we see that the quantity $r_\bot = r \sin\theta$, referred to as the <em>perpendicular lever arm</em>, is equal to the perpendicular distance between the line of action of the force and the axis of rotation. We use the Greek letter $\tau$ (pronounced tau) to denote torque, and define it as follows: the torque due to a force of magnitude $F$ about a point $O$ is the product of $F$ and the lever arm. Equivalently, we can also define the torque as the product of the radius arm $r$ and the component of $F$ perpendicular to $r$. In <a href="../unit01/index01.html#unit01-units-of-measurement">SI units</a>, torque is measured in $\text{N}\cdot\text{m}$.</p>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit09-equilibrium">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Statics and Torque</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Equilibrium</h2>

                <p>The Latin word equilibrium means &ldquo;equality of forces.&rdquo; In the simple situation in which a body is subjected to two forces, equilibrium will obviously mean that the two forces are equal and opposite, so that the net force on the body is equal to zero. In general, an object is in equilibrium when the vector sum of the forces acting on it is zero. This requirement is known as the <em>first condition of equilibrium</em>.</p>

                <p>Most objects in real life, however, are extended bodies, and the first condition alone cannot guarantee stability. Consider, for example, a stick placed on a frictionless surface. If two equal and opposite forces are applied at the two ends, the net force on the stick will be zero. So, the first condition of equilibrium is satisfied and the stick will not have any translational motion. However, from our experience we know that the stick will rotate, as shown in <a href="#unit09-fig03"><b>Figure 9.3</b></a>. To ensure the absence of any type of motion, we need a second requirement&mdash;that the net torque on a body must be equal to zero. This requirement is known as the <em>second condition of equilibrium</em>.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit09-fig03">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-fig03.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 9.3</b>: Equal and opposite forces applied at th ends of a stick.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>We will confine ourselves to analyzing bodies in static equilibrium, with no translational or rotational motions. Furthermore, we will consider only those situations in which all the forces lie in a common plane, which we will assume to be the $x$-$y$ plane. With these restrictions, we will need to deal with only three scalar quantities, the $x$ and $y$ components of the forces, and the torque of the forces about any axis perpendicular to the $x$-$y$ plane. The two conditions of equilibrium thus provide us with the following three equations
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, F_x &= 0 \\[6pt]
                        \text{net}\, F_y &= 0 \\[6pt]
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= 0
                        \end{align}
                which must be satisfied simultaneously. Note that the axis of the torque equation is arbitrary and can be chosen anywhere.</p>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                  <video controls>
                  <source src="./unit09-vid01.mp4" type="video/mp4">
                  </video>
                  <br><b>Video 9.1</b>: Torque and equilibrium.
                </p>

                <h3>PhET Interactive Simulation: Torque</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-9.pdf#page=3" title="Chapter 9" target="_blank">textbook</a>, &ldquo;investigate how torque causes an object to rotate. Discover the relationships between angular acceleration, moment of inertia, angular momentum and torque.&rdquo;</p>

                <p><div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 197px;"><a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/rotation/torque_en.jnlp" style="text-decoration: none;"><img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/rotation/torque-screenshot.png" alt="Torque" style="border: none;" width="300" height="197"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);"></div><table style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px;"><tr><td style="text-align: center; color: #000; font-size: 24px; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Click to Run</td></tr></table></a></div>

                <div class="source">Source: <a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/legacy/torque" target="_blank">PhET Interactive Simulations</a>, University of Colorado Boulder.</div>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-9.pdf" title="Chapter 9" target="_blank">Chapter 9</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-9.pdf#page=2" title="Chapter 9" target="_blank">9.1.&nbsp; The First Condition for Equilibrium</a></li>
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-9.pdf#page=3" title="Chapter 9" target="_blank">9.2.&nbsp; The Second Condition for Equilibrium</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit09-center-of-gravity">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Statics and Torque</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Center of Gravity</h2>

                <p>In studying the motion of various bodies, we have been treating them as point masses&mdash;without explicitly saying so. However, in real life we deal with three-dimensional extended bodies, which may create a problem in specifying locations. In other words, what point inside (or outside) the body, can be used to mark its exact position? Another added complication is that a three-dimensional body may rotate or spin while in motion, causing different parts of the body to have different velocities.</p>

                <p>That, however, should not stop us from studying motion of bodies as point masses. For a given body, we can always find a point, called the <em>centre of mass</em>, where we can imagine that the total mass of the body is concentrated. If it rotates, while in motion, the axis of rotation will go through the centre of mass. Motion of an extended body can then be analyzed into a translational motion (of the centre of mass) and a rotational motion about the center of mass. In other words, what we have been doing so far&mdash;treating extended bodies as point masses&mdash;are not meaningless exercises. We just need to add the extra complication due to rotation.</p>

                <p>When the mass of the body is evenly distributed over its entire volume, the centre of mass coincides with the <em>geometric centre</em> of the body. For example, the centre of mass of a uniform solid sphere is at the centre of the sphere. The centre of mass of a hollow sphere of uniform thickness will also be at the centre of the sphere&mdash;outside of the body. So the centre of mass can be located inside or outside the body.</p>

                <p>Another related term is the <em>centre of gravity</em>, which refers to the point at which the force of gravity appears to act. The centre of gravity of an extended body may differ from its centre of mass if the gravitational acceleration cannot be assumed uniform throughout the body. However, for all purposes of this course the terms <em>centre of mass</em> and <em>centre of gravity</em> can be used interchangeably.</p>

                <h3>PhET Simulation: Balancing Act</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-9.pdf#page=14" title="Chapter 9" target="_blank">textbook</a>, &ldquo;test what you&rsquo;ve learned by trying the Balance Challenge game.&rdquo;</p>

                <p><div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 200px;"><a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/html/balancing-act/latest/balancing-act_en.html" target="_blank" style="text-decoration: none;"><img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/html/balancing-act/latest/balancing-act-600.png" alt="Balancing Act" style="border: none;" width="300" height="200"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 60px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);"></div><table style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 60px;"><tr><td style="text-align: center; color: #000; font-size: 24px; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Click to Run</td></tr></table></a></div>

                <div class="source">Source: <a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/balancing-act" target="_blank">PhET Interactive Simulations</a>, University of Colorado Boulder.</div>

                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit09-examples">
                 <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Statics and Torque</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Examples</h2>

                    <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of examples relevant to the content of <span style="white-space: nowrap;">Unit 9</span>. Make an attempt to answer each question on your own, before you read through the solution provided.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit09-e01">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 9, Example 1</div>
                <div class="panel-body">The entrance guard can exert a force of $150\,\text{N}$ to close a castle gate $2.10\,\text{m}$ wide. Calculate the magnitude of the torque if the force is exerted straight ahead, when the gate is open by $20.0^\circ$, as shown in <b>Figure E9.1</b>.
                <hr>
                <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-e01.svg" alt="image"><br>
                <br><b>Figure E9.1</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="answer-e01_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solutionDiagram-e01_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solution-e01_btn">Solution</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$296\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-e01s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E9.1s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>The magnitude of the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit09-torque">torque</a> is equal to the applied force times the lever arm&mdash;the perpendicular distance between the direction of the force and the axis of rotation. When the force ($F = 150\,\text{N}$) is applied straight ahead at the end of the gate, the perpendicular lever arm (see <b>Figure E9.1s</b>) is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        r_\bot & = (2.10\,\text{m})\, \cos 20.0^\circ \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.97\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                and the magnitude of the toque is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau & = r_\bot\, F \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (1.97\,\text{m})\, (150\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 296\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit09-e02">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 9, Example 2</div>
                <div class="panel-body">Two cables support a $75.0$-$\text{kg}$ sign at $30.0^\circ$ and $40.0^\circ$ angles with the horizontal, as shown in <b>Figure E9.2</b>. Determine the tension in each cable.
                <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-e02.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure E9.2</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="answer-e02_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solutionDiagram-e02_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solution-e02_btn">Solution</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$599\,\text{N},\; 677\,\text{N}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-e02s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E9.2s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>From the free-body diagram (<b>Figure E9.2s</b>), we see three forces acting on the sign: its weight ($w = mg$) and the tensions ($T_1$ and $T_2$) in the supporting cables. Since the sign is in <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit09-equilibrium">static equilibrium</a>, the net force on it must be equal to zero. This means the sum of all the horizontal components of the three forces is equal to zero (or $\text{net}\, F_x = 0$), and the sum of all the vertical components is also equal to zero (or $\text{net}\, F_y = 0$). So, we write
                        \begin{align}
                        -T_1 \cos\theta_1  + T_2 \cos\theta_2 &= 0 \label{unit09_e02_Fx}\\[6pt]
                        T_1 \sin\theta_1 + T_2 \sin\theta_2 - m g &= 0 \label{unit09_e02_Fy}
                        \end{align}
                where $\theta_1 = 30.0^\circ$, $\theta_2 = 40.0^\circ$, and $m = 75.0\,\text{kg}$ is the mass of the hanging sign.</p>

                <p>From Equation \ref{unit09_e02_Fx}, we have
                        \begin{equation}
                        T_2 = T_1 \left(\frac{\cos\theta_1}{\cos\theta_2}\right)
                        \label{unit09_e02_T2}
                        \end{equation}
                By substituting for $T_2$ from Equation \ref{unit09_e02_T2} into Equation \ref{unit09_e02_Fy}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        T_1 \sin\theta_1 + T_1 \left(\frac{\cos\theta_1}{\cos\theta_2}\right) \sin\theta_2 - m g &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad T_1\, (\sin\theta_1 + \cos\theta_1 \tan\theta_2) &= m g
                        \end{align}
                So the tension in the first cable is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        T_1 &= \frac{m g}{\left(\sin\theta_1 + \cos\theta_1 \tan\theta_2\right)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(75.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)}{\sin 30.0^\circ + (\cos 30.0^\circ \times \tan 40.0^\circ)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 599\,\text{N}
                        \label{unit09_e02_T1}
                        \end{align}
                We can now determine the tension in the second cable by substituting from Equation \ref{unit09_e02_T1} into equation \ref{unit09_e02_T2} as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        T_2 &= (599\,\text{N}) \left(\frac{\cos 30.0^\circ}{\cos 40.0^\circ}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 677\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit09-e03">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 9, Example 3</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A wooden board of mass $m$ and length $l$ leans against a smooth wall, as shown in <b>Figure E9.3</b>. Determine the angle $\theta$, between the floor and the board, when its lower end is on the verge of slipping? In your solution, take $\mu_\text{s}$ to be the coefficient of static friction with the floor.
                <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-e03.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure E9.3</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="answer-e03_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solutionDiagram-e03_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solution-e03_btn">Solution</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$\tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1}{2 \mu_\text{s}}\right)$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-e03s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E9.3s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>We begin by analyzing the different forces that act on the wooden board, as shown in the free-body diagram (<b>Figure E9.3s</b>). In the vertical direction, we see the downward force of gravity ($mg$) which acts at the board&rsquo;s centre of mass and also the upward <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-normal-force">normal force</a> ($N$) on the lower end of the board. The other force on the lower end is the horizontal <a href="../unit05/index05.html#unit05-friction">force of static friction</a>, which resists slipping against the floor. Since the wall is frictionless, it does not resist any vertical motion of board&rsquo;s upper end, which experiences a normal force ($F_\text{w}$) perpendicular to the wall.
                </p>

                <p>The four forces in <b>Figure E9.3s</b> must cancel each other, resulting in a zero net force, to prevent any translational motion. In addition, the net torque on the board must be equal to zero to prevent any rotational motion. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, F_x &= f_\text{s} - F_\text{w} = 0 \label{unit09_e03_Fx}\\[6pt]
                        \text{net}\, F_y &= N - m g = 0 \label{unit09_e03_Fy}\\[6pt]
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= \Big(l \sin\theta\Big) F_\text{w} - \Big(\tfrac{1}{2} l \cos\theta\Big) m g = 0 \label{unit09_e03_tau}\\[6pt]
                        \end{align}
                Note that the net torque is conveniently calculated about the lower end of the board. In this case the normal and frictional forces have zero lever arm and do not contribute to the net torque. However, the rotation axis can be chosen arbitrarily without affecting the final result.</p>

                <p>From  Equation \ref{unit09_e03_tau}, we can express the horizontal normal force caused by the wall as
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_\text{w} =  \frac{m g}{2 \tan\theta}
                        \end{equation}
                Note that $F_\text{w}$ increases as $\theta$ decreases. Since $f_\text{s}$ is equal to $F_\text{w}$, according to Equation \ref{unit09_e03_Fx}, we can argue that the force of static friction also increases as the board leans at smaller angles with the floor, and we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        f_\text{s} &= F_\text{w} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=  \frac{m g}{2 \tan\theta}
                        \end{align}
                However, the force of static friction, between the floor and the bottom end of the board, cannot exceed the maximum value of
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{max}\, f_\text{s} &= \mu_\text{s}\, N \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \mu_\text{s}\, m g
                        \end{align}
                where we substituted $N = m g$ from Equation \ref{unit09_e03_Fy}.
                <p>

                <p>When the board is on the verge of slipping, $F_\text{w}$ is equal to the maximum value of static friction, or
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{w} = \frac{m g}{2 \tan\theta} &= \mu_\text{s}\, m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \frac{1}{2 \tan\theta} &= \mu_\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                So, the minimum angle at which the wooden board will not slip is equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        \theta = \tan^{-1}\left( \frac{1}{2 \mu_\text{s}}\right)
                        \end{equation}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit09-e04">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 9, Example 4</div>
                <div class="panel-body">To get up on the roof, a person (mass $74.0\,\text{kg}$) places a $20.0$-$\text{ft}$ uniform aluminum ladder (mass $13.0\,\text{kg}$) against the building, where the wall is covered by smooth vinyl siding. The base of the ladder is $6.00\,\text{ft}$ from the building, as shown in <b>Figure E9.4</b>. When the person is standing $6.70\,\text{ft}$ from the top end of the ladder, determine (a) the normal force exerted by the ground at the base, (b) the force exerted by the wall at the top end, and (c) the force of static friction that prevents the ladder from slipping.
                <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-e04.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure E9.4</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="answer-e04_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solutionDiagram-e04_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solution-e04a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solution-e04b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solution-e04c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $853\,\text{N}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $172\,\text{N}$</p>
                      <p>(c) $172\,\text{N}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit09-e04s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E9.4s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>While the question indicates that the wall is frictionless, the concrete ground is not. If the ground were also frictionless, the ladder would slip and stability would not be achieved.</p>

                <p>Since the system is in static equilibrium, the net horizontal force on the ladder must be equal to zero. Two forces act on the ladder in this direction (see <b>Figure E9.4s</b>): The force ($F_\text{w}$) applied at the top end away from the wall, and the force of static friction ($f_\text{s}$) applied at the bottom end towards the building. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, F_x &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_\text{w} - f_\text{s} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_\text{w} &= f_\text{s}
                        \label{unit09_e04_netFx}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>The ladder also experiences vertical forces, which add up to zero. These forces are: The weight of the ladder ($w_\text{l} = m_\text{l}\, g$) which acts downward at its centre of gravity, the weight of the person ($w_\text{p} = m_\text{p}\, g$) which acts downward below his feet, and the upward normal force ($N$) applied by the ground at the base. So, by adding the vertical forces, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, F_y &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  N - w_\text{l} - w_\text{p} &= 0
                        \end{align}
                which allows us to calculate the upward normal force exerted by the ground at the base of the ladder to be
                        \begin{align}
                        N &= w_\text{l} + w_\text{p} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (m_\text{l} + m_\text{p})\, g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (13.0\,\text{kg} + 74.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 853\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>First, we calculate the angle that the ladder makes with the ground,
                        \begin{align}
