                        \theta &= \cos^{-1} \left(\frac{6.00\,\text{ft}}{20.0\,\text{ft}}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 72.5^\circ
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>To proceed with our calculations, we now require the net torque on the ladder to be equal to zero. For this purpose, it is more convenient to choose the base of the ladder as the pivot point. This way, we do not need to worry about the (yet) unknown force of friction. So, we write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{p} + \tau_\text{l} - \tau_\text{w} &= 0
                        \label{unit09_e04_net_tau}
                        \end{align}
                In Equation \ref{unit09_e04_net_tau}, the counterclockwise torque produced by the person&rsquo;s weight is calculated as follows (see <b>Figure E9.4s</b>)
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau_\text{p} &= r_{\text{p} \bot}\, w_\text{p} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (13.3\,\text{ft} \times \cos\theta)\, (m_\text{p}\, g) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(13.3\,\color{red}{\text{ft}} \times \frac{0.3048\,\text{m}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{ft}}} \times \cos 72.5^\circ \right) \big( 74.0\,\text{kg} \times 9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2 \big) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 882.0\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                        \label{unit09_e04_taup}
                        \end{align}
                Refer to <a href="../textbook/appendices.pdf#page=13" title="Chapter 5" target="_blank">Table C7</a> in the textbook for the unit of length conversion factor. Similarly, the counterclockwise torque produced by the ladder&rsquo;s weight is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau_\text{l} &= r_{\text{l} \bot}\, w_\text{l} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (10.0\,\text{ft} \times \cos\theta)\, (m_\text{l}\, g) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 116.5\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                        \label{unit09_e04_taul}
                        \end{align}
                The clockwise torque produced by the wall&rsquo;s normal force is expressed as
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau_\text{w} &= r_{\text{w} \bot}\, F_\text{w} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (20.0\,\text{ft} \times \sin\theta)\, F_\text{w} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (5.815\,\text{m})\, F_\text{w}
                        \label{unit09_e04_tauw}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>By substituting from Equations \ref{unit09_e04_taup}, \ref{unit09_e04_taul} and \ref{unit09_e04_tauw} into Equations \ref{unit09_e04_net_tau}, we have
                        \begin{equation}
                        882.0\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m} + 116.5\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m} - (5.815\,\text{m})\, F_\text{w} = 0
                        \end{equation}
                The force exerted by the wall at the top of the ladder is then calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{w} &= \frac{998.5\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}}{5.815\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 172\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04c">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>From Equation \ref{unit09_e04_netFx}, we see that the force of static friction between the ladder&rsquo;s base and the ground has a magnitude of
                        \begin{align}
                        f_\text{s} &= F_\text{w} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 172\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-conceptual-questions">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Statics and Torque</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Conceptual Questions</h2>

                  <p>Following, are detailed solutions of a number of conceptual questions selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-9.pdf#page=24" title="Chapter 9" target="_blank">Chapter 9</a> in the textbook.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-q02">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Question 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Under what conditions can a rotating body be in equilibrium? Give an example.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q02_btn">Answer</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>A rotating body is in equilibrium when it does not experience any linear or angular accelerations. This means the net force and the net torque on the body are both equal to zero. An example would be a ceiling fan rotating uniformly at a constant <a href="../unit06/index06.html#unit06-angular-quantities">angular velocity</a>.</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-q04">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Question 4</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A wrecking ball is being used to knock down a building. One tall unsupported concrete wall remains standing. If the wrecking ball hits the wall near the top, is the wall more likely to fall over by rotating at its base or by falling straight down? Explain your answer. How is it most likely to fall if it is struck with the same force at its base? Note that this depends on how firmly the wall is attached at its base.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q04_btn">Answer</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>If the ball hits near the top of the wall, it is more likely to fall over by rotating at its base. The perpendicular lever arm in this case is equal to the entire height of the wall, and the torque produced by the applied force is at its maximum value. If the wall is hit near its base, only a small torque is produced since the wrecking ball exerts a force near the point of rotation. In this case the wall is more likely to fall straight down.
                      </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 11 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-q11">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Question 11</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Why are the forces exerted on the outside world by the limbs of our bodies usually much smaller than the forces exerted by muscles inside the body?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q11_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q11">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>While in equilibrium, a limb is balanced by external forces due to the outside world, and internal forces caused by the muscles. However, most of the tendons attach the muscles to the skeletal bones close to the joints. This requires the a muscle to exert a relatively greater force to balance the torque on the relevant limb caused by the outside world.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 15 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-q15">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Question 15</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Certain types of dinosaurs were bipedal (walked on two legs). What is a good reason that these creatures invariably had long tails if they had long necks?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q15_btn">Explanation</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q15">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Bipedal dinosaurs with long necks must have long tails in order to keep the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit09-center-of-gravity">centre of gravity</a> above the legs. Otherwise, such animals would need to work very hard to stand and keep the balance.
                      </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-problems">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Statics and Torque</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Solutions of Selected Problems</h2>
                    <p>Next are detailed solutions to a number of problems selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-9.pdf#page=26" title="Chapter 9" target="_blank">Chapter 9</a> in the textbook. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve each problem independently, before you read through the solution provided. You are also advised to make a second attempt to solve the problem if your answer is different from the one posted. If you reach an impasse and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p01">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 1</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) When opening a door, you push on it perpendicularly with a force of $55.0\,\text{N}$ at a distance of $0.850\,\text{m}$ from the hinges. What torque are you exerting relative to the hinges? (b) Does it matter if you push at the same height as the hinges?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer01_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram01_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution01a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution01b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer01" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $46.8\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}$</p>
                      <p>(b) No</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p01s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.01s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution01a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Here, we are given that a force of $F = 55.0\,\text{N}$ is applied at a distance of $r = 0.850\,\text{m}$ from the hinge. Since the force is perpendicular to the door (see <b>Figure P9.01s</b>), the resulting <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit09-torque">torque</a> is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau &= r_\bot\, F \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.850\,\text{m})\, (55.0\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 46.8\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution01b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If you push at different heights, but with same force and at equal distances to the hinge, the door experiences equivalent torques.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p03">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 3</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Two children push on opposite sides of a door during play. Both push horizontally and perpendicular to the door. One child pushes with a force of $17.5\,\text{N}$ at a distance of $0.600\,\text{m}$ from the hinges, and the second child pushes at a distance of $0.450\,\text{m}$. What force must the second child exert to keep the door from moving? Assume friction is negligible.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer03_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram03_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution03_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$23.3\,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p03s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.03s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution03" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Here, child $\text{A}$ pushes with a force of $F_\text{A} = 17.5\,\text{N}$ at a perpendicular lever arm of $r_\text{A} = 0.600\,\text{m}$. Child $\text{B}$ pushes at a distance of $r_\text{B} = 0.450\,\text{m}$ from the hinges, in the opposite direction, as shown in <b>Figure P9.03s</b>. In order to keep the door from moving, it must experience zero net torque. So, if $F_\text{B}$ is the force applied by child $\text{B}$, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau_\text{A} - \tau_\text{B} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad r_\text{A}\, F_\text{A} - r_\text{B}\, F_\text{B} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  F_\text{B} &= \left(\frac{r_\text{A}}{r_\text{B}}\right) F_\text{A} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{0.600\,\text{m}}{0.450\,\text{m}}\right) \times (17.5\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 23.3\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 7 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p07">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 7</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Two children of mass $20.0\,\text{kg}$ and $30.0\,\text{kg}$ sit balanced on a seesaw with the pivot point located at the centre of the seesaw. If the children are separated by a distance of $3.00 \,\text{m}$, at what distance from the pivot point is the small child sitting in order to maintain the balance?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer07_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram07_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution07_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer07">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$1.8\,\text{m}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram07">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p07s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.07s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution07">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>In order for the two children to sit balanced on the seesaw, the torque produced by the child of mass $m_A = 20\,\text{kg}$ must be equal in magnitude to the torque produced by the child of mass $m_B = 30\,\text{kg}$. This allows us to write
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau_\text{A} &= \tau_\text{B} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad r_\text{A}\, w_\text{A} &= r_\text{B}\, w_\text{B} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad r_\text{A}\, (m_\text{A}\, g) &= r_\text{B}\, (m_\text{B}\, g) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad r_\text{A}\, m_\text{A} &= r_\text{B}\, m_\text{B}
                        \label{ch09_p07_tau}
                        \end{align}
                      Note that $w_\text{A} = m_\text{A}\, g$ and $w_\text{B} = m_\text{B}\, g$ are the weights of the smaller child and the bigger child, respectively. The seesaw achieves balance when the children set at distances $r_\text{A}$ and $r_\text{B}$ from the pivot point at the centre, as shown in <b>Figure P9.07s</b>.</p>

                      <p>Since the two children sit a distance $d = 3.00\,\text{m}$ apart, then
                        \begin{align}
                        r_\text{A} + r_\text{B} &= d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad r_\text{B} &= d - r_\text{A}
                        \label{ch09_p07_rb}
                        \end{align}
                      By substituting from Equation \ref{ch09_p07_rb} into Equation \ref{ch09_p07_tau}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        r_\text{A}\, m_\text{A} &= (d - r_\text{A})\, m_\text{B} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  r_\text{A}\, (m_\text{A} + m_\text{B}) &= d\, m_\text{B}
                        \end{align}
                      We can now solve for $r_\text{A}$ as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        r_\text{A} &= \left(\frac{m_\text{B}}{m_\text{A} + m_\text{B}}\right) d \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{30.0\,\text{kg}}{20.0\,\text{kg} + 30.0\,\text{kg}}\right) \times (3.00\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.8\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 9 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p09">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 9</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A person carries a plank of wood $2.00\,\text{m}$ long with one hand pushing down on it at one end with a force $F_1$ and the other hand holding it up at $0.500\,\text{m}$ from the end of the plank with force $F_2$. If the plank has a mass of $20.0\,\text{kg}$ and its centre of gravity is at the middle of the plank, what are the forces $F_1$ and $F_2$?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer09_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram09_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution09_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer09">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$196\,\text{N},\; 392\,\text{N}$<p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram09">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p09s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.09s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution09">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>To solve this problem, we first select a pivot point to calculate the torque about. A good choice would be the left end of the plank, where the person&rsquo;s hand pushes down with a force $F_1$. Of course, this force produces no torque in this case.</p>

                      <p>The two other forces on the plank are, the upward force ($F_2$) exerted by the other hand at $0.500\,\text{m}$ from the pivot point, and the weight of the plank ($m g$) which acts at its centre a distance $1.00\,\text{m}$ from either end (see <b>Figure P9.09s</b>). Since the plank is in static equilibrium, the torques produced by these two forces must balance each other, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        (0.500\,\text{m})\, F_2 = (1.00\,\text{m})\, (m g)
                        \end{equation}
                      So, the upward force exerted by the person on the plank is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F_2 &= \left(\frac{1.00\,\text{m}}{0.500\,\text{m}}\right) m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (2.00)\, (20.0\,\text{kg}\times 9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 392\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>

                      <p>The other condition for equilibrium is that the upward force must balance the downward forces, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        F_2 = F_1 + m g
                        \label{ch09_p09_netF}
                        \end{equation}
                      By substituting the known and calculated values into Equation \ref{ch09_p09_netF}, we can determine the downward force exerted by the person on the end of the plank as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        F_1 &= F_2 - m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 392\,\text{N} - (20.0\,\text{kg}\times 9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 196\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 10 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p10">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 10</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A $17.0$-$\text{m}$-high and $11.0$-$\text{m}$-long wall under construction and its bracing are shown in <b>Figure P9.10</b>. The wall is in stable equilibrium without the bracing but can pivot at its base. Calculate the force exerted by each of the $10$ braces if a strong wind exerts a horizontal force of $650\,\text{N}$ on each square meter of the wall. Assume that the net force from the wind acts at a height halfway up the wall and that all braces exert equal forces parallel to their lengths. Neglect the thickness of the wall.
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p10.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P9.10</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer10_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram10_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution10_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$2.12\times 10^4\,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p10s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.10s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution10">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The wall shown in <b>Figure P9.10</b> is $17.0\,\text{m}$ high and $11.0\,\text{m}$ long and it is supported by ten braces inclined at an angle of $35.0^\circ$ with the vertical. When the wind blows onto the left side, the wall experiences a pressure of $P = 650\,\text{N}/\text{m}^2$. Since, the total area facing the wind is
                        \begin{align}
                        A &= (17.0\,\text{m})\, (11.0\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 187\,\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                    the total horizontal force exerted onto the wall by the blowing wind is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{wind} &= P A \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (650\,\text{N}/\text{m}^2)\, (187\,\text{m}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 121{,}550\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>Since it is still under construction and not yet fixed to the ground, the wall is supported by braces, which apply forces parallel to their lengths as shown in <b>Figure P9.10s</b>. Since the wall remains in static equilibrium, the net torque on it must be equal to zero. By taking the bottom of the wall as the axis of rotation, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{braces} - \tau_\text{wind} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{braces} &= \tau_\text{wind} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad (8.50\,\text{m})\, F_\text{braces}\, \sin 35.0^\circ &= (8.50\,\text{m})\, F_\text{wind} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_\text{braces}\, \sin 35.0^\circ &= F_\text{wind} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \end{align}
                    So, the magnitude of the total force exerted by the ten braces is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{braces} &= \frac{F_\text{wind}}{\sin 35.0^\circ}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{121{,}550\,\text{N}}{\sin{35.0^\circ}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.12\times 10^5\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    which means that each brace exerts a force of
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{b} &= \frac{F_\text{braces}}{10}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.12\times 10^4\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 12 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p12">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 12</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose the weight of the drawbridge in <b>Figure P9.12</b> is supported entirely by its hinges and the opposite shore, so that its cables are slack. (a) What fraction of the weight is supported by the opposite shore if the point of support is directly beneath the cable attachments? (b) What is the direction and magnitude of the force the hinges exert on the bridge under these circumstances? The mass of the bridge is $2{,}500\,\text{kg}$.
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p12.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P9.12</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer12_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram12_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution12a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution12b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="interactive12_btn">Interactive Activity</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer12" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $1/6$</p>
                      <p>(b) $2.0\times 10^4 \,\text{N},\; \text{upward}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram12">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p12s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.12s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution12a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Here, we consider the situation when the cables are slack (zero tension) and that the weight of the drawbridge is supported entirely by its hinges and the opposite shore. Since the drawbridge is in equilibrium, the net torque about the hinge is equal to zero. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  \tau_\text{s} - \tau_w &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  \tau_\text{s} &= \tau_w \nonumber\\[6pt]
												\Rightarrow\quad (9.0\,\text{m})\, F_\text{s} &=  (1.5\,\text{m})\, w
                        \label{ch09_p12_net_tau}
                        \end{align}
                    where $\tau_\text{s}$ is the torque due to the upward force $F_\text{s}$ exerted by the opposite shore, as shown in <b>Figure P9.12s</b>.  The other torque ($\tau_w$) is produced by the weight ($w = m g$) of the drawbridge at the centre of gravity ($\text{CG}$).
From Equation \ref{ch09_p12_net_tau}, we find that the opposite shore exerts an upward force on the right end of the drawbridge equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{s} & = \left(\frac{1.5\,\text{m}}{9.0\,\text{m}}\right) m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        & = \tfrac{1}{6} m g
                        \label{ch09_p12_Fs}
                        \end{align}
                    So, one sixth ($1/6$) of the bridge&rsquo;s weight is supported by the opposite shore.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution12b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>To find the magnitude of the upward force exerted by the hinge ($F_\text{h}$) we need to consider the first condition for equilibrium, such that
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, F_y &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_\text{h} + F_\text{s} - w &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_h &= w - F_s \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m g - \tfrac{1}{6} m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{5}{6} m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{5}{6}\, (2{,}500\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m/s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.0\times 10^4 \,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="interactive12">
                <div class="panel-heading">Interactive Activity</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <div class="panel-body">
                    <p class="centerText"><a href="./ch09-p12i.cdf"><img  src="ch09-p12i.png" alt="image"></a><br>
                    <br><b>Figure P9.12i</b></p>
                </div>

                    <p>Use <a href="https://www.wolfram.com/cdf-player/" target="_blank">Wolfram CDF Player</a>
                    to open the interactive diagram <a href="./ch09-p12i.cdf"><b>Figure P9.12i</b></a>.</p>

                    <p>Answer the questions below and use the interactive diagram to check your calculations.</p>

                        <p>
                        <ol>
                        <li>If the a $T = 3.00\,\text{kN}$ tension of is created in the cable, how much force ($F_\text{s}$) does the opposite shore exert on the free end of the bridge?
                        <li>Determine the direction and magnitude of the force the hinges exert on the bridge under in this case.</li>
                        <li>What is the minimum tension ($F_\text{h}$) that causes the bridge to rotate?</li>
                      </ol>

                    </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 20 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p20">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 20</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose you needed to raise a $250$-$\text{kg}$ mower a distance of $6.0\,\text{cm}$ above the ground to change a tire. If you had a $2.0$-$\text{m}$ long lever, where would you place the fulcrum if your force was limited to $300\,\text{N}$?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer20_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram20_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution20_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$22\,\text{cm}$ from the output force</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p20s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.20s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution20">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Assume that the simple lever in <b>Figure P9.20s</b> is used to lift the mower, of mass $m = 250\,\text{kg}$. For this purpose, the lever must produce an output force of
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{o} &= m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (250\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m/s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2{,}450\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    If this is achieved when the maximum input force of $F_\text{i} = 300\,\text{N}$ is applied, the system must be balanced about the fulcrum. This means the net torque on the lever is equal to zero, or
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{i} - \tau_\text{o} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad l_\text{i}\, F_\text{i} - l_\text{o}\, F_\text{o} &= 0
                        \label{ch09_p20_net_tau}
                        \end{align}
                    where $l_\text{i}$ and $l_\text{o}$ are the lever arms for the input and output forces, respectively. Since the lever has a total length of $2.0\,\text{m}$, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        l_\text{i} + l_\text{o} &= 2.0\,\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad l_\text{i} &= 2.0\,\text{m} - l_\text{o}
                        \label{ch09_p20_li}
                        \end{align}
                    Bu substituting from Equation \ref{ch09_p20_li} into Equation \ref{ch09_p20_net_tau}, we find
                        \begin{align}
                        (2.0\,\text{m} - l_\text{o})\, F_\text{i} - l_\text{o}\, F_\text{o} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad l_\text{o}\, (F_\text{i} + F_\text{o}) &= (2.0\,\text{m})\, F_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad l_\text{o} &= \left(\frac{F_\text{i}}{F_\text{i} + F_\text{o}}\right) (2.0\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.22\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the fulcrum should be placed $22\,\text{cm}$ away from the output force.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 21 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p21">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 21</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) What is the mechanical advantage of a wheelbarrow, such as the one in <b>Figure P9.21</b>, if the centre of gravity of the wheelbarrow and its load has a perpendicular lever arm of $5.50\,\text{cm}$, while the hands have a perpendicular lever arm of $1.02\,\text{m}$? (b) What upward force should you exert to support the wheelbarrow and its load if their combined mass is $55.0\,\text{kg}$? (c) What force does the wheel exert on the ground?
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p21.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P9.21</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer21_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram21_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution21a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution21b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution21c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer21">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $18.5$</p>
                      <p>(b) $29.1\,\text{N}$</p>
                      <p>(c) $510\,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram21">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p21s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.21s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution21a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>As shown in <b>Figure P9.21s</b>, the wheelbarrow (mass $m = 55.0\,\text{kg}$) is balanced by two opposing torques about the wheel&rsquo;s axle. The first one is the counterclockwise torque ($\tau_w$) produced by the downward weight ($w = m g$) at the centre of gravity with a perpendicular (output) lever arm of $l_w = 0.0550\,\text{m}$. The second one is the clockwise torque ($\tau_\text{h}$) produced by the upward force ($F_\text{h}$) exerted by the hand, with a perpendicular (input) lever arm of $l_\text{h} = 1.02\,\text{m}$. Note that the normal force ($N$) does not produce any torque because it has zero lever arm.<p>

                    <p>Since the system is in rotational equilibrium, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_w - \tau_\text{h} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad l_w\, w - l_\text{h}\, F_\text{h} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad l_w\, w &= l_\text{h}\, F_\text{h}
                        \label{ch09_p21_net_tau}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the mechanical advantage ($\text{MA}$) of the wheelbarrow can be calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{MA} &= \frac{\text{output force}}{\text{input force}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{w}{F_\text{h}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{l_\text{h}}{l_w} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{1.02\,\text{m}}{0.0550\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 18.5
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution21b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>From Equation \ref{ch09_p21_net_tau}, we calculate the force exerted by the hand to support the wheelbarrow as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{h} &= \left(\frac{l_w}{l_\text{h}}\right) m g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{0.0550\,\text{m}}{1.02\,\text{m}}\right) (55.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m/s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 29.1\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution21c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the net vertical force is equal to zero, we can write
                         \begin{align}
                         \text{net}\, F_y &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         \Rightarrow\quad  F_\text{h} + N - w &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         \Rightarrow\quad  N &= m g - F_\text{h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= (55.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m/s}^2) - 29.1\,\text{N} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 510\,\text{N}
                         \end{align}
                    Referring to Newton&rsquo;s third law of motion, we can argue that the wheel exerts a downward force on the ground equal to $510\,\text{N}$.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 24 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p24">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 24</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">If you used an ideal pulley of the type shown in <b>Figure P9.24</b> to support a car engine of mass $115\,\text{kg}$ , (a) What would be the tension in the rope? (b) What force must the ceiling supply, assuming you you pull straight down on the rope? Neglect the pulley system&rsquo;s mass.
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p24.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P9.24</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer24_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram24_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution24b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer24">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $564\,\text{N}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $1.69\,\text{kN}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram24">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p24s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.24s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>We begin by drawing a free-body diagram for each pulley, as shown in figure <b>Figure P9.24s</b>. Note that for an ideal massless pulley, the tension is the same along the entire rope. Since the system is in equilibrium, the net force on each pulley must be equal to zero. Considering the lower pulley, we see that the upward tensions in two sections of the rope are balanced by the downward weight ($w = m g$) of the supported car engine. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, F_y &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  T + T - w &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  2T &= m g
                        \end{align}
                    So, the tension in the rope is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        T &= \frac{m g}{2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(115\,\text{kg})\,(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)}{2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 564\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution24b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>From the free-body diagram of the upper pulley (in <b>Figure P9.24s</b>) we see that the downward tensions in three sections of the rope are balanced by the upward support force ($F_\text{c}$) supplied by the ceiling. So, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, F_y &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_\text{c} - T - T - T &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad F_\text{c} &= 3 T \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3\, (563.5\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.69\times 10^3\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that this value is also equal to the engine&rsquo;s weight plus the downward pull on the free-end of the rope.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 28 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p28">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 28</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The upper leg muscle (quadriceps) exerts a force of $1{,}250 \,\text{N}$, which is carried by a tendon over the kneecap (the patella) at the angles shown in <b>Figure P9.28</b>. Find the direction and magnitude of the force exerted by the kneecap on the upper leg bone (the femur).
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p28.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P9.28</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer28_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram28_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution28_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer28">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$1.1\,\text{kN}$, $10^\circ$ below the negative $x$-axis </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram28">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p28s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.28s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution28">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>From <b>Figure P9.28</b>, we can calculate the $x$ and $y$ components of the net force exerted by the tendon on the kneecap, as
                        \begin{align}
                        F_x &= -F_\text{Q}\, \cos{55^\circ} - F_\text{Q}\, \cos{75^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - (1{,}250\,\text{N})\, \cos{55^\circ} - (1{,}250 \,\text{N})\, \cos{75^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - 1{,}040\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    and
                        \begin{align}
                        F_y &= F_\text{Q}\, \sin{55^\circ} - F_\text{Q}\, \sin{75^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (1{,}250 \,\text{N})\, \sin{55^\circ} - (1{,}250 \,\text{N})\, \sin{75^\circ} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -183\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    This force has a magnitude of
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= \sqrt{F_x^2 + f_y^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(1{,}040\,\text{N})^2 + (-183\,\text{N})^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.1\times 10^3\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    and a direction (see <b>Figure P9.28s</b>) of
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta &= \tan^{-1} \left(\frac{183\,\text{N}}{1{,}040\,\text{N}}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 10^\circ
                        \end{align}
                    So, the kneecap exerts a force of $1.1\,\text{kN}$ on the femur, at $10^\circ$ below the negative $x$-axis.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 34 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p34">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 34</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A father lifts his child as shown in <b>Figure P9.34</b>. What force should the upper leg muscle exert to lift the child at a constant speed?
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p34.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P9.34</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer34_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution34_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer34">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$2.25\,\text{kN}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution34">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>As shown in <b>Figure P9.34</b>, we are given the perpendicular lever arms of the different forces on the lower leg bone, as measured from the axis of rotation $O$. This means we don&rsquo;t need to worry about angles in this problem. The three forces, which contribute to the torque, are: the force ($F_\text{Q}$) due to the upper leg muscle (quadriceps), the weight ($w_\text{leg} = m_\text{leg}\, g$) of the lower leg, and the weight ($w_\text{child} = m_\text{child}\, g$) of the child.</p>

                    <p>Since the child is lifted at a constant speed, the lower leg bone does not experience any acceleration, and the net torque on it must be equal to zero. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{Q} - \tau_\text{leg} - \tau_\text{child} & = 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  r_{\text{Q}\bot}\, F_\text{Q} - r_{\text{l}\bot}\, w_\text{leg} - r_{\text{c}\bot}\, w_\text{child} &= 0
                        \label{ch09_p34_tau_net}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that the contact force between the femur and lower leg bone does not contribute to the net torque. This is because the corresponding force line passes through the axis of rotation ($O$) and therefore has zero lever arm. From Equation \ref{ch09_p34_tau_net}, we can calculate the force applied by the upper leg muscle (quadriceps) as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{Q} &= \frac{r_{\text{l}\bot}\, w_\text{leg} + r_{\text{c}\bot}\, w_\text{child}}{r_{\text{Q}\bot}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{r_{\text{l}\bot}\, m_\text{leg} + r_{\text{c}\bot}\, m_\text{child}}{r_{\text{Q}\bot}} \times g \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(0.200\,\text{m} \times 4.00\,\text{kg}) + (0.380\,\text{m} \times 10.0\,\text{kg})}{0.020\,\text{m}} \times (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.25\times 10^3\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 37 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p37">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 37</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) What force should the woman in <b>Figure P9.37</b> exert on the floor with each hand to do a push-up? Assume that she moves up at a constant speed. (b) The triceps muscle at the back of her upper arm has an effective lever arm of $1.75\,\text{cm}$, and she exerts force on the floor at a horizontal distance of $20.0\,\text{cm}$ from the elbow joint. Calculate the magnitude of the force in each triceps muscle, and compare it to her weight. (c) How much work does she do if her centre of mass rises $0.240\,\text{m}$? (d) What is her useful power output if she does $25$ pushups in one minute?
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p37.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P9.37</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer37_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram37_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution37a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution37b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution37c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution37d_btn">Solution (d)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer37" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $147\,\text{N}$ </p>
                        <p>(b) $1.68\,\text{kN}$ </p>
                        <p>(c) $118\,\text{J}$ </p>
                        <p>(d) $49.0\,\text{W}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram37">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p37s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.37S</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution37a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the woman moves at a constant speed during a push-up, then she is in equilibrium and the net torque on her body is equal to zero. By taking her toes as the axis of rotation (see <b>Figure P9.37</b>), we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{reaction} - \tau_w &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{reaction} &= \tau_w \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad (1.50\,\text{m})\, F_\text{reaction} &= (0.90\,\text{m})\, m g
                        \label{ch09_p37_net_tau}
                        \end{align}
                    where $m = 50.0\,\text{m}$ is the woman&rsquo;s mass. From Equation \ref{ch09_p37_net_tau}, we calculate the upward reaction force applied by the floor on both hands to be
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{reaction} &= \frac{(0.90\,\text{m})\, m g}{1.50\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 294\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    This means, each hand exerts a force on the floor equal to
                    \begin{align}
                    F_\text{h} &= \frac{F_\text{reaction}}{2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                    &= \frac{294\,\text{N}}{2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                    &= 147\,\text{N}
                    \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution37b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Here we focus on the equilibrium of the the lower arm only. The two forces that act on each lower arm is the upward reaction force ($F_\text{h}$) and the force ($F_\text{triceps}$) exerted by the triceps muscle. The perpendicular lever arms of the two forces, about the elbow joint, are as shown in <b>Figure P9.37s</b>. So, for the net torque on the lower arm, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{h} - \tau_\text{triceps} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{triceps} &= \tau_\text{h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad (0.0175\,\text{m})\, F_\text{triceps} &= (0.200\,\text{m})\, F_\text{h}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the magnitude of the force in each triceps muscle, is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{triceps} &= \frac{(0.200\,\text{m})\, F_\text{h}}{0.0175\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(0.200\,\text{m})\, (147\,\text{N})}{0.0175\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1{,}680\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that this is $3.43$ times greater than the woman&rsquo;s weight.
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution37c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The work done agonist the force of gravity is equal to the woman&rsquo;s wight multiplied by the vertical displacement of her centre of mass. This is calculated to be
                         \begin{align}
                         \text{work} &= (mg)\, (0.240\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= (50.0\,\text{kg})\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (0.240\,\text{m})\nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 118\,\text{J}
                         \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution37d" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (d)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The useful power output for $25$ push-ups in one minute ($t = 60\,\text{s}$), is calculated as follows
                         \begin{align}
                         P &= \frac{25\times \text{work}}{t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= \frac{25\times (117.6\,\text{J})}{60\,\text{s}}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 49.0\,\text{W}
                         \end{align}
                        </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 38 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter09-p38">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 9, Problem 38</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">You have just planted a sturdy $2\,\text{m}$-tall palm tree in your front lawn for your mother&rsquo;s birthday. Your brother kicks a $500\,\text{g}$ ball, which hits the top of the tree at a speed of $5.0\,\text{m/s}$ and stays in contact with it for $10\,\text{ms}$. The ball falls to the ground near the base of the tree and the recoil of the tree is minimal. (a) What is the force on the tree? (b) The length of the sturdy section of the root is only $20\,\text{cm}$. Furthermore, the soil around the roots is loose and we can assume that an effective force is applied at the tip of the $20\,\text{cm}$ length. What is the effective force exerted by the the tip of the root to keep the tree from toppling? Assume the tree will be uprooted rather than bend. (c) What could you have done to ensure that the tree does not uproot easily?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer38_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram38_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution38a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution38b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution38c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer38" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $250\,\text{N}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $2{,}500\,\text{N}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram38">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch09-p38s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P9.38s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution38a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>After impact, the ball falls to the ground near the base of the tree. This means that the ball loses all its horizontal speed ($v_\text{f} = 0$) as a result of the collision with the top of the tree. Since the ball initially moves at $v_\text{i} = 5\,\text{m/s}$, it experiences a change in horizontal momentum equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta p &= m\, \Delta v \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m\, (v_\text{f} - v_\text{i}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.50\,\text{kg})\, (0 - 5.0\,\text{m/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - 2.5\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>If the impact lasts for $\Delta t = 0.010\,\text{s}$, the average force exerted on the ball is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        F &= \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{-2.5\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}}{0.010\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -250\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                    Here the negative sign indicates that the force acts opposite to the initial direction of motion. From <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-third-law" target="_self">Newton&rsquo;s third law of motion</a>, we can say that the reaction force exerted by the ball on the tree is $F_\text{tree}= 250\,\text{N}$ parallel to initial horizontal velocity, as shown in <b>Figure P9.38s</b>.
                   </p>
                   </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution38b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>To avoid toppling, the tree must be in equilibrium, with zero net torque about the section of trunk at ground level (see <b>Figure P9.38s</b>). So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{net}\, \tau &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{tree} - \tau_\text{root} &= 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tau_\text{root} &= \tau_\text{tree} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad (0.20\,\text{m})\, F_\text{root} &= (2.0\,\text{m})\, F_\text{tree}
                        \end{align}
                    So, the effective force exerted by the tip of the root is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        F_\text{root} &= \left(\frac{2.0\,\text{m}}{0.20\,\text{m}}\right) F_\text{tree} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{2.0\,\text{m}}{0.20\,\text{m}}\right) (250\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2{,}500\,\text{N}
                        \end{align}
                   </p>
                   </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution38c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Normally, new trees are stabilized by attaching the middle of the trunk to stakes using suitable strings. This should provide the necessary counter torque to restore equilibrium, especially on windy days.
                   </p>
                   </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
