            <div class="page-signature">
              <article>
                <p class="runhead1"><strong>Physics 200</strong> Introductory Physics I</p>

                <p  class="unit">Unit 10 (Chapter 10)</p>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10" >

                  <!-- to change: the following content -->
                  <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                  <hr>

                  <p>When you were younger, you probably enjoyed playing with that little toy called the yo-yo. It basically consists of two discs with a short axle joining them and a piece of string attached to and wrapped around the axle. If you hold the end of the string in your hand and then release the yo-yo, it will accelerate downward unwrapping the string. However, you will notice that the yo-yo does not behave like a free falling object. The downward acceleration of the yo-yo will be smaller than the gravitational acceleration $g$. Further more, you will also notice that the yo-yo spins about its centre with increasing speed. So, how do we describe the motion of a yo-yo? To answer this question we need to understand rotational dynamics, which is introduced in this unit.</p>

                  <p style="margin-top:2.0em;">
                  <div class="learningobjectives">
                    <h3>Learning Objectives</h3>
                    <p>After completing this unit, you should be able to</p>
                    <ul>
                        <li>define angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration.</li>
                        <li>explain the relationships among linear displacement, velocity, and acceleration and their angular counterparts.</li>
                        <li>write out the kinematic equations, which describe the motion of a body experiencing constant angular acceleration.</li>
                        <li>use the kinematic equations to describe and predict the angular motion of a body rotating (or rolling) with constant angular acceleration.</li>
                        <li>define moment of inertia.</li>
                        <li>explain the dynamics of rotational motion.</li>
                        <li>discuss the law of conservation of mechanical energy as applied to a body having both translational and rotational motion.</li>
                        <li>define angular momentum.</li>
                        <li>discuss the law of conservation of angular momentum.</li>
                    </ul>
                  </div>

                  <!-- end of content -->

                </div> <!-- end of this section -->

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-angular-acceleration">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Angular Acceleration</h2>

               <p>The concept of angular velocity ($\omega$) was introduced in <a href="../unit06/index06.html#unit06-angular-quantities" target="_self">Unit 6</a> using the example of a door, of width $r$, rotating about its hinges (see <a href="#unit10-fig01"><b>Figure 10.1</b></a>). If the <a href="../unit06/index06.html#unit06-angular-quantities">angular velocity</a> of the door changes uniformly, by an amount equal to $\Delta\omega$ during a time interval $\Delta t$, then we have constant <em>angular acceleration</em> ($\alpha$), defined as the rate of change of angular velocity. This is expressed mathematically as,
                        \begin{equation}
                        \alpha = \frac{\Delta \omega}{\Delta t}
                        \end{equation}
               where the appropriate units are $\text{rad}/\text{s}^2$, $^\circ/\text{s}^2$, or $\text{rev}/\text{s}^2$.</p>

               <p>
                  <figure id="unit10-fig01">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-fig01.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 10.1</b>: Top view of a door, which rotates with uniform angular acceleration about the hinges.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


               <p>The relation between angular and linear accelerations is given by
                        \begin{align}
                        \alpha &= \frac{(\Delta v/r)}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(\Delta v/\Delta t)}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{a}{r}
                        \label{unit10_alpha_ar}
                        \end{align}
               where $v = \omega/r$ is the linear velocity of the free end of the door, and $a$ is its linear acceleration. It is important here not to confuse angular acceleration with centripetal acceleration. The later is a type of linear acceleration directed towards the centre of rotation. Also, note the difference in the units of each quantity.</p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">Chapter 10</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=2" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">10.1.&nbsp; Angular Acceleration</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-rotational-kinematics">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Rotational Kinematics</h2>

                <p>With the definitions of angular displacement, velocity, and acceleration, we can describe the kinematics of a body moving in a circular path in terms of angular quantities&mdash;just as we expressed the kinematics of linear motion in <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-constant-acceleration" target="_self">Unit 2</a>. In this regard, we consider only uniform rotational motion, or motion along a circular path with constant angular acceleration ($\alpha$).</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit10-fig02">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-fig02.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 10.2</b>: Top view of a door, which rotates with uniform angular acceleration during a time period $t$.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>Referring to <a href="#unit10-fig02"><b>Figure 10.2</b></a>, the initial angular position of the door is labeled $\theta_0$, while its initial angular velocity is labeled $\omega_0$. Note that, for convenience, timing is reset such that $t_0 = 0$. At a later time $t$, the angular position of the uniformly accelerating door becomes $\theta$, while its angular velocity changes to $\omega$. Such motion is described by the following kinematic equations
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= \omega_0 + \alpha t \label{unit10_ke_w}\\[6pt]
                        \theta &= \theta_0 + \omega_0 t + \tfrac{1}{2}\, \alpha t^2 \label{unit10_ke_theta}\\[6pt]
                        \omega^2 &= \omega_0^2 + 2 \alpha (\theta - \theta_0) \label{unit10_ke_w2}\\[6pt]
                        \theta &= \theta_0 + \bar{\omega} t \label{unit10_ke_theta_w}
                        \end{align}
                where the average velocity ($\bar{\omega}$) in Equation \ref{unit10_ke_theta_w} is defined as
                        \begin{equation}
                        \bar{\omega} = \frac{\omega_0 + \omega}{2}
                        \end{equation}
                Note the similarity to the <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-constant-acceleration">equations for linear motion</a> with constant acceleration.</p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">Chapter 10</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=6" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">10.2.&nbsp; Kinematics of Rotational Motion</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-rotational-dynamics">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Rotational Dynamics</h2>

                <p>Consider a small body of mass $m$, which is restricted to move along a circular path of radius $r$. Suppose a force $F$ acts on the body parallel to its direction of motion, as shown in <a href="#unit10-fig03"><b>Figure 10.3</b></a>. According to Newton's second law of motion, the linear acceleration of the body is proportional to the net external force (or $F = ma$). The question is: Do we have a similar relationship for rotational motion? The answer is yes, and the corresponding relationship says: The angular acceleration of a rotating body is proportional to the net external <em>torque</em>.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit10-fig03">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-fig03.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 10.3</b>: A body rotates along a circular path under the influence of a constant force, parallel to the direction of motion.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>At this point, we introduce the concept of torque ($\tau$), which is a physical quantity equal to the applied force multiplied by the <em>moment arm</em> (i.e. the perpendicular distance to the axis of rotation). So, the small body in <a href="#unit10-fig03"><b>Figure 10.3</b></a> experiences a torque, about the axis of rotation $O$, equal to</p>
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau &= r\, F \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= r\; m a \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= r\; m\, (r \alpha) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (m r^2)\,\alpha
                        \label{unit10_tau_rf}
                        \end{align}
                Here, $a$ is the linear acceleration directed tangent to the circular arc, while $\alpha$ is the corresponding angular acceleration. The quantity between brackets is called the <em>moment of inertia</em>, where
                        \begin{equation}
                        I = m r^2 \quad (\text{for a particle})
                        \label{unit10_Iparticle}
                        \end{equation}
                Note that Equation \ref{unit10_Iparticle} is applicable to a small body (or particle) of mass $m$ rotating along a circular path of radius $r$. Equation \ref{unit10_tau_rf} can, actually be expressed in the more general form of
                        \begin{equation}
                        \tau = I\,\alpha
                        \label{unit10_tau_Ialpha}
                        \end{equation}
                So, in the absence of a net torque (i.e., $\tau = 0$), the angular acceleration is equal to zero and the body rotates at a constant angular velocity. When a net constant torque is applied, the body experiences constant angular acceleration.</p>


                <p>The similarity between the relations $\tau = I\alpha$ and $F = ma$, requires further exploration. The torque $\tau$ plays a similar role in rotational motion as $F$ in linear motion, whereas the angular acceleration $\alpha$ corresponds to the linear acceleration $a$, and the moment of inertia $I$ is the rotational equivalent of the mass $m$. There is, however, a small complication related to the moment of inertia, which is not a simple intrinsic quantity like the mass. The moment inertia can have different values for the same body, depending on its geometry and the location of the pivot axis.</p>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-moment-rigid-body">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Moment of Inertia of a Rigid Body</h2>

                <p>To see how the moment of inertia of a rigid body is computed, we consider a simple example&mdash;a thin hoop, of radius $R$ and mass $M$, which can rotate about its cylinder axis, as shown in <a href="#unit10-fig04"><b>Figure 10.4</b></a>. If we imagine the hoop as a composition of very small sections, of masses $m_1$, $m_2$, etc., then each section can be treated as a particle allowed to rotate along a circular path of radius $R$. In addition, each section of the rigid hoop experiences the same angular acceleration $\alpha$.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit10-fig04">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-fig04.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 10.4</b>: A thin hoop, of radius $R$ and mass $M$, rotates about its cylinder axis.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>The total torque on the rotating hoop of <a href="#unit10-fig04"><b>Figure 10.4</b></a>, can be calculated by adding the individual torques on the imaginary sections using  Equation \ref{unit10_tau_rf}. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau &= \tau_1 + \tau_2 + \cdots \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (m_1 R^2)\,\alpha + (m_2 R^2)\,\alpha + \cdots \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (m_1 + m_2 + \cdots)\, R^2\; \alpha \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (M R^2)\, \alpha \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= I \alpha
                        \end{align}
                So, the moment of inertia of the thin hoop, of mass $M$ and radius $R$, about its cylinder axis, is given by the expression
                        \begin{equation}
                        I = M R^2 \quad (\text{hoop, about its cylinder axis})
                        \label{unit10_Ihoop}
                        \end{equation}
                It is important to note that the moment of inertia of the same hoop about a different axis of rotation (see <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=13" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">Figure 10.12</a> in the textbook) will not be the same as in Equation \ref{unit10_Ihoop}. This is because the distances between the various sections of the hoop and the axis of rotation are altered.
                </p>

                <p>The moments of inertia of solid bodies of regular shapes can be calculated using calculus methods, which is beyond the scope of this course. For example, the moment of inertia of a solid uniform cylinder of mass $M$ and radius $R$, about its cylinder axis, takes the expression
                        \begin{equation}
                        I = \tfrac{1}{2} M R^2 \quad (\text{solid cylinder, about its cylinder axis})
                        \label{unit10_Icylinder}
                        \end{equation}
                Note that moment of inertia, in SI units, is measured in $\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2$.</p>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">Chapter 10</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=11" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">10.3.&nbsp; Dynamics of Rotational Motion: Rotational Inertia</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-rotational-kinetic-energy">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Rotational Kinetic Energy</h2>

                <p>When a rigid body rotates about a fixed axis, all sections of the body execute circular motions with the same <a href="../unit06/index06.html#unit06-angular-quantities">angular velocity</a>. The linear velocities, however, may vary, depending on the rotation radii of the different sections.</p>

                <div id="fig-10.4" class="pictures">
                <div><a href="#close" title="Close" class="close">&#10006;</a><br>
                <img src="unit10-fig04.svg" alt="image"><br>
                <b>Figure 10.4</b></div></div>

		<p>Again, consider the thin loop of mass $M$ and radius $R$, shown in <a href="#fig-10.4"><b>Figure 10.4</b></a>.
                If the hoop rotates about its cylinder axis with angular velocity $\omega$, then each section moves with the same linear speed of $v = R \omega$, which is directed along the tangent of the hoop. The <em>rotational kinetic energy</em> of the hoop is then equal to the sum of the kinetic energies of all sections. So, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{KE}_\text{rot} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m_1 v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} m_2 v^2 + \cdots \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} (m_1 + m_2 + \cdots)\, v^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} M v^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} M (R \omega)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} (M R^2)\, \omega^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega^2
                        \label{ch10_KErot}
                        \end{align}
                where $I$ is as defined in Equation \ref{unit10_Ihoop}. The expression derived in Equation \ref{ch10_KErot} is actually a general result, which applies to any rigid body of moment of inertia $I$ and angular velocity $\omega$. Note that the unit of rotational kinetic energy is the joule, where we have
                        \begin{align}
                        (\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2)\cdot\text{s}^{-2} &= (\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\cdot\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \text{N}\cdot\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \text{J}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-conservation-mechnical-energy">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Conservation of Mechanical Energy</h2>

                <p>Consider a wheel, of mass $M$, rolling down an inclined plane, as shown in <a href="#unit10-fig05"><b>Figure 10.5</b></a>. When it is at a height $h_1$, the wheel&rsquo;s translational and rotational speeds are $v_1$ and $\omega_1$, respectively. These speeds change to $v_2$ and $\omega_2$ when the wheel is at height $h_2$, as indicated in the diagram. Note that the total mechanical energy of this system is conserved, if the definition of kinetic energy is extended to include the kinetic energy of rotational motion. Mathematically, this can be expressed as,
                        \begin{equation}
                        \tfrac{1}{2} M v_1^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega_1^2 + M g h_1 = \tfrac{1}{2} M v_2^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega_2^2 + M g h_2
                        \end{equation}
                where $I$ is the moment of inertia of the wheel about its axle.
                </p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit10-fig05">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="unit10-fig05.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 10.5</b>: A wheel rolling down an inclined plane.</figcaption>
                  </figure>

<!-- ****** Reading ****** -->
                <p style="margin-top:1.5em;">
                <div class="readassign">
                <h3>Reading Assignment</h3>
                    <p>Read the following section from <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">Chapter 10</a> in the textbook</p>
                    <ul class="readassignlist">
                      <li><a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=15" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">10.4.&nbsp; Rotational Kinetic Energy: Work and Energy Revisited</a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>


                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-angular-momentum">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Angular Momentum</h2>

                <p>Consider a particle of mass $m$, which moves with a velocity $v$, as shown in <a href="#unit10-fig06"><b>Figure 10.6</b></a>. The <a href="../unit08/index08.html#unit08-linear-momentum">linear momentum</a> of the particle is equal to $p = m v$. Another important quantity is the <em>angular momentum</em> $L$, which is defined in association with a specific axis of rotation as
                        \begin{equation}
                        L = r_\bot\; p
                        \label{unit10_Lrp}
                        \end{equation}
                where, $r_\bot$ is the perpendicular distance to the reference axis $O$.</p>

                <p>
                  <figure id="unit10-fig06">
                  <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-fig06.svg" alt="image"></p>
                  <figcaption><b>Figure 10.6</b>: A particle moves in the $x$ $y$ plane.</figcaption>
                  </figure>


                <p>With the definition in Equation \ref{unit10_Lrp}, we can derive the following relation for the angular momentum
                        \begin{align}
                        L &= r_\bot\; p \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (r\, \sin\phi)\, m v \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (m r^2) \left(\frac{v\, \sin\phi}{r}\right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= I\, \omega
                        \label{unit10_LIw}
                        \end{align}
                From <a href="#unit10-fig06"><b>Figure 10.6</b></a>, we see that the radial component of the particle&rsquo;s velocity ($v \cos\phi$) is directed away from the axis and, therefore, does not generate any angular displacement about $O$. On the other hand, the transverse component ($v \sin\phi = \omega r$) produces angular displacement about $O$. Note that $\omega = \Delta\theta/\Delta t$, in this case. Equation \ref{unit10_LIw} is actually a general relation, which can be applied to any rigid body. The unit of angular momentum, in the SI system, is $\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}$.
                </p>

                <h3>PhET Simulation: My Solar System</h3>

                <p>As mentioned in the <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=22" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">textbook</a>, &ldquo;build your own system of heavenly bodies and watch the gravitational ballet. With this orbit simulator, you can set initial positions, velocities, and masses of 2, 3, or 4 bodies, and then see them orbit each other.&rdquo;</p>

                <p><div style="position: relative; width: 300px; height: 197px;"><a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/my-solar-system/my-solar-system_en.html" target="_blank" style="text-decoration: none;" rel="external"><img src="https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/my-solar-system/my-solar-system-600.png" alt="My Solar System" style="border: none;" width="300" height="197"/><div style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px; background-color: #FFF; opacity: 0.6; filter: alpha(opacity = 60);"></div><table style="position: absolute; width: 200px; height: 80px; left: 50px; top: 58px;"><tr><td style="text-align: center; color: #000; font-size: 24px; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Click to Run</td></tr></table></a></div>

                <div class="source">Source: <a href="https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/legacy/my-solar-system" target="_blank">PhET Interactive Simulations</a>, University of Colorado Boulder.</div>

                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-examples">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                <hr>
                <h2>Examples</h2>

                    <p>Following, are detailed solutions to a number of examples relevant to the content of <span style="white-space: nowrap;">Unit 10</span>. Make an attempt to answer each question on your own, before you read through the solution provided.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-e01">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 10, Example 1</div>
                <div class="panel-body">The disk of a computer hard drive starts from rest and reaches its maximum rotation rate of $7{,}200\,\text{rpm}$, in $9.00\,\text{s}$. What is the average angular acceleration of the disk?
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e01_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e01_btn">Solution</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$83.8\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e01">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>After the computer is turned on, the angular speed of the hard disk increases from the initial value of $\omega_0 = 0$ to the final value of $\omega = 7.20\,\times 10^3\,\text{rev/min}$ in a time interval of $\Delta t = 9.00\,\text{s}$. So, the change in the angular speed of the disk is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta \omega &= \omega - \omega_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (7.20\,\times 10^3\,\text{rev/min}) - 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{7.20\,\times 10^3\,\color{red}{\text{rev}}}{\color{blue}{\text{min}}} \times \frac{2\pi\,\text{rad}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{rev}}} \times \frac{1\,\color{blue}{\text{min}}}{60\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 754\,\text{rad/s}
                        \end{align}
                The average <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-angular-acceleration">angular acceleration</a> of the disk is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \alpha &= \frac{\Delta\omega}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{754\,\text{rad/s}}{9.00\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 83.8\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-e02">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 10, Example 2</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A tire, $30.0\,\text{in}$ in diameter, is mounted on a wheel balancer machine and spins at $53.0\,\text{rpm}$. At $t = 0$ the machine starts to accelerate uniformly until it reaches $100\,\text{rpm}$ after $7.00\,\text{s}$. Calculate the (a) angular, (b) centripetal, and (c) tangential accelerations of a point on the edge of the tire at $t = 3.00\,\text{s}$.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e02_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e02_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e02c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                <p></p>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>(a) $0.703\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    <p>(b) $22.4\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    <p>(c) $0.268\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-e02s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E10.2s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>The tire accelerates uniformly from an initial speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega_0 &= 53.0\,\text{rev/min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.55\,\text{rad/s}
                        \end{align}
                to a final speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega_7 &= 100\,\text{rev/min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 10.47\,\text{rad/s}
                        \end{align}
                in a time period of $\Delta t = 7.00\,\text{s}$. The angular acceleration of the tire is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \alpha &= \frac{\Delta \omega}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{\omega_7 - \omega_0}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{10.47\,\text{rad/s} - 5.55\,\text{rad/s}}{7.00\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.703\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>Note that the tire does not perform uniform circular motion. This is because the speed of any point on the tire increases with time. So, after $3.00\,\text{s}$ of uniform acceleration, the wheel reaches an angular speed of (see <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-rotational-kinematics">kinematic Equation \ref{unit10_ke_w}</a>)
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= \omega_0 + \alpha\, (3.00\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.55\,\text{rad/s} + (0.703\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2)\, (3.00\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 7.66\,\text{rad/s}
                        \end{align}
                At this time, a point on the edge of the tire (see <b>Figure E10.2s</b>) rotates in a circle of radius
                        \begin{align}
                        r &= \frac{30.0\,\text{in}}{2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{30.0\,\color{red}{\text{in}}}{2} \times \frac{0.0254\,\text{m}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{in}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.381\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                at a linear speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= \omega\, r \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (7.66\,\text{rad/s})\, (0.381\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.92\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>So, the <a href="../unit08/index08.html#unit06-circular-motion">centripetal acceleration</a> of a point on the edge of the tire at $t = 3.00\,\text{s}$, is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        a_\text{c} &= \frac{v^2}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(2.92\,\text{m/s})^2}{0.381\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 22.4\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e02c">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>The acceleration of a point on the edge of the tire is tangent to the circular path, as shown in <b>Figure E10.2s</b>, and has a magnitude of (see <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-angular-acceleration">Equation \ref{unit10_alpha_ar}</a>)
                        \begin{align}
                        a_\text{t} &= \alpha\, r \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.703\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2)\, (0.381\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.268\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-e03">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 10, Example 3</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A carpenter is sanding a wooden ball rotating at $360\,\text{rpm}$ on a lathe, as shown in <b>Figure E10.3</b>. The force of friction between the sandpaper and the wood is $0.40\,\text{N}$. (a) What is the maximum torque produced by the sanding process, if the ball has a diameter of $20\,\text{cm}$? (b) After the machine is turned off, how long does it take the ball to stop, assuming that the only significant torque is due to the sandpaper? The density of the wood is $0.74\,\text{g}/\text{cm}^3$.
                <hr>
                <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-e03.svg" alt="image"><br>
                <br><b>Figure E10.3</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e03_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e03b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $0.040\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $12\, \text{s}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>Since the force of friction ($f = 0.40\,\text{N}$) is tangent to the ball&rsquo;s surface, the lever arm is just equal to the radius of rotation. If the direction of the ball&rsquo;s rotation is taken to be positive, then the torque generated by the resistive force of friction is negative. This is because it attempts to cause rotation in the opposite direction. Maximum torque ($\tau$) occurs when the lever arm is equal to the ball&rsquo;s radius ($R = 0.10\,\text{m}$), or
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau &= - R\, f \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - (0.10\,\text{m})\, (0.40\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - 0.040\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e03b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>The mass of the wooden ball is given by
                        \begin{align}
                        M &= \text{density} \times \text{volume} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \rho\, \left( \tfrac{4}{3} \pi R^3 \right) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{4}{3} \pi \rho R^3
                        \end{align}
                where, the density of the wood is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \rho &= \frac{0.74\,\color{red}{\text{g}}}{\color{blue}{\text{cm}^3}} \times \frac{1\,\text{kg}}{1000\,\color{red}{\text{g}}} \times \left(\frac{100\,\color{blue}{\text{cm}}}{1\,\text{m}}\right)^3 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 740\,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3
                        \end{align}
                 </p>

                 <p>The moment of inertia of the solid wooden sphere about its central axis (see
                <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=13" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">Figure 10.12</a> in the textbook) is calculated as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        I &= \tfrac{2}{5} M R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{2}{5} \left(\tfrac{4}{3} \pi \rho R^3\right) R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{8}{15} \pi \rho R^5 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{8}{15} \pi\, (740\,\text{kg}/\text{m}^3)\, (0.10\,\text{m})^5 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.0124\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                 </p>

                <p>If $\tau$ is the only torque on the ball, then it would slow down at a constant rate of (see <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-rotational-dynamics">Equation \ref{unit10_tau_Ialpha}</a>)
                        \begin{align}
                        \alpha &= \frac{\tau}{I} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{- 0.040\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}}{0.0124\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -3.23\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                With the initial angular speed equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega_0 &= 360\,\text{rev/min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 37.7\,\text{rad/s}
                        \end{align}
                the time it takes the wheel to stop ($\omega = 0$) is calculated by substituting into the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-rotational-kinematics">kinematic Equation \ref{unit10_ke_w}</a>, as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= \omega_0 + \alpha t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= 37.7\,\text{rad/s} + (-3.23\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2)\, t
                        \end{align}
                By solving for $t$, we find that the ball stops after
                        \begin{align}
                        t &= \frac{37.7\,\text{rad/s}}{3.23\,\text{rad}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 12\, \text{s}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 4 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-e04">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 10, Example 4</div>
                <div class="panel-body">An Atwood&rsquo;s machine consists of two masses, $m_1$ and $m_2$, connected by a light string that passes over a pulley, as shown in <b>Figure E10.4</b>. Determine the linear acceleration of the system, (a) when the pulley is considered a massless body, and (b) when the pulley is considered a short cylinder of radius $R$ and mass $M$.
                <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-e04.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure E10.4</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="answer-e04_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solutionDiagram-e04_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solution-e04a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default" id="solution-e04b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $(m_1 - m_2)/(m_1 + m_2)\, g$</p>
                      <p>(b) $(m_1 - m_2)/(m_1 + m_2 + \tfrac{1}{2} M)\, g$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e04">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-e04s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E10.4s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>We begin with the simple case of a massless and a frictionless pulley. In other words we will ignore the presence of the pulley except for the purpose of transferring the motion from one mass to the other through the light string. In this case, no torque is required to rotate the pulley and the tension ($T$) is the same along the entire string. It is intuitive that, when $m_1 > m_2$, the system accelerates towards the heavier mass ($m_1$). In this case, the string provides the necessary tension so that both masses move with the same speed and have the same acceleration.</p>

                <p>When <a href="../unit04/index04.html#unit04-newton-second-law" target="_self">Newton&rsquo;s second law of motion</a> is applied to each mass we can write the following two equations
                        \begin{align}
                        m_1\, g - T &= m_1\, a \label{unit10_e04_m1a}\\[6pt]
                        T - m_2\, g  &= m_2\, a \label{unit10_e04_m2a}
                        \end{align}
                By adding the two equations above, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        m_1\, g - m_2\, g &= m_1\, a + m_2\, a  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \rightarrow\quad (m_1 - m_2)\, g  &= (m_1 + m_2)\, a
                        \end{align}
                which gives the following expression for the acceleration
                        \begin{equation}
                        a = \left(\frac{m_1 - m_2}{m_1 + m_2}\right) g
                        \label{unit10_e04_a_noplulley}
                        \end{equation}
                </p>

                <p>Note that the acceleration is zero when the masses are equal (i.e., $m_1 = m_2$). Also, if we substitute $m_2 = 0$ in Equation \ref{unit10_e04_a_noplulley}, we have $a = g$. In other words, if one of the masses is removed, the other mass performs a free fall.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e04b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>If the mass of the pulley cannot be ignored then its rotation will affect the motion of the hanging masses. Note that a point on the rim also moves with the same linear acceleration ($a$) as the rest of the system. This means, the pulley experiences angular acceleration equal to
                        \begin{equation}
                        \alpha = \frac{a}{R}
                        \end{equation}
                In this case, the tension in the string is not the same on both sides of the pulley, as shown in <b>Figure E10.4s</b>. Such difference produces the required torque ($\tau$) to accelerate the pulley. If $T_1$ and $T_2$ are the tensions in the sections of the string attached to $m_1$ and $m_2$, respectively, we can write the following equation to describe the rotation of the pulley
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau &= I \alpha \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \tau_1 - \tau_2 &= I \alpha \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad T_1\, R - T_2\, R &= \left(\tfrac{1}{2} M R^2\right) \frac{a}{R} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad (T_1 - T_2) &= \tfrac{1}{2} M a
                        \label{unit_e04_T1T2Ma}
                        \end{align}
                The corresponding equations for the hanging masses are
                        \begin{align}
                        m_1\, g - T_1 &= m_1\, a \label{unit10_e04_m1T1a}\\[6pt]
                        T_2 - m_2\, g  &= m_2\, a \label{unit10_e04_m2T2a}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>By adding the Equations \ref{unit10_e04_m1T1a} and \ref{unit10_e04_m2T2a}, we get
                        \begin{align}
                        m_1\, g - m_2\, g - T_1 + T_2 &= m_1\, a + m_2\, a  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad (T_1 - T_2) &= (m_1 - m_2)\, g  - (m_1 + m_2)\, a
                        \label{unit_e04_T1T2m1m2a}
                        \end{align}
                We can now substitute from Equation \ref{unit_e04_T1T2Ma} into Equation \ref{unit_e04_T1T2m1m2a} and write
                        \begin{align}
                        \tfrac{1}{2} M a &= (m_1 - m_2)\, g  - (m_1 + m_2)\, a  \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \left(m_1 + m_2 + \tfrac{1}{2} M\right) a &= (m_1 - m_2)\, g
                        \end{align}
                So, the pulley system accelerates at
                        \begin{equation}
                        a = \left(\frac{m_1 - m_2}{m_1 + m_2 + \tfrac{1}{2} M}\right) g
                        \end{equation}
                Note that when the mass of the pulley is ignored (or $M = 0$), the expression above reduces to that of a massless pulley (Equation \ref{unit10_e04_a_noplulley}).</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 5 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-e05">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 10, Example 5</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A thin spherical shell starts from rest at a height $1.30\,\text{m}$ above the ground and rolls down a ramp, as shown in <b>Figure E10.5</b>. Determine the linear speed of the spherical shell as it rolls on the ground.
                <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-e05.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure E10.5</b></p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e05_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e05_btn">Solution</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e05">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$3.91\,\text{m/s}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e05">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>In the absence of any resistive forces, such as air drag, the total <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-conservation-mechnical-energy">mechanical energy</a> of the system is conserved. This implies that gravitational potential energy is converted into kinetic energy, as the spherical shell moves down the ramp. For rolling motion, however, kinetic energy appears in two forms: translational and rotational.</p>

                <p>So, when the spherical shell is still at rest at the top of the ramp, the total mechanical energy of the system is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{PE}_\text{i} + \text{KE}_\text{i} &= m g h + 0\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m g h
                        \end{align}
                where $m$ is the mass of the spherical shell, and $h = 1.30\,\text{m}$ is its initial height, as shown in <b>Figure E10.5</b>. When it reaches the ground at the end of the ramp, the spherical shell loses all its gravitational potential energy, and rolls away with a mechanical energy given by
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{PE}_\text{f} + \text{KE}_\text{f} &= \text{PE}_\text{f} + \text{KE}_\text{trans} + \text{KE}_\text{rot} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0 + \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} \left(\tfrac{2}{3} m r^2\right) \left(\frac{v}{r}\right)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 + \tfrac{1}{3}  m v^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{5}{6} m v^2
                        \end{align}
                Note that when a circular body of radius $r$ performs rolling motion, without slipping, the angular speed ($\omega$) is related to the linear speed ($v$) by the equation $\omega =  v/r$. In the calculations above, we also substituted (refer to
                <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=13" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">Figure 10.12</a> in the textbook) $I = \tfrac{2}{3} m r^2$ for the moment of inertia of a thin spherical shell about an axis through its centre.</p>

                <p>Since, the total mechanical energy of the system is conserved, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        \text{PE}_\text{i} + \text{KE}_\text{i} &= \text{PE}_\text{f} + \text{KE}_\text{f} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad m g h &= \tfrac{5}{6} m v^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad g h &= \tfrac{5}{6} v^2
                        \end{align}
                So, the spherical shell rolls on the ground with a final linear speed of
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= \sqrt{\frac{6 g h}{5}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{\frac{6\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (1.30\,\text{m})}{5}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.91\,\text{m/s}
                        \label{unit10_e05_v}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Example 6 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="unit10-e06">
                <p><br/></p>
                <div class="panel panel-primary">
                <div class="panel-heading">Unit 10, Example 6</div>
                <div class="panel-body">A two-blade propeller, of mass $31.0\,\text{kg}$ and length $1.50\,\text{m}$, rotates at $1{,}250\,\text{rpm}$ about its centre. (a) What is the angular momentum of the propeller? (b) If it takes $9.00\,\text{s}$ to stop, determine the average torque exerted. You can model the two-blade propeller as a thin rod that is free to rotate about an axis through its centre, perpendicular to its length.
                </div>
                </div>

                <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-e06_btn">Answer</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram-e06_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e06a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution-e06b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-e06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $761\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $84.5\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}$</p>

                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram-e06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./unit10-e06s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure E10.6S</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e06a">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>The <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-angular-momentum">angular momentum</a> ($L$) of a rotating body is equal to its moment of inertia ($I$) times the angular velocity ($\omega$), or
                        \begin{equation}
                        L = I \omega
                        \label{unit10_e06_LIw}
                        \end{equation}
                For the propeller, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= 1.25\times 10^3\,\text{rev/min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 130.9\,\text{rad/s}
                        \label{unit10_e06_w}
                        \end{align}
                If it is modelled as a thin rod, of length $l = 1.50\,\text{m}$ and mass $m = 31.0\,\text{kg}$, the two-blade propeller has a moment of inertia (see
                <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=13" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank"><b>Figure 10.12</b></a> in the textbook) equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        I &= \tfrac{1}{12} m l^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{12}\, (31.0\,\text{kg})\, (1.50\,\text{m})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.81\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2
                        \label{unit10_e06_I}
                        \end{align}
                </p>

                <p>By substituting from Equations \ref{unit10_e06_w} and \ref{unit10_e06_I} into Equation \ref{unit10_e06_LIw}, the angular momentum of the propeller is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        L &= (5.81\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2)\, (130.9\,\text{rad/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 761\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}
                        \end{align}
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution-e06b">
                <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                <div class="panel-body">
                <p>The net torque applied on an object is equal to the rate of change of its angular momentum, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        \tau_\text{net} = \frac{\Delta L}{\Delta t}
                        \end{equation}
                When the propeller stops rotating, its angular momentum changes by
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta L &= 0 - 761\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= - 761\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}
                        \end{align}
                If this occurs in a period of $\Delta t = 9.00\,\text{s}$, then the net torque exerted on the propeller has the average value
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau_\text{net} &= \frac{- 761\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}}{9.00\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -84.5\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                The negative sign indicates that the torque acts to oppose the propeller&rsquo;s rotation.
                </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-conceptual-questions">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Conceptual Questions</h2>

                  <p>Following, are detailed solutions of a number of conceptual questions selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=36" title="Chapter 9" target="_blank">Chapter 10</a> in the textbook.</p>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-q01">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Question 1</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Analogies exist between rotational and translational physical quantities. Identify the rotational term analogous to each of the following: acceleration, force, mass, work, translational kinetic energy, linear momentum, impulse.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer-q01_btn">Answer</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer-q01">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Acceleration $\rightarrow$ angular acceleration
                        <br> Force $\rightarrow$ torque
                        <br> Mass $\rightarrow$ moment of inertia
                        <br> Work $\rightarrow$ work
                        <br> Translational kinetic energy $\rightarrow$ rotational kinetic energy
                        <br> Linear momentum $\rightarrow$ angular momentum
                        <br> Impulse $\rightarrow$ change in angular momentum
                      </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 3 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-q03">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Question 3</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">In circular motion, a tangential acceleration can change the magnitude of the velocity but not its direction. Explain this statement.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q03_btn">Explanation</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q03">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Since the tangential acceleration is parallel to the tangential velocity, only the magnitude of the velocity is affected. In order for any moving body to change its direction of motion, it must experience some acceleration perpendicular to its velocity.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 6 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-q06">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Question 6</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Why is the moment of inertia of a hoop that has a mass $M$ and a radius $R$ greater than the moment of inertia of a disk that has the same mass and radius? Why is the moment of inertia of a spherical shell that has a mass $M$ and a radius $R$ greater than that of a solid sphere that has the same mass and radius?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q06_btn">Explanation</button>

                  <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The entire mass of the hoop is concentrated at the edge, at a distance $R$ from the central axis. For the disk, the same mass is spread evenly from the central axis to the edge, with average radius less than $R$. A similar argument is applicable to the spherical shell and the solid sphere.</p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Question 19 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-q19">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Question 19</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">When there is a global heating trend on Earth, the atmosphere expands and the length of the day increases very slightly. Explain why the length of a day increases.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="explanation-q12_btn">Explanation</button>

                <p></p>
                <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="explanation-q12">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Explanation</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>As the atmosphere expands, the total moment of inertia ($I$) of the planet increases by a small amount. Since, the net angular momentum ($L = I \omega$) is conserved, the angular velocity ($\omega$) must decrease slightly, which makes a day on Earth a little longer.
                      </p>
                </div>
                </div>

                </div>

<!--  *********************************  -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-problems">
                <h1 style="margin-bottom:1.0em">Rotational Motion and Angular Momentum</h1>
                  <hr>
                  <h2>Solutions of Selected Problems</h2>
                    <p>Next are detailed solutions to a number of problems selected from the end of <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=40" title="Chapter 9" target="_blank">Chapter 10</a> in the textbook. It is crucially important to your learning that you endeavour to solve each problem independently, before you read through the solution provided. You are also advised to make a second attempt to solve the problem if your answer is different from the one posted. If you reach an impasse and cannot proceed, then refer to the worked solution, but only to the point at which you can again proceed on your own. Use the solutions to check your work, but do the work first!</p>
                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 1 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p01">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 1</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">At its peak, a tornado is $60.0\,\text{m}$ in diameter and carries $500\,\text{km/h}$ winds. What is its angular velocity in revolutions per second?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer01_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution01_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer01" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.737\,\text{rev/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution01" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The linear velocity of the wind carried by the tornado is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= 500\,\text{km/h} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{500\,\color{red}{\text{km}}}{\color{blue}{\text h}} \times \frac{1000\,\text{m}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{km}}} \times \frac{1\,\color{blue}{\text h}}{3{,}600\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 138.9\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    Since the tornado has a radius of $r = 30.0\,\text{m}$, the angular velocity is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= \frac{v}{r}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{138.9\,\text{m/s}}{30.0\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 4.630 \,\text{rad/s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{4.630\,\color{red}{\text{rad}}}{\text{s}} \times \frac{1\,\text{rev}}{2\pi\,\color{red}{\text{rad}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.737\,\text{rev/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 2 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p02">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 2</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">An ultracentrifuge accelerates from rest to $100{,}000\,\text{rpm}$ in $2.00\,\text{min}$. (a) What is its angular acceleration in $\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2$ ? (b) What is the tangential acceleration of a point $9.50\,\text{cm}$ from the axis of rotation? (c) What is the radial acceleration in $\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ and multiples of $g$ of this point at full $\,\text{rpm}$?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer02_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution02a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution02b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution02c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer02">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $87.3\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                      <p>(b) $8.29\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                      <p>(c) $1.04\times 10^7 \,\text{m}/\text{s}^2,\; (1.06\times10^6)\, g$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution02a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The ultracentrifuge accelerates from rest ($\omega_0 = 0$) to a final angular velocity
                                \begin{align}
                                \omega &= \frac{100{,}000\,\color{red}{\text{rev}}}{\color{blue}{\text{min}}} \times \frac{2\pi\,\text{rad}}{1\,\color{red}{\text{rev}}} \times \frac{1\,\color{blue}{\text{min}}}{60\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 10{,}472\,\text{rad/s}
                                \end{align}
                      in a time period of
                                \begin{align}
                                \Delta t &= 2.00\,\text{min} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 120\,\text{s}
                                \end{align}
                      </p>

                      <p>So, the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-angular-acceleration">angular acceleration</a> of the ultracentrifuge is calculated as follows
                                \begin{align}
                                \alpha &= \frac{\Delta \omega}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{\omega - \omega_0}{\Delta t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= \frac{10{,}472\,\text{rad/s}}{120\,\text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 87.3\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2
                                \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution02b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>A point located at a distance $r = 0.0950\,\text{m}$ from the axis of rotation, experiences a tangential acceleration equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        a_\text{t} &= r \alpha \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.0950\,\text{m})\, (87.3\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 8.29\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution02c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The radial (or <a href="../unit06/index06.html#unit06-circular-motion">centripetal</a>) acceleration of this point at full speed ($\omega$), is calculated as follows
                         \begin{align}
                         a_\text{c} &= \frac{v^2}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= \frac{(r \omega)^2}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= r \omega ^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= (0.0950\,\text{m})\, (10{,}472\,\text{rad/s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 1.04\times 10^7 \,\text{m}/\text{s}^2
                         \end{align}
                      The answer can also be expressed as multiples of $g$, where
                         \begin{align}
                         a_\text{c} &= \left(1.04\times 10^7 \,\color{red}{\text{m}/\text{s}^2}\right) \times \frac{g}{9.80\,\color{red}{\text{m}/\text{s}^2}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= \left( 1.06\times10^6 \right) g
                         \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 6 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p06">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 6</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose a piece of dust finds itself on a CD. If the spin rate of the CD is $500\,\text{rpm}$, and the piece of dust is $4.3\,\text{cm}$ from the centre, what is the total distance traveled by the dust in $3$ minutes? (Ignore accelerations due to getting the CD rotating.)
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer06_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram06_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution06_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$405\,\text{m}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch10-p06s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P10.6s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution06">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Since the CD performs $500$ revolutions in one minute, then the total number of revolutions completed in a $3$-minute period is equal to
                                \begin{align}
                                \theta &= (500\,\text{rev/min})\, (3\,\text{min}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                                &= 1{,}500\, \text{rev}
                                \end{align}
                       A piece of dust located at a distance $r = 0.043\,\text{m}$ from the centre (see <b>Figure P10.6s</b>) travels a linear distance equal to $2\pi r$ in a single revolution. As a result, the total linear distance travelled in $3$ minutes is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        s &= 1{,}500\times 2 \pi r \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1{,}500\times 2 \pi\, (0.043\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 405\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 8 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p08">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 8</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">During a very quick stop, a car decelerates at $7.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2$ .
                      (a) What is the angular acceleration of its $0.280$-$\text{m}$-radius tires, assuming they do not slip on the pavement?
                      (b) How many revolutions do the tires make before coming to rest, given their initial angular velocity is $95.0\,\text{rad/s}$ ?
                      (c) How long does the car take to stop completely?
                      (d) What distance does the car travel in this time?
                      (e) What was the car&rsquo;s initial velocity?
                      (f) Do the values obtained seem reasonable, considering that this stop happens very quickly?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer08_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution08a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution08b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution08c_btn">Solution (c)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution08d_btn">Solution (d)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution08e_btn">Solution (e)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution08f_btn">Solution (f)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer08">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $-25.0\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2$<p>
                      <p>(b) $28.7\,\text{rev}$<p>
                      <p>(c) $3.80\,\text{s}$<p>
                      <p>(d) $50.5\,\text{m}$<p>
                      <p>(e) $26.6\,\text{m}$<p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution08a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>Since the car slows down with a <a href="../unit02/index02.html#unit02-constant-acceleration">linear acceleration</a> of $a = -7.00\,\text{m}/{s}^2$, a point on the tire&rsquo;s edge experiences a tangential acceleration of equal magnitude. Since the radius of the tire is $r = 0.280\,\text{m}$, then its <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-angular-acceleration">angular acceleration</a> equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \alpha &= \frac{a}{r} \nonumber\\[6pt]
