                        &= \frac{-7.00\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2}{0.280\,\text{m}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -25.0\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution08b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The tires start with an initial <a href="../unit06/index06.html#unit06-angular-quantities">angular velocity</a> of $\omega_0 = 95.0\,\text{rad/s}$, and decelerates to rest ($\omega = 0$). Based on the information provided, it is more convenient to use the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-rotational-kinematics">kinematic equation</a>
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega^2 &= \omega_0^2 + 2 \alpha \theta \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= \omega_0^2 + 2 \alpha \theta
                        \end{align}
                      So, the angular displacement of each tire, during the deceleration process, is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \theta &= - \frac{\omega_0^2}{2 \alpha} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -\frac{(95.0\,\text{rad/s})^2}{2\, (-25.0\,\text{rad/s}^2)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 180.5\,\text{rad} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 180.5\,\color{red}{\text{rad}} \times \frac{1\,\text{rev}}{2\pi\,\color{red}{\text{rad}}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 28.7\,\text{rev}
                        \label{ch10_08_theta}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution08c">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The stopping time can be calculated using a different <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-rotational-kinematics">kinematic equation</a> as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= \omega_0 + \alpha t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 0 &= \omega_0 + \alpha t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad t &= -\frac{\omega_0}{\alpha} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= -\frac{95.0\,\text{rad/s}}{(-25.0\,\text{rad/s}^2)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.80\,\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution08d">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (d)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>The distance ($x$) travelled by the car in this time is equal to the number of tire revolutions (Equation \ref{ch10_08_theta}) multiplied by the circumference ($2\pi r$) of the tire, or
                         \begin{align}
                         x &= (28.7\,\text{rev})\, (2 \pi\times 0.280\,\text{m/rev}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 50.5\,\text{m}
                         \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution08e">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (e)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>One way to calculate the initial linear speed ($v_0$) of the car is to substitute into one of the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-rotational-kinematics">kinematic equations</a> of motions as follows
                      \begin{align}
                         v &= v_0 + a t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         \Rightarrow\quad 0 &=v_0 + a t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         \Rightarrow\quad v_0 &= - a t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= - (-7.00\,\text{m}/{s}^2)\, (3.80\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 26.6\,\text{m} \quad (\text{or}\; 95.8\,\text{km/h})
                         \end{align}
                      </p>

                      <p>However, in this case, it is simpler to use the initial angular velocity, or
                         \begin{align}
                         v_0 &= r \omega_0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= (0.280\,\text{m})\, (95.0\,\text{rad/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 26.6\,\text{m/s}
                         \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution08f">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (f)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>With the car moving initially at about $96\,\text{km/h}$, a braking distance of approximately $50\,\text{m}$ is reasonable, for an emergency stop.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 12 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p12">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 12</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">The triceps muscle in the back of the upper arm extends the forearm. This muscle in a professional boxer exerts a force of $2.00\times 10^3\,\text{N}$ with an effective perpendicular lever arm of $3.00\,\text{cm}$, producing an angular acceleration of the forearm of $120\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2$. What is the moment of inertia of the boxer&rsquo;s forearm?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer12_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram12_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution12_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer12">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.500\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram12">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch10-p12s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P10.12s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution12">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The triceps muscle exerts a force of $F_\text{t} = 2.00\times 10^3\,\text{N}$ on the forearm with an effective perpendicular lever arm of $r_\text{t} = 0.0300\,\text{m}$, as shown in <b>Figure P10.12s</b>. As a result, the forearm experiences a torque equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau &= r_\text{t}\, F_\text{t} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.0300\,\text{m})\, (2.00\times 10^3\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 60.0\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    Since the resulting angular acceleration is $\alpha = 120\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2$, we can calculate the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-moment-rigid-body">moment of inertia</a> of the boxer&rsquo;s forearm as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        I &= \frac{\tau}{\alpha}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{60.0\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}}{120\,\text{rad/s}^2}\nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.500\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                      </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 14 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p14">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 14</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose you exert a force of $180\,\text{N}$ tangential to a $0.280$-$\text{m}$-radius $75.0\,\text{kg}$ grindstone (a solid disk). (a) What torque is exerted? (b) What is the angular acceleration assuming negligible opposing friction? (c) What is the angular acceleration if there is an opposing frictional force of $20.0\,\text{N}$ exerted $1.50\,\text{cm}$ from the axis?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer14_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram14_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution14a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution14b_btn">Solution (b)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution14c_btn">Solution (c)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer14" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>(a) $50.4\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}$</p>
                      <p>(b) $17.1\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                      <p>(c) $17.0\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram14">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch10-p14s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P10.14s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14a" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the applied force ($F = 180\,\text{N}$) is tangential to the edge (see <b>Figure P10.14s</b>), the grindstone (of radius $r = 0.280\,\text{m}$) experiences a torque equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau &= r F \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.280\,\text{m})\, (180\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 50.4\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14b" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-moment-rigid-body">moment of inertia</a> of the grindstone (solid disk of mass $m = 75.0\,\text{kg}$) is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        I &= \tfrac{1}{2} m r^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2}\, (75.0\,\text{kg})\, (0.280\,\text{m})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.94\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                    So, the angular acceleration is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \alpha &= \frac{\tau}{I} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{50.4\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}}{2.94\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 17.1\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution14c" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (c)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the force of friction $f = 20.0\,\text{N}$ is exerted at a distance of $r_f = 0.0150\,\text{m}$ from the central axis, as shown in <b>Figure P10.14s</b>, the grindstone experience a resistive torque equal to
                         \begin{align}
                         \tau_f &= r_f\, f \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= (0.0150\,\text{m})\, (20.0\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 0.300\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                         \end{align}
                    So, the net torque is equal to
                         \begin{align}
                         \tau_\text{net} &= \tau - \tau_f \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 50.4\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m} - 0.300\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 50.1\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                         \end{align}
                    and the angular acceleration (with friction) becomes
                         \begin{align}
                         \alpha_f &= \frac{\tau_\text{net}}{I} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= \frac{50.1\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}}{2.94\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 17.0\,\text{rad}/\text{s}^2
                         \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 18 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p18">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 18</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Starting with the formula for the moment of inertia of a rod rotated around an axis through one end perpendicular to its length ($I = M l^2/3$), prove that the moment of inertia of a rod rotated about an axis through its centre perpendicular to its length is ($I = M l^2/12$). You will find the graphics in <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=13" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">Figure 10.12</a> (in the textbook) useful in visualizing these rotations.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram18_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution18_btn">Solution</button>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram18">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch10-p18s.svg" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P10.18s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution18">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>We can imagine the rod (of mass $M$) is constructed of two shorter rods, each of length $l/2$ and mass $M/2$, glued together end-to-end as shown in <b>Figure P10.18s</b>. So, when the rod rotates about its centre, each of the shorter rods rotates about its end. So, the moment of inertia ($I$) of the rod of length $l$ about an axis through its centre perpendicular to its length is equal to the sum of the moments of inertias ($I_\text{s}$) of the shorter rods about their ends. So, we can write,
                        \begin{align}
                        I &= I_\text{s} + I_\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 2 I_\text{s} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2\times \frac{(M/2)\, (l/2)^2}{3} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{M\, l^2}{12}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 22 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p22">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 22</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">What is the final velocity of a hoop that rolls without slipping down a $5.00$-$\text{m}$-high hill, starting from rest?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer22_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution22_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer22">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$7.00\,\text{m/s}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution22">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>As we saw in <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-e05">Example 5</a>, this problem can be solved using the law of <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-conservation-mechnical-energy">conservation of mechanical energy</a>,
                        \begin{equation}
                        \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega_0^2 + m g h_0 = \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega^2 + m g h
                        \label{ch10_p22_mechanical_energy_1}
                        \end{equation}
                    The hoop starts from rest ($v_0 = 0$ and $\omega_0 = 0$) at an initial height of $h_0 = 5.00\,\text{m}$ and then rolls down the hill to $h = 0$. So, Equation \ref{ch10_p22_mechanical_energy_1} becomes
                        \begin{align}
                        0 + 0 + m g h_0 &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega^2 + 0 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad m g h_0 &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega^2
                        \label{ch10_p22_mechanical_energy_2}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>From <a href="../textbook/chapter-10.pdf#page=13" title="Chapter 10" target="_blank">Figure 10.12</a> in the textbook, we see that the moment of inertia of a hoop of mass $m$ and radius $r$ is given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        I = m r^2
                        \label{ch10_p22_I_mr2}
                        \end{equation}
                    When the hoop rolls down to the foot of the hill, it gains a final linear velocity $v$ and a final angular velocity
                    \begin{equation}
                    \omega = v/r
                    \label{ch10_p22_w_vr}
                    \end{equation}
                    By substituting from Equations \ref{ch10_p22_I_mr2} and \ref{ch10_p22_w_vr} into Equation \ref{ch10_p22_mechanical_energy_2}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        m g h_0 &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} (m r^2) \left(\frac{v}{r}\right)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad g h_0 &= \tfrac{1}{2} v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} v^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad g h_0 &= v^2
                        \end{align}
                    So, the final velocity of the hoop is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        v &= \sqrt{g h_0} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \sqrt{(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\,(5.00\,\text{m/s})} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 7.00\,\text{m/s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 28 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p28">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 28</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">A ball with an initial velocity of $8.00\,\text{m/s}$ rolls up a hill without slipping. Treating the ball as a spherical shell, calculate the vertical height it reaches. (b) Repeat the calculation for the same ball if it slides up the hill without rolling.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer28_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution28a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution28b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer28">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $5.44\,\text{m}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $3.27\,\text{m}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution28a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>By applying the law of <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-conservation-mechnical-energy">conservation of mechanical energy</a> (see <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-e05">Example 5</a> and <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#chapter10-p22">Problem 22</a>) for a ball of mass $m$ and initial speed $v_0 = 8.00\,\text{m/s}$ rolling up a hill to a final height $h$, we write
                        \begin{equation}
                        \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega_0^2 = m g h
                        \label{ch10_p28_mechanical}
                        \end{equation}
                    where, $\omega_0 = v_0/r$ is the initial angular velocity of the ball at the foot of the hill. Since it is a spherical shell of radius $r$, the moment of inertia of the ball is given by
                        \begin{equation}
                        I = \frac{2 m r^2}{3}
                        \end{equation}
                    </p>

                    <p>By substituting into Equation \ref{ch10_p28_mechanical}, we have
                        \begin{align}
                        \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} \left(\frac{2 m r^2}{3}\right) \left(\frac{v_0}{r}\right)^2 &= m g h \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tfrac{1}{2} v_0^2 + \tfrac{1}{3} v_0^2 &= g h \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tfrac{5}{6} v_0^2 &= g h
                        \end{align}
                    So, the ball stops, momentarily, at a vertical height
                        \begin{align}
                        h &= \frac{5 v_0^2}{6 g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{5\, (8.00\,\text{m/s})^2}{6\,(9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 5.44\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution28b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>If the ball slides without rolling, then $\omega_0 = 0$ and Equation \ref{ch10_p28_mechanical} changes to
                        \begin{align}
                        \tfrac{1}{2} m v_0^2 &= m g h \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \tfrac{1}{2} v_0^2 &= g h
                        \end{align}
                    In this case, the ball reaches a final height of
                        \begin{align}
                        h &= \frac{v_0^2}{2g} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{(8.00\,\text{m/s})^2}{2\, (9.80\,\text{m/s}^2)} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 3.27\,\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    Note that the total mechanical energy of the system is reduced because of the missing rotational kinetic energy.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 32 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p32">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 32</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">What is the moment of inertia of an object that rolls without slipping down a $2.00$-$\text{m}$-high incline starting from rest, and has a final velocity of $6.00\,\text{m/s}$? Express the moment of inertia as a multiple of $M R^2$, where $M$ is the mass of the object and $R$ is its radius.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer32_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution32_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer32">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p>$0.0889\, M R^2$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution32">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Since the object rolls from rest, we can write
                        \begin{align}
                        M g h_0 &= \tfrac{1}{2} M v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad M g h_0 &= \tfrac{1}{2} M v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} I \left(\frac{v}{R}\right)^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad 2\, M R^2\, g h_0 &= M R^2\, v^2 + I\, v^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad  I\, v^2 &= (2g h_0)\, M R^2 - M R^2\, v^2
                        \end{align}
                    where $h_0 = 2.00\,\text{m}$, and $v = 6.00\,\text{m/s}$. So, the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-moment-rigid-body">moment of inertia</a> can be expressed as a multiple of $M R^2$, as shown below
                        \begin{align}
                        I &= \left(\frac{2 g h_0}{v^2}\right) M R^2 - M R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{2 g h_0}{v^2} - 1\right) M R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left[\frac{2\, (9.80\,\text{m}/\text{s}^2)\, (2.00\,\text{m})}{(6.00\,\text{m/s})^2} - 1 \right] MR^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 0.0889\, M R^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 36 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p36">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 36</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">(a) Calculate the angular momentum of the Earth in its orbit around the Sun. (b) Compare this angular momentum with the angular momentum of Earth on its axis.
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer36_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution36a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution36b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer36">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $2.66\times 10^{40}\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{ m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $7.06\times10^{33}\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{ m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution36a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Referring to <a href="../textbook/appendices.pdf#page=12" title="Appendices" target="_blank">Table C3</a> in the textbook, Earth has a mass of $M_\text{E} = 5.974\times 10^{24}\,\text{kg}$ and orbits the Sun at an average distance of $R = 1.496\times 10^{11}\,\text{m}$. In this part of the question, it is safe to consider our planet as a point particle performing a circular motion around the Sun at a uniform angular velocity of
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega &= \frac{2 \pi}{1\,\text{year}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{2 \pi}{365.25 \times 24.0 \times 60 \times 60\, \text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.99 \times 10^{-7}\,\text{rad/s}
                        \end{align}
                    and a moment of inertia equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        I &= M_\text{E}\, R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (5.974\times 10^{24}\,\text{kg})\, (1.496\times 10^{11}\,\text{m})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 1.337\times 10^{47}\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                    So, the <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-angular-momentum">angular momentum</a> of Earth in its orbit around the Sun is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        L &= I \omega \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (1.337\times 10^{47}\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2)\, (1.99 \times 10^{-7}\,\text{rad/s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2.66\times 10^{40}\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2 \cdot \text{s}^{-1}
                        \label{ch10_p36_L}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution36b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>In this part of the question, we treat Earth as a uniform solid sphere of radius $R_\text{E} = 6.376\times10^6\,\text{m}$. So, the moment of inertia of Earth about its central axis is calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        I_\text{E} &= \tfrac{2}{5} M_\text{E}\, R_\text{E}^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{2}{5}\, (5.974\times 10^{24}\,\text{kg})\, (6.376\times10^6\,\text{m})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 9.714\times 10^{37}\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                    Since the angular velocity of Earth&rsquo;s spin about its axis is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega_\text{E} &= \frac{2 \pi}{1\,\text{day}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \frac{2 \pi}{24.0 \times 60 \times 60\, \text{s}} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 7.27 \times 10^{-5}\,\text{rad/s}
                        \end{align}
                    we calculate the corresponding angular momentum to be
                        \begin{align}
                         L_\text{E} &= I_\text{E}\, \omega_\text{E} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= (9.714\times 10^{37}\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2)\, (7.27 \times 10^{-5}\,\text{rad/s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                         &= 7.06\times10^{33}\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}
                         \label{ch10_p36_LE}
                         \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>By taking the ratio of Equations \ref{ch10_p36_L} and \ref{ch10_p36_LE}, we see that the angular momentum of Earth around the Sun is $3.77$ million times greater than around its axis.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 38 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p38">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 38</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Suppose you start an antique car by exerting a force of $300\,\text{N}$ on its crank for $0.250\,\text{s}$. What angular momentum is given to the engine if the handle of the crank is $0.300\,\text{m}$ from the pivot and the force is exerted to create maximum torque the entire time?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer38_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solutionDiagram38_btn">Solution Diagram</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution38_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer38" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$22.5\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}$ </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solutionDiagram38">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution Diagram</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                      <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch10-p38s.png" alt="image"><br>
                      <br><b>Figure P10.38s</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution38" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (a)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The crank produces a torque on the engine (see <b>Figure P10.38s</b>) calculated to be
                        \begin{align}
                        \tau &= r F \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (0.300\,\text{m})\, (300\,\text{N}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 90.0\, \text{N}\cdot\text{m}
                        \end{align}
                    So, during a time interval $\Delta t = 0.250\,\text{s}$, the engine receives <a data-role="linkInUnit" href="#unit10-angular-momentum">angular momentum</a> equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        \Delta L &= \tau\, \Delta t \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (90.0\, \text{N}\cdot\text{m})\, (0.250\,\text{s}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 22.5\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 40 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p40">
                  <p><br/></p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 40</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Three children are riding on the edge of a merry-go-round that is $100\,\text{kg}$, has a $1.60\,\text{m}$ radius, and is spinning at $20.0\,\text{rpm}$. The children have masses of $22.0$, $28.0$, and $33.0\,\text{kg}$. If the child who has a mass of $28.0\,\text{kg}$ moves to the centre of the merry-go-round, what is the new angular velocity in $\text{rpm}$?
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer40_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution40_btn">Solution</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer40" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>$25.3\,\text{rpm}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution40" >
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The merry-go-round system consists of a solid disk, of mass $M = 100\,\text{kg}$ and radius of $R = 1.60\,\text{m}$, and three children riding on the edge with masses $m_1 = 22.0\,\text{kg}$, $m_2 = 28.0\,\text{kg}$, and $m_3 = 33.0\,\text{kg}$. Initially, the system has a moment of inertia equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        I_\text{i} &= \tfrac{1}{2} M R^2 + m_1 R^2 + m_2 R^2 + m_3 R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\tfrac{1}{2} M + m_1 + m_2 + m_3\right) R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{100\,\text{kg}}{2} + 22.0\,\text{kg} + 28.0\,\text{kg} + 33.0\,\text{kg} \right) R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 340.5\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                    After the child of mass $m_2$ moves to the centre, the moment of inertia of the system reduces to the final value
                        \begin{align}
                        I_\text{f} &= \tfrac{1}{2} M R^2 + m_1 R^2 + m_2\, (0) + m_3 R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\tfrac{1}{2} M + m_1 + m_3\right) R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{100\,\text{kg}}{2} + 22.0\,\text{kg} + 33.0\,\text{kg} \right) R^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 268.8\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>In the absence of any external torque, as the child relocates to the centre of the merry-go-round, the angular momentum of the system must be conserved, or
                        \begin{align}
                        L_\text{i} &= L_\text{f} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad I_\text{i}\, \omega_\text{i} &= I_\text{f}\, \omega_\text{f}
                        \label{ch10_p40_LiLf}
                        \end{align}
                    By substituting the initial angular velocity ($\omega_\text{i} = 20.0\,\text{rpm}$) into Equation \ref{ch10_p40_LiLf}, we find that the angular velocity increases to the new value of
                        \begin{align}
                        \omega_\text{f} &= \left(\frac{I_\text{i}}{I_\text{f}}\right) \omega_\text{i} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \left(\frac{340.5\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2}{268.8\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2}\right) \times 20.0\,\text{rpm} \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 25.3\,\text{rpm}
                        \end{align}
                   </p>
                   </div>
                  </div>

                </div>

<!-- ****** Problem 45 ****** -->
                <div title="sectionContent" id="chapter10-p45">
                  <p><br/>
                  </p>
                  <div class="panel panel-primary">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Chapter 10, Problem 45</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">Twin skaters approach one another as shown in <b>Figure P10.45</b> and lock hands. (a) Calculate their final angular velocity, given each had an initial speed of $2.50\,\text{m/s}$ relative to the ice. Each has a mass of $70.0\,\text{kg}$, and each has a centre of mass located $0.800\,\text{m}$ from their locked hands. You may approximate their moments of inertia to be that of point masses at this radius. (b) Compare the initial kinetic energy and final kinetic energy.
                    <hr>
                        <p class="centerText"><img src="./ch10-p45.svg" alt="image"><br>
                        <br><b>Figure P10.45</b></p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                  <p></p>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="answer45_btn">Answer</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution45a_btn">Solution (a)</button>
                  <button class="btn btn-default btnString" data-role="button" id="solution45b_btn">Solution (b)</button>

                  <p></p>
                  <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="answer45">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Answer</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                        <p>(a) $3.12\,\text{rad}/\text{s}$</p>
                        <p>(b) $438\,\text{J}$</p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution45a">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>Each skater (mass $m = 70.0\,\text{kg}$) moves at the initial velocity of $v = 2.50\,\text{m/s}$, in the directions shown in <b>Figure P10.45</b>. Note that each skater makes a clockwise rotation about the axis ($O$), which is located a distance $r = 0.800\,\text{m}$ from the velocity of her centre of mass. As a result, their angular momenta add up to the initial value
                        \begin{align}
                        L_\text{i} &= mv\,r + mv\,r \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &=2 mv\, r \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2\, (70.0\,\text{kg})\, (2.50\,\text{m/s})\, (0.800\,\text{m}) \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 280\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1}
                        \label{ch10_p54_Li}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>Since no external torques act on the skaters when they lock hands, their total angular momentum must be conserved, or
                        \begin{equation}
                        L_\text{i} = L_\text{f}
                        \label{ch10_p54_Lif}
                        \end{equation}
                    After they lock hands, the two-skater system rotates with angular velocity $\omega$ about the axis $O$, as shown in <b>Figure P10.45</b>. The moment of inertia of the system in this state is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        I &= m r^2 + m r^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2 m r^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 2\, (70.0\,\text{kg})\, (0.800\,\text{m})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 89.6\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2
                        \end{align}
                   and the final total angular momentum can be expressed as
                        \begin{align}
                        L_\text{f} &= I\, \omega \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (89.6\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2)\, \omega
                        \label{ch10_p54_Lf}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>

                    <p>By substituting from Equations \ref{ch10_p54_Li} and \ref{ch10_p54_Lf} into Equation \ref{ch10_p54_Lif}, we can calculate the final angular velocity as follows
                        \begin{align}
                        280\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2\cdot\text{s}^{-1} &= (89.6\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2)\, \omega \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        \Rightarrow\quad \omega &= 3.12\,\text{rad}/\text{s}
                        \end{align}
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                   <div title="solution" class="panel panel-success" id="solution45b">
                    <div class="panel-heading">Solution (b)</div>
                    <div class="panel-body">
                    <p>The initial kinetic energy of the two-skater system is equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        KE_\text{i} &= \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 + \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= m v^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= (70.0\,\text{kg})\, (2.50\,\text{m/s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 438\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    After they lock hands, the system has a final kinetic energy equal to
                        \begin{align}
                        KE_\text{f} &= \tfrac{1}{2} I \omega^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= \tfrac{1}{2}\, (89.6\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2)\, (3.125\,\text{rad}/\text{s})^2 \nonumber\\[6pt]
                        &= 438\,\text{J}
                        \end{align}
                    So kinetic energy is conserved in this collision.
                    </p>
                    </div>
                  </div>

                </div>
